DOC.HEAD: Researchers Lose Contact with Misha and Echo
DOC.TEXT: An experiment to determine whether dolphins can be safely returned to the open sea after years in captivity has suffered a setback: Echo and Misha cannot be found. Rough waters and trouble with a coin-sized radio transmitter have kept researchers from spotting the two male bottlenose dolphins, who were returned to Tampa Bay on Saturday after two years in a California research project. Researchers expected to spot the mammals again when the seas become calmer, said Jay Gorzelany, a biologist at Mote Marine Laboratory in Sarasota. Scientists hope the project will prove that captive animals can be successfully released, thus reducing the perceived need to keep dolphins in captivity permanently. A team of researchers who will monitor the dolphins for a year to see how they adjust to being wild again tracked Echo and Misha until dusk Saturday. The pair stayed close to the coast and were once seen racing near shore with a group of wild dolphins. ``They were last seen near the site where they were released,'' Gorzelany said. Echo and Misha spent three weeks at the marine lab resting and learning how to catch fish again before being set free in the bay. Researchers have been unable to locate the dolphins since then because waves whipped up by stiff winds made it impossible to distinguish the dolphins' dorsal fines from whitecaps on the water, Gorzelany said. The team had hoped a radio transmitter placed on Echo would lead them to the dolphins, but the device either stopped working or fell off, Gorzelany said. However, the device was designed to fall off after just two weeks. The research team will concentrate on tracking the dolphins visually, and expect the pair to remain in the bay. ``The team seems pretty unconcerned,'' Gorzelany said. ``They believe they're out there, staying together and doing fine.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Orders ABC To Give Defense Contractor Copies of Missing Documents
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court has ordered ABC News to give a military contractor copies of missing documents the contractor says were stolen. The network used the documents two years ago in a news report that suggested FMC Corp. had overcharged the Defense Department for parts for the Bradley Fighting Vehicle. The 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last week upheld a lower court ruling that Capital Cities-ABC Inc. should hand over the documents or copies of them because they are FMC's property. FMC said it doesn't have copies of the missing documents and needs them for a Defense Department audit. ``They have something that is ours. We asked for it. They didn't give it back. It's that simple,'' FMC attorney Joe Cari, of Coffield Ungaretti Harris & Slavin in Chicago, said Tuesday. Samuel Fifer, an attorney for the New York-based multi-media company, said ABC may ask the court for a rehearing. ABC disagrees with the ruling because the court considered intangible information as property, Fifer said. The broadcast company said it has only copies of the documents, not the originals, and thus possesses only information, not property. However, the appeals court noted that the since the company no longer has the information on the documents, the copies are ``functional equivalents'' of the originals. In the same decision Thursday, the federal panel reversed a U.S. District Court's decision to award the Chicago-based FMC damages. The company had sought unspecified damages, contending it had suffered financially because of ABC's exposure of its military and pricing records. FMC also has private contracts for food, machinery and chemicals. ABC refused to supply the company duplicates of the documents after they were displayed in a report on ``World News Tonight'' on Oct. 20, 1988. The story indicated the defense contractor had overcharged the government for parts. FMC disputed the report. The documents apparently outline the company's pricing policy, but FMC is uncertain of their content, Cari said. The company realized the papers were missing after seeing the news report and searching through its records, he said. FMC never accused ABC of stealing the documents. ABC refused to hand over the four pages of documents saying it would infringe upon its First Amendment rights, which ensure freedom of the press. ``Because ABC has refused to return copies of the documents that FMC has a right to use, ABC's retention of the documents amounts to the exercise of unlawful dominion over them,'' the court said. FMC maintains it needs the documents because the Army contract requires the company to keep complete records. The company typically does not make copies of such documents because contracts tend to be ``hundreds of thousands'' of pages long, Cari said.

DOC.HEAD: Official: President, U.S. Ambassador Targeted by Traffickers
DOC.TEXT: The government is probing an alleged plot by cocaine traffickers to assassinate President Jaime Paz Zamora, U.S. Ambassador Robert Gelbard and others, the commander of the nation's anti-drug forces says. Speaking before a congressional committee on Monday, Gen. Lucio Anez also claimed he was targeted for death as well as Interior Minister Guillermo Capobianco and attorney Juan del Dranado, who is representing some victims of the 1980 military coup. ``We are evaluating the information we have received and I do not wish to provide any more details until investigations are concluded,'' Annez said. Last month, Gelbard said U.S. officials warned him he was the target of an assassination ordered by former Interior Minister Luis Arce Gomez, who was extradited to Miami on drug trafficking charges in December. Arce Gomez, one of the leaders of the 1980 coup, has denied the accusation. Anez said the information about the planned killings came from a credible source, but he would not elaborate. The military government lasted a year after the 1980 coup.

DOC.BYLINE: Versace Steals The Show ^By DANIELA PETROFF
DOC.TEXT: Showbiz's favorite designer, Gianni Versace, stole the show with a collection sure to put Milan back in the fashion limelight. His styles for the Spring-Summer 1991 are lively, sexy, and avant garde with an endless series of stretch pants and catsuits, mini shift dresses, micro skirts and fiery hot pants. Versace also uses the most colorful palette ever to be seen on the Milan runway, traditionally devoted to drab brown, gray and black. Circus reds and blues, neon greens and yellows, disco purples and pinks combine to create work-of-art prints which are sure to be the talk of the town in Beverly Hills, where Versace is a household name. In fact his clients include such movie and rock star notables as Jane Fonda, Sylvester Stallone, and Elton John. Even ``Born in the U.S.A.'' Bruce Springsteen wears Versace. Front-row guests at his Spring-Summer show Sunday night included top model turned film star Carol Alt and Brazilian Formula One racing driver Aryton Senna. Beyond the entertainment bent of his look, Versace has become the trend-setter in Milan, reaching beyond the classic, man-tailored styles which had put the Italian label at the top of ready-to-wear, but which in recent seasons was taking a back seat to the more creative far-out French design. A year ago, he shocked the fashion world by hiking the hemline so high that panties became a hot fashion item. Versace knew that very few would dare to wear the micro mini, but the scandalous skirt served to secure a place for short hemlines in the next decade. Sexy hip-hugging trousers, plunging necklines and flesh revealing slits were all part of Versace's call to women to come out of the man-tailored closet and flaunt their femininity. Color was another Versace innovation. Unlike most of his colleagues who are native northern Italians, Versace grew up in sun basked Calabria, where bright Mediterranean shades are the daily fare. While everyone else was dressing women in gloomy city hues, Versace was lighting up the runway with bright reds, blues and greens. Sparkling sequins were another of the vivacious designer's show-stoppers. On the second day of the five-day Spring-Summer 1991 collections it was clear that the Versace message has caught on. Styles are short, sexy and colorful, with body-clinging stretch outfits the favorite style. Cheerful floral and block prints abound, and the runway sparkles in a myriad of multi-colored sequins. Krizia, who showed Monday morning, abandoned her usual accordian pleats to burst out in a series of short evening dresses in large kaleidoscope sequined prints with matching jewelry and one-color stretch catsuits worn under a loose floral printed silk blouse. Missoni, who also showed Monday morning, transposed the shades of his famous knit prints onto a series of glittering unitards, and floor length evening gowns. But the real works of art were a Versace exclusive. His prints, all designed by the maestro, turned the runway into an art gallery in motion, with geometric designs combining with floral patterns, and pop-art decorations such as pictures of Hollywood myths James Dean and Marilyn Monroe and covers of Vogue magazine. Some of the prints were painted onto the fabric, usually stretch. Others were stiched in thousands of baubles and spangles. Everything in the collection from shoes and stockings to necklaces, bracelets and earrings reproduced the printed motif. The designer, who received a standing ovation after the close of an hour-long show, announced that proceeds from the worldwide sale of an elegant silk shirt printed with past and present Vogue covers will go towards AIDS research promoted by the C.F.D.A., the Council of Fashion Designers of America.

DOC.HEAD: New Aquino Office Attacked as Extravagant Amid Economic Crisis
DOC.TEXT: As Filipinos are being asked to tighten their belts, President Corazon Aquino is preparing to move into a multimillion- dollar office. Critics are calling this shameless extravagance. Public outrage over Mrs. Aquino's new office, a four-story former brewery near her current office, emerged after hearings of the Senate Finance Committee disclosed last month that the administration was spending more than $3.2 million to refurbish the building while the president was urging austerity in government. Nearly half the cost went for furnishings and another 25 percent for security equipment, according to project manager Ernesto de Castro. ``The timing of the construction of such a building is very bad especially with a public perception that the executive branch is extravagant,'' said opposition Rep. Salvador Escudero. The project also has caught on as a public issue because it contrasts so sharply with Mrs. Aquino's early efforts to distance herself from the style and excesses of her ousted predecessor, Ferdinand Marcos. Since assuming the presidency in February 1986, she had kept her office at the presidential Guest House to show she was but a ``transient'' in the nation's highest office. She transformed Marcos' phrey running and will move within 60 minutes.
DOC.HEAD: STRICKEN CHILDREN PICTURE PACKAGE:
DOC.TEXT: The AP will transmit a picture package Tuesday morning showing the devastating effect Nicaragua's crumbling health care system is having on children. The photos, shot by staff photographer John Gaps III, will move in advance for release Sunday, Oct. 14, accompanied by a story slugged: AP Photo Package: Stricken Children. The seven photos will move in black and white on the mainline network between 3 a.m. and 6 a.m. EDT Tuesday. All seven photos will move as color on LaserPhoto II.
DOC.HEAD: The AP
Snow in the 80s: Just Melting Away
DOC.TEXT: The northern half of the planet seems to be losing its snowy blanket, but researchers are reluctant to say why or predict whether the meltdown will continue. The area covered by snow was less in 1988 and 1989 than at any time in the nearly 20 years that records have been kept, researchers report. Low snow cover has continued this year, David A. Robinson of Rutgers University said Monday. Robinson and Kenneth F. Dewey of the University of Nebraska analyzed snow cover records in a report in the journal Geophysical Research Letters, published by the American Geophysical Union. ``Northern Hemisphere snow cover during 1988 and 1989 was at its lowest extent since the advent of reliable satellite snow cover monitoring in 1972, running some 8 percent to 10 percent below'' average, they said. But Robinson was not ready to blame the widely reported threat of global warming for the disappearance of the snow. ``That doesn't mean we're in a greenhouse warming,'' he said. ``It could totally turn around in the next decade, or it could be an early sign of global warming, but it's too early to tell with just a 20-year record.'' It could be that global warming causes the snow to melt. But it also could be that melting snow exposes more ground, which absorbs more heat from the sun, and that causes more warming. ``We're starting to look at it on a regional basis to get a handle on it, but it's premature to ascribe it to a chicken or egg. In the long run I'll bet it turns out to be a little of both,'' Robinson said. The theory of greenhouse warming predicts that precipitation will increase in polar regions. If this occurs, the snowpack could increase again, resulting in a cooling in those areas. The greenhouse theory contends that carbon dioxide and other chemicals released into the atmosphere by human activities could trap heat from the sun and warm the Earth in somewhat the way a greenhouse traps heat. The amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere has increased significantly over the last century. However, scientists disagree over whether any warming has actually occurred during that period. Snow cover information is collected by satellites operated by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. NOAA researcher Chet Ropelewski has reported that snow cover in the Northern Hemisphere in June and July was the lowest on record, at about 57 percent of normal in North America and 40 percent over Eurasia. In June, for example, about 1.35 million square miles of North America had a covering of snow. In a normal June, 2.47 million square miles would be snow-covered. While month-to-month variation is understandable, the periods with highest snow cover tended to occur in the 1970s, with a marked decline in the 1980s. Maximum Northern Hemisphere snow cover during the period of record was in February 1978, at 20.4 million square miles. The minimum was in August 1989, at 1 million square miles.

DOC.HEAD: After The Riots: Arabs Shed Tears, Vent Anger
With PM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The hospital director in east Jerusalem tried to calm thousands of anxious Palestinians, some weeping and others vowing revenge, as he pushed his way to the emergency ward. ``It's manslaughter,'' he told reporters. Some of the Palestinians at Mukassed Hospital on Monday were mourning relatives killed when police fired on Arab rioters in Jerusalem's Old City. Others shook with fear over the fate of missing children or husbands. Youths, some wearing masks, waved outlawed Palestinian flags and shouted for retaliation. A chant went up from a group of grieving women: ``Bring Bush! Bring Bush!'' They wanted President Bush, leader of Israel's staunchest ally, to see for himself the aftermath of Monday's bloody confrontation. Arab ambulances arrived from all over the occupied West Bank, sirens screaming. They ferried victims from Temple Mount in the Old City to Mukassed and nearby Augusta Victoria, the main hospitals in Arab east Jerusalem. Israeli police opened fire with tear gas and bullets on the Temple Mount, site of one of Islam's most sacred shrines, after Moslems pelted Jewish worshipers with rocks at the adjacent Wailing Wall, Judaism's holiest site. Scattered shooting incidents followed in the Old City. Hospital officials said at least 19 Palestinians were killed and 140 wounded, many with live ammunition. Adnan Hamad, the administrative director of Mukassed, called it ``manslaughter'' when he spoke to reporters. He tried his best to comfort 3,000 to 4,000 anxious people. Police Commissioner Yaacov Terner said the incident ``started with a major riot, which was dangerous.'' Still, he said, he felt compassion for the families at Mukassed. ``Families of the dead and wounded ... I can understand their pain,'' Terner told Israel radio. Mukassad had been thrust right into the violence. At one point, paramilitary border police fired tear gas inside the hospital, apparently to stop Palestinians outside from pushing their way in. Babies coughing from tear gas were passed through hospital windows to people outside to get them away from the fumes. Hospital officials called a fire truck to bring fans and other equipment to clear the gas from areas housing patients. Mukassed was so overwhelmed with casualties that 11 elderly women overcome by tear gas were treated with oxygen in the hospital's mosque and library. In the hospital morgue, seven dead Palestinians lay on slabs. All appeared to be in their 20s. One had half his head shot away. Blood spattered walls and floors. It soaked the bedding on stretchers. Police blocked most private cars from reaching the hospital but let U.N. buses pass. They carried Palestinians who had volunteered to donate blood. Among the officials who rushed to the hospital was Hashem Mahamid, an Arab member of the Israeli Parliament. He later told Israel radio that the tear gas firing ``was a very brutal act.'' At Augusta Victoria Hospital, Khaled Shalatef, of the West Bank town of Ramallah, was treated for head and eye wounds from rubber bullets. ``We are Moslems, and we came to defend our mosque,'' said the 26-year-old. The Palestinians had begun stoning the Jews at the Wailing Wall after rumors spread that Jewish extremists planned to march on the Temple Mount. ``I did not expect Jews to perform such terrible massacres against unarmed people,'' Shalatef said.

DOC.HEAD: Livestock Output Up Modestly
DOC.TEXT: A modest increase in livestock output is under way, and Agriculture Department economists say it could take some of the upward pressure from retail meat prices in 1991. Early projections by the department's Economic Research Service point to 1991 gains in beef production, up 1 percent from this year; pork, 3 percent; and broilers and turkeys, about 5 percent. A major reason for the stepped-up livestock production is the bumper harvest of corn and other crops this fall, which has helped reduce feed costs. Improved grazing has helped, too. For example, range and wheat pasture conditions a year ago deteriorated in many areas, pushing larger number of lighter-weight cattle into feedlots. ``This pattern is not likely to be repeated this fall unless forage conditions deteriorate,'' the report said. ``Recent rains have further improved prospects for fall grazing.'' Prices of stocker and feeder cattle are expected to ``remain well above a year ago'' this fall, it said, and with strong demand for lighter-weight animals to put on pastures, fewer will be moving into feedlots. Market prices of Choice-grade steers averaged about $77 per 100 pounds in the first two weeks of September but have been declining seasonally, the report said. One factor has been the record weights of cattle going to slaughter. Some of that extra weight - translated into more beef - has been due to producers holding back cattle because of the uncertainty over the federal budget and the possibility of a furlough of meat inspectors. Plants would have had to cease operations on days inspectors didn't work. ``However, as feedlot marketings become more current (meaning lighter cattle weights) and beef supplies tighten in the late fall and early winter, fed steer prices are expected to strengthen into the upper $70s per hundredweight,'' the report said. But seasonally larger pork supplies and record poultry production probably ``will compete aggressively'' with beef at retail counters, it said. That will dampen further price increases in the coming months. Beef output in 1991 is forecast to rise about 1 percent from this year, with all of the increase coming from fed cattle. ``Hog producers are expected to cautiously expand breeding herds this year and in early 1991, despite generally favorable net returns through midsummer,'' the report said. ``A sharp drop in hog prices late this summer clouded the long-term profit outlook.'' Even so, based on surveys of producer intentions and historical trends, it appears hog production in the first half of 1991 may rise about 2 percent from a year earlier. Production in the second half could be up 4 percent from the year-earlier mark. Hog prices at the major markets may average ``in the high $40s to low $50s per hundredweight in 1991,'' the report said. That would compare with the mid-$50s expected as this year's average. Overall, commercial pork production next year is projected to increase about 3 percent from this year. And that means retail prices ``are expected to decline slightly from this year's record,'' the report said. Looking at broilers, the report said production will continue growing in 1991 but at a slightly slower pace, perhaps 5 percent to 6 percent above this year's level. Wholesale broiler prices for all of 1990 probably will average 54 to 56 cents per pound, and the continued increase in production is expected to cause prices to slip slightly in 1991. Retail prices for whole fryers in the second half of 1990 are expected to average 85 to 90 cents per pound, down 5 percent to 6 percent from last year. Turkey production is expected to gain only 5 percent in 1991, about half this year's sharp increase, the report said. The prospective slowdown was attributed to ``this year's low producer returns.'' ``Red meat prices, particularly for pork, will, as usual, play a key role in fourth-quarter turkey prices,'' the report said. For all of 1990, consumer turkey prices are expected to average 99 cents to $1.02 per pound, about the same as last year. Little change is expected in 1991 at the retail level.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Committee Meeting Reveals No New Allegations Against McCain
DOC.TEXT: A closed-door Senate Ethics Committee meeting last week revealed no new information to challenge a recommendation that Sen. John McCain be dropped from a savings and loan investigation, a congressional source says. McCain, of Arizona, is the only Republican among five senators under investigation for their ties to a major political donor, former thrift owner Charles H. Keating Jr. McCain is pressing hard for a committee decision, before Congress adjourns later this month, to adopt a special counsel's recommendation to end the case against him. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, who also met privately with the committee last week, is pushing just as hard for dismissal of his case. Special counsel Robert S. Bennett also recommended dismissal of the case against Glenn. Bennett proposed that the investigation be expanded against Democratic Sens. Alan Cranston of California, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan. The congressional source, speaking on condition of anonymity, told The Associated Press that the committee's questioning of McCain covered the same facts that led to the dismissal recommendation. The source said if any new allegations against McCain had surfaced, they likely would have been raised at last week's closed testimony, when Committee Chairman Howell Heflin, D-Ala. did most of the questioning. McCain and the four other senators intervened with U.S. banking regulators as Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan was heading toward failure. The federal government seized the Irvine, Calif.-based institution in April 1989, and it could cost taxpayers $2 billion to cover its losses. The source familiar with McCain's appearance said the questions dealt with two crucial meetings McCain and his colleagues held with banking regulators on Keating's behalf, and trips the senator took on Keating's airplanes. Also discussed were an investment by McCain's wife in a Keating shopping center and even McCain's philosophy on what constitutes proper behavior for a senator. McCain has given public explanations of these same matters. McCain received $112,000 from Keating and associates for his campaigns, some of it donated before Keating bought the Irvine, Calif.-based Lincoln. The congressional source said McCain was pressed on why he joined Cranston, DeConcini and Glenn in meeting with top S&L regulator Edwin J. Gray on Keating's behalf April 2, 1987. McCain had told the panel that only a week earlier, he threw Keating out of his office - and ended their personal friendship - after refusing to negotiate with regulators for Lincoln's owner. McCain told regulators, the source said, that he had an obligation to make sure a major Arizona employer was treated fairly after Keating complained the regulators were dragging out their examination of Lincoln. Lincoln's parent company, American Continental Corp., was based in Phoenix. When asked what constituted proper behavior for a senator in a case like this one, McCain said it was his role to see that a constituent is treated fairly by regulators. But he said negotiating for the constituent would be improper, the source commented. McCain, according to the source, cited to the committee his comments on this theme in an April 9, 1987, meeting that all five senators had with the regulators who were examining Lincoln. In a transcript made by one of the regulators, McCain said, ``I wouldn't want any special favors'' for Lincoln and, ``I don't want any part of our conversation to be improper.'' McCain was asked, the source said, about vacation flights he and his family took to the Bahamas from 1984 through 1986 in Keating's corporate and chartered airplanes. McCain paid $13,433 to Keating's company in 1989 for the trips, which were taken when the senator was a member of the House and were not mentioned on his financial disclosure forms. McCain cited to the committee its own letter saying the trips were a matter for the House, and a House ethics panel letter saying the payments ended the matter. McCain said the investment by his wife and father-in-law in a Keating shopping center partnership was proper because he was not involved and did not benefit from the deal.

DOC.HEAD: Governor Says He's Not Worried About Possible Challenge
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer says he is not worried about a possible re-election challenge from ex-Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke. Roemer said Monday that the race by Duke against U.S. Sen. J. Bennett Johnston showed that voters have ``a lot of anger and anxiety ... against the federal government.'' He said the people think the government is not responsive on energy policy and balancing the budget. Running as a maverick Republican, Duke picked up 44 percent of the vote in Saturday's primary against Johnston, a Democrat. ``He lost, as he does most races. Maybe he can change,'' Roemer said of Duke. Duke, a first-term member of the Louisiana House, says he will decide in the coming weeks on a 1991 governor's race. Duke noted that he received a larger percentage of the vote than Roemer did in 1987.
DOC.HEAD: Martinez Proposes 12-Year Limit on Legislative Terms
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bob Martinez is proposing limiting lawmakers to 12 years in office and sharply curbing gifts to public officials. In a series of campaign stops, the Republican governor said Monday that if re-elected he would push for the limit in a constitutional amendment that would be placed on the 1992 ballot for voters to decide. The proposal also would limit Cabinet members to a pair of four-year terms, the same restriction now placed on the governor. Voters in Oklahoma approved such a limit earlier this year, and similar measures will appear on ballots in California, Colorado and Missouri next month. The measures are seen as examples of voters' growing dissatisfaction with incumbents. The governor's proposed legislation to curtail the gifts and travel lavished on public officials comes amid an investigation by State Attorney Willie Meggs of Tallahassee into whether lawmakers properly disclosed what they've received from lobbyists over the past five years. Records of both lobbyists and legislators have been subpoenaed. Martinez is running against former U.S. Sen. Lawton Chiles.
DOC.HEAD: Casey Leads In Post-Gazette, WTAE Poll
DOC.TEXT: Democrat Robert Casey holds a strong lead over the GOP's Barbara Hafer in the governor's race, according to a statewide poll conducted for the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette and television station WTAE. Monday's Pennsylvania Poll says Gov. Casey led Auditor General Hafer 68 percent to 21 percent among 719 voters who were surveyed Friday through Sunday. Eleven percent were undecided. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus four percentage points. Among 298 respondents the poll said were most likely to vote, Casey's lead was 66 percent to 24 percent, with 10 percent undecided.
DOC.HEAD: Four Indicted Candidates Remain In Race
DOC.TEXT: Four legislators indicted as a result of the FBI's probe into a cash-for-votes scandal at the Statehouse remain candidates in the Nov. 6 election. Democratic state Reps. Ennis Fant, Larry Blanding, B.J. Gordon and Luther Taylor have been indicted on charges that they accepted cash for their support of a parimutuel betting bill. Having recently been arraigned on the charges, they are seeking re-election and remain on the November ballot, said Betsy DuRant, executive director of the state Democratic Party. None has opposition. Six other legislators who have been indicted either have withdrawn their candidacies or resigned without seeking re-election. State election officials said an indictment doesn't disqualify a candidate for office, and the legislators are innocent until proven guilty. The charges came after the FBI used lobbyist Ron Cobb to pay cash bribes to lawmakers.

DOC.HEAD: Arabs Condemn Israeli Massacre; Threaten Retaliation
With PM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The killings of at least 19 Palestinians by Israeli police set off a barrage of Arab warnings and threats. Iraq's ruling Arab Baath Socialist Party said today that the ``crime'' would lead Arabs to the ``liberation of Jerusalem and all other (Moslem) holy places,'' a reference to Saudi Arabia, where U.S.-led military forces massed after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, criticized by Iraq and its friends for joining the U.S.-led force, warned that Monday's bloodbath at the Temple Mount in Jerusalem could lead to ``grave consequences'' in the Middle East. In New York, the U.N. Security Council delayed action Monday night on an Arab-backed resolution to condemn the killings as a ``criminal act.'' The United States was resisting the proposal, and Israel rejected outright its provision for a three-member U.N. mission to investigate the killings. Israeli police opened fire on stone-throwing Palestinians on the Temple Mount, a site holy to both Moslems and Jews, in the bloodiest incident in Jerusalem since Israel seized its Arab sector from Jordan in 1967. Israeli Police Minister Roni Milo said 19 people died and 140 were wounded. Police moved in after Arabs began stoning Jewish worshipers at Judaism's holiest site, the Wailing Wall, which is located on one side of the Temple Mount. Twenty-two people, most of them worshipers at the wall, also suffered minor injuries. The clash was touched off by rumors that Jewish fundamentalists were planning to defile the al-Aqsa Mosque on Temple Mount, Islam's third holiest site. In the shantytown Palestinian camps around the Jordanian capital of Amman, hundreds of young men waved Palestinian flags and black banners shortly after the bloodshed. Mohammed Milhem, a member of the PLO's ruling 15-man Executive Committee, warned that Palestinians might start using weapons in the 34-month-old uprising in the occupied lands. ``The massacre heralds a new stage for the intefadeh,'' he said. An editorial published today in Al-Thawra, the official publication of Iraq's Baath Party, said Monday's deaths ``will not go without retaliation, and the Arab nation is certainly capable to retaliate and it will.'' ``It will turn into a massive wave of indignation, which will take the pan-Arab struggle into a step toward the liberation of Jerusalem and all other holy places and claim the Arab homeland from treachery and occupation,'' the editorial said. Iraqi leaders and many Moslems have denounced the foreign presence on Saudi soil, which they claim is a desecration of Islam's two holiest shrines at Mecca and Medina. Al-Thawra's editorial also criticized Saudi Arabia's King Fahd and Mubarak, saying Arab indignation over the Palestinian deaths ``will sweep them away, even if they issue verbal condemnations of the crime.'' A statement issued by Mubarak's office Monday night said Israel's ``savage repressive measures exceeded all limits'' and added that the Jewish state is ``fully responsible'' for protecting Islamic shrines in Jerusalem. In Jordan, where Palestinians comprise more than half the population of 3.5 million, the foreign ministry called on the international community to intervene quickly ``to halt these inhumane practices and protect the Palestinian population.''

DOC.HEAD: Utah Ex-Governor's Son Suspects A-Bomb Test Fallout in Cancer Death
LaserPhoto SK1 of Oct. 7
DOC.TEXT: The son of former Gov. Scott M. Matheson believes the open-air atomic testing whose dangers his father fought to expose caused the cancer that killed him. Matheson died Sunday at age 61 of multiple myeloma. He lived in Cedar City in the early 1950s when the government conducted dozens of above-ground tests 300 miles away in Nevada that caused radioactive fallout to drift into Utah. As governor from 1977 to 1985, Matheson fought to expose the dangers of those tests and gain compensation for radiation victims - an effort that succeeded with the passage by Congress last week of a compensation bill. Scott M. Matheson Jr. said Monday his father found it an ``interesting wrinkle'' that he was diagnosed with a disease that Congress recognized as having possible links to atomic fallout. ``When the doctors diagnosed him, they asked whether he'd spent any time in southern Utah. The reason was in connection with the testing,'' Matheson said. Multiple myeloma is a cancer of the blood-producing bone marrow and has been recognized as a malignancy that can be caused by radiation. ``While it's speculation to say anything conclusive about the cause, it is noteworthy ... and it adds some cruel irony to the sequence of events as they unfolded for him,'' he said. From 1952 to 1954, Matheson was a deputy Iron County attorney in Cedar City. From 1951 to 1958, the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission set off more than 100 atomic bombs at the Nevada Test Site. ``Those were some of the heaviest years of (open air) testing, I believe,'' Matheson said. ``And we were there.'' Numerous relatives and family friends from that part of the state have also died of cancer, he said. The 1963 Nuclear Test-Ban Treaty outlawed atomic tests in the atmosphere and under water, permitting only underground explosions. Democratic Rep. Wayne Owens co-sponsored the compensation bill with Utah Republican Sen. Orrin Hatch. Matheson ``was a champion of that cause,'' Owens said. ``He testified in favor of legislation of the kind we ultimately passed, not knowing that it would have anything to do with him.'' The bill provides for payment of up to $50,000 to fallout victims or their heirs and lists specific disease and residency requirements. Victims also are to receive a formal apology from the government. The Justice Department has complained that the measure could leave the government open to further liability and opposed its passage. President Bush has said he will let the bill become law withot his signature. The bill followed an unsuccessful attempt by so-called ``downwinders'' to gain compensation through a class-action lawsuit in the early 1980s. A federal judge found in favor of the victims, but the ruling was overturned by an appeals court. Matheson said the family has not discussed whether it will apply for the compensation.

DOC.HEAD: `Marked for Death' Tops Weekend Box Office, `Henry' Lures the Curious
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: The karate film ``Marked for Death'' topped weekend box office sales, while curious moviegoers also flocked to see ``Henry & June,'' the first movie to carry the new adult rating. The controversy over the new NC-17 rating prompted sellout crowds for Universal's ``Henry & June,'' which took in $868,000 in only 76 theaters for a robust $11,427 per-screen average. The movie chronicling the affairs of Anais Nin with Henry Miller and his wife is the first released under the Motion Picture Association of America's new rating. The NC-17 excludes anyone under 17 and replaces the X-rating. ``Marked for Death,'' starring Steven Seagal took in $10.5 million to finish first in the weekend box-office ratings, according to figures released Monday. Disney's re-release of its half-century-old cartoon classic ``Fantasia'' came in second with $5.2 million, followed by the yuppie tenant nightmare ``Pacific Heights'' with $5.1 million. The supernatural love story ``Ghost'' was fourth with $4.7 million, and the mob film ``GoodFellas'' was fifth with $4.5 million. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Sunday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Marked for Death,'' 20th Century Fox, $10.5 million, 1,968 screens, $5,344 per screen, $10.5 million, one week. 2. ``Fantasia,'' Disney, $5.2 million, 461 screens, $11,280 per screen, $5.2 million (1990), one week (1990). 3. ``Pacific Heights,'' 20th Century Fox, $5.1 million, 1,283 screens, $3,953 per screen, $14 million, two weeks. 4. ``Ghost,'' Paramount, $4.7 million, 1,766 screens, $2,664 per screen, $161.5 million, 13 weeks. 5. ``GoodFellas,'' Warner Bros., $4.5 million, 1,328 screens, $3,420 per screen, $21.6 million, three weeks. 6. ``Postcards From the Edge,'' Columbia, $2.92 million, 1,321 screens, $2,209 per screen, $27.5 million, four weeks. 7. ``Flatliners,'' Columbia, $1.25 million, 1,306 screens, $961 per screen, $55.5 million, nine weeks. 8. ``Narrow Margin,'' Tri-Star, $1.23 million, 1,238 screens, $990 per screen, $8.5 million, three weeks. 9. ``Desperate Hours,'' MGM, $1.2 million, 1,033 screens, $1,163 per screen, $1.2 million, one week. 10. ``Funny About Love,'' Paramount, $1.08 million, 1,039 screens, $1,039 per screen, $6.8 million, three weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Black Leaders Hope to Revive Plan to Carve New City Out of Part of Boston
DOC.TEXT: After failing twice at the polls, community activists will try a different tack next month in their goal to secede from Boston and create a new city named for black South African leader Nelson Mandela. Non-binding referendums in support of carving out a city from Boston's predominantly black inner-city neighborhoods failed by wide margins in 1986 and 1988. But during the next election, on Nov. 6, residents of just one inner-city legislative district will be asked whether they would like to see a study on the financial feasibility of creating a new city. If that non-binding referendum is approved, it could be used as a lobbying tool to get the Legislature to endorse the study, said Sadiki Kambon, chairman of Project FATE, or Focusing Attitudes Toward Empowerment. The next goal would be a binding referendum on the feasibility study in 1992, which could lead to another vote on the secession question in 1994, Kambon said. Approximately 126,000 of the city's 563,000 residents are black, and many live in the inner-city area, which some black leaders say has been allowed to decay over the years. To revive it, they say they must create their own city and take charge of their own destiny. ``Because we don't have any control, our community is dying,'' said Andrew Jones, a founder of the secession movement. But Lee Jackson, Boston's treasurer, says a new city would start out in worse financial shape than inner-city Boston, which he said benefits from the city's ``healthy downtown tax base.'' ``You'd start with a city that would immediately have a huge deficit and be hoping the state would bail it out,'' Jackson said. Mayor Raymond Flynn has also opposed proposals to create a separate city, saying it would segregate the community. Some black leaders have also opposed the effort on the grounds that the city could not survive without Boston's tax base. But Kambon said the feasibility study would end questions about whether such a city could function. He added that he hoped the study would also show resources were available to support the city.

DOC.HEAD: Waterless Yacht Club Gets Club Gets Last Laugh
DOC.TEXT: Their boats are cardboard, their coveted trophy is a pink flamingo and their annual regatta is held in a corn field. Bolingbrook Yacht Club members say they have just about everything discriminating mariners could want - except water. With Lake Michigan some 30 miles away, residents of this Chicago suburb have formed a unique version of one of the lakeside city's most elite cliques. ``You make do with what you have,'' said Commodore Dennis Scott, head of the club jokingly named ``Bolingbrook by the Sea.'' The club was founded 10 years ago by residents of this landlocked one-time farm community who wanted to shake the town's rube reputation. ``We went out and bought sails, some kazoos and other things we thought a yacht club should have,'' said founding father Terrence Little. ``And we got an official song. You may know it: `By the sea, by the sea, by the Bolingbrook sea ...''' In their annual ``regatta,'' Bolingbrook yachtsmen run, cheat and bribe their way through an obstacle course in a corn field, though the event also can be held on the Village Hall lawn. ``Bolingbrook should be proud,'' Scott said. ``We are the originators of the sport and the largest corn field society in the world.''

DOC.HEAD: Bloodshed At Holy Site Is Like Match In Ammunitions Depot
With PM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Temple Mount is like a vast ammunition depot of emotions that can be set off by the smallest provocation. Both Moslems and Jews claim it as the symbol of their religious and national aspirations. Its graceful domed mosques and honey-colored Western Wall, or Wailing Wall, have long been a fault line in the Arab-Israeli conflict, especially in the 34-month Palestinian uprising. The 35-acre platform is venerated by the Jews as the site of their two biblical temples. The temples' only remainder, the Western Wall lining one side of the platform, is Judaism's holiest site. The Moslems, who call the compound Haram es-Sharif, or ``Noble Enclosure,'' believe it is the place where the Prophet Mohammed ascended to heaven on a white stallion. The tree-lined Temple Mount, site of the Al Aqsa mosque and gold-roofed Dome of the Rock, is Islam's third holiest site after Mecca and Medina in Saudi Arabia. When Israel captured the Old City and surrounding Arab east Jerusalem in the 1967 Middle East war, it allowed Moslems to retain control of Haram es-Sharif. But Moslems are suspicious that Israel and the Jews want to destroy the mosques and build the Third Jewish Temple in their place. Fears are fueled by the Temple Mount Faithful and other nationalist Jewish groups who demand that Israel take control over the platform to restore Jewish greatness. On Monday, tension heightened when the Temple Mount Faithful announced plans to lay the cornerstone for the Third Temple before being blocked by police. Successive Israeli governments have barred Jews from praying on the Temple Mount, except in small groups, for fear of clashes with Moslems. In addition, a rabbinical ruling says Jews must keep out lest they tread holy ground. But the Temple Mount Faithful, once considered a fringe group, is winning more and more support in the right-wing government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. Science Minister Yuval Neeman of the ultra-rightist Tehihya Party on Monday denounced what he called Israel's ``policy of weakness'' and demanded that Jews take control of the Temple Mount. Israelis claim that Palestinian militants take cover behind their holy places to stage anti-Israeli violence. Palestinians see the Haram es-Sharif as the symbol and center of their would-be Palestinian state. During the early months of the Palestinian uprising, hundreds of masked youths staged weekly demonstrations after Friday noon prayers, hurling stones at border police and raising outlawed Palestinian flags. On July 3, 1988, Moslem preachers used mosque loudspeakers to call Palestinians to the ``defense'' of Haram es-Sharif, saying the Israelis planned to dig a tunnel to the shrine. Hundreds of Palestinians responded, hurling stones at police. It turned out that the tunnel was part of an archaeological dig along the Western Wall.

DOC.HEAD: Pittsburgh Ballboy Reflects on 35 Years in Dugout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to DELETE incorrect reference to Three Rivers Stadium. Version also moved on sports lines.
DOC.TEXT: The blue-eyed ballboy chewing a wad of gum in the Pittsburgh Pirates' dugout is not overawed that his team has reached the National League baseball playoffs. Angelo Donatelli was in the Pirates' dugout when Bill Mazeroski hit the home run that won the 1960 World Series. With the exception of relief pitcher Ted Powers, none of the players on the Pirates' roster was born when Donatelli started the job 35 years ago. Now white-haired and 63 years old, Donatelli is keeping his fingers crossed he can watch another World Series from his vantage point on the bench. It's his job to monitor the number of balls that go into the stands during a game and to keep the umpire supplied with replacements. ``I just sit here and I notice when a ball goes into the stands,'' Donatelli said. ``Then I take one out and set it beside me. When the umpire asks me for a ball, I say, `I've got 'em right here.' '' The Pirates trail the Cincinnati Reds 2-1 in their best-of-seven league championship series.

DOC.HEAD: Residents of Quiet Suburb Try to Put Bloody Slayings Behind Them
DOC.TEXT: Customers at the Lakeside Coffee House in this affluent Chicago suburb would rather talk about baseball, not murder. Three days after a high school senior was arrested in connection with the slayings of a couple and their unborn child, residents of this city of million-dollar homes and sprawling estates were philosophical Monday. ``If someone gets shot, it happens. It's sad, but it happens all over. Just because it happened here doesn't make much difference,'' said Paola Nilsson, a waitress at the coffee shop where several residents gathered Monday to watch the National League playoffs. But the arrest of David Biro, 17, of Winnetka, did rekindle some fears first ignited when the bloody slayings of Richard Langert and his pregnant wife, Nancy, occurred last April. The couple were gunned down in the basement of their townhouse. It also brought to mind a shooting rampage in 1988 that shattered this quiet community of 13,000, which has seen only four murders in its history. Two years ago, Laurie Dann entered a Winnetka elementary school and shot six children, killing one. Then she fled and barricaded herself in a nearby house, shooting a college student before killing herself. ``People keep it in the back of their minds,'' Loretta Purcell said as she watched the baseball game from the coffee shop counter. ``You had Laurie Dann; now you've got this,'' she said. ``What's going to happen next? You look behind you when you walk down a back street. I tell my nieces when they're home alone, even in the daytime, don't answer the door.'' Until Biro's arrest, the case had baffled police, in part because more than $500 remained untouched in Mrs. Langert's purse. Police had tracked one dead-end lead after another, one leading as far as Northern Ireland and the Irish Republican Army. The Chicago Sun-Times reported Sunday that Biro was arrested after he allegedly told another youth details of the crime that had not been disclosed publicly. Police have refused to confirm that report, but they have said Biro and the victims knew each other. Talk among many residents turned to Biro on Monday. Some described him as a lonely person who ran twice for class president of New Trier High School just to attract attention. ``He was always, like, `Look at me,' '' said Nilsson, 16, who spent one year at New Trier. ``I'd see him walking around town in an overcoat and a fedora. He was a strange bird,'' said Steve Szczepaniak, 19, who graduated from New Trier last year.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Approval Rating Drops Amid Dissatisfaction With Budget Deficit
DOC.TEXT:
Two new polls show President Bush's approval ratings remain high even though they have dropped to the lowest point of the year. An ABC-Washington Post poll conducted Thursday through Saturday and released Monday showed 65 percent approving the way Bush is handling his job, down from 75 percent a month earlier and equal to the 65 percent recorded in July. That 65 percent was the lowest approval rating since Bush took office. A CBS-New York Times poll conducted Sunday gave Bush an approval rating of 62 percent, down from a peak of 76 percent in August just after troops were sent to Saudi Arabia. Congress fared little better: -In the ABC-Washington Post poll, 57 percent said Congress was more to blame than the president for the budget impasse. -In the CBS-New York Times poll, 54 percent blamed the budget snarl on Congress and the president equally. The ABC-Washington Post poll interviewed 775 people and the CBS-New York Times poll interviewed 756. Both surveys were done by telephone and reported a likely margin of error of 4 percentage points either way.
---
DOC.HEAD: Striped Bass Ban Set
DOC.TEXT:
Fishing for Atlantic striped bass will be prohibited in most federal waters starting Nov. 1, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration announced. Harvest and possession of striped bass will be banned in federal waters extending from 3 miles to 200 miles off shore. The only exception is an area of Block Island Sound, Rhode Island, where fishermen will be permitted to transport to the mainland bass taken legally in state waters at Block Island. The regulations are intended to protect the striped bass, which is slowly recovering from a severe decline in the 1970s and early 1980s, NOAA's National Marine Fisheries Service said. Taking of striped bass in state waters is subject to varying regulation.
---
DOC.HEAD: Group Gearing Up to Send Christmas Gifts to Gulf GIs
DOC.TEXT: An organization that sent $3 million worth of gift packages to servicemen in Vietnam is gearing up to ship Christmas packages to U.S. soldiers in the Persian Gulf region. Roger Chapin, president of Help Hospitalized Veterans, said his goal is to raise enough money to send 250,000 packages, enough for every American serving in Operation Desert Shield to receive one. Chapin said each of the packages will have a retail value of at least $15, including packaging and shipping, and will contain nuts, cookies, dates, raisins, hard candies and other treats. Each package will include a Christmas card from the donor, along with a card the recipient can mail back. Chapin said the cost to the donor for one package would be $15. Two can be sponsored for $25, four for $50, six for $75 and eight for $100. People wishing to donate may call 1-800-755-GIFT (or 1-800-755-4438) from Oct. 14 to Nov. l5, or may send a check or money order to ``G.I. Christmas Gift Pac'' at P.O. Box 91560, Washington, D.C. 20090. Help Hospitalized Veterans is an offshoot of Vietnam Gift Pac, which Chapin, a former San Diego real estate developer, founded in 1967 after a chance meeting with a Navy corpsman wounded in Vietnam. Chapin, an Army veteran, founded Help Hospitalized Veterans in 1970. The non-profit organization provides hospitalized veterans with arts and crafts kits. In a related development, the Postal Service urged Americans mailing Christmas gifts to service personnel in the gulf region to mail early. The Postal Service said that to ensure timely delivery to the Middle East, air parcels should be mailed by Nov. 16, letters and cards by Nov. 26, parcel airlift mail by Nov. 10 and space-available mail by Nov. 3.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Passes Deficit-Reduction Plan; Government Shutdown Averted
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs files; inserts White House statement as new 9th graf, ``The president; should stand for AMs
DOC.TEXT: A government shutdown ended early Tuesday after a night of budget breakthroughs in Congress that also saw the Senate give final approval to a $500-billion deficit-reduction plan. The Senate passed an emergency bill on a voice vote Monday night that would let the government open normally Tuesday morning and the House concurred, 362-3, at about 1:30 a.m. EDT. The White House said President Bush would sign the legislation and that all federal employees should report to work as scheduled. Shortly after midnight, the Senate voted 66-33 for final approval to a separate measure, a five-year, $500-billion package of tax increases and spending cuts. The plan envisioned smaller cuts in Medicare, but possibly higher tax increases, than an earlier version the House rejected last week. ``Tonight we reap the bitter harvest of a decade of national indulgence,'' said Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine. Majorities of both parties voted for the budget plan. Democrats favored it 42-13, and Republicans voted for it by a 24-20 margin. This outline plan mapped the way for specific spending cuts and tax increases, which Congress planned to put in a separate bill and pass by Oct. 19. The outline does not require the president's signature, but the later bill does. The emergency spending measure would allow the government to operate normally through Oct. 19. Congressional leaders hope all budget work will be completed by then, and that the members can adjourn to work on their re-election campaigns. ``The president will sign the continuing resolution (the emergency bill) this morning. The government can resume operations. All federal employees should report to work this morning,'' White House spokeswoman Laura Melillo said after the House gave its final approval. The Statue of Liberty, museums and national parks have been closed since Saturday because the budget crisis had prevented Congress from approving any spending legislation for the new fiscal year. But the full brunt of the federal shutdown was masked because of the long Columbus Day weekend. Earlier in the day, lawmakers warned of chaos if the White House and Congress failed to resolve their months-long impasse over the federal deficit. ``We're not just dealing with programs,'' warned Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, urging his colleagues to pass the measure quickly. ``We're dealing with individual human beings and families, and their hopes and fears and dreams.'' ``This has just een playing marshmallow stuff'' so far, said Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., the Senate's assistant Republican leader, referring to the limited impact on the government during the Columbus Day holiday weekend. ``Any thoughtful, reasonable person now knows what happens to this government tomorrow.'' Debate on the budget began in the early evening. Leaders of both parties had spent the day trying to line up support for the budget and for a separate measure bringing the shut-down government back to life Tuesday morning. ``This is not a shining moment for anyone,'' Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., said of the budget mess as debate began. ``And frankly, our countrymen are rightly tired of it.'' The House passed the budget outline 250-164 in a post-midnight session early Monday. The measure contains far fewer specific spending cuts and tax increases than the version that went down to defeat last week, putting off those decisions for later in the month. The vagueness of the new package left some senators unhappy. ``I'm not going to sign onto this fill-in-the-blanks package,'' said Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas, who supported and helped write the first package. Sasser said of the new proposal, ``The best argument is it reduces the deficit by historic proportions over the next five years and gives Congress flexibility on issues and problems that have troubled members and constituents over the last few days.'' Many lawmakers of both parties believe that in the end the new plan will also contain a cut in the capital gains tax rate and higher income taxes for the wealthy. Bush has wanted to slash the capital gains tax - levied on sales of property - for years, while Democrats have demanded the higher rates on the wealthy as a tradeoff. The new proposal would eliminate many of the specifics from savings proposals that had driven a majority of both Democrats and Republicans to reject an initial package Friday in the House. Gone was one-third of the earlier plan's $60 billion in Medicare reductions - including higher costs and lower benefits for beneficiaries. Specifics on higher taxes for gasoline, home-heating oil, alcohol, tobacco and other items were also deleted. Instead, the new version would pare Medicare savings to $40 billion. New taxes over the five years could total $10 billion more than the $135 billion in the old package, but all decisions about specific spending cuts and tax boosts were to be left to Congress' committees. This approach worked in the House, which approved the new plan despite opposition from most minority Republicans. Like the rejected package, the new plan claims to save $40 billion in the fiscal year that started Oct. 1, and $500 billion over the next five years. House Democratic leaders told their rank-and-file that under the new plan, the Medicare deductible paid by recipients for doctors' costs would rise gradually from $75 to $100, instead of the $150 in the old package. The House also approved the temporary spending bill 305-105 early Monday. Without Senate approval and Bush's signature on that measure, all but crucial government services would shut down Tuesday, and hundreds of thousands of federal workers would be sent home. Over the three-day weekend, the effects of the government's legal inability to spend money have been spotty. Essential services such as air traffic control and federal prisons functioned normally, but the Statue of Liberty and many other national parks shut down.

DOC.HEAD: Violent Incidents At The Temple Mount
With PM-Temple Mount
DOC.TEXT: Here are some of the major incidents of violence and bloodshed at the Temple Mount, worshiped by Jews as the site of two biblical temples and by Moslems as the place from which the Prophet Mohammed went to heaven. July 20, 1951: King Abdullah of Jordan is shot to death in the Al Aqsa Mosque by an Arab who objected to Jordan's annexation of the West Bank. His grandson, who later became King Hussein, witnesses the slaying. Aug. 21, 1969: A mentally disturbed Australian Christian tourist, Dennis Michael Rohan, sets fire to the Al Aqsa Mosque. Rohan says he believed the Messiah would not come until abominations had been cleared from the Temple Mount. The arson causes serious damage and sparks rioting by Arabs. April 11, 1982: U.S. immigrant Allan Harry Goodman shoots his way into the compound, killing a Moslem guard and wounding four Arabs. Goodman, who was sentenced to life in prison in 1983, claimed to be a Jewish liberator. The attack triggered anti-Israeli riots, and 11 Arabs were killed by troops in the clashes. March 11, 1983: Police arrest 43 Jewish extremists who planned to dig a tunnel and break into the Dome of the Rock. April 7, 1989: About 4,000 Palestinians chanting ``Palestine is Moslem'' hurl stones on Jews praying at the Wailing Wall below. A dozen people are injured and 37 Arabs arrested.

DOC.HEAD: George Strait Is Top Country Music Entertainer Again
LaserPhotos NS4-8
DOC.TEXT: George Strait, who nearly quit singing 11 years ago, is the Country Music Association's top entertainer for the second straight year. Strait, frustrated over a lack of success, considered giving up his career in 1979 to work for a company that designs cattle pens, but he decided to keep going and soon became one of country music's top stars. His second win of the association's most prestigious honor came Monday during the CMA's 24th annual awards show. ``They were both surprises,'' the 38-year-old singer said after the nationally televised show. ``Everyone nominated certainly deserved to be there. But I'm glad they picked me.'' Over the summer, he had the biggest hit record of his career, ``Love Without End, Amen.'' His album ``Livin' It Up'' also has been a swift seller. ``It's hard not to be affected by this stuff,'' Strait said of his awards success. He shared laurels Monday night at the Grand Ole Opry House with the Kentucky HeadHunters, who won two awards, and with Clint Black and Kathy Mattea, who were chosen best vocalists. Tennessee Ernie Ford, 71, ``the Ol' Peapicker,'' capped off his career by being chosen for the Country Music Hall of Fame. ``Bless your little pea-pickin' hearts. Tonight I'm a happy man,'' said Ford, a TV pioneer known for his 1955 hit record ``Sixteen Tons.'' The Kentucky HeadHunters, a five-piece band whose shaggy hair and rock 'n' roll stylings make them unlikely country music stars, won vocal group of the year and best album for ``Pickin' on Nashville.'' ``Does this mean we get to keep our hair?'' jested HeadHunters' guitarist Greg Martin. Another double winner was newcomer Garth Brooks, who won top music video for ``The Dance'' and the Horizon Award for career development. His music video included clips of former President John Kennedy, the Challenger crew and John Wayne. Vince Gill, a singer who has done backup vocals for more than 100 of his peers, was rewarded by his friends when he won single of the year for ``When I Call Your Name.'' ``I've been around for a long time and I've waited for this for a long time so I'm going to stand up here for a long time,'' Gill, 33, said in accepting the award. The Judds, a mother-daughter duo, were chosen best vocal duo for the third straight year. ``I have just one more space on my mantel. I was really hoping for this,'' daughter Wynonna Judd said. Lorrie Morgan and her late husband, Keith Whitley, won vocal event of the year honoring performers who normally don't sing together. Their award was for ``'Til a Tear Becomes a Rose,'' which Whitley recorded alone. Morgan added her vocals after his death in May 1989. Song of the Year, a songwriter's award, went to Jon Vezner and Don Henry for the poignant ``Where've You Been,'' which was recorded by Mattea, Vezner's wife. Fiddler Johnny Gimble won musician of the year for the fourth time in the past five years. Randy Travis, who has sold more than 10 million records in just four years, failed for the fourth time to win the entertainer of the year award. Ricky Van Shelton, voted No. 1 male singer a year ago, won nothing this year despite being nominated in three categories. Travis and Reba McEntire was hosts of the show. Winners were chosen by the 6,000 voting members of the CMA, mostly singers, musicians, songwriters, song publishers, record company employees and disc jockeys. The Hall of Fame honoree was selected by an anonymous 300-member committee.

DOC.HEAD: END HOUSE EMERGENCY SPENDING BILL ROLL CALL - 3 TAKES
Bush Gets Bill to Limit Ads
DOC.TEXT: People who think children are brainwashed by watching too many television commercials hope President Bush will overcome his reservations and sign into law a bill that would limit the number of TV sales pitches to youngsters. The legislation passed unanimously by both the House and the Senate also would require TV stations to pay more attention to the educational needs of young viewers. Broadcasters say they can live with the measure, but White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said last week the administration had ``very strong reservations'' about the bill, which would condition a station's license renewal on how well its programs serve the needs of children. The Justice Department has advised Bush that the bill unconstitutionally intrudes into program content and thus would be an infringement on the First Amendment guarantee of free speech. The president has not said what he will do. Children's TV advocates fear he will veto it. The legislation, which received final congressional approval last week, would limit commercials during children's shows to 12 minutes per hour weekdays and 10.5 minutes per hour weekends. After similar restrictions were lifted from broadcasters in 1984, commercial air time crept up to as much as 14 minutes per hour for some kids' shows, while the amount of informational and educational programs for kids declined sharply, according to a survey released by the House Energy and Commerce telecommunications and finance subcommittee. By comparison, regular prime time programming averages less than eight minutes of commercials an hour. The bill would establish a $6 million endowment for children's programming and require the Federal Communications Commission to begin a review of so-called program-length commercials - programs that interweave programming and commercial material, usually toys. Some observers have noted, however, that any FCC rules that banned such shows as ``Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles'' also could be used against programs such as ``Sesame Street,'' which also has a large commercial spinoff of toys and other products. The measure has the support of a wide array of children's, religious and psychiatric groups. And with the unanimous support in Congress, a Bush veto probably could be overridden. There has been some speculation that instead of vetoing the bill, Bush will let it become law without his signature.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0471 to CORRECT writethru designation.
High-Achieving Teen-agers Say `No' to Drugs, `Yes' to Chinese Revolutionaries
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT spelling to Capriati sted Capriotti. CORRECTS spelling and style to `teen-agers' in grafs 7 and 11. Picks up 12th graf pvs, `Nearly half...
DOC.TEXT: The nation's best and brightest teen-agers are saying ``no'' to drugs and ``yes'' to the Chinese students of Tiananmen Square, according to a nationwide survey. The report on 2,000 high school juniors and seniors paints them in a much more conservative hue than their predecessors of 20 years ago, but with a streak of idealism. From a list that included Mick Jagger, Madonna, Mchael Jordan, Tom Cruise and Jennifer Capriati, the teen-agers chose the Chinese students who demonstrated for democracy at Beijing's Tiananmen Square as the year's No. 1 heroes. Those surveyed were selected from among the 650,000 high achievers listed in the 1990 edition of ``Who's Who Among American High School Students.'' ``We've heard so much about kids not having heroes,'' Paul C. Krouse, publisher of the high school Who's Who, said Monday. ``The good news, is, yes they do have heroes; the bad news is that there were no Americans among the top choices,'' he said. Among other findings of the 21st annual survey of high achieving teen-agers: 25.3 percent have had sexual intercourse; 66 percent of sexually active respondents say they always use a contraceptive; 6 percent would approve of a constitutional amendment making abortion illegal; and half say they've changed eating habits for a healthier lifestyle. Just 2.3 percent said they use marijuana, compared with 10 percent in 1970, and 98 percent said they have never tried crack, heroine, cocaine or steroids. ``They certainly seem to be much more conservative than the students of 20 years ago,'' Krouse said. ``Go to college, get a good job and make money - there's much less concern for social service.'' Their college goals were topped by studies of medicine, business and engineering sciences. Far down the list were teaching, law, journalism and government. In some areas, the teen-agers favored increased control by the adult world. Nearly half - 47 percent - said all high school students should be tested for alcohol use, and 64 percent favored drug testing for all. More than half - 57 percent - favored warning labels on records, tapes, cassettes and videos containing ``objectionable material,'' such as profanity. In choosing their heroes, the teens named Mikhail Gorbachev a distant second to the Chinese students, followed by Mother Teresa and Nelson Mandela. President Bush beat out professional basketball player Michael Jordan for fifth place by a fraction of a percentage point. Black teens selected Mandela as their No. 1 hero, followed by Jesse Jackson. Forty-four percent of the sexually active students had their first sexual experience at age 16. Fifty-nine percent said they have had only one partner. Teens living in rural areas appear to be more sexually active than others. While 25.3 percent of those surveyed said they have had sex, the figure was 30.6 percent for those from rural areas, 20.8 percent from cities and 19.2 percent from suburbs.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Dips Again, Stocks Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar narrowed losses against the Japanese yen and ended slightly lower Tuesday in Tokyo following approval by the U.S. Senate of a deficit reduction plan. Share prices erased early gains and fell. The dollar ended the day at 129.95 yen, down 0.10 yen from Monday's 130.05-yen close. It opened lower at 129.65 yen and ranged between 128.95 yen and 130.35 yen. Tuesday's close was the lowest since Mar. 15, 1989, when the dollar closed at 129.88 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 134.89 points, or 0.57 percent, ending at 23,495.11. The index at late afternoon fell about 550 points from the day's high before narrowing the losses toward the end of the afternoon session, traders said. They said the index fell as market players, discouraged by the slowdown in the yen's surge against the dollar, started selling issues. Meanwhile, the dollar inched up in mixed trading after opening lower following a ``substantial amount'' of dollar selling in the Sydney market, which opens earlier than Tokyo, dealers said. They said the dollar turned upward in the late morning when the Bank of Japan made ``rate check'' phone calls to some Japanese banks. A rate check does not involve any market activity, but is a tactic the central bank uses to make banks voluntarily refrain from too much dollar selling. Also, reports that the U.S. Senate gave final approval to a $500 billion deficit-reduction plan helped support the dollar, said Yoshikazu Kuroda, a dealer with Fuji Bank. The Senate passed an emergency bill on a voice vote Monday night that would let the government open normally Tuesday morning and the House concurred, 362-3. The vote came just as dollar trading closed in Tokyo. The White House said President Bush would sign the legislation and that all federal employees should report to work as scheduled. But the dollar will remain weak despite temporary fluctuations, according to Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. ``There are no positive factors to encourage dollar buying now,'' he said. ``In addition to already serious worries over the U.S. economy, market players are heavily discouraged by the House's disapproval of the budget plan,'' Kanai said. Expectations that the Federal Reserve Board will lower interest rates are also depressing the dollar, dealers said.

DOC.HEAD: Small Crowd Expected for Discovery's Wednesday Landing
With PM-Space Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: NASA expects a crowd of 5,000 to 10,000 people will watch shuttle Discovery land Wednesday. Discovery is scheduled to touch down on concrete Runway 22 on Rogers Dry Lake at 9:58 a.m. EDT Wednesday, National Aeronautics and Space Administration spokesman Don Haley said Monday. ``We expect good weather'' and there should be no problem from mild Santa Ana winds, which usually don't speed up until later in the day, he said. Haley said he anticipates a small crowd of between 5,000 and 10,000 spectators because it will take place during a school day. A record 500,000 spectators watched Columbia land at the desert military base on July 4, 1982. Haley said the smallest crowd was about 2,200 people who watched Columbia land last Jan. 20. Haley said Discovery will land on a paved runway instead of an unpaved strip because NASA wants to test the shuttle's brakes on concrete. Such tests are a prelude to eventual landings at the shuttle's launch site at Cape Canaveral, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: United States Balks at Arab Proposal to Condemn Israel in Riots
With PM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States is resisting an Arab-led groundswell in the Security Council for a resolution accusing Israel of a ``criminal act'' in the killings of 19 Palestinians during riots in Jerusalem. Arab delegates argued Monday that the world should put the Palestinian issue on a par with the Persian Gulf crisis, which was pushed from the top of the council's agenda for the first time in two months. ``We do not understand how oil in the gulf can be valued more highly by you than Palestinian blood and Moslem rights and shrines,'' said Palestinian observer Zuhdi Labib Terzi, speaking to the 15-member council during debate. Israeli Ambassador Johanan Bein accused the PLO of raising the issue to divert attention away from Iraq's takeover of Kuwait. The PLO has backed Iraq, while most of the international community has denounced it and joined in imposing an embargo on trade with Baghdad. The Security Council meeting was adjourned until this morning, and vote prospects remained uncertain. It was not known whether the United States would veto, abstain or support a milder resolution criticizing Israel. It was also possible that a general statement would be issued without a vote. Western diplomats said the United States objected to a phrase in the proposed resolution citing ``indiscriminate opening of fire ... against unarmed Palestinian civilians.'' The Israeli forces moved in Monday after Palestinians threw stones at Jews praying at the Wailing Wall in Jerusalem's Old City. Israel already has rejected the proposed resolution's provision for a three-man fact-finding mission from the Security Council to investigate the killings. In Monday's debate, 13 speakers assailed Israeli authorities for the use of deadly forces during the riots, which also left about 140 Arabs wounded. It was the worst violence in Jerusalem in 23 years. The Arab envoys demanded that Israel be denounced for the ``criminal act'' of allowing police to open fire on Palestinians. ``We do not understand how the Security Council can ignore our plea for protection. ... We appeal to the civilized world: Come to our protection before it is too late,'' Terzi, the Palestinian envoy, said in his speech Monday. However, Israeli ambassador Bein said the PLO had ``attempted to ambush thousands of Jewish worshipers'' at the Wailing Wall. ``It was a provocation that was planned ahead and the only people who will try to gain from it are the Palestinians and (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein.'' Saddam has suggested linking any international accord on Kuwait with a settlement of the Palestinian issue. Western powers have rejected any preconditions on an Iraqi pullout but suggested that the Palestinian question could be discussed afterward. The new flareup in Israel has put U.S. officials in a delicate position. Washington does not wish to be accused of exercising a double standard toward Kuwait and the Palestinians, especially when it is trying to keep Arab support for the U.S.-led international force countering Iraq. Arab diplomats hinted Monday that a U.S. veto could jeopardize the international and Arab coalition assembled against Iraq. However, the United States, Israel's staunchest ally, was reported unwilling to vote for any fact-finding commission that Israel would reject. The United States already has criticized use of live fire by Israeli police. U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering reaffirmed that opposition Monday and told reporters the U.S. government wants restraint. He said extremists on both sides are trying to inflame the situation in Jerusalem. Soviet Ambassador Yuli Vorontsov said the Soviet Union ``sternly condemns these inhuman and provocative activities on the part of Israel.'' Most speakers condemning Israel proposed that a U.N.-sponsored international peace conference devise a political settlement in the Middle East, and demanded political rights or statehood for Palestinians.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Ranks Kennedy Assassination as Most Memorable Moment in TV History
DOC.TEXT: Blurred images of first lady Jacqueline Kennedy, her arms reaching out in anguish from the car carrying her mortally wounded husband, were part of TV's most memorable broadcast, a survey found. President John F. Kennedy's 1963 assassination in Dallas topped astronaut Neil Armstrong's 1969 moon walk as the single most important television program in history, according to the survey released Monday, ``The Best of the First 50 Years of Television.'' The acclaimed television miniseries ``Roots'' rated third, according to the survey released by the Siena Research Institute of Siena College, a small liberal-arts school. Huundreds of college professors, TV and newspaper critics and others were asked to pick television's finest efforts from a wide range of categories. The purpose was to prompt discussion and criticism, said Professor Thomas Kelly II. ``Roots,'' which looked at the history of slavery in America by tracing the ancestors of one black man, was chosen the best miniseries ever made. ``It was a highly dramatic historical presentation that people found attractive and revolting at the same time,'' Kelly said. The survey named former RCA president and broadcast pioneer David Sarnoff the most significant figure in television history. The development of color broadcasts was chosen the most important technical innovation. ``Hill Street Blues,'' created by Stephen Bochco, was voted the best drama series by a 2-1 margin over second-place finisher ``Playhouse 90.'' Finishing sixth in the category was another Bochco creation, ``L.A. Law.'' The survey also distinguished Bochco as the second-most significant producer in television history, behind ``All in the Family'' creator Norman Lear. ``I Love Lucy'' was ranked the No. 1 comedy series of all time, narrowly defeating ``M.A.S.H.'' ``Gunsmoke'' was the overwhelming winner of the best Western series category, followed by ``Bonanza.'' ``The Ed Sullivan Show'' topped the list of best variety series, ranked above ``Carol Burnett'' and ``Your Show of Shows.'' Jay Sandrich, whose credits include ``Get Smart,'' ``The Mary Tyler Moore Show,'' ``Soap'' and ``The Cosby Show,'' was chosenmost significant director, edging out Alfred Hitchcock and Rod Serling. In the news-documentary category, ``60 Minutes'' was ranked first, followed closely by the 1950s show ``See it Now.''
