DOC.HEAD: Attorney Challenges 2 Live Crew Jury Selection
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection in the obscenity trial of rap group 2 Live Crew was slowed by legal wrangling over the racial makeup of the jury pool and the state's challenge of the judge. Group leader Luther Campbell and band members Chris Wongwon and Mark Ross face misdemeanor obscenity charges stemming from a June 10 adults-only performance at a nightclub in nearby Hollywood. If convicted, the three could be sentenced to up to a year in jail and fined $1,000. Pre-trial hearings and jury selection were scheduled for today. Bruce Rogow, the attorney defending the black rappers, challenged Broward County's voter-based jury pool as unconstitutional in cases that depend on community standards, like obscenity. ``Because it relies only on voter registration lists it leaves you always with a pretty middle-class, semi-middle-aged, disproportionately white jury pool because those are the people who register to vote in the greatest numbers,'' Rogow said. Only three of 25 potential jurors questioned Monday were black. Broward Circuit Judge June Johnson said she wanted to see the whole 70-person pool before ruling on the defense motion. No jurors for the six-member panel were chosen Monday. The defense attorney didn't suggest an alternative way to choose potential jurors. Rogow also represented Charles Freeman, a black record store owner convicted last week by an all-white jury on a similar charge for selling the group's album, ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' ``Freeman's case woke everybody up to the fact there's something wrong with the jury system,'' Campbell said Monday. The album, which U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez earlier ruled obscene, has sold about 2 million copies. Freeman complained after his conviction that the jury ``doesn't represent my community.'' An elections official said about 8.5 percent of registered voters in Broward County are black. Johnson rejected a prosecution request Monday that she disqualify herself from the case because she had been a law student of defense attorney Rogow 15 years ago. Prosecutors are appealing the decision. The judge approved a defense motion that neither Freeman's conviction nor Gonzalez's ruling should be allowed as evidence at the group's trial. Most obscenity cases are argued on the U.S. Supreme Court's Miller v. California test. Essentially, it holds that material is obscene if the average person, applying contemporary local community standards, would find that it is designed to cause sexual arousal, if it depicts sex in a patently offensive way, and if, taken as a whole, it lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Agreement in Place, the Government is Open for Business
With PM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of thousands of federal workers need not endure the discomfort today of learning the Republic will go on without them. The federal government is open for business. The three-day shutdown of the government affected mostly tourists. It happened over a holiday weekend and caused the closing of national monuments, parks and museums. The real pinch would have been today when everyone was coming back to work. But Monday night's accord between Congress and the White House on an emergency spending bill will give government the legal authority to spend money until Oct. 19. By then, congressional leaders hope to work out a deficit-reducing budget that will carry things through next September. The alternative would have been to let the government's 2.4 million employees show up for work this morning and then send home all but those whose services are considered essential. By some estimates that could have meant roughly 2 million of those people would learn that the government was prepared to do without their services and they would have to do without their pay. The prospect of this made some angry. ``It's demoralizing,'' said John Sturdivant, president of the 700,000-member American Federation of Government Employees. ``All the anxiety, all the wasted time on sending out furlough notices and memos.'' Essential workers included air traffic controllers, law enforcement agents, prison guards and nurses in Veterans' Administration hospitals. Thousands of other federal employees - ranging from meat inspectors to press secretaries to U.S. troops in the Middle East - remained on the job after government authorization to pay them expired Friday night. But the government was planning to send home the bulk of the people who collect its taxes, monitor its environment, support its farmers and other day-to-day operations. Some employees were not told in advance whether they were considered essential, and their job status for today was left hanging over the weekend. ``I'm really rather confused about what is going on,'' Vic Lara, who processes Social Security claims in Mesa, Ariz., said Monday. ``There's a chance I might not be working. It's hard enough to make it on my pay level at full time.'' One official who declined to be identified by name or agency said the Office of Management and Budget had set guidelines stating that normally only 15 percent of a civilian agency should be considered essential. Fifteen percent would mean 360,000 people would stay on the job and about 2 million would be sent home. However, in past shutdowns only a few hundred thousand have gone home.

DOC.HEAD: Chess Foes Kasparov, Karpov Take Up Where They Left Off - With a Draw
LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Bitter foes Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov finally sat down to their long-awaited world chess rematch, but five hours after their first game began, the result was the same as the last time they met - a draw. The two opened the 1990 World Chess Championship on Monday at the Hudson Theater, where a hushed crowd of about 700 paid up to $100 a ticket to watch the first of 24 scheduled games. After 30 moves apiece, Kasparov, the champion, offered a draw and Karpov accepted. The two play again Wednesday. When they last met for the championship in 1987 the competition ended in a draw and Kasparov retained the title he won from Karpov in 1985. They are polar opposites when it comes to chess styles, politics and personalities. Their rivalry is intense. Kasparov, 27, the highest-rated player in the history of chess, has a bold, attacking style. Karpov, 39, relies on methodical, defense-minded strategies. The younger man is a flamboyant champion who does not hesitate to criticize his country's communist leaders. The older chessman is a Communist Party member who has been quoted as saying, ``I have two loves: communism and chess.'' Kasparov plays under the flag of the Russian republic, not the Soviet Union, in protest against a government he calls tyrannical. On Monday, Kasparov opened with the Byrne Variation of the King's Indian Defense, named for Robert Byrne, The New York Times chess columnist who popularized it. As the two played, the audience of several hundred, including actors Steve Martin and Rick Moranis, sat in rapt silence. The crowd offered up a ``shhhhhhhh'' at one point when someone in the back spoke up. The game ended when Kasparov took a pawn from Karpov, evening their forces. ``It's an unavoidable draw,' said international master Vitaly Zaltzman of New York. Chess buffs in attendance said the lack of a victor didn't bother them. ``It's not very often that you get to see the two best chess players in the world,'' said William Mulcahy, 36. He paid $100 to see the game and said he'll be back to see another. ``I wouldn't want to be on that stage right now,'' said 10-year-old Matthew Blank. ``I'd be killed in 15 moves. But someday, I wouldn't mind.'' This year's tournament is to feature 12 games in New York, then 12 in Lyon, France. The winner will receive $1.7 million and the loser $1.3 million. The match, played on a board linked to a computer, is aimed at the TV generation. Above the stage is a screen, about 10 feet high, bearing a drawing of a blue and pink chess board with black and white pieces. When Kasparov or Karpov makes a move, the pieces on the screen move, too, for the audience's benefit. Two video screens, about 5 feet high, flank the center screen, allowing the audience to see the players up close. Karpov appeared calm during Monday's match, looking at times as if he had just woken up. Kasparov pressed his chest against the table and fidgeted, bouncing one foot, puffing out his cheeks, scowling, wincing, pursing his lips. He often assumed his most famous pose: cheeks or forehead enveloped in both hands. Karpov surprised many of the grandmasters present when on his fifth move he pursued a line of play the two had ever used in their 121 previous matches. He chose a series of moves known as the Saemisch Variation, a flexible opening that allows white to attack on either side of the board. Observers felt Kasparov's 19th move - attacking Karpov's rook with his bishop - was a mistake and a turning point in the game. ``Karpov played rather listlessly in the opening, but Kasparov pressed too hard and nearly let (the game) get away,'' said grandmaster Joel Benjamin of New York.

DOC.HEAD: Dozens Arrested As Protest Turns Violent
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with more precise numbers for demonstrators, those arrested. Picks up 4th pvs, `The march ...'
DOC.TEXT: A protest over Aboriginal land rights turned violent today as a group of about 400 demonstrators ripped down the state Parliament's front gate and clashed with police. A police spokesman said 11 protesters were arrested and charged with offenses ranging from assaulting police to malicious damage. The violence broke out after several protesters scaled the iron gates of the New South Wales Parliament House and members of the increasingly irate crowd managed to rip out two sections of the gate. Protesters poured toward Parliament's front door and were met by police reinforcements. Scuffles broke out as police battled to remove the protesters. Police kept the protesters from entering the building. They managed to force the crowd back onto the street and formed a human chain to cover the six-meter-wide hole in the fence. The demonstrators took away a section of the cast-iron front gate and dumped it in the street. Chanting and waving signs, they also began throwing beer cans and rocks at police. The march was organized to protest an alleged lack of consultation over changes that the state government plans in the Aboriginal Land Rights Act. The amended act is expected to be passed by the state Parliament's Upper House this week. Last month, the Aboriginal Land Council and the state government reached an agreement that both said would guarantee land council autonomy. Land Council chairman David Clark described it as a ``historic'' agreement because it was the first time Aborigines, Australia's indigenous people, were consulted in forming policies that affect them. The amendments give the Land Council automony at a grass-roots level and provide for the election of a 13-member, state-level body. But there is dissatisfaction in some quarters because the amendments are shifting power away from the middle tier of the power structure. State Premier Nick Greiner expressed disappointment at the protest. ``This is a minority group that feels its power base has been eroded - they're probably right about that and they are entitled to their view,'' he said. ``They're not entitled to express it in a ratbag way.'' Land councils in New South Wales were established in 1983 as a three-tiered, democratically elected system to administer Aboriginal land. The councils invest their allotment of a land tax in property and businesses. Some Aborigines, but far from all, live on rural land that is purchased by the councils. Many of those who hold jobs work for businesses bought by the land councils.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in the East and South
DOC.TEXT: Rain was falling in the East and South today and some drizzle was reported in the Midwest. A broadening, Austin-to-Boston connection of showers was in the forecast, with a wide band of rain and thunderstorms stretching from Texas to New England. Heavy rain, up to two inches, was possible in the Ohio Valley, forecasters said. Warm, humid weather was likely to dominate the Southeast and most of the Deep South into Wednesday. High temperatures in the 50s were seen in the Great Lakes region and New England, the 60s in the Midwest and Pacific Northwest, the 70s in the Middle Atlantic states, the 80s in most of the South and California and the 90s in the Southwest and Florida. DOC.HEAD: Bar That Inspired the TV Show Won't Change Its Name to `Cheers'
DOC.TEXT: The neighborhood bar that inspired the hit television series ``Cheers'' has decided to keep its original name - the Bull & Finch Pub. ``The Bull & Finch has been a Boston landmark for 20 years now,'' owner Thomas Kershaw said in a statement Monday. ``Our regulars made a compelling case to keep the Bull & Finch tradition alive.'' Kershaw had planned to change the pub's name in time for a local celebration next month in honor of the 200th episode of ``Cheers.'' Ted Danson and other stars of the 8-year-old show are expected to be in Boston on Nov. 8 to take part in the festivities, which will include a parade. The Bull & Finch, which opened in a basement in 1969, was a neighborhood bar until word spread that it was the inspiration for ``Cheers.'' The TV set is a mirror image of the Boston bar. Now, the bar reports an estimated 500,000 tourists drop by each year. ``The Bull & Finch Pub is still basically a neighborhood bar. Our neighborhood has just gotten a lot bigger,'' Kershaw said.

DOC.HEAD: Steve Martin, Rick Moranis See Comedy in World Championship Chess
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final 2 grafs to CORRECT typo to empty-handed sted emptyhanded and to show that Moranis also appeared in ``Parenthood.''
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Chess Showdown, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Comedy actors Steve Martin and Rick Moranis joined hard-core chess fans at a world championship match between two bitter Soviet rivals - and found something to laugh about. ``I don't know anything about checkers,'' Moranis quipped, explaining that he came to the opening game Monday only because Martin ``bought the tickets.'' Martin, said he came for the excitement and ``to see the fights in the audience,'' but the hottest crowd action came when someone in the back spoke out loud and miffed spectators let out a unified ``shhhh!'' The actors watched as defending champion Garry Kasparov and challenger Anatoly Karpov battle to a draw in the opening match of the 1990 World Chess Championship at the Hudson Theater. Martin, who appeared in such films as ``Parenthood'' and ``The Three Amigos,'' didn't leave empty-handed - he bought himself a chess clock. Moranis co-starred in ``Parenthood'' and also appeared in the ``Ghostbusters'' films and ``Honey, I Shrunk the Kids.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Makes First Arrests Of Former Communist Officials
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To DELETE extraneous words, SUB 3rd graf, `The arrests ...' Picks up 4th, `When Prime ...' ^By ANDRZEJ STYLINSKI
DOC.TEXT: Authorities have arrested two retired Interior Ministry generals and charged them with masterminding the 1984 murder of popular pro-Solidarity priest Jerzy Popieluszko. Prosecutors on Monday also announced the arrests of a former interior minister and six others on corruption charges. The arrests represent the first efforts by the Solidarity-led government to prosecute former Communist officials for abuses committed during four decades of authoritarian rule. When Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki became the East bloc's first non-Communist government leader last year, he said there would be no ``witch hunts'' or settling of scores with former Communist officials. Unlike other budding democracies in Eastern Europe, there were no arrests of ousted former high-ranking officials. But Mazowiecki is now running for president against Solidarity chairman Lech Walesa and a key issue in the race is whether he has been too slow to remove Communists from prominent positions in the administration and industry. The balloting is set for Nov. 25 and Mazowiecki, a former Walesa adviser, only announced on Thursday that he would be challenging the Solidarity chief. Poland's general prosecutor, Aleksander Herzog, named the two men arrested in Popieluszko's death as former Deputy Interior Minister Wladyslaw Ciaston and Zenon Platek, former head of the ministry department that had monitored the Roman Catholic church. ``The two generals were presented with charges that in September and October 1984, they instigated their subordinates to kill the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko, and on Oct. 19 they directed the realization of the murder,'' Herzog said in a television interview. Four secret policemen from Platek's department were convicted in the crime, which helped rally pro-democracy forces in predominantly Catholic Poland at a time the Solidarity free trade union movement had been forced underground. Two of those convicted have been paroled, but two others remain in jail. The politically charged investigation that led to their conviction did not find involvement by their superiors. The Prosecutor's office opened a new investigation into the Popieluszko case on July 24, three weeks after the resignation of Interior Minister Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak. He was in charge of the secret and uniformed police forces at the time of Popieluszko killing. The civilian who replaced Kiszczak as head of the Interior Ministry is systematically purging the department. In a front-page commentary in Gazeta Wyborcza today, journalist Jerzy Jachowicz, who has covered the security services for many years, called the arrests that began Thursday ``unprecedented.'' He wrote: ``A great number of former functionaries of the Interior Ministry were arrested, among them a man who even in the 1980s held the highest party and state positions. At that time, an especially repressive and ruthless fight against any manifestation of social independence was being carried out.'' Among those arrested on corruption charges was former Interior Minister Gen. Miroslaw Milewski, a one-time Communist Party Politburo member and a Central Committee secretary. Milewski, 62, worked for the security service from 1944 at least until 1981. He was interior minister in 1980-81. Kiszczak replaced Milewski as interior minister in July 1981. Milewski was then appointed a Politburo member and Central Committee secretary in charge of internal affairs until his quiet dismissal in January 1985, shortly after the murder of Popieluszko. The inquiry involves ``the acceptance of material benefits of great value, including many kilograms of gold and jewelry,'' said Herzog. He did not name the others charged but said they included two other generals and two colonels. He did not elaborate but stressed that the case was not connected with the murder of Popieluszko. The investigation is being carried out by the Office for Protection of the State, created when the secret service was disbanded in May.

DOC.HEAD: Rwanda Tries to Put Down Insurgency with Hundreds of Arrests
DOC.TEXT: Rwanda's government has stepped up efforts to put down an invasion of ethnic Tutsi rebels by rounding up hundreds of suspected rebel supporters. Meanwhile, in the northeast of that central African nation, soldiers continued their battle with what the government is now describing as a force of 10,000 rebels - several times largest than earlier estimates. More than 230 people have been killed in the 10-day-old war, the government announced Monday. In a briefing for foreign envoys on Monday, Foreign Minister Casimir Bizimungu of Rwanda said about 500 people had been arrested for questioning. News reports from France and Belgian, the former colonial power, said up to 3,000 people, mainly members of the minority Tutsi tribe, had been picked up. Diplomats in the capital, Kigali, could not give a precise figure but said hundreds were being held in jails and at a stadium outside the city. Bizimungu put the size of the invading force at 10,000 and said 30 army troops and 200 rebels had been killed. He also claimed the rebels were ``assassinating'' civilians but did not elaborate. In telephone interviews, diplomats who attended the briefing said they understood from other sources as well that civilians had been killed in the fighting zone, but it was unclear by whom. One foreign envoy said travelers from the north had told him of seeing ``many corpses,'' but had provided no specific numbers. Rebels calling themselves the Rwandese Patriotic Front invaded across the northern border with Uganda on Sept. 30. The force is made up of Rwandan refugees, mainly Tutsis. Many are deserters from Uganda's army. The rebels accuse the government of President Juvenal Habyarimana of corruption, human rights abuses and dictatorial leadership. They say theirs is not an ethnic war. However, this country of 6.7 million has a long history of enmity between Tutsis and Hutus, who dominate the government. Nearly 100,000 Tutsi refugees have lived in Uganda since the late 1950s and early 1960s after fleeing massacres by the Hutu tribe. Habyarimana, a Hutu, has ruled Rwanda since a 1973 coup. Forces from other countries have been drawn into the new conflict. France, Belgium and Zaire have sent nearly 1,500 troops, saying the mission is to protect their citizens and embassies in Kigali. The rebels have warned foreign governments not to interfere in the fighting. Nearly 1,000 expatriates, mostly women and children, left Rwanda on special flights over the weekend. But the exodus appeared to have ended by Monday. Fighting was reported around the capital Friday. Shops began to reopen and people were again allowed to move freely around the city Monday. Residents today reported hearing no shooting in the capital overnight. They said most businesses had reopened. Bizimungu said the country was calm, except for the northeastern Mutara region where Rwandese soldiers were fighting the rebels. He claimed the invaders had sophisticated weaponry including mortars, armored vehicles and machine guns. In a weekend interview with a London newspaper, The Independent, a rebel leader denyed those claims. But Maj. Peter Bayingana did say that the rebels had pushed army troops out of the region and set up headquarters about 12 miles inside Rwanda. Bayingana was also quoted as denying harming civilians: ``The local people are astonished that we haven't done what the government said we'd do - raping them, killing them.''

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan Expels Four Indian Diplomats
DOC.TEXT: The government has ordered four Indian diplomats expelled for ``undesirable activities'' in the latest blow to deteriorating relations between the two countries. The Indian Embassy said the expulsions, ordered late Monday, represent a move by Pakistan to whip up fears of an Indian plot to sabotage this country's Oct. 24 parliamentary elections. The ousted diplomats were working at the Indian consulate in the southern port city of Karachi. They have been ordered to leave the country within 10 days, a Pakistani Foreign Ministry release said. ``These Indian officials were involved in undesirable activities which were totally incompatible with their official status,'' the statement said. The ministry refused to elaborate. ``I think it's been in the cards for some time, what with this orchestrated thing building up in the press ... charging Indians are doing a lot of subversive activity,'' said an Indian Embassy spokesman, referring to almost daily reports of an Indian-backed sabotage plot. Last week, army chief-of-staff Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg said an ``extremely dangerous'' plot to sabotage polling had been uncovered. He hinted that a ``foreign hand'' was behind it, a term Pakistan uses when referring to India. The government has since said 58 Indian-trained agents have been arrested and scores more have slipped into the country's ethnically troubled southern province of Sindh. Shooting sprees by various groups in the past five months have killed at least 500 people in the southern cities of Karachi and Hyderabad. The Indian Embassy spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity, said India expelled two Pakistani diplomats during the summer. ``This is probably also tit-for-tat,'' he said. Relations between India and Pakistan soured in January when a violent secessionist uprising began in India's state of Jammu-Kashmir. More than 1,300 people have died in the conflict since January, when the Indian army launched its military crackdown on Moslem insurgents fighting for either independence or union with Pakistan. The two countries have twice gone to war over Kashmir, in 1947-48 and in 1965. The wars have left Kashmir divided into Pakistani and Indian sectors. Predominantly Hindu India fought Moslem Pakistan in a third war in 1971 over Bangladesh.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Ambassador Hurt In Car Accident
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Ambassador William Swing suffered a concussion and a broken collarbone when his vehicle collided with a taxi on rain-slickened streets, the U.S. Embassy said today. Swing, 56, remained hospitalized today following the accident Monday evening, but he was in good condition and was expected to be released shortly, said Embassy spokesman Barry Walkley. Swing was being driven to the airport when the accident occurred near downtown Johannesburg. The ambassador's chauffeur, Edison Mmusa, was slightly injured.

DOC.HEAD: Myron Natwick, Creator of Betty Boop Cartoon Character
DOC.TEXT: Myron ``Grim'' Natwick, the animator who gave life to a curvaceous flapper with a kewpie-doll face whose favorite refrain was ``Boop-Boop-A-Doop,'' has died. He was 100. Natwick died Sunday at Santa Monica Hospital Medical Center of complications from pneumonia, hospital spokesman Ted Braun said Monday. Natwick introduced the mini-skirted Betty Boop in 1930. Betty, with help from singer Helen Kane, soon became known for her coy trademark, ``Boop-Boop-A-Doop.'' ``Although she was never vulgar or obscene, Betty was a suggestion you could spell in three letters: S-E-X,'' Natwick said in a recent interview. ``She was all girl.'' Betty Boop marked a comeback with a cast of other classic cartoon figures in 1988's ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit?'' Natwick's talents were much admired by fellow artists and others in the animation industry, said Noel Blanc, son of the late Mel Blanc, known as the ``man of a thousand voices.'' ``Everybody loved Natwick,'' he said. ``Betty Boop was everybody's favorite lady cartoon.'' The Betty Boop character - one of the earliest animated figures - has enjoyed a recent resurgence, said Blanc, who succeeded his father as the voice of ``Bugs Bunny.'' ``Her popularity in the last five years has been amazing,'' he said. ``A cartoon character goes on forever with the happiness it brings to people.'' Natwick is survived by his daughter and two grandsons.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Attends $2,000-a-Plate Fund-Raising Breakfast
DOC.NOTE: Eds: retransmitting a0519 to correct category code.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush attended a $2,000-a-plate breakfast fund-raiser for two Alaska Republicans today that pulled in at least $150,000. Arliss Sturgulewski, the GOP candidate for governor, and Rep. Don Young were the beneficiaries of the event, which was also attended by Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska. Some 75 guests turned out for the event at the Sheraton Carlton Hotel, a few blocks from the White House. Reporters were not allowed to cover the fund-raiser. Bush shook hands and posed for pictures with each guest before making brief remarks.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Goes Back To Prison - As A Visitor
LaserPhoto CPN1
DOC.TEXT: African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela returned to prison today - but only as a visitor. Mandela, returning to Pollsmoor and Robben Island prisons for the first time since his release in February, spoke to jailed ANC members about government plans to free political prisoners. ``It evokes all kinds of memories ... but I'm concentrating on the pleasant ones,'' Mandela said with a smile before boarding a boat for the short ride from Cape Town to Robben Island. While waiting to get on the boat, Mandela recognized one of his former prison guards and greeted him warmly. ``Oh, you are a sergeant now,'' Mandela said. Mandela was jailed for more than 27 years for plotting to overthrow the government. He spent almost two decades on Robben Island and was moved to Pollsmoor, east of Cape Town, in 1982. Today, he first visited prisoners at Pollsmoor, then went to Robben Island. The ANC has said the government must free the political prisoners before the black opposition movement will enter full-scale negotiations on ending apartheid. The government has released dozens of prisoners in recent months, and 15 more are to be freed Wednesday. But the ANC says there are about 3,000 inmates they consider political prisoners. President F.W. de Klerk has said his government will free all political prisoners, but he has not said how many inmates fall into that category. De Klerk said today that the ANC's estimated 20,000 exiles could begin applying for amnesty to clear the way for their return to South Africa. De Klerk, who legalized the ANC in February, cautioned that amnesty would not automatically be granted to everyone who applied. The ANC was banned in 1960 and launched a guerrilla campaign the following year that was suspended two months ago. The release of political prisoners and the return of exiles are two main obstacles to negotiations on ending apartheid. De Klerk says he wants to draw up a new constitution with opposition groups that would allow the 5 million whites and 30 million blacks to share power. The government and the ANC have been holding preliminary talks since May.

DOC.HEAD: Literature Prize to Be Announced Thursday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to CORRECT date of Nobel will in graf 2, typo in Stockholm in 6th pvs, `The Nobel...' No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Nobel Prize in literature will be announced on Thursday, the Swedish Academy said today. Under terms of the 1896 will of dynamite inventor Afred Nobel, the award should go to a person for outstanding, idealistic work. The literature prize is one of five being awarded this month. The dates for the others are set several months in advance, but the literature prize traditionally is announced with only a few days' notice. The Nobel Prize in medicine was announced Monday and shared by an American who performed the first successful organ transplant and an American who pioeered bone marrow transplants. Joseph E. Murray of Boston and E. Donnall Thomas of Bellevue, Wash., will share the prize, worth $704,000. The Nobel Peace Prize will be announced Monday in Olso, Norway, and the prizes in chemistry and physics will be announced Oct. 17 in Stockholm. The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science, created by the Central Bank of Sweden in 1969, will be awarded in Stockholm on Oct. 16.
