DOC.HEAD: Desert Shield - The Game - Teaches Sober Lessons To Armchair Generals
DOC.TEXT: You've seen it on television and in the papers, now there's the board game - Desert Shield. Armchair generals who hunker down with the $40 game, due to be shipped to stores today, will learn that Iraq's brute force is no match for U.S. technological superiority, the game's maker says. But Mark Herrman, a Defense Department consultant who designed the game for Avalon Hill Game Co., said his game aims to teach another, more sobering lesson. Driving Iraq out of Kuwait without heavy U.S. casualties requires patience - and a little luck. ``There is a lot of force on the other side of the line; you just don't go after them head on,'' Herrman said. Desert Shield is actually an update of a 1983 game by Herrman called Gulf Strike in which the premise is Iran invading Saudi Arabia. The game of Desert Shield simulates in living room safety the standoff in the Persian Gulf between Iraq and the United States and its allies. The board is a map of the gulf broken into octagonal sections. The game pieces are cardboard rectangles representing troops and armaments. Players do battle moving back and forth over the octagons, with a die and game cards to direct the outcome. The game gives the U.S. side a technological advantage, and is set up so that unless the Iraqi side shows a Napoleonic gift for strategy, the United States wins every time. But Herrman said the real challenge for the U.S. player is to defeat Iraq while keeping losses down. Herrman cautioned prospective players that his game is not a three-day war. ``This can take time,'' he said. And even if the U.S. player shows proper patience and tactics, there is no guarantee against heavy battlefield losses. ``War is always chance,'' Herrman said.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed in Shootout at Northern Ireland Farm
DOC.TEXT: Troops killed two men in a shootout at a farmhouse outside Belfast today, and a news agency said one of the victims was a suspect in several attacks on police and soldiers. Britain's domestic news agency, Press Association, identified the man who was wanted for questioning as Dessie Grew. His brother, IRA member Seamus Grew, was killed by police in 1982. Police in Belfast said in a statement that two men and woman also were arrested and three rifles seized during the shootout in the village of Loughgall, County Armagh, 30 miles southwest of Belfast. Soldiers confronted the armed gang in a farmyard. People in the area told Press Association they heard three bursts of gunfire. The news agency said the shootings are believed to have followed an army undercover operation. Security in County Armagh had been increased in the last few weeks following a rise in the number of attacks on off-duty police and soldiers. The attacks were blamed on the outlawed Irish Republican Army. In May 1987, eight IRA members were shot and killed at Loughgall in an undercover operation by British army commandos. The IRA men died as they launched a bomb attack on the village police station. A bystander died when he was caught in cross fire. Last month, the same police station was demolished in an IRA bombing. The building was empty at the time. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA is fighting British rule in Northern Ireland. It wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Premier Urges Go-Slow Policy for Next Five Years
DOC.TEXT: Premier Li Peng, aaking his first public pitch in the debate over economic policy, said today that China should pursue a policy of slow but steady growth. ``You can ask the ordinary folk, do they feel their living standard has fallen? Most think things aren't going too bad, prices are stable and goods in the markets are abundant,'' Li said, defending a 2-year-old austerity policy that critics say has slowed the economy too sharply. ``We cannot develop blindly,'' the premier said. He said priority should be given to agriculture and the economic infrastructure instead of opening new Special Economic Zones, which have served to foster market-style reforms. After taking the lead in market reforms among socialist countries for the past 10 years, China's aging top leadership is engaged in a heated backstage debate over the next decade's course. The government is due to approve a new Five Year Plan to guide the economy from 1991 through 1995, but as the starting date for the plan nears, the leaders appear nowhere near agreement. Li said in a toast at a National Day reception Sept. 30 that the Communist Party's decision-making Central Committee will hold a plenum to discuss a draft plan, but he gave no date for the meeting. Foreign diplomats say several drafts have been written but none has enough support to win Central Committee approval. Li, 61, stepped down in July as minister of the State Commission for Restructuring the Economy, which under ousted party General Secretary Zhao Ziyang had served as a think tank for promoting economic reforms. However, Li's speech indicated he intends to continue playing a key role in economic policy. The speech was delivered Aug. 2 to a conference on industrial production and was published today in the party newspaper, the People's Daily. The paper said it also will appear in the party's weekly magazine, Seek Truth. The official media have published few statements recently from leaders regarded as more reformist. But Chinese economists writing mainly in professional publications have made guarded pleas for a resumption of price reforms, regarded by many as the key to a successful transition from rigid central planning to a market economy. In his speech, Li emphasized price stability and said state price subsidies should be reduced gradually. An estimated one-third of the state budget goes for price subsidies for urban residents, who pay artificially low prices for food, housing and transportation. ``Some localities and departments have started again to strive for projects and want to invest, leaning toward speed,'' Li said. ``If this continues, the construction front will become too long, things will be done on too large a scale ... and we will repeat the old error of being overeager for results. ``We must earnestly learn the lessons of the past and advance steadily during the Five Year Plan and coming decade,'' he said. Zhao's slide from power began in 1988, when hard-liners led by Li accused him of encouraging chaotic and inflationary economic growth. Li helped write an austerity program that has reduced inflation from nearly 40 percent to less than 4 percent. However, the austerity program also forced millions of small rural factories out of business by cutting off credit and supplies and worsened the indebtedness of many large state factories. Reform initiatives have halted and some reforms have been rolled back.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Takes His Seat on Supreme Court
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 8 grafs Souter taking court oath; picks up 5th graf pvs, As Souter; DELETES 17th graf pvs, At last... now outdated
DOC.TEXT: David H. Souter, a mild-mannered, well-read and previously little-known judge from New Hampshire, became history's 105th Supreme Court justice today after pledging to ``do equal right to the poor and to the rich.'' In a brief ceremony in the crowded courtroom, Souter, 51, was administered the judicial oath of office by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and almost immediately got to work hearing high court arguments with his eight new colleagues. In taking the oath, Souter said, ``I do solemnly swear to administer justice without respect to persons, and do equal right to the poor and to the rich.'' Afterward, Souter and Rehnquist posed for photographers outside the building on Capitol Hill before heading back inside for a reception attended by members of the Senate Judiciary Committee, other Washington dignitaries and Souter's friends and well-wishers. Souter, facing a group of photographers and television cameras outside, said, ``I got to work on time this morning. I'm starting off on the right foot.'' As cameras clicked and whirred, Souter said, ``Hurry and load up. I've got to go to work.'' He also disclosed that he has found a place to live in the Washington, D.C., area, but declined to give any details. A short time later, Souter took his seat at the end of bench assigned to the newest justice for the start of the court's regularly scheduled proceedings. As Souter pledged to uphold the Constitution in a separate oath-taking ceremony Monday at the White House, President Bush praised him as ``a very thoughtful and caring man.'' Souter said Monday he hopes to pass on the Constitution ``in as vigorous condition as I have received it this afternoon, as it were, from Justice Brennan.'' Souter was picked as Bush's first high court nominee to replace William J. Brennan, who retired in July because of failing health. Brennan had been a leading voice of liberalism on the court for 34 years. Souter joins the court at a pivotal time in its history. A reliably conservative majority led by appointees of former President Reagan only recently has begun to emerge. The future of legalized abortion and other highly controversial issues such as affirmative action and church-state relations hang in the balance, with relatively little known about how Souter may vote. Souter, who recently described himself as ``a moderate conservative,'' revealed little about his views on major constitutional issues in three days of testimony before the Senate Judiciary Committee. The Senate confirmed him 90-9. Senate Judiciary Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., said Monday it is hard to predict what type of justice Souter will be. ``Once they are in there and they are no longer accountable to their spouse or their God, anything can happen,'' said Biden, apparently disregarding the fact that Souter is a bachelor. Souter last week underscored his own potential importance as a swing vote. He told reporters that other justices were eager for him to come aboard to avoid the possibility of 4-4 ties in controversial cases. The court's 1990-91 term began last week with the justices hearing arguments in cases to be decided by July. Before being named a federal appeals court judge by Bush earlier this year, Souter spent seven years as a member of the New Hampshire Supreme Court. He previously served as a trial judge and as his state's attorney general. Souter lacks a permanent staff, having been assigned only a temporary secretary and a temporary messenger. Each justice is allowed four law clerks, two secretaries and a messenger. Souter said earlier he hoped to select his law clerks by next week. He moved into a suite of offices formerly occupied by Justice Antonin Scalia, who gave them up when he moved into Brennan's old chambers. The gold nameplate put on the door days ago says ``Justice Souter,'' but court officials waited until his swearing-in to remove adhesive paper that covered the plate.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-NTT Chairman Found Guilty in Recruit Stock Scandal
LaserPhoto TOK2
DOC.TEXT: A court today convicted a former chairman of Japan's largest company in the Recruit scandal, an influence-peddling case that helped bring down twoprime ministers. The Tokyo District Court imposed a two-year suspended prison term and a $175,000 fine on Hisashi Shinto, 80, for accepting stock shares at bargain prices before they were publicly listed, court officials said. The non-jury trial of the former head of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp. has been closely watched in Japan as a test of what constitutes a bribe in this country, where gift-giving is common in business and politics. ``Considering NTT's mission to serve the public, the defendant's position and the extent of influence caused by the scandal, (Shinto) bears serious responsibility,'' presiding Judge Ken Toyota said. NTT Chairman Masashi Kojima released a statement after the ruling saying the company ``again apologizes for causing trouble to the public.'' Shinto's conviction is the latest development in the 2-year-old scandal involving Recruit Co., an information conglomerate. The scandal has resulted in five trials with 12 defendants, including politicians and government employees. Two prime ministers - Noboru Takeshita and Sousuke Uno - and three Cabinet members resigned after being tainted by the Recruit affair or to take responsibility for election losses attributed to the scandal. Hiromasa Ezoe, the former chairman of Recruit, was charged with bribery for allegedly selling stock in a real estate subsidiary, Recruit Cosmos, to about 160 influential politicians, businessmen and government officials before the shares went public in October 1986. Ezoe has yet to be tried. Shinto was offered unlisted shares of Recruit Cosmos for $230,000 in September 1986. He quickly sold them at $400,000 just after the stock went public, prosecutors said. Shinto denied doing any special favors for Recruit. The prosecution had alleged that Recruit got favorable terms on telephone lines, maintenance and other services as it sought to enter the telecommunicatons field. Prosecutors also claimed Shinto helped Recruit buy two U.S.-made supercomputers. Shinto was chairman of NTT for less than a year when he resigned in December 1988 in response to allegations he was involved in the scandal. Earlier, as company president, Shinto guided the telecommunications giant from government ownership to a company whose shares are traded on the stock exchange. His arrest in March 1989 stunned Japanese business circles.

DOC.HEAD: Man Advertises on Car Trunk for Spouse, No Takers
DOC.TEXT: John Young is looking for love but he must be going to all the wrong places, at least when he takes his car. Two months after he put a bumper sticker on his car trunk advertising ``wife wanted'' along with his phone number, no one has given the single Minnesota native a jingle. ``I've had no takers. Absolutely none. Not even a crank call,'' said the 45-year-old convenience store manager who is divorced. ``I think it's being taken lightly, like a joke, rather than a serious attempt at making contact,'' Young said Monday. ``I'm pretty much of a homebody. If you're a mid-40s homebody, alone, what do you do?'' he said. Bars aren't his scene, he said. He'd rather read, fish or listen to music. ``I spent 14 years in the infantry, 2{ years in Vietnam, and I like things that are peaceful,'' he said, seated on the couch of the Largo mobile home he shares with a black feline named Mama Cat. Young, who describes himself as intelligent, sensitive and curious, said his ideal woman would be intelligent and pretty. ``And from there on, it's just a matter of chemistry.'' What does he offer? ``I care,'' he said. ``And I'm absolutely serious about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Aerospace Firm Said Beset With Problems
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force review found the Northrop Corp., manufacturer of the B-2 stealth bomber, beset with problems in nearly every aspect of its business, a lawmaker said today. Concerned about Northrop's poor performance in the production of several weapons systems, the Air Force conducted an in-depth study of the company in June and July that ound problems in six major areas. The service identified weaknesses in systems engineering; the transition from research and development to production; software management; subcontract management; organization and personnel; and business systems, which includes cost and schedule estimates. ``The Air Force team found that Northrop failed miserably in every key management area necessary to the successful development and production of a major weapons system,'' said Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee and its investigations subcommittee. The subcommittee's ranking Republican, Rep. Thomas J. Bliley of Virginia, said he found ``it distressing that a company that has been entrusted with over $36 billion since 1980, and that has been counted upon to manage programs critical to our national defense, could have so many fundamental deficiencies.'' The Associated Press obtained a draft copy of Dingell and Bliley's opening statements for a subcommittee hearing today. Loye Miller, a spokesman for Northrop in the Washington, D.C., area, said the company had not seen Dingell's statement and would have no immediate comment on the allegations. Justice Department officials told the panel in July that the California company should be barred from government business. The officials described how Northrop falsified reports on the air-launched cruise missile and conducted improper tests on the Harrier AV-8B jet. Northrop also manufactures the B-2 bomber and is in competition with Lockheed for the contract on the Advanced Tactical Fighter. The company's action led to its guilty plea in February on 34 charges of fraud and a fine of $17 million, the largest criminal fine ever imposed on a defense contractor. At the same hearing, John Betti, undersecretary of defense for acquisitions, said he did not anticipate any debarment procedure against the company. Betti testified that Pentagon officials overseeing management at Northrop ``have assured me that all monitoring systems necessary to protect the interests of the taxpayers and national security are currently in place and working well at Northrop.'' In his statement for today's hearing, Dingell noted a June 5 letter to Kent Kresa, Northrop's president and chief executive officer, in which the Air Force said that ``while some programs have shown improvement in the past year, others, including Tacit Rainbow (a missile program) and key classified programs, continue to reflect poor performance.'' J.J. Welch Jr., the assistant secretary of the Air Force for acquisition, informed Kresa in the letter that the service planned an in-depth review. ``The nature of the performance problems is most serious,'' Welch said. ``I encourage your direct, personal involvement in promptly correcting them.'' Two months later, after the Air Force had conducted its review, Betti testified before the panel. Although Betti had been briefed three times before his appearance, he had not been told of the Air Force's findings from its review, according to Dingell.

DOC.HEAD: 50 Fishermen Killed, 100 Missing in Bay of Bengal
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rain sent tidal waves surging up the Bay of Bengal, killing at least 50 fishermen and swamping the boats of hundreds of others, newspapers and officials said today. At least 5,000 boats carrying tens of thousands of fishermen were in the bay when the storm-driven waves crested up to 5 feet higher than normal Monday, the Bengali-language newspaper Dainik Bangla said. At least 50 fishermen were killed and at least 100 others were missing, the newspaper said. The fate of hundreds of others was not known, it added. The stricken districts lie 75 to 125 miles south of Dhaka, capital of this low-lying nation. Affected were four coastal districts: Patuakhali, Noakhali, Bhola and Barguna; as well as the inland Barisal district, where several tidal rivers overflowed. A senior official at the sea resort town of Cox's Bazar, 185 miles southeast of Dhaka, said searches would be launched for the missing men as soon as the rain stops. The storms and resulting tidal waves are an annual and deadly phenomenon in October, November and December, the official noted when contacted by telephone. Speaking on condition of anonymity, he said he did not yet know the number of deaths or the extent of damage. A senior official at the Relief Ministry in Dhaka said vast areas of crops, mostly rice, had been devastated and a ``substantial number'' of mud and straw houses were damaged. He also spoke on condition of anonymity. Heavy rains across the nation for the past three days have caused flooding in many areas, the Weather Office reported. But so far there were no reports of other mass casualties in inland areas. In Dhaka, between one and two feet of water stood in shantytowns and other low-lying areas.

DOC.HEAD: Parents Offer to Sell Son
DOC.TEXT: An estranged couple has offered to sell one of their three sons, saying they need the money to pay bills. Phillip and Judith Walther, who live in the small town of Moe in southeastern Victoria state, posted notices at a shopping center offering to sell one of their three sons: Benjamin, 21 months; Andrew, 4; and David, 7. The family could not be contacted for comment today, but Walther, 31, told a television interviewer Monday he ``would have to get at least $15,000 for one of them'' to repay his debts. Victoria's Community Services department said it was undecided whether the boys should be taken from their parents. Community Services Minister Kay Setches said the family's case was being assessed during discussions with the family. ``It is a matter of concern to me where parents are driven to a situation where they would make this offer, and what we want to do is ensure they know the degree of support that is available to them,'' she said. She said it was too early to consider charges against the couple and called the offer to sell the children a ``cry for help.'' ``When you look at the degree of pressure the family is under when they are in economic difficulties, they can be driven to make statements they might not want to carry out in a day or two's time,'' she said. But she added: ``Certainly it's a type of child abuse to actually say to your children: `I'm going to sell you' - that concerns me.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Americans Should Avoid West Bank and Gaza
With PM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: The State Department today advised Americans to avoid travel to the West Bank and Gaza Strip due to recurrent disturbances in these areas. A department notice said that U.S. citizens who must travel to these areas ``should be aware of continuing unrest and tension, including stone-throwing, which can affect visitors.'' The advisory was issued after Israeli police killed 19 Arabs at holy sites in East Jerusalem.

DOC.HEAD: Political Tension Mounts over Domestic Spy Scandal
LaserPhoto SEL1
DOC.TEXT: Top opposition leader Kim Dae-jung, backed by 200 supporters staging a sit-in, fasted for a second day today to demand that President Roh Tae-woo disband a military intelligence unit. Dissidents and radical students called for nationwide protests this week, including a major rally Saturday in Seoul. They are angry over allegations that Roh's government conducted military surveillance of more than 1,300 citizens. Roh fired his defense minister and the powerful chief of military intelligence on Monday to minimize the impact of the surveillance scandal, the most serious since he took office in early 1988. About 200 members of Kim's party staged a sit-in to support the opposition leader, who began the hunger strike Monday at his office. Kim is demanding that the government disband the Defense Security Command - the intelligence unit - and carry out economic reform. Roh appealed for a truce in the political fighting and asked the opposition to settle issues through dialogue. Kim's Party for Peace and Democracy rejected his overtures. It also threatened to mount a national movement to topple Roh if the president rejects Kim's calls for reform and refuses to end ``dirty political operations aimed at harassing opposition parties.'' Domestic politics have been in turmoil since August when opposition lawmakers resigned from parliament en masse, charging the government with railroading bills and curtailing democratic reforms. The hardened position of Kim, a veteran opposition leader, was apparently propelled by mounting public criticism of Roh's administration. In stepping up their attack on Roh, dissidents said the allegations that the military spied on civilians showed Roh's government is ``a disguised military government.'' Dissident leaders decided Monday to hold anti-government rallies with radical students this week in Seoul and provincial cities. Roh pledged to keep the military out of politics, and anger over the allegations prompted the opposition to set aside their divisions and join forces. Yoon Suk-yang, a 24-year-old deserter from the military intelligence unit, alleged last week that the military was spying on dissidents, intellectuals and opposition lawmakers. Yoon provided confidential papers, computer discs and data he said were evidence of massive and systematic spying on civilians. Roh captured two-thirds of the 299-member National Assembly in January by merging his party with two minor opposition groups. But his popularity has fallen because of inflation, social disturbances and disputes within the enlarged governing party.

DOC.HEAD: Frankly, Natasha, I Don't Give a Samovar
DOC.TEXT: The movie may not sound romantic as ``Unesennye Vetrom.'' But in Russian it's ``Gone With the Wind,'' and it's making its premiere in the Soviet Union next week. That's 51 years after the U.S. debut of David O. Selznick's film classic about the Civil War that starred Clark Gable and Vivien Leigh. The film's newest venue will include a fund-raiser in Moscow for fighting AIDS, said media tycoon Ted Turner, whose Turner Entertainment Corp. owns the film. ``It's a pleasure to share this crown jewel in the TEC library with the citizens of the Soviet Union,'' Turner said in a statement Monday. The film's first Soviet screening will be Oct. 19 at Moscow's October Cinema. The following night it will be seen in Tbilisi. The current versions for Soviet consumption are in English with Russian subtitles and there are plans to dub a version in Russian for release in January.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Will Hear Appeal on Hospital Unions
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to review a federal rule that lets employees of private hospitals, according to their jobs, organize into eight separate collective bargaining units. The court said it will hear an appeal by the American Hospital Association seeking fewer employee categories. The National Labor Relations Board adopted the rule in 1989. It recognizes separate bargaining units for physicians, registered nurses, other professional employees, medical technicians, skilled maintenance workers, clerical workers, guards and other nonprofessional employees. The regulation applies to employees at more than 4,000 private hospitals nationwid. The Chicago-based 7th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the rule last April. The hospital industry favors recognizing no more than three bargaining units - professional employees, guards and nonprofessional employees. From the employer's perspective, the appeals court noted, ``The more units there are the more costly it will be for the employer to negotiate collective bargaining contracts. And work stoppages will be likelier because there will be more separate decision-makers (to) call a strike.'' But the appeals court said the NLRB did not exceed its authority in fixing on eight categories. The board could have chosen a larger number, the appeals court said, noting New York regulators had permitted 21 separate hospital bargaining units. ``It is not for us to fine-tune the regulatory process by telling the labor board that its rule should make slightly more distinctions that it does, or slightly fewer. ... We therefore uphold its rule without pretending that we consider it Utopia,'' the appeals court said. Bush administration lawyers, even though they defended the NLRB rule, urged the justices to hear the hospitals' appeal. The government lawyers said a high court ruling would head off a host of local challenges that could disrupt labor-management relations at hospitals. The case is American Hospital Association vs. NLRB, 90-97.

DOC.HEAD: More Than 20 People in Germany Suspected of Delivering Weapons to Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: More than 20 people working for German companies are suspected of helping Iraq obtain chemical weapons and other arms, a prosecutor said today. Darmstadt state prosecutor Thomas Brand said the suspects were employed by nine German companies. Of the more than 20 people suspected, Brand said, four people are in investigative custody and three have been released either on bail or for health reasons. They remain under investigation. ``Our suspicions have been widely confirmed,'' said Brand, who heads an inquiry into illegal exports to Iraq that began three years ago, long before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Brand declined to say exactly how many people are suspected of violating export laws. The inquiry was stepped up after a recent confidential report by an independent expert, he said. He declined to disclose details of the report. The newsmagazine Der Spiegel said in its issue Monday that the report concluded six Iraqi poison gas factories were delivered by German companies. Brand said one suspect, Peter Leifert, a partner in the Hamburg-based Water Engineering Trading Co., has admitted delivering chemical equipment that can be used for military purposes by Iraq. Spiegel said Leifert also worked for German intelligence for about two years. In a series of articles since August, Spiegel has named nearly 40 German companies it said had played a major role in supplying Iraq with equipment needed to produce chemical, biological, nuclear and conventional weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Challenge to San Francisco Affirmative Action Plan
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact an affirmative action plan for the San Francisco Fire Department. The court, without comment, rejected a union's challenge that said the plan violates the rights of white men. The 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last December upheld the city's agreement to hire and promote women and minorities to overcome past discrimination. The appeals court said the plan is ``fundamentally fair, adequate and reasonable'' and narrowly tailored to avoid hurting white men unnecessarily. In upholding a federal judge's approval of the agreement, the appeals court noted that the fire department first hired blacks in 1955 and women in 1987. The city's hiring and promotion tests for firefighters repeatedly were judged discriminatory from 1970 to 1987. The consent decree the city signed to implement affirmative action ended 18 years of lawsuits by women and minority groups. The Reagan administration challenged the city's affirmative action efforts in 1984 and was joined by Firefighters Union Local 798. The Bush administration did not join the union's appeal to the Supreme Court to throw out the plan. In December 1987, U.S. District Judge Marilyn Hall Patel in San Francisco also ordered the fire department to crack down on racial harassment after a swastika was found in the office of two minority firefighters. Fire Chief Ed Phipps resigned shortly afterward. When the consent decree was approved, the department had 225 minority members and seven women on a force of 1,100. The plan set long-term goals of 40 percent minorities and 10 percent women in the department. The agreement called for filling 55 percent of all openings with minorities and 10 percent with women through 1994. The city also agreed to develop unbiased examinations for hiring and promotion, and to promote 33 minority firefighters to the rank of lieutenant. In the appeal acted on today, lawyers for the firefighters union said hiring and promotion goals were based improperly on the population of the city and county of San Francisco. The union said the affirmative action plan should be based on the composition of the work force in a larger area of Northern California. The union also alleged that minorities who lack minimum qualifications will be promoted, and contended that the plan unlawfully seeks to impose racial balance in the department. The case is San Francisco Firefighters Local 798 vs. City and County of San Francisco, 90-248.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
WASHN: in services.
DOC.TEXT:
Bush and members of Congress went about their work as federal workers breathed a collective sigh of relief that there would be no forced furloughs. The government had faced the prospect of a shutdown of non-essential services today without an agreement. The budget crisis worsened late last week when the House rejected a bipartisan plan that called for $134 billion in tax increases and a wide array of military and program spending cuts. Increases in Medicare fees were rolled back slightly and an alternative plan has been approved. Democrats have complained the budget plans have been unfairly weighted against the middle income taxpayers to the benfit of wealthier Americans. Bush's remarks indicated that the final tax package is still in negotiation. Raising income tax rates would be contrary to Bush's oft-stated pledge during the 1988 presidential campaign not to raise taxes. There were minimal disruptions in services during the long Columbus Day weekend. Tourist attractions such as the Washington Monument and Smithsonian Institutioin were shut for three days, but the full brunt of a shutdown did not occur.
MORE

DOC.HEAD: Dispute Over Natural Gas Costs Rejected
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today turned away a multibillion dollar dispute over natural gas costs. The court, without comment, refused to reinstate a federal regulation to ease a burden on pipeline companies. The regulation dated to an over supply of gas in the early 1980s. The pipeline companies often signed contracts in the late 1970s and early '80s that required them to buy quantities of gas from producers at a specified price. The pipelines were required to pay for the gas even if they couldn't sell it. The so-called take-or-pay agreements were signed when the price of gas was higher than it is today. Natural gas supplies began to exceed demand by 1982 because of warm winters, a recession and customers' switching to alternate fuels. As a result, the pipeline companies were left with billions of dollars in costs for unwanted gas. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission adopted a plan in 1987 to help the pipelines cope, allowing the companies to charge customers part of the cost. The surcharge is based on a comparison of the amount of gas customers bought in 1982 and the reduced amounts they purchased from 1983 to 1986. The more they bought in 1982 and the less purchased from them in the ensuing years, the greater the pipeline companies' share of the take-or-pay burden. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here threw out the plan in December, saying the charges to pipeline customers amounted to a retroactive change in rates without advance warning. ``Indeed, the commission now even forces past customers who no longer purchase any gas from (the pipelines) to pay their share of the take-or-pay liability,'' the appeals court said. Conversely, the appeals court said, current customers who didn't buy gas from a pipeline until after 1986 would not have to pay any part of the liability. The appeals court, which reviewed the problem in a case involving Tennessee Gas Pipeline Co., sent the case back to the commission for another solution. Gas customers in Mississippi, Louisiana, Tennessee, Kentucky and Ohio who could face higher gas rates because of the appeals court ruling joined the Bush administration and Tennessee Pipeline in urging the Supreme Court to step in. Other gas customers urged the high court not to disturb the appeals court ruling, saying FERC exceeded its authority in ordering them to shoulder costs retroactively. The cases are The Berkshire Gas Co. vs. Associated Gas Distributors, 89-1988; Tennessee Small General Service Customer Group vs. AGD, 89-1989; Tennessee Gas Pipeline Co. vs. AGD, 89-1990; National Fuel Gas Supply Corp. vs. AGD, 89-2000; Federal Energy Regulatory Commission vs. AGD, 89-2016

DOC.HEAD: Court Rejects Appeal by Parents of Emotionally Disturbed Boy
DOC.TEXT: The parents of an emotionally disturbed Texas boy allegedly beaten by his school principal lost a Supreme Court appeal today. The court, over one dissenting vote, let stand a ruling that the child's constitutional rights were not violated. Only Justice Byron R. White voted to hear arguments in the case. Four votes are needed to grant such review. Tracy Fee was 12 and attending a class for emotionally troubled youngsters at a Dickinson, Texas, school when the incident occurred in 1985. His parents, Ronald and Nancy Fee, said school principal Joseph Herndon brutally beat the boy when he refused to submit to being paddled three times for misbehaving in class. The Fees said Herndon punched Tracy on the jaw and held him down on the floor and hit him numerous times on the buttocks with a paddle. They also accused Herndon of grabbing Tracy by the neck and throwing him back into a chair so that the child's head snapped back and hit the wall. Herndon and a teacher who was present said the principal paddled the boy three times on the buttocks but did no more. School officials said any injuries Tracy suffered were caused by his thrashing about on the floor of the principal's office as he sought to avoid the paddling. The school officials also noted Mrs. Fee previously had authorized Herndon to administer three paddle swats to Tracy if he misbehaved. The Fees said their son was hospitalized for six months in a psychiatric ward because of the beating, and said they spent $90,000 for medical care. They said he has not fully recovered. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in May that the Fees are not entitled to sue in federal court alleging their son's constitutional due-process rights were violated. It noted Texas law forbids use of excessive force against school children. ``We find no constitutional warrant to usurp classroom discipline where states, like Texas, have taken affirmative steps to protect their students from overzealous disciplinarians,'' the appeals court said. The case is Fee vs. Herndon, 90-249.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: all this.''
DOC.TEXT: ``Israeli security forces need to be better prepared for such situations, need to act with greater restraint,'' Bush said. ``Now, what is needed most of all is calm on both sides. We want to see the longstanding policy of open access to holy places preserved.'' Bush renewed an earlier warning that Saddam Hussein should not attempt to justify his ``illegal invasion of Kuwait by trying to tie it in to the Palestine question.'' Saddam's efforts to do this are ``not working,'' Bush said. ``The Arab world is united, almost united, against him,'' the president said. ``If he tries to use this unfortunate incident to link the two issues, I do not think it will be successful.'' MORE

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Astronauts to Pack And Test Systems on Final Full Day in Orbit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with robot arm retracted, Columbia moving off launch pad, picking up 10th graf previous, ``Both Columbia.''
DOC.TEXT: Discovery's astronauts awoke early today to begin their final full day of a nearly flawless mission in which they dispatched the Ulysses probe on a five-year journey to explore the sun. The flight, NASA's first shuttle mission in nearly six months, is scheduled to end Wednesday morning at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. Good weather is expected for the landing. Commander Richard N. Richards and pilot Robert Cabana completed a series of tests this morning to make sure Discovery's systems were ready for the fiery dive through the atmosphere and touchdown at the desert base. A problem was reported when a heater on one of the shuttle's three auxiliary power units failed, but a backup heater was put into operation and was working fine, Mission Control said. The auxiliary power units are used during landing, while the heaters operate during the mission to keep the fuel lines from freezing. Even if both heaters failed on a unit, they could be manually operated, Mission Control said. Later today, Richards and Cabana planned to briefly fire twin braking rockets, which will be used Wednesday to drop the shuttle out of orbit for the trip back to Earth. Also, the crew of five was scheduled to stow cabin gear. The men retracted the shuttle's robot arm back into the cargo bay this morning. The arm was extended Sunday for an experiment. Astronauts Bruce Melnick and Bill Shepherd ran one final test of an experimental system that uses voice commands to control the shuttle cameras. Shepherd has had trouble getting it to recognize his voice, but he finally met with success today after retraining the system. At Kennedy Space Center in Florida, NASA began moving the shuttle Columbia off a launch pad and back to the assembly building today because of bad weather expected from Tropical Storm Klaus. Both Columbia and Atlantis will remain in the assembly building until the storm passes, NASA officials said. Mission Control awakened the crew shortly before 2 a.m. EDT today with the songs, ``Fanfare for the Common Man,'' a favorite of Cabana's, and the fight song for the University of Missouri, Richards' alma mater. After the brief serenade, the crew quietly went about their morning tasks aboard the shuttle. Their primary goal was accomplished Saturday with the successful deployment of the Ulysses sun probe. The $250 million European probe continued to speed through space on its roundabout trip to the sun. It is headed towards Jupiter so it can use that giant planet's gravity to sling it back through the solar system and into a polar orbit around the sun. Ulysses is expected to pass over the sun's south pole in 1994 and the north pole in 1995. Before the crew went to bed Monday, Mission Control's Kathy Thornton told them Ulysses still was doing ``great - no changes.'' The smooth flight has delighted NASA officials, who have been plagued by a number of problems in recent months. Flight director Ron Dittemore described the mission Monday as one of the ``cleanest'' shuttle flights ever. ``The greatest pleasure comes when you work a flight and everything goes perfectly nominal,'' Dittemore said. ``Hopefully, we're getting better every time we go.'' The astronauts spent much of Monday working on experiments, but they took time out to sing ``Happy Birthday'' to mission specialist Tom Akers' wife, Kaye, who turned 34. They floated in front of a shuttle TV camera as they sang. Mrs. Akers and other crew members' relatives saw the tape Monday afternoon at Mission Control. After viewing the tape and another one showing the astronauts eating dinner and relaxing at the end of their work day, the families sent up this message: ``You guys are really getting good at throwing unusual birthday parties. How in the world are you going to top this one next year?''

DOC.HEAD: Dance Troupe Threatened by Defections, Alleged Abduction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Chhieng cq.
DOC.TEXT: A Cambodian dance troupe may cancel peformances in New York after four of its members defected and a fifth received death threats, said the troupe's director. The tour's sponsors say the defections and alleged threats are the result of Cambodian-Americans trying to undermine the troupe for political reasons. The director of the Cambodian Classical Dance Company, Proeung Chhieng, 42, pleaded for help Monday. ``We beg you to help us,'' Chhieng told reporters through an interpreter at the Joyce Theater, where the dancers were scheduled to perform tonight. ``We don't want our art and culture to get lost,'' he said. Three of the company's 36 dancers defected last week in St. Paul, Minn. A fourth defected Sunday in Lowell, Mass., by walking into a police station and requesting political asylum. The troupe is part of the government-controlled University of Fine Arts in Phnom Penh. The tour's chief sponsor in this country is the U.S. Indochina Reconciliation Project. Project director John McAuliff said Monday the private, non-profit group works with the people of Laos, Vietnam and Cambodia. He said certain Cambodian-Americans have formed an ``aggressive, organized'' network that has used threats, coercion and propaganda to influence the dancers and the media. ``What has clearly happened is some of the political groups that are against the government in Phnom Penh have done the one thing they can do: pressure the dancers to defect,'' he said. ``It's been clear that they have been trying very hard to undermine the tour.'' One of the troupe's star dancers, Yim Devi, was the target of an attempted abduction at knifepoint Monday by a Cambodian man who has followed her around the country since the company performed in Los Angeles, according to Eileen Blumenthal, the company's executive producer. A decision has not yet been made about whether the dancers will perform in New York, Blumenthal said. The company manager said Devi was ``frightened and confused'' because of the threats against her. The troupe's tour marks the first artistic exchange between the United States and Cambodia since the Vietnam War. Chhieng, who had been a child star in the Cambodian Ballet, survived the terror of the Khmer Rouge, which massacred about 3 million people, including Chhieng's parents, 12 of his brothers and sisters and most of his relatives. The 1000-year-old Cambodian dance is characterized by precise, angular body movements and fluidity. Dancers must be sewn into their costumes, a process that takes three hours.

DOC.HEAD: Lennon's `Imagine' Broadcast Worldwide on 50th Birthday
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Ono quotes, U.N. observance, Hollywood observance, picking up at the 4th graf previous, ``Beatles fans.''
DOC.TEXT: The 50th anniversary of John Lennon's birth was observed with a global celebration today as his peace anthem ``Imagine'' was played for an estimated 1 billion people in 130 nations. The song was played shortly after 10 a.m. following a brief ceremony at the United Nations that featured the ex-Beatle's widow, Yoko Ono. Marcela Perez de Cuellar, wife of the U.N. secretary general, also provided a brief introduction. A recorded message from the slain Beatle was played as well. ``In celebration of John's life, let's use our power of dreaming,'' Ono said. ``Let's dream of trees growing in abundance, birds flying in clear air, fish swimming in clear water and our children living in joy. ``Let's dream of men and women feeling good together and people embracing each other regardless of their creed and religion,'' she said. ``Let's dream of all races praising one another in the knowledge that the differences are what makes the human race.'' The U.N. Trusteeship Council Chamber was about one-third full with a couple of hundred people for the observance and about 150 people watched on television monitors in the visitors' lobby. A group of 10 teen-agers in blue jeans and T-shirts sat on the floor, held hands and meditated. More than 1,000 radio stations and networks from 50 countries had signed on for the satellite broadcast by last week. U.S. Armed Forces television and radio beamed the event to 80-plus countries. MTV was to broadcast the program in 25 countries, said network spokeswoman Andrea Smith. More than 50 fans gathered at the late Beatle's sidewalk star on the Hollywood Walk of Fame in Los Angeles to honor the singer-songwriter. Some held candles and others carried birthday balloons. Beatles fans gathered in Liverpool today to pay tribute to Lennon. Civic dignitaries planned to join them at the city's Cavern Walks shopping precinct - on the ite of the legendary Cavern Club where the group was discovered. In New York, fans planned a tearful pilgrimage to the spot outside the Dakota apartment building where Lennon was gunned down almost 10 years ago. ``Lennon always symbolized for us somebody who was able to handle rock and roll with a sense of humor and later, even more importantly, as someone who cared for the rights of an individual, human rights in general, and who had the right concept of freedom and peace,'' said Ondrej Konrad, the editor of Czechoslovakia's leading popular music publication. Jeff Pollack, head of the California-based Pollack Media Group, proposed the idea to Ono, who gave it the go-ahead. She believes recent events around the world - in Germany, Eastern Europe and particularly the Middle East - show the importance of Lennon's peace message. ``When this was discussed, we had no knowledge of what would happen in Iraq and Kuwait, you know. And now it seems very appropriate that this be sung all over the world,'' Ono said. ``I don't know, the timing is incredible. It's beyond me ... It's beautiful.'' ``Imagine'' is Lennon's musical vision of a world free of war and poverty. Lennon was born Oct. 9, 1940 and helped lead the Beatles to international stardom, along with co-members Paul McCartney, George Harrison and Ringo Starr. He fatally gunned down by an obsessed fan outside his Manhattan apartment building in December 1980. The tribute coincides with the release of a four-compact disc set of 73 songs, including 61 written by Lennon. Also in honor of Lennon's 50th birthday, McCartney is releasing his live version of ``Birthday.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Will Hear Case on Excluding Hispanics from Juries
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether the rights of a Hispanic man were violated when he was convicted of attempted murder by a jury from which Hispanics had been excluded. The justices said they would use the New York City case to decide whether Hispanics may be excluded from juries because they might not accept official translations of testimony given in Spanish. The court will hear an appeal by Dionisio Hernandez, convicted in 1986 of trying to kill his girlfriend and her mother in a shooting outside a Brooklyn restaurant. Two restaurant patrons also were wounded. The prosecutor in the case used what are known as peremptory - or automatic - challenges to bar Hispanics, saying there was uncertainty whether they could ``accept the interpreter as the final arbiter'' of what was said by each witness. The New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, said Hernandez was not the victim of unlawful racial bias because the prosecutor made his decision on a non-discriminatory basis. It based its ruling on a 1986 Supreme Court decision that said prosecutors may not exclude blacks from juries unless the prosecutors can prove they acted for reasons that are racially neutral. The case acted on today is Hernandez vs. New York, 89-7645.

DOC.HEAD: Goooood Maaaaawrning Saudi Arabia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS New Castle to two words in 7th graf ``Besides Yank...'' Subs 11th, ``They named...'' to specify that schmoozing is slang of Yiddish origin.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: There was a little bit of Adrian Kronauer in the Navy chief petty officer who started the first live armed forces broadcasts in Saudi Arabia today. ``It's 9:05 a.m. Tuesday, Oct. 9. Goooood Maaaaawrning Saudi Arabia,'' bellowed disk jockey Rich Yanku, echoing the famous character played by comedian Robin Williams in the movie about Armed Forces Radio in Vietnam. ``We really didn't want to do a Goooood Maaaawrning Saudi Arabia, but it probably would be anti-climactic if we didn't,'' said Navy Lt. Arnie Pon, a Bronx native who heads the unit making the live broadcasts from an air base in Saudi Arabia. The first song on Desert Shield Network FM 107 brought the troops a little closer to home - The Clash's ``Rock The Casbah'' about a fight over ``boogie sound'' in a traditional Middle Eastern city. Lt. Col. David MacNamee, commanding officer of Armed Forces Radio and Television in Saudi Arabia, said the kingdom's government put some restrictions on broadcast content. Television broadcasts are under negotiation. He would not detail the restrictions. But he said they were basically common sense guidelines about what might offend listeners in a traditional Moslem society that bars alcohol and the mixing of men and women in public. Besides Yanku of Albany, N.Y., the disc jockeys include two air force staff sergeants - Harry Lockley, 25, of New Castle, Pa., and John Haynes, 27, of Albany, N.Y. The fourth is Army Spec. Brooke Perkins, 35, who was previously based in West Germany. The general format is mostly rock 'n' roll or country music from their 8,800 compact discs interspersed with news, sports and public service messages. They range from pep talks on Saudi Arabian customs to the dangers of snake bites in the desert. The newscast carried at the top of the hour is the AP Network News. The radio is on the air 24 hours a day, with a feed from the broadcast center in Sun Valley, Calif., when the team in Saudi Arabia is not working. They named their two trailers Camp Schmooz because Pon was always accusing them of ``schmoozing,'' Yiddish slang for standing around gossiping. The armed forces has 12 transmitters set up in Saudi Arabia. Three have a reach of over 30 miles, but the rest just reach three or four miles. About 80 percent of the estimated 200,000 troops deployed in Saudi Arabia should be able to hear it if they have radios. More transmitters are due in, along with 30,000 radios for the troops. Several thousand radios have been distributed so far. The radio takes requests from the troops. The first request from a soldier came from a woman named Kim, dedicating Bruce Springsteen's ``Born in the U.S.A.'' to her fellow troops.

DOC.HEAD: Postal Service Gives Advice on German Addresses
DOC.TEXT: People sending mail to the newly united Germany need to use care to avoid confusion in the addresses, the U.S. Postal Service reports. The problem arises because similar systems of postal codes were used in the former East and West Germanys. Until a new system can be developed, the codes for locations formerly in West Germany should be preceded by the letter W (for west), and for those formerly in East Germany by the letter O. Ost is the German word for east. For example, addresses might include the line ``W-5300 Bonn'' or ``O-7010 Leipzig.'' In either case, the country name to use is Federal Republic of Germany.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: first-class job.
DOC.TEXT: So, I think tha need a little time to calm things down, cool things off, and let's try to go forward. I think it's my responst - but also youibility to say, ``Look, it's not easy. All of us have had to compromise. Now let's move the country forward to what really everybody wants, and that is getting these deficits under control.'' Yeah? Q: Mr. President, getting back to the lack of support from Republicans, tomorrow you're going to be campaigning in North Carolina for Senator Jesse Helms, who was one of your opponents on the budget. What is your message to the voters? Vote blindly Republican or vote for legislators who support your policies? A: If we had more people on fiscal policy like Jesse Helms, and by that I mean control of the Senate, we wouldn't be in this mess. People would have been doing it more the way I want it done. So I can't confiport. But I guess I learned that I can't do it exactly my way when we get down on something like the deficit. I do think internationally the support is still very, very strong. So when you get into somebody's pocketbook or you get worrying about a tax or a spending cut that affects someone, I've learned that it's just not going to be done the way I want it, especially if you don't control the Senate or you don't control the House. So I can't worry too much about it. I just have to try to get this process moved forward, and that's what we've done. I've had to compromise, but I think it will come it out all right. Yeah? Q: If I might, I wonder if you think, though, that you're paying the price now in asking the American people to sacrifice, and having them rebuff it the way it happened - paying the price for all these years in the Reagan-Bush administration that you sold supply-side economics? A: No, I don't think so. I think that when you see Democratic votes against the leadership, we're talking about something a little shorter-term here. I think you're looking at something that, when people have analyzed a package, and don't like parts of it, because they're still saying, ``Hey, we like -- we want you to vote for the overall package.'' So the problem comes from some specific part of the package. That's the way I analyze it. Yeah, John?
