DOC.HEAD: Students Take Dream Field Trip
DOC.TEXT: Pupils from the Three Kings Primary School may have a hard time topping their latest field trip. The 23 children, accompanied by their parents and teachers, took a 3,000-mile round trip Monday to the South Pacific island of Niue. The trip was a gift after Niue Airlines discovered it had 40 vacant seats on the flight to the tiny island. The airline offered to take a group from the school, provided they had passports. After a four-hour flight from Auckland, the children were greeted with garlands of flowers, appeared on Niue television, had a swim and were seen off after a whirlwind 1{-hour trip by Premier Sir Robert Rex.

DOC.HEAD: Forecasts Halted By Strike At National Weather Service
DOC.TEXT: France went without official weather forecasts Tuesday as hundreds of employees at the national weather service joined a strike. Three unions launched the strike Monday night to demand better compensation for 200 to 300 employees, who face a transfer from Paris to the southern city of Toulouse in September 1991. The strike was scheduled to end Wednesday morning, after 36 hours. It involved an estimated 400 employees of the information, forecasting and research sections of the agency's technical operations center in Paris.

DOC.HEAD: Bar, Electrician Cut Each Other Off
DOC.TEXT: A hotel bar cut off service to a tipsy, off-duty electrician, and he returned the favor - stumbling outside and cutting off the bar's power. Barkeepers at the Skogstad Hotel in Hemsedal refused to serve a local power company employee because he was already drunk, the Oslo newspaper Verdens Gang reported Tuesday. The electrician, not named in the report, went to the nearest power company switch box, traced the hotel's circuit and plunged the building into darkness Saturday evening. The blackout was described only as ``lengthy.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Legislation Keeping Government Open
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 10-11, bgng, Senate Majority... to UPDATE with Mitchell reaction; CORRECTS 20th graf pvs, Capital gains... to eliminate extraneous words at end of sentence
DOC.TEXT: President Bush signed emergency legislation today restoring business as usual for the federal government, and said he was willing to raise income tax rates on wealthy Americans if a final budget included his long-sought cut in the capital gains tax. Bush said he would do ``everything in my power'' to see that Congress follows up in the next few days with a five-year plan to cut the deficit by $500 billion. Federal workers breathed a collective sigh of relief that there would be no forced furloughs. The government, closed over the holiday weekend due to the budget impasse, had faced the prospect of a shutdown of non-essential services today without an agreement. The president met with reporters as lawmakers, exhausted after a string of late-night sessions, were returning to the work of deciding precisely which spending programs to cut and whose taxes to raise. Under Monday's late-night agreement between the White House and Congress, that work must be completed by Oct. 19 - or the government faces the risk of yet another shutdown in services. The budget crisis erupted last week when the House rejected a bipartisan plan that called for $134 billion in tax increases and a wide array of military and program spending cuts. Increases in Medicare fees were rolled back slightly and an alternative plan has been approved, although it contains fewer specifics than the one that was rejected. Democrats have complained the budget plans have been unfairly weighted against the middle income taxpayers to the benfit of wealthier Americans, and Bush's remarks indicated that the final tax package is still in negotiation. One subject: the ``bubble'' by which some taxpayers pay a 33 percent rate rather than the 28 percent rate applied to the wealthiest taxpayers. Asked about the possibility of raising tax rates on the wealthy, Bush said: ``That's on the table. That's been talked about. And if it's proper, if it can be worked in proper balance between the capital gains rate and income tax changes, fine.'' It was the first time Bush has state explicitly he could go along with a hike in income tax rates. His opposition to changing the rate structure had been the last remnant of another campaign pledge: ``no new taxes'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said he was heartened by Bush's statement. ``I have personally advocated (an increased tax rate) on those making more than $200,000 a year for some time,'' he said. ``And I'm pleased that the president has now come around, or apparently come around, to our point of view and to recognize the fairness o fsuch a change.'' ``The action is in the Congress, but we'll work with them'' on filling in the gaping blanks in the deficit-cutting agreement, Bush said ``I will do everything in my power to encourage Congress as it struggles to bring forth the most comprehensive and signficiant deficit cutting plan ever.'' The president took pains to defend his top aides for their help in the budget confrontation with Congress. White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and Budget Director Richard Darman have come in for criticism from Republicans and Democrats, who accuse them of high-handed tactics. ``When passions get high, there's bound to be a little broken china,'' Bush said. ``They did an outstanding job,'' he said of his negotiators, dismissing critical comments from ``squeaky wheels'' on Capitol Hill. Bush signed the emergency spending legislation shortly after 7 a.m. The House gave final congressional approval to the emergency funding legislation on a 362-3 vote at 1:45 a.m. The Senate passed it on a voice vote. The long-term deficit reduction plan was passed Monday 250-164 by the House and ratified by the Senate early this morning on 66-33 vote. Senate Budget Committee Chairman Jim Sasser, D-Tenn., said today that ``our task now is to enforce the budget resolution that was passed.'' ``It's going to be tough, and it's going to be hard to vote for,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``Next week will be very intense,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. By his comments on taxes, Bush signalled a willingness to compromise on one of the most fiercely fought issues in the budget confrontation. The president has been seeking a cut in the capital gains tax since before his election in 1988. Democrats in Congress have blocked his effort last year, and have said that any cut must be accompanied by an increase in tax rates on the wealthy. Capital gains come from money made from the sale of stocks, real estate, and other assets. Democrats, meantime, targeted for elimination a quirk in the federal tax system where the marginal tax rate goes as high as 33 percent for upper-middle-income but then drops back to 28 percent at hiher incomes. The pattern has become known as the ``bubble.'' With Congress and the White House looking for ways to raise revenue to reduce the federal deficit, talk of trading the ``bubble'' for capital gains has increased. Bush said he would be willing to negotiate the bubble ``at some level, sure.'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said Monday he expected such a proposal to be made as Congress considers legislation enacting its five year, $500 billion deficit reduction plan. Even if both sides agree a trade can be made, there could be tough battles over just how much to cut the capital gains rate and raise the income tax rate. Bush's decision to sign the emergency spending bill marked a pause in several days of confrontation with Congress. The House on Friday rejected a compromise package Bush had pitched on television. Legislators in both parties objected to proposals such as a 12-cent increase in gasoline taxes and higher Medicare deductibles and fees. The president then vetoed an attempt by Congress to keep the government open while the plan was revised. As a result, sites such as the Washington Monument, the Statue of Liberty, Yosemite and other weekend government services were stopped. The long-term budget plan is a broad outline of taxes and spending restraints that are similar in scope - but without the detail - of the budget pact between Bush and congressional leaders the House killed last week. But the outline is a document that is supposed to provide the shape of legislation to follow imposing specific taxes and spending restraints. That includes things items as alcohol taxes, increased Medicare premiums and cuts in farm subsidies that are seen as needed to produce the mandated savings, including $40 billion in the current fiscal year. The emergency spending bill also included a temporary increase in the national debt, to $3.195 trillion, needed to prevent a default by the Treasury. The three House members voting against the legislation today were: William Dannemeyer, R-Calif.; Philip Crane, R-Ill.; and Pat Williams, D-Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Jolts Iranian City
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook the southeastern Iranian city of Kerman early Tuesday, official Tehran Radio reported. The quake, which measured 4.9 on the Richter scale, caused no loss of life or serious damage, said the broadcast, monitored in Nicosia. It struck at 3:49 a.m. (8:19 p.m. EDT), the broadcast said. An earthquake of such intenisity can cause considerable damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Folksy Actor-Turned-Legislator in Fight for Political Life
DOC.TEXT: When Ben Jones left his acting career for politics two years ago, he quickly became a darling of the Democrats in Congress. Now the folksy House freshman, who played Cooter on TV's ``Dukes of Hazzard,'' is in a fight for his political life. The Georgia Democrat is up against veteran state Rep. John Linder in a race the national GOP has placed on its top 10 ``hit list.'' Linder, a wealthy businessman, portrays his campaign as a fight against a liberal ``just a little left of Michael Dukakis.'' Jones casts himself as a mainstream congressman who votes his conscience. He supports abortion rights, environmental issues and gun control legislation. His celebrity status makes him a popular attraction at the fund-raisers of fellow Democrats and he has won praise for speaking out on tough issues. For example, he was a vocal opponent of a proposed ban on flag burning. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., calls Jones ``probably the most highly regarded'' freshman House member. Jones ``takes the positions he thinks are right,'' Foley said at a fund-raiser in August. ``He doesn't go out and take a poll first. If it feels right to him ... he takes that position come hell or high water.'' This year's campaign is a far cry from 1988, when Jones ousted Republican Rep. Pat Swindall in what was one of the dirtiest campaigns in the nation. Swindall, who was indicted for perjury 22 days before the election, characterized Jones as an alcoholic wife-beater. Jones admitted to ``wild'' behavior and a misdemeanor assault conviction for shoving his wife in a bar, but said his drinking problems were behind him. In this year's contest, the two candidates have clashed mainly on patriotism. Jones led the controversial effort last summer to defeat an constitutional amendment that would prohibit flag burning, saying it would be overreacting to a ``handful of malcontents.'' Linder went on the offensive, announcing he supported the amendment and criticizing Jones' call for display of American flags in support of U.S. troops in the Middle East as hypocritical. Jones retaliated by saying that Linder didn't support veterans in the Legislature and skippe meetings of the Defense and Veterans Affairs committees. Linder emphasizes the two years he served in the Air Force as a dentist and notes his brother is serving in Saudi Arabia. And he says the media made more out of the flag-burning issue that he did. ``The one thing voters hate worse than a flag burner is someone who wraps themselves in the flag,'' Linder said. ``Do I question his patriotism? That's a bunch of bull. But it does come up when I address veterans' groups. ``It's just one of a series of issues we think definitely place him a little to the left of Michael Dukakis,'' said Linder. Linder also is focusing on the tax issue, blaming Democrats for stalling the budget while pushing the country to the brink of sweeping Gramm-Rudman cuts. He says the way to solve the budget crisis is to cut spending on such programs such as farm subsidies, the National Endowment for the Arts and large staffs and franking for congressmen. ``I've been a businessman for a long time. When businesses get into trouble with declining revenues, they cut overhead. They lay off people, give others early retirement,'' Linder said. ``They don't go to their neighbors and say give us more money.'' Both candidates support a reduction in the capital gains tax. Linder has been busy canvassing neighborhoods in the district's east Atlanta suburbs. The district is one of the most highly educated and culturally sophisticated in the South, but it has no clear political party preference. Jones has been in the district as often as four days a week since his election. He impresses constituents by taking notes while they talk to him. ``I married into a police family and I heard a lot about old-time policing, where the community knows you and you know them,'' Jones told a group of law enforcement officers. ``I try to take that kind of old-fashioned attitude with me wherever I go, even in the halls of Congress. If you know somebody, you can talk to them.''

DOC.HEAD: Ebony Magazine Managing Editor Charles L. Sanders
DOC.TEXT: Charles L. Sanders, managing editor of Ebony Magazine, has died. He was 58. Sanders died Thursday at Michael Reese Hospital in Chicago after a long illness. Sanders began his journalism career at the Cleveland Call & Post as a reporter and feature writer, then later as general editor of the newspaper's state editions. In 1963, Sanders joined Ebony as an associate editor. He covered the award of the Nobel Peace Prize to the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. in Sweden in 1964 and opened the magazine's first overseas bureau in Paris in 1965. For three years in Paris, Sanders also wrote a column, ``Paris Scratchpad,'' for Ebony's sister magazine, Jet. He returned to Ebony as managing editor. Sanders also served with comedian Bill Cosby as co-chairman of the NAACP's Entertainment Committee for Life Members. He also was a board member of the Gospel Music Workshop of America. Survivors include two sisters and a brother. Services were scheduled for Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: Yeah, John?
DOC.TEXT: Q: So you say you've learned that you just can't have things the way you want it on the budget. But earlier this year, you raised the stakes when you said the budget crisis would be the biggest test domestically of your presidency. So far, have you failed the test, given that fiasco of the ... A: Give me a couple weeks here. I want to see if we can't get this deal through. Q: Well, do you think ... A: I thought we did pretty well when we got an agreement with the Republican leadership and the House leadership, Democrat and Republican. To me, that's getting something done. Now we couldn't get it through the Congress yet, so we'll try again. So I think the jury's still out on that, John. Q: Do you suddenly feel politically a bit more vulnerable now? The Democrats smell blood. They're looking to '92 now. George Bush has slipped. What do you think? A: Well, without referring to the polls, that I don't like to refer to, have them take a look. Yeah, Ann? Q: Considering the movement to limit terms in Congress that has been spreading around the country, would you support it either because of your current problems with Congress or because of the philosophy of term limitations? A: No, that was in the Republican platform. So I may go, go public on that. I'm certainly not opposed to it. And so it was, I haven't decided exactly. But I think there's, people want a change against the incumbents up there on the Hill. And I think that, you saw what happened in Oklahoma. I don't know what's going to happen. There's two of those state - what do they call them? - on the ballot in - yeah, referendums - on the ballot in California. Both of them are different, slightly, in terms of how they are put into effect. But I expect they have a good chance. And as I say, we are committed on our platform to some limitation. But whether I make that a, a prime mover in the political campaign that lies ahead in the next few weeks, I don't know. But I will remind people that's in there. Q Mr. President? A: Yes. Q: Can we clarify something that we talked about earlier. Many of the lawmakers say that the repudiation of the budget packet reflects the fact that people feel that economic policy in this country over the last 10 years was fundamentally unfair, that it redistributed income too much to the wealthy and too little to the poor. Do you think that that is part of the reason that yor package was rejected? A: It might have been part of the reason, but I don't think the entire reason, because I don't think that's why Republicans rejected it at all. Q: Could you also clarify your statement on the bubble? You said that ``it was talked about.'' Is that one of your positions, that you would support ... A: At some level. Q: ... the top rate ... A: Sure, at some level. Q: What rate would you ... A: Well, as I've told you, I'm not going to try to negotiate it here. I want to get something done in these committees. So what we've got to do is get with the Senate leaders, House leaders, on Finance and Ways and Means, and see if we can reach a formula. I don't think it would be helpful to draw a line in the sand on what percentage of the exclusion of capital gains, and then what on the - what we'd give in terms of the leveling out the bubble or getting rid of the bubble. Yes, Maureen, and then Charles and then Jim. Q: Mr. President, during the campaign, when you took the position that you absolutely, positively would not raise taxes under any circumstance. And then a lot of your fellow Republicans, as you know, were encouraged to follow suit by taking this anti-tax pledge, do you think that that now is part of the reason ... A: Yes. Q: ... that you're having so much trouble? A: I think that makes it more difficult for people. Q: Do you regret that you took that position? A: No, because what I do is take a look at, at the situation at the time, see the changed economics, and say I've got to, got to, you know, go forward here. Q: Except that the deficit was very large then, also.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: then, also.
DOC.TEXT: A: Well, I know, but I thought we could get into effect the program that I ran on. I, we ran up against a lot of Democratic opposition, sent a budget up that didn't gain the support we wanted and have done that twice. So, but I think you raise a good point. I think, and some have told me that when I was talking to them. Yeah, Charles? Q: Mr. President, a question about the process, the budget now being back in the hands of the congressional committees where it was envisioned in the first place. Do you have second thoughts about all this summitry that led up to this situation? A: No, I don't because what we did is to get a deal that I think has support from the American people overall, and we've gotten out a lot of the underbrush. We've moved out a lot of the debate and moved it into a package that was supported by the president, by the Republican and, leader in the House and the Senate, and by the Democratic leaders in the House and the Senate. So I think it's, I think we've made some progress even though obviously it didn't get through either house. But now we're going to have to keep working this week. And some of the members who would like to do it exactly his or her way are going to see that it doesn't work quite that way. So I don't think it's been time wasted at all. Q: Well how badly does it undercut you politically in terms of some of the antagonism between your staff, your budget director, your chief of staff, people on the Hill, and within the Republican Party? A: I don't, I don't worry about that at all. I really don't. I have been campaigning for and will continue to campaign for people that might agree with me on this or might disagree with me on this. And we have broad principles that unite us. And when people get tired and stay up till three o'clock in the morning, every morning, why there's bound to be tensions. Calm them, calm it down and try to go forward. That's my approach to it. Jim? Q: Mr. President, yesterday Israeli forces used live ammunition to put down a demonstration in Israel, killing 19 Palestinians. Today, Saddam Hussein is using that incident in an attempt to rally Arab support against Israel and especially against the United States in the region. Do you think this incident could create a crack in the alliance against Iraq? And what's your reaction to the incident? A: Well, I don't think it could do that, but look, let me just express my strong feelings about this. First my sorrow at this tragedy. It is particularly saddening, given the sanctity of the holy places and observances there, that violence shattered all of this. And I want to echo what Jim Baker said earlier, that Israeli security forces need to be better prepared for such situations, need to act with greater restraint, particularly when it comes to the use of deadly force. And at this point what is needed most of all is calm on all sides. Let me - I do''t think I need to say this - but, let me just state that we want to see the longstanding policy of maintaining open access to the holy places preserved, tempered only by mutual respect for people of other faiths. And so I am very, very saddened by this needless loss of life, and I would call on all for restraint. The action will shift to the United Nations now. To your other part of the question, Jim, there's no relationship here. Saddam Hussein is trying to, from the very beginning, justify the illegal invasion of Kuwait by trying to tie it in to the Palestine question. And that is not working. The Arab world is united - almost united - against him. And I don't think if he tries now to use this unfortunate incident to link the two questions, I don't think that will be successful. And certainly, I will be doing what I can to see that it is not successful. Having said that, I hope nobody questions our interest in seeing a solution to the Palestine question, to the implementation of the Security Council resolutions. And that's what Jim Baker has been working so hard on for such a long time. But let's separate out this violence and say, we deplore it, and it must not happen. And regret it, the loss of life for everybody.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Public Schools Cannot Exclude Religious Groups
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout to ADD Souter swearing in, other court actions. This stands for Scotus Rdp
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today left intact a ruling that says public schools that allow civic groups and others to rent school space can't refuse such access to religious organizations. The justices, without comment, rejected the appeal of a Pennsylvania high school forced to rent weekend use of its auditorium to the Campus Crusade for Christ. The action was announced the day David H. Souter became history's 105th justice, but he did not participate in the case. Souter was sworn in a brief courtroom ceremony before all nine justices took the bench to issue orders in new cases and hear arguments in cases to be decided by July. In another case involving religion, the court rejected an appeal by a small fundamentalist church in Evanston, Ill., that blamed its trouble finding a permanent home on a local zoning ordinance. The court, without comment, refused to revive Love Church's challenge to the city ordinance. In a third case, the court turned down the appeal of a Seattle church that says King County should have to pay it for blocking the use of church-owned land. It left intact a Washington Supreme Court ruling that a lawsuit filed against the county by the Presbytery of Seattle was premature. In other cases, the court: -Let stand a ruling that the constitutional rights of an emotionally disturbed Texas boy allegedly beaten by his school principal were not violated. Ronald and Nancy Fee, said Joseph Herndon brutally beat their 12-year-old son when he refused to submit to being paddled three times for misbehaving in class. Herndon and a teacher who was present said the boy was paddled three times on the buttocks and that injuries he suffered were caused by his thrashing about on the floor as he sought to avoid the paddling. -Revived a $4 billion lawsuit by a millionaire inventor Arthur Jones, who says ABC-TV's ``20-20'' program falsely portrayed him as a liar and hypocrite. The justices told a federal appeals court to restudy the libel suit filed after a 1987 report on the fate of 63 baby elephants Jones rescued from death in Africa. Jones invented the Nautilus exercise machines. The justices said the case should be reconsidered in light of their June ruling that the Constitution's guarantee of free speech did not ``create a wholesale defamation exemption for anything that might be labeled opinion.'' -Agreed to decide in a Florida case whether police may conduct random drug searches aboard buses and trains after passengers have consented. Florida officials say the searches are necessary because the state is a pipeline for drugs. In the Pennsylvania case involving the use of public school facilities by religious group, the state court upheld the dismissal of the suit. It said the church failed to exhaust its administrative remedies because it never even applied for a building permit. In June, the high court upheld the federal Equal Access Act, in which Congress required that virtually all public high schools must allow student prayer groups to meet and worship if other student clubs are permitted at school. The court said then the law doesn't violate the constitutionally required separation of church and state. But the federal law applies only to student groups - not to outside organizations seeking sue of school facilities. The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals relied on the First Amendment when it ruled last summer that Centennial, Pa., school officials violated the free-speech rights of Student Venture, a subsidiary of the Campus Crusade for Christ. The officials refused to rent space for a William Tennent High School program aimed at religious conversion. By a 2-1 vote, the appeals court said the school district had created an ``open public forum'' by renting space to, among others, the local Rotary and Kiwanis clubs, an adult education program and two labor unions. The appeals court said religious groups could not be excluded from such an open forum because of their message. The school district's lawyers said schools nationwide let various community groups use school property when classes are in session, and that the appeals court ruling means such use has ``converted most American public school facilities into open public forums, to which even the most fractious religious and political speakers must be routinely allowed access.'' The three cases involving religion were: Centennial School District vs. Gregoire, 90-304; Love Church vs. Evanston, 90-296; and Presbytery of Seattle vs. King County, 90-298.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli On Trial Again for Meeting Arafat
DOC.TEXT: Peace activist Abie Nathan went on trial Tuesday on charges he met twice this year with PLO leader Yasser Arafat in violation of Israel's anti-terrorism law. Nathan was convicted last year for a 1988 meeting with Arafat and served four months of a six-month prison sentence before he was released for good behavior. Nathan acknowledged in Ramle's Magistrates Court Tuesday that he met the Palestine Liberation Organization leader twice in March in Tunisia. But he pleaded innocent, maintaining the law under which he was charged was unjust. Israel considers the PLO to be a terrorist organization, and a 1986 amendment to Israel's anti-terror law makes meetings with PLO leaers punishable by jail terms of up to three years. Court officials said Nathan faces up to seven years in jail - three for each alleged violation and an additional year that was ``suspended'' in the earlier case. Nathan told reporters after the session that he was ready to return to jail. ``I am prepared to give my whole life for peace,'' Nathan said. ``I will continue to fight against this unjust law because it is a law you cannot accept.'' Nathan, 64, first met Arafat in 1982 when he went to Lebanon during the Israeli siege of Beirut in an unsuccessful attempt to gain freedom for a captured Israeli soldier. He has met him eight times since. He is best known for making a dramatic trip in a private plane to Cairo in 1966 to try to convince Egypt to make peace with Israel. His pirate radio station, the Voice of Peace, operates from a ship in the Mediterranean Sea.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: for everybody.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Also, a follow, please. Saddam Hussein also indicated today that the Iraqis have a new sort of missile that can reach into Israel and reach the U.S. troops. And he's threatening to use that force. A: I noticed that and I notice he's getting a little more bellicose. Once in a while you see a conciliatory statement, and then you hear a lot of heightened rhetoric about what he is going to do and what he's not going to do. Now I'm satisfied that we can defend our interests now. And I am satisfied that, that these threats of his are counter-productive in terms of solving any peaceful resolution of the question. They don't help a thing, they just polarize. So, you don't want to overreact to it. I keep reading statements like this, ever since this illegal annexation, illegal aggression took place. There's no - not too good a pattern. We watch it very carefully, and it's pretty hard to detect a pattern. Now, there's a theme, and that is trying to link the Palestine question into his, kind of giving justification for what he did against Kuwait, and yet the logic falls totally flat. Yes, Frank? Q: Mr. President, on that subject, you said the action now shifts on this one to the United Nations. Having just been to the United Nations and talked about its increased relevance and role, how far are you prepared to go as far as the United States is concerned in meeting some of the Arab efforts to partially condemn Israel's action and pass a resolution that ... A: Well, I think it all depends what the resolution is, and so that's just starting up there now and we're not sure exactly what direction it all will take. So I'd want to stop short of saying exactly what I could, you know, what the U.S. government could support or what it couldn't support. Q If I may, sir, on a related topic, when the emir of Kuwait was here, you expressed grave concern about the dismantling of Kuwait. A: Yes, I did. Q: Your advisers said that that could affect the timetable for permitting sanctions to work. What is your feeling on that now? Is the dismantling ... A: I thought General Scowcroft put it very well after the emir left here. And I am very much concerned, not just about this physical dismantling, but of the brutality that has now been written on by Amnesty International confirming some of the tales told us by the emir. Of brutality and, oh, it's just unbelievable, some of the things at least he reflected. I mean, people on a dialysis machine cut off, the machine sent to Baghdad; people in babies in incubators heaved out of the incubators and the incubators themselves sent to Baghdad. Now, I don't know how many of these tales can be authenticated, but I do know that when the emir was here he was speaking from the heart. And after that came the Amnesty International, who were debriefing many of the people at the border. And it's sickening. And so I - if your question was how long, I can't give you an answer in days or months. But it is a matter that, it's a new equation in the last three weeks, the systematic dismantling of Kuwait that concerns us enormously. And I think the more people understand it, the more Saddam Hussein will be condemned. But I have to stop short of telling you what that, where that leads me to, in terms of recommending action by the allied forces there. Q: It does sound like your patience is wearing thin on the sanctions. A: It's wearing very thin on that account, yes. Q: Mr. President, a couple of minutes ago, you said that public opinion seemed to support your handling of foreign affairs better than domestic affairs. Why do you think that you're so much more comfortable with and better at foreign matters than domestic? To some people, it seems like almost two presidents. A: Well, I've read that sophisticated analysis, and I'm troubled, because I don't the, I don't really know the answer to it. Perhaps it has to do with the fact that in one, I think the Vandenburg theory applies. People really basically want to support the president on foreign affairs, and partisanship does, in a sense, stop at the water's edge. Whereas on domestic policy, here I am with Democratic majorities in the Senate and Democratic majorities in the House, having to try to persuade them to do what I think is best. And it's complicated.

DOC.HEAD: Robbers Ram Armored Car With Bulldozer, Kill Guard
DOC.TEXT: Robbers trapped an armored car between a stolen garbage truck and stolen bulldozer Tuesday and shot all three guards, killing one, but fled empty-handed, police said. It was the fourth fatal attack this year on security company guards transporting funds. Three men were killed in two separate attacks on armored cars, and two guards on foot were shot dead while delivering money to a bank. The latest attack occurred about in Lentilly, six miles northwest of Lyon. The armored car, owned by the Transval security company, encountered a garbage truck blocking a narrow street, police said. The car then was struck in the rear by a stolen bulldozer and smashed into the garbage truck, according to police. The robbers opened fire, fatally wounding Henri Marion, 57, and seriously injuring the two other guards, police said. But investigators said the robbers apparently were unable to open the safe in the vehicle, and decided to flee in a stolen car. In Paris, union leaders representing employees of security companies urged guards to launch a strike to demand a risk bonus and better safety arrangements.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Claims Iraq Has Developed a New Missile
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 25 grafs with more quotes from Saddam, comment from weapons analyst, editing to conform. Picks up 18th graf pvs ``He said details...
DOC.TEXT: President Saddam Hussein said today Iraq has developed a new missile with a range of several hundred miles. Such a weapon would allow Iraq to strike deep into Saudi Arabia where tens of thousands of American troops are deployed. The new missile is called the al-Hijara, or Stone, apparently named to honor young Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip who are confronting the Israelis with stones. The killings of 19 Palestinians by Israeli police at the Temple Mount in Jerusalem on Monday brings Israel ``closer to the abyss,'' Saddam said in a statement read by an announcer over state-run Baghdad Radio. Addressing Israel, he said: ``The faithful Palestinians faced up to you ... with stones which no power on earth can withhold from those who wish to use them.'' It was not possible to obtain independent verification of Saddam's claim to have developed a new missile. But Don Kerr, a weapons analyst at London's International Institute for Strategic Studies, said such a claim would not be extraordinary. ``Iraq has had considerable success with surface-to-surface missiles, mostly derivatives of the Soviet-made Scud,'' Kerr said by telephone. Iraq's al-Hussein missile has a range of 310-370 miles and the al-Abbas missile a range of 500-560 miles, Kerr said. Both carry conventional high-explosive warheads. Saddam, who has linked a withdrawal from occupied Kuwait with an Israeli pillout from Arab territory captured in 1967, appeared to seeking to exploit Monday's violence in Jerusalem to build support for his invasion of Kuwait. The Palestinians, along with many other Arabs in Jordan, Sudan, Yemen and Algeria, are among Saddam's staunchest supporters. Also today, rock 'n' roll music boomed out across the Saudi desert when U.S. armed forces radio began broadcasting live for the nearly 200,000 U.S. troops. ``It's 9:05 a.m. Tuesday, Oct. 9. Goooood Maaaaawrning Saudi Arabia,'' bellowed disk jockey Rich Yanku, echoing the famous character played by comedian Robin Williams in the movie about Armed Forces Radio in Vietnam. The Navy, meanwhile, searched for eight Marines whose two helicopters disappeared Monday over the North Arabian Sea during a training exercise. Rescue teams have located debris from one of the aircraft, but no bodies. Two American airmen who had volunteered for duty in the Persian Gulf crisis died in a jet crash Monday in Saudi Arabia. In other developments: -A study published this week said Iraq should be able to survive the U.N. trade embargo for at least another six months. The report, by The Economist, a financial magazine published in London, said that since the West is not likely to wait that long, a military strike against Iraq seemed inevitable. -A U.S. Embassy official in Baghdad said that a U.S.-chartered Iraqi jetliner on Wednesday will evacuate about 350 more Americans and an unknown number of other foreigners from Kuwait. -The killings at the Temple Mount set off a barrage of Arab warnings and threats. Some Israeli opponents said the incident, which occurred when police fired on stone-throwers at a holy site, demonstrated the link between the gulf crisis and the Israelie-occupied lands. The gulf crisis began after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Since then, the Iraqis have massed close to 500,000 soldiers in Kuwait. The United States leads a multinational force that includes nearly 200,000 U.S. soldiers deployed in Saudi Arabia and the region to deter any further aggression. Saddam described Iraq's new missile in a statement monitored in Nicosia. ``Al-Hijara became capable of reaching targets that are hundreds of kilometers (miles) from where it is launched,'' the statement said. ``They are the new missiles which Iraq invented,'' it said. ``It is capable of reaching its targets from where it is launched, and there are many al-Hijaras in Iraq.'' The statement did not give details on the number of missiles Iraq possesses or what kind of warhead it can carry. Also today, a spokesman for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said there was reason to be upbeat about prospects for a settlement to the Persian Gulf crisis following a visit to Iraq by a Soviet envoy. Presidential spokesman Vitaly Ignatenko expressed optimism for a settlement in the gulf crisis following Friday's meeting between Saddam and Soviet envoy Yevgeny Primakov. Ignatenko would not give details in Moscow but said Gorbachev would inform President Bush by letter of the latest Soviet efforts. ``I can only tell you that we are today more able to look more optimistically at the prospect of a political settlement in that region,'' Ignatenko said in Moscow. He said details would become known ``within one or two weeks.'' Saddam has suggested that if negotiations are held to solve the crisis, that all regional conflicts, including the Palestinian uprising in Israel's occupied lands, also be placed on the agenda. In one of the military accidents Monday, an RF4C Phantom reconnaisance jet crashed in the southern Saudi Arabian peninsula. The jet belonged to a unit of the Alabama Air National Guard on a training mission, the guard said. It identified the victims as Maj. Barry K. Henderson, 40, a senior pilot from Tuscumbia, Ala., and Maj. Stephen G. Schramm, 43, a master navigator from Birmingham, Ala. Both were assigned to the 106th Tactical Reconnaissance Squadron of the 117th Tactical Reconnaissance Wing and had volunteered for duty, military officials said. Their unit had not been activated. The Marine helicopters vanished over the North Arabian Sea on Monday while on a training mission and the search for them continued today.

DOC.HEAD: India Discloses Expulsion Of Four Pakistani Embassy Personnel
DOC.TEXT: India quietly expelled four Pakistani embassy personnel earlier this year for alleged spying, a Foreign Ministry statement said Tuesday. The statement said Pakistan was retaliating for the previously unanounced expulsion when it demanded Monday that four Indian officials be recalled from the consulate in Karachi. It said the Pakistani press, in ``obviously inspired'' reports, suggested in advance that the expulsion of the Indians was imminent, and linked it to the expulsion is from the High Commission in New Delhi between March and August. The statement confirmedof four Pakistan these reports and said the four were asked to leave ``on account of their proven espionage activities in India.'' India previously had not made the expulsions public. ``It was done quietly, one by one,'' said a Foreign Ministry official. He gave no explanation, and said he did not have the names of the Pakistani officials or whether they were diplomats. The statement said ``the government categorically rejects'' allegations by Pakistan that the Indian consulate officials were engaged in security offenses. The officials were told to leave the southern port city of Karachi within 10 days. ``Pakistan's action can hardly be calculated to restore confidence in relations between our two countries,'' le program violates campaign finance laws. The committee is allowed to donate $17,500 directly to Senate candidates and may spend an additional amount on a candidate's behalf. The limit on the size of the latter contributions varies from state to state depending on population. The Common Cause and DSCC complaints allege the Republicans are using the Inner Circle campaign to circumvent the limits by ``bundling'' contributions it raises from the direct-mail Inner Circle program and donating the money to certain GOP Senate candidates. In its Inner Circle fund-raising solicitation, the NRSC says it will serve as a conduit and channel the money to Republican Senate candidates. The NRSC contends these donations do apply against its contribution limits because the money never enters NRSC accounts. The Common Cause complaint asserts that the NRSC is too loosely interpreting federal election laws. It says the GOP organization cannot claim to be simply a conduit because it ``selected, or played a major role in selecting, which campaigns would receive the proceeds.'' Common Cause won an earlier lawsuit challenging a 1986 ``bundling'' program run by the NRSC.

DOC.HEAD: Tax Increase Aimed at Stamping Out Tobacco in Marlboro Country
DOC.TEXT: Voters in the heart of ``Marlboro Country'' will decide whether to make their state cigarette tax the highest in the nation to discourage smoking and fund anti-tobacco education. Both sides agree that the real goal of Initiative 115 is to reduce, even eliminate, the use of tobacco in Montana. ``No question,'' said Dr. Robert M. Shepherd, a Helena physician who is treasurer and chief spokesman for the initiative. ``I think that would do more for the health of the population here than anything else we could do.'' Jerome Anderson, a Helena attorney and tobacco lobbyist, complains the proposal on the Nov. 6 ballot would use taxes ``to establish social mores.'' ``We feel this is not the intended use of taxation,'' he said. The initiative would raise Montana's cigarette tax 140 percent from 18 cents a pack to 43 cents, and double the tax on other tobacco products to 25 percent of the wholesale price. It would take effect July 1. Texas currently has the highest state cigarette tax: 41 cents a pack, according to the Tobacco Institute in Washington, D.C. Congress also is considering hiking cigarette taxes nationwide four cents in 1991, to 20 cents a pack, and to 24 cents in 1993 to help balance the federal budget. Estimates on how much the proposed Montana tax would produce range from $27.6 million to $34 million. The initiative would assign 58 percent of that money to a new tobacco education and preventive health-care fund. The rest would go to long-range building accounts, which are financed by the current tobacco tax. Backers of the initiative gathered 18,351 signatures, but have raised only about $20,000 to campaign for it. The American Cancer Society gave $9,435, the American Lung Association donated $1,500, and the American Heart Association had kicked in $7,500 in late September, with the rest coming from small individual contributors. The tobacco industry, meanwhile, has poured more than $600,000 into the state to defeat it - about $2 for every likely vote. That included contributions of $267,000 from R.J. Reynolds and $103,000 from Philip Morris. The I-115 sponsor, the Coalition for a Healthy Montana, is depending mainly on news conferences and free public-service announcements on radio and television to deliver its message. ``The message is that smoking is the No. 1 killer in the United States, and it's costing us a lot of money,'' Shepherd said. Smoking, says Shepherd, is a major cause of cancer, heart disease, stroke, emphysema, bronchitis, miscarriages and even house fires. It will kill 1,500 Montanans this year and will cost the state $265 million, or $330 for every Montana resident, he says. Anderson dismisses the health questions: ``You can prove anything with statistics.'' The real issue, Anderson argues, is that a tax increase for any purpose is still a tax increase. And he says the additional tax money would create a new bureaucracy with hundreds of new government workers - a tobacco education and preventive health-care fund in the state Health Department. Shepherd contends the higher tax would reduce consumption, most notably among teen-agers. Anderson says it would only drive many buyers to Montana's seven Indian reservations, where cigarettes are exempt from state taxes.

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: it's complicated.
DOC.TEXT: I mean, I think that's part of it. And, well, I don't want to get stretched out on the couch too far in terms of analysis now. But, you know, when you get a problem with the complexities that one, that the Middle East has now, and the Gulf has now, I enjoy trying to keep this, put the coalition together and keep it together and work towards what I think is a proper end, seeing that this aggression doesn't succeed. I'm, I can't say I just rejoice every time I go up and talk to Danny Rostenkowski, my dear friend, about what he's going to do on taxes. I mean, it's just, does that help you? Q: Not ... A: That's about - have you got a follow-up? Q: It doesn't sound like you have as much fun as you do with the other. A: That's about right, yeah. Yes, Ellen? Marlin Fitzwater: Final question, please. Q: Mr. President, you pulled out all the stops on this budget deal, and it just flopped. Are you concerned, sir, that your leadership on other domestic issues now will be eroded since you didn't carry even half your own party in the House? You talk about clean air, you talk about crime. Are you worried that you're just going to - the honeymoon is entirely over? A: No, because I want to talk to Speaker Foley about this, and Leader Mitchell, because they pulled out all the stops and they didn't get the votes they needed. And so I don't think they feel that they can't conduct their business in the House or in the Senate, and certainly I don't feel that I can't conduct my business here. So I don't think there is erosion. In fact, you saw the House side come together in terms of a veto, right quick, like that. And I think that, that's, you know - there's a certain maturity there, and we go on to the next event. I mean, and stay with it. You can't, can't stay there forever and mope about it. So I don't, no, I don't worry about that. Q: But in terms of the disdain up on the Hill from both Republicans and Democrats for some members of your staff, some of them in this room, have you taken any of your staff to the woodshed, sir? A: Absolutely not. I have full confidence in him, and when the passions get high, I understand that there is bound to be a little broken china up there. But, hey, look, If I got outraged every time I watched C-SPAN and heard some outrageous Democrat go after me, and I sulked about it, and I fretted about it, and I called Tom Foley about it and said, said, ``Why do you permit this?'' And, you know, I, I wouldn't be able to do anything. So I don't worry about that. And in terms of my team, they did an outstanding job and I have had more members tell me that. And so what you hear is the squeaking wheel. You hear those that don't, aren't particularly happy. Maybe you didn't get it exactly their way. And the news, of course, is ``Man Bites Dog - Republican Goes After Republican.'' So I don't, I don't think we've got a problem at all. We've got three bright people working hard to move this, move my objectives forward and I think they happen to be the country's objectives forward. Q: Who, sir, are these members of Congress who are hailing the work of your team? A: Plenty of them. Go talk to the leadership. Talk to Bob Michel. Talk to Bob Dole. They're the leaders. They're the key leaders of the Congress. You want to talk about a squeaking wheel from time to time, and I want to talk about those that have a broader view of things. Yes? Q: Mr. President ... A: You've got two more. One, two, and that's the second. That's where we counted the votes on the deal. Go ahead. Q: Following on Helen's question, do you think anyone on your staff, or do you think that in general, without naming names which I am certain you won't want to do in any case, didn't the White House end of this handle anything wrong? Is it all ... A: I probably made some mistakes and I thought frankly that we had a deal that would get support on the, from a majority of the Republicans and I tried very hard. I made, golly, I can't remember how many phone calls, and so I think there is you know, if we're trying to assign blame, lay it right here.

DOC.HEAD: Strait's Path Leads Home, As Soon As He Can Get There
With AM-Country Awards List
DOC.TEXT: George Strait's path is clear. From Entertainer of the Year, to North Dakota, to Kansas and then back to the ranch. That's where music business success is leading the soft-speaking, hard-singing Texan. Backstage Monday night at the Country Music Association's awards ceremony, Strait smiled from under his black hat and talked about how it's been. ``It's hard not to be affected by this stuff. It's great,'' said Strait, who won the CMA's top award the second consecutive year. Strait, like most country acts, will tour small towns and cities across the naton this winter. But Strait will stop after 80 or so appearances and return to his ranch in early November. ``I made up my mind I wasn't going to tour as much,'' said Strait, known outside the country industry for his TV beer commercials. Members of the fast-rising group Kentucky HeadHunters figure two awards means they won't have to cut their hair. Their locks were longer than anyone's at the awards ceremony - except for Crystal Gayle's. ``Does this mean we get to keep our hair?'' asked Greg Martin, one of five HeadHunters taking home crystal trophies for Album of the Year, ``Pickin' on Nashville,'' and for Vocal Group of the Year. The only other double winner was Garth Brooks, with the Horizon Award (for career development) and Music Video of the Year for ``The Dance.'' Tennessee Ernie Ford was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame, an honor that made the 71-year-old singer consider the youth of some other winners. ``These people who performed tonight, I've got neckties older than they are,'' Ford said on the nationally televised awards presentation. Clint Black won Male Vocalist of the Year and Kathy Mattea won top female vocalist honors. The Judds, Wynonna and mother Naomi, picked up Vocal Duo of the Year award. Single of the Year went to Vince Gill for ``When I Call Your Name.'' Vocal Event of the Year, for performers who do not normally sing together, went to Lorrie Morgan and her late husband, Keith Whitley. Song of the Year, a songwriter's award, was given to Jon Vezner and Don Henry for ``Where've You Been.'' Johnny Gimble received Musician of the Year award.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Diplomatic Missteps Blamed on Domestic Infighting
DOC.TEXT: Two diplomatic embarrassments this week, both linked to party leaders jostling for power, have strengthened the view that Japan's political fractiousness at home often prevents coherent policy abroad. The incidents concerned negotiations with the Soviet Union and the two Koreas, highly sensitive affairs usually conducted by the Foreign Ministry. In both cases, however, the talks were taken up independently by powerful politicians without official posts. Their missteps reinforced the criticism of Japanese government as a mass of competing interests with no real center, analysts say. In addition, the unofficial talks may have undermined the already weak stature of the prime minister's office. The post is usually filled through a tenuous alliance between intra-party factions in the governing Liberal Democratic Party. ``It's not easy to identify a sort of power center in the Japanese system like you can in the United States,'' said Seiichiro Takagi, an international relations expert at Saitama University. Perhaps the best-known critic of this tendency of Japanese government is Dutch writer Karl Van Wolferen, whose opinions have stirred considerable controversy here: ``The Japanese prime minister has less real power than any head of government in the Western world, or in most countries of Asia,'' he wrote in his recent book, ``The Enigma of Japanese Power.'' ``Tokyo evades foreign questions concerning Japan's global political and economic intentions because there is no one with the authority to answer them.'' In one incident this week, lawmakers from the powerful party faction led by Shintaro Abe said Soviet officials told them the Soviet Union might compromise on a territorial dispute that has kept the two nations from signing a World War II peace treaty, according to Japanese news reports. Abe has been considered the heir apparent to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, who is a member of a weak Liberal Democratic Party faction and is believed to have very shallow support within the party. The Foreign Ministry cautiously welcomed the news Monday. Later in Moscow, however, the Soviet Foreign Ministry denied it had made any such offer and denounced the report as ``disinformation.'' It was an embarrassment both for Abe and the government. ``It's a free country. We cannot control what private individuals do,'' Foreign Minister Taizo Watanabe said Tuesday. But he commented pointedly, ``Issues related to the Soviet Union should be conducted in government-to-government negotiations.'' In the second incident, powerful Liberal Democrat Shin Kanemaru was forced to apologize to South Korean President Roh Tae-woo Monday for beginning dialogue with North Korea too quickly. South Korea, the North's bitter rival, said it was surprised by the move. Kanemaru, a former deputy prime minister, led a delegation of high-level Japanese governing and opposition party legislators who signed a declaration with North Korea last month urging the two countries to start talks on normalizing relations. Kanemaru told Roh the trip to the North had been organized by political parties, not governments, and he was sorry for creating ``misunderstanding and controversy.'' Analysts say unofficial emissaries often have been used by Japan's rigidly conservative government to test new policies. If it works, the policies can be taken up by the government. If not, the move can be repudiated, as in Abe's case with the Soviet Union. And Kanemaru's opening with North Korea still has a good chance of working, officials said. ``It's a kind of human trial balloon,'' said Robert Orr, director of the Stanford Japan Center. But some critics say such methods are unsuited to long-term foreign-policy planning, and prevent the possibility of reacting to events with a unified voice. And too often, they are carried out by politicians with far more experience in infighting than statesmanship. Japan can ill afford such mishaps as it gets pressed more and more into a global leadership role, these critics say. ``It's just another indication of the weakness of the Kaifu regime,'' said Orr. ``There are people in the Foreign Ministry who are delighted with all this. It undercuts the politicians and reinforces the reason why the bureaucracy should be in charge of foreign policy.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Approves Test-Ban Treaties, Calls For Global Ban
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds 3 grafs after the last pvs, `The treaties...' to explain what held up the ratification of the treaties. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet parliament today ratified two U.S.-Soviet treaties from the 1970s that place tight limits on underground nuclear weapons testing by the superpowers. The lawmakers voted 347-0, with nine abstentions, to approve the treaties and to appeal to world ``parliaments and social organizations'' to seek a global ban on nuclear testing. In the same vote, the parliament referred to its international and national security committees questions stemming from several reservations about the treaties, which were also ratified last month by the U.S. Senate. The treaties focus mainly on verification methods for arms control agreements, and allow each country to maintain intrusive, on-site monitoring equipment at three sites on each other's soil. U.S. Sen. William Cohen, R-Maine, cautioned after the Senate vote that the Soviets could use their monitoring equipment for espionage and urged no inspections be allowed until security procedures were tightened. Supporters say the new verification measures are likely to become important precedents for more ambitious arms control treaties. The treaties limit underground explosions to 150 kilotons or less. They are a follow to the 1963 Limited Test Ban Treaty, which barred nuclear tests in the atmosphere, water and in space. The latest treaties were not ratified at first because then-President Carter wanted a more comprehensive test ban. The Reagan administration did not think that adequate means existed for verifying that the Soviets were not cheating. That issue was settled by the signing of a verification protocol in June in Washington by President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a transcript of President Bush's press conference Tuesday in the White House press room. President Bush: Let me just go with an opening statement, and then I'll be glad to respond to questions. First, on the budget, the committees of Congress now take up the arduous task of implementing the budget resolution that they just passed. We've been pulling and tugging at this framework agreement for nearly five months, and it's been difficult because that whole underlying problem is difficult. And we're trying to reduce the federal deficit by $500 billion over the next five years - 40 billion of it in the first year. And this would be the largest such cut in history. So while it's easy to get caught up in the maneuvers and the counter-maneuvers of the legislative process, I want to assure the American people this morning that I will do everything in my power to encourage Congress as it struggles to bring forth the most comprehensive and significant deficit-cutting plan ever. This morning I outlined several conditions for a budget reconciliationbill. As the committees of Congress begin to fill in the blanks in determining how we raise the revenues and cut the spending, we must be mindful not to let the hard-won goals of the budget resolution dissipate or lose direction. The Budget Reconciliation Bill, due on October 12, must measure up to the savings Congress has outlined, without smoke and mirrors, with growth-oriented tax incentives, with process reform, with enforceability, with bipartisan support, and with passages of both Houses -- by both Houses of Congress by October 19th. These are the objectives that we fought for since the beginning of the long budget struggle, but they're worthy of our effort. In any undertaking of this size, there is bound to be anguish, and I want to recognize the valiant federal work force that had to suffer through some uncertainty of this period. On Saturday morning I said we cannot have business as usual. But the Congress has finally acted and we are back on course and there can be no letup in our attention to detail and our commitment to purpose. We must fulfill the requirements of the budget resolution. Now, I'd be glad to take some questions. Q: Mr. President? A: Yeah, Terry? Q: A week ago you asked Americans to help get a budget passed and they gave you the back of the hand. Then, despite a government shutdown, Congress still hasn't been able to produce a budget. How can Americans fail to have anything except grave questions about, the - your ability and that of Congress to govern? A: Well, I think there probably are some questions. I don't feel the American people gave the back of the hand to the budget agreement. If you look at the surveys that were carried in the magazines and all of this, they show that, I think, more people wanted the agreement than not. So we've just got to do a better job of getting it through. But listen, I can understand the frustration. I feel it myself at times. And when you have a government with one party controlling the Congress, where the action is and where the action will remain now for a while, and then you have a president of a different party, nobody thought it would be easy, and it isn't. So I think there is some frustration, but I notice that there was strong support for the package. The problem was that you ask in individual categories of the package, ``Oh, no, we don't want this, we don't want that, we don't - '' you know, a lot of special interests. But people seem to want the deal. I think the deal, though not keeping me happy in every way, was a good one and I was proud to join with the Republican and Democratic leaders in supporting that original budget agreement. Now we've got some of the main ingredients of it, broad instruction to these committees that were contained within the original agreement, and let's see if the Congress can get moving and come up with a deal that I can accept. And we'll be working with them. We're not, I'm not up here to assign blame. Yeah, Helen? Q: Mr. President, no matter what you say, there was a lot of feeling in the country that the package was not fair. Are you willing to accept a higher tax rate for the wealthy, perhaps in exchange for a capital gains cut, but even so, a higher tax rate?
DOC.NOTE: MORE,

DOC.HEAD: WASHN: tax rate?
DOC.TEXT: A: I haven't seen great sentiment for raising people's income tax rates, and I'm not for that. Now, during the budget process, and this was little noted, there was discussion about getting capital gains for straightening out the bubble, which means raising some rates. We were quite open-minded, there was some negotiation. So I'm not, let me say this, I - that's on the table, that's been talked about. And if it's proper, if it can be worked in proper balance between the capital gains rate and income tax changes, fine. But I don't think it's fruitful here to negotiate the details, or try to. What we've got to do is get up now with - particularly Ways and Means and Finance, Danny Rostenkowski, Lloyd Bentsen, Bill Archer, and Bob Packwood - and discuss with them quietly what we can accept. I want them to know it. But I don't think I can stand here and kind of negotiate or mandate exactly what will happen. Q: Sir, don't you think, though, the secrecy was an impediment? It fell like a lead balloon. The senior citizens in this country do not consider themselves a special interest; they're a quarter of the population. A: Right. Q: People who drive to work 50 miles every day, or less, certainly did consider it a hardship. So had you not negotiated more in public, more public dialogue, more debate, don't you think you would have been better off? A: Well, I don't know that any person who is opposed to raising gasoline taxes would have been more inclined to accept them if it had been more - the negotiations between Democrats and Republicans on these committees had been done in public. But I think now the positions are clear, and what I want to do is see us go forward now. I mean, those are all out there now, and so let's - the committees know where the opposition's coming from. But, Helen, the basic problem is this, nobody wants to do anything in terms of where they're affected. I mean, they just don't want that, and yet they want the deficit down, and that's what makes it difficult. And that's why I was very pleased to see the agreement. Everyone had to give a little bit. But we'll go back now and see if we can't, in that spirit, get a deal by the 19th that I can sign. Yeah, Brit? Q: Mr. President, House Republicans, by the end of last week, were being accused of behaving like Democrats. There seemed to be fairly deep divisions within their ranks. You didn't carry, you and the leaders did not carry a majority of House Republicans on the budget deal. What hope do you now have, and what reason do you have for holding that hope that you can do that the next time on a program that will, in effect, be written by the Democratic Party? A: Well, I see that - Brit, you only stated - if I could , I don't want to be argumentative, but the Democrats didn't have their troops behind them. They didn't have what they needed to get it through. So it isn't just the Republicans. I think the hope is that people see more clearly now that it isn't easy, and as people go to go with their own alternatives now, they find that they can't get the support. So we may, so I think what we'll end up doing is staying very close to the agreement that I reached with the Republican and Democratic leaders. The last couple of, few days have been like a catharsis. There's been a clearing of the air. People out - ``Here's what I'd do; here's what I'd like to do'' - and then they find, well, there's no votes to do exactly what they'd like to do. So I think we just have to work the process now and hope that the Congress will come up with a reasonable deal. The action is in the Congress, I keep pointing out, but we'll work with them. Yes? Q: There seemed to be considerable bitter feeling among Republicans towards some members of your team, who felt they had been dealt with in a ham-handed or high-haned way. Has anything been done to patch this up, sir, and have you talked to members about that? A: Well, I've talked to the leaders, our leaders, Dole and Michel and others, Bill Archer yesterday, over the weekend, Al Simpson and others. But, you know, anytime you have a difficult road like this, there's bound to be griping about it. I have total confidence in our team. I think they did a first-class job, and I don't think we would have ever gotten the agreement out if they hadn't done a first-class job.

DOC.HEAD: More Violence on Jerusalem's Temple Mount
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with two border policemen stabbed, attackers shot, mosque key returned, Bush reax. Editing to conform. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY4,5
DOC.TEXT: Police closed the holy Temple Mount today and fired tear gas after 200 Moslem worshipers tried to break through the cordon. Jerusalem's 80-year-old chief Moslem cleric was overcome by tear gas. The temporary closure came one day after riots on the Temple Mount, Islam's third-holiest site, in which at least 19 Palestinians were killed and about 140 were wounded by police gunfire. In an Arab neighborhood of Jerusalem today, a Palestinian stabbed two border policemen with a screwdriver. The attacker and another Arab were shot and wounded, police said. Clashes between stone throwers and police also erupted in three other Jerusalem Arab neighborhoods, and widespread protests were reported in Israeli Arab towns where leaders called for a two-day strike over the Temple Mount bloodshed. Palestinian leaders in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip have demanded U.N. protection and announced a protest strike beginning today, the start of the 36th month of the anti-Israeli uprising in the territories seized during the 1967 Middle East war. Monday's violence forced the Palestinian question back toward the top of the international agenda. It was the bloodiest clash in Jerusalem since the 1967 war, and the highest single-day death toll in the uprising. Arab leaders denounced the use of deadly force by Israel. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, which joined the multinational force formed after Iraq invaded Kuwait, said the violence could lead to ``grave consequences.'' Also condemning the Temple Mount violence were the Japanese Foreign Ministry, the European Community's executive body and the president of the European parliament. President Bush said today Israel should have acted ``with more restraint'' at the Temple Mount. But he said Iraq's Saddam Hussein should not use the violence to try to link his occupation of Kuwait with the Israeli-Palestinian dispute. ``The Arab world is united, almost united, against him,'' Bush said. ``If he tries to use this unfortunate incident to link the two issues, I do not think it will be successful.'' Moslem leaders said today's closure of the Temple Mount marked the first time police had blocked entry to the 35-acre site and its two mosques since Israel captured the surrounding Old City in 1967. The keys to the gates of the wall around the Temple Mount were returned to Moslem officials this afternoon and one of the mosque's doors was opened, Moslem clerics said. Before control of the Temple Mount was returned to the Moslems, the chief Moslem cleric, the mufti of Jerusalem, led 200 Moslems to a gate of the shrine. Border police blocked their way and ordered them to leave. When the Moslems refused, police fired tear gas, and the mufti, Saad al-Din al-Alami was overcome, an Arab reporter said. The mufti, who has a heart condition, was taken to Mukassed Hospital, where he was reported in satisfactory condition. Earlier, police arrested the mufti's deputy on charges of inciting Monday's rioting. On the southern outskirts of Jerusalem today, three Arabs stopped at a border police roadblock jumped out of their car. One of them plunged a screwdriver into the side of one officer and stabbed a second officer in the arm. The three then tried to speed away but police opened fire, shooting two of the Palestinians, police said. Both the officers and the Arabs suffered slight wounds, police spokesman Uzi Sanduri said. In Nazareth today, police fired tear gas to disperse dozens of activists who blocked roads with overturned garbage cans and stones, an Arab reporter said. Masked youths shouting pro-Iraqi slogans broke into a department store, smashing windows and beating shoppers. The army extended curfews on the Gaza Strip and most of the occupied West Bank, restricting the more than 1 million Palestinian residents to their homes. The U.S. State Department advised Americans to avoid travel to the occupied territories. The curfews were imposed after three Palestinians were killed and at least 65 were wounded Monday by army gunfire during protests that followed the Temple Mount violence. Also today, Deputy Foreign Minister Benjamin Netanyahu suggested Israel would block a proposed U.N. fact-finding mission to Israel. He urged Washington to veto an inquiry into the violence at the Temple Mount. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has said Monday's riots were engineered by pro-Iraqi Palestinian extremists to deflect attention from Iraqi aggression. The violence began Monday after 3,000 Arabs hurled stones from the Temple Mount onto 14,000 to 20,000 Jews praying at the Wailing Wall below. The wall, the last remnant of the Jewish Temple, is Judaism's holiest site. About 25 people were injured by the stones, and police stormed the mosque compound, firing tear gas, rubber bullets and live ammunition. Authorities said 22 civilians and five or six officers were hurt by stones, and 120 Arabs were arrested. The Arabs apparently were angered by rumors a Jewish group planned to march onto the Temple Mount, which is revered by Moslems and Jews. Palestinians also said tensions were raised by a speech in which Shamir said he hoped a new Jewish neighborhood would be built in east Jerusalem. The deaths raised the uprising toll to 758 Palestinians killed by troops or Israeli civilians. At least 278 Arabs have been slain by Palestinians, most as suspected collaborators. Forty-eight Israelis have been killed.

DOC.HEAD: Court Lets Stand Ruling Favoring Landlord in Discrimination Suit
DOC.TEXT: The Minnesota Supreme Court has let stand its ruling that a landlord may refuse to rent to an unmarried couple because of his religious beliefs. The court Monday denied a petition to rehear the discrimination case, in which it ruled 4-3 last month in favor of landlord Layle French of Marshall. The court had ruled that French's rights of conscience take precedence over the couple's rights under the state's laws against discrimination. State Human Rights Commissioner Stephen Cooper sought the rehearing, saying the decision contradicted the state Legislature's intent to prevent discrimination on the basis of marital status. Cooper said the ruling opened the door to landlords imposing their morality on tenants. In June 1989, an administrative law judge found that French had violated the law when he voided an agreement to rent a house to Sue Parsons after learning Parsons would live in the house with her fiance. French cited his religious beliefs against sex outside marriage. A state Appeals Court panel upheld the judge last fall, although it did not dispute the sincerity of French's religious beliefs. The state Supreme Court reversed that decision.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Visits Prison With Good News For Comrades
LaserPhoto CPN1
DOC.TEXT: A smiling Nelson Mandela returned to prison Tuesday, this time on a visit with promising news for African National Congress comrades still jailed for anti-apartheid activities. ``It evokes all kinds of memories ... but I'm concentrating on the pleasant ones,'' said Mandela, who was released in February after 27 years in prison for trying to overthrow the white-led government. He went to Pollsmoor and Robben Island to tell jailed ANC members about government plans to release political prisoners. Mandela spent nearly two decades on Robben Island, some of it breaking rocks in hard labor, before his transfer in 1982 to Pollsmoor. He described Tuesday's meetings as emotional. ``The atmosphere was one of enthusiasm and the spirit of comradeship was so strong that when we meet, the emotions run wild,'' he said after his visits. Mandela said he spoke only to ANC members, but that the organization seeks the release of all political prisoners, irrespective of affiliation. ``We have set a date by which all political prisoners will be released and that is the end of April 1991,'' he said. ``All that we are concentrating on is that political prisoners are released as soon as possible and we are busy with that process.'' The ANC has said the government must free all political prisoners before the black opposition movement will enter full-scale negotiations on ending apartheid and white-minority rule. The government has released dozens of prisoners in recent months and 15 more are scheduled to be freed Wednesday from Robben Island. Another six also are to be released from other South African prisons, the ANC said. It says there are some 3,000 people it considers political prisoners. President F.W. de Klerk has said his government will free all political prisoners, but has not said how many inmates fall in that category. On Monday, de Klerk said the ANC's estimated 20,000 exiles could begin applying for amnesty to clear the way for their return to South Africa. De Klerk, who legalized the ANC in February, cautioned that amnesty would not automatically be granted to everyone who applied. The release of political prisoners and the return of exiles are two main obstacles to negotiations on ending apartheid. De Klerk says he wants to draw up a new constitution with opposition groups that would allow the 5 million whites and 30 million blacks to share power. The government and the ANC have been holding preliminary talks since May. Mandela appeared in a jovial mood before visiting Robben Island. He smiled broadly while boarding a boat to the prison, the most noroious in South Africa. He recognized a guard on the craft and greeted him warmly, saying, ``Oh, you are a sergeant now.'' Later, Mandela recalled some aspects of prison life. ``As you know, we were not allowed to read newspapers,'' he said, ``and I remembered very well how successful we were in smuggling in newspapers.''

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storms KLaus, Lili Dying Out
DOC.NOTE: EDs: UPDATES throughout with both storms dying.
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Klaus fell apart off the Florida coast today after punishing the Bahamas with rains and gale-force winds, forecasters said. Top winds dropped to 35 mph as the system disintegrated, and all storm warnings in the Bahamas were dropped. Tropical Storm Lili also appeared ready to peter out in the mid-Atlantic, forecasters said. No more advisories were planned for bot storm systems. Klaus had prompted the Navy to cancel shore leave for sailors visiting Fort Lauderdale and order the fleet out to sea, but that order was dropped when the storm weakened into a tropical depression late this morning. The biggest continuing danger from the storm's remnants was heavy rain across south Florida, coastal erosion and flooding, said Bob Sheets, director of the National Hurricane Center in Coral Gables. Flood warnings went up from the northern Florida Keys to Jupiter Inlet in Palm Beach County. Water managers welcomed the rain, however, saying it can help alleviate the effects of a two-year drought. By noon EDT, the depression left by Klaus was centered near 24.0 north latitude and 76.0 west longitude, or about 115 miles southeast of Nassau in the Bahamas. It was heading west-northwest at about 15 mph and was expected to continue on that course. Klaus, the 11th named storm of the 1990 Atlantic hurricane season, briefly reached hurricane status Friday, leaving at least six dead and 1,500 homeless in the northeastern Caribbean before being downgraded Saturday to a tropical storm when its top winds dropped below 74 mph. On Sunday, it was downgraded to a tropical depression when its winds dipped below 39 mph, but picked up enough strength to become a tropical storm again until today. Lili, meanwhile, remained in the open Atlantic, and was turning into just another storm. At noon EDT, Lili' was centered near 30.3 north latitude and 49.0 west longitude, or about 930 miles east of Bermuda. Lili had top sustained winds of 65 mph and was expected to weaken by Wednesday as it headed south southwest at 8 mph. The Atlantic hurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget, Bjt
Frustrated Workers Angered by Budget Process That Leaves Them Dangling
