DOC.TEXT: Federal workers, spared at least temporarily from layoffs by a last-minute budget deal, trooped back to work on Tuesday, frustrated by the chaotic process that left them dangling for weeks. ``Other countries of the world have got to be laughing their heads off. We try to run the world, but we can't manage our own affairs,'' said Tom Doherty, an Occupational Safety and Health Administration inspector from Allentown, Pa. ``It's been up and down every day ... Every federal employee is feeling that bit of salt in the wound,'' said Dale Bodinus, a ``non-essential'' tax collector from Detroit who faced being laid off from the Internal Revenue Service. The government, closed over the holiday weekend due to a budget stalemate between Congress and the White House, had faced the prospect of a paralyzing shutdown of non-essential services on Tuesday without an agreement. A deal was struck late Monday, and widespread layoffs of hundreds of thousands of the nation's 2.4 million federal workers were averted. Many federal employees contend Congress and the Bush administration have used them in a political tug-of-war. ``We feel like pawns, like we're very expendable ... except when it comes to who can use us for more power, to get their bills passed or to raise taxes,'' said Gretchen Kenney, a Social Security claims processor in Chicago. The yearly budget fiasco threatens to make government work - which already suffers a bad reputation - even less appealing, federal workers said. John Sturdivant, president of the 700,000-member American Federation of Government Employees, said federal workers make, on average, about 22 percent less than their counterparts in the private sector. In addition, the government pays about 1,100 less in health care premiums for each worker than the average medium or large corporation pays. ``If you were in the top 5 percent of your class, and were excited about doing some significant research for a cure for AIDs, would you want to come to work for the federal government? I think not,'' Sturdivant said. Federal workers have always known ``they're not going to get rich,'' said Robert Tobias, president of the National Treasury Employees Union. ``But there was an implicit agreement that they had job security. That agreement has been ripped apart the past few weeks,'' Tobias said. The uncertainty of federal workers' job status is not over. If a final budget isn't reached by Oct. 19, a government shutdown could still occur. The threat of forced furloughs had been hanging over workers for weeks. They were notified more than a month ago that they might face up to 22 days of furloughs under the Gramm-Rudman deficit-cutting law if Congress and the Bush administration did not strike a budget deal. The possibility of a wholesale government shutdown - which would have sent thousands of non-essential workers home indefinitely - hit last Friday when Congress balked at passing the original deficit-reduction plan Bush pitched on television. ``You have no idea the turmoil this has caused for some people, the ones trying to support a family on one pay check,'' said Doherty, the OSHA inspector from Pennsylvania. ``They don't know what to do. I do. I keep telling them, your voice is at the ballot box. Come election time, good, bad or indifferent, we just go in and vote for the guy's opponent,'' Doherty said. Bodinus, the tax collector from Detroit, said, ``I've got 27 years with the federal government, and I take a little bit of pride in my job. Unfortunately, I don't think Congress is taking the same kind of pride in their job. ``They've become experts in taking things down to the wire. They've done more work in the past week than they have all year. I pay my taxes faithfully, and I don't think I'm getting my money's worth.''

DOC.HEAD: Orr Says She's Been Threatened, Cancels Campaign Stop
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to recast lead and ADD dropped `it' in 4th graf, picks up 5th graf, `Mrs. Orr...'
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Kay Orr said today her life has been threatened and she will not campaign in a county divided by plans to build a low-level radioactive waste facility. The threat came within the past six months and she knows who made it, Orr said at a news conference this morning. But the governor refused to disclose the name. The Nebraska State Patrol was investigating it, she said. The sparsely-populated Boyd County has been in turmoil since a company developing a low-level radioactive waste warehouse for five states said it wanted to build the facility there. Mrs. Orr said she had hoped the situation in Boyd County wouldn't deteriorate to the point where threats were made. ``There are a lot of things that you consider when you step into a public office,'' Mrs. Orr said. ``I think most of it was pretty well understood by Bill (her husband) and me. ``It's dismaying to think that we have gotten to this point that people lose faith and confidence in their government,'' she said. State Patrol spokesman Jeff Hanson said a letter was received in early August that contained some implied threats but lacked some elements needed before authorities could carge a person with making terroristic threats. Hanson declined to release any specifics about when the letter was received, where it came from or what it said. ``We are concerned and we are continuing the investigation,'' Hanson said. Doug Parrott, a spokesman for the Orr campaign, said the state continues to review US Ecology's application for a permit to develop the site near Butte near the South Dakota border. The reinforced concrete warehouse would hold waste from five states in the Central Interstate Low-Level Radioactive Waste Compact Commission: Nebraska, Arkansas, Louisiana, Oklahoma and Kansas. The news of the threat came at a conference in which she was releasing information on her campaign finances. Mrs. Orr released a report that showed she has spent $1.5 million in her gubernatorial race against Democrat Ben Nelson. Orr, the nation's first Republican woman elected governor, said Nelson has spent at least $500,000 of his own money and 73 percent of his support has come from outside Nebraska. Nelson's campaign manager, Sonny Foster, said this was the first he had heard of the threat to Mrs. Orr and said that it had ``absolutely nothing'' to do with the Nelson campaign. Nelson has visited Boyd County and has said that he is concerned about the divisions in the community, Foster said. ``You have neighbors pitted against neighbors,'' he said. Nelson is scheduled to make one more trip to Boyd County to attend a fund-raiser in Naper on Sunday, Foster said.

DOC.HEAD: Wind Fans Fires In Three Counties; Homes Damaged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with second Ventura County fire; comments from Riverside fire chief on damage, possible cause; fire near Glen Helen was controlled. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Two brush fires burned out of control today, threatening more Southern California homes a day after fires fanned by Santa Anas damaged 28 houses and charred hundreds of acres. A 600-acre blaze threatened homes in dense brush near South Mountain, south of Santa Paula, said Ventura County fire dispatcher CeCe Grives. Three air tankers and more than 220 firefighters attacked the blaze, which began 11 p.m. Monday and raged uncontained 50 miles north of Los Angeles. Firefighters formed a defense line overnight to protect 20 homes from the flames near South Mountain, Grives said. No residents were evacuated. Another fire broke out 8 a.m. today and raced up a hill 10 miles north in the Mupu area of Santa Paula Canyon, blackening at least 10 acres but not threatening any homes, said Fire Department spokeswoman Bobbie Barker. Northeast winds began blowing up to 15 mph early today. ``That's going to hamper the firefighters,'' Barker said. In Riverside and Los Angeles counties, nearly 300 acres of brush were burned and 28 homes damaged Monday by stubborn fires pushed by Santa Anas. A 125-acre wildfire that began in the dry Santa Ana River bottom in Riverside damaged 20 homes. In the Los Angeles suburb of Diamond Bar, a 20-acre fire badly damaged three homes and slightly damaged four. The Diamond Bar fire caused an estimated $1 million damage, said Los Angeles County Fire Department spokesman Lawrence Beals. A total damage estimate in the Riverside fire was not immediately available, said Fire Chief Phil Clinton. The fires' causes were under investigation. Clinton said arson investigators were checking reports that teenagers were playing in the Santa Ana River area shortly before the fire. Authorities called a red flag fire warning because of winds gusting to 50 mph and low humidity associated with the fall's first Santa Ana conditions. The strong gusts occur as high pressure over the desert interior forces air over the region's mountains and down toward the Pacific Ocean. The Riverside blaze began at 10:30 a.m. Monday in dense brush and bamboo, sweeping up the Santa Ana River's embankments and into backyards. Authorities evacuated 900 youngsters from Mountain View Elementary School and ordered residents to leave more than 40 houses. At least 20 homes were damaged before 200 firefighters contained the fire at 9 p.m., said city fire Battalion Chief Bud Palmer. Three firefighters and three residents suffered minor injuries. Residents hosed down their roofs and yards as helicopters dumped water on the blaze from above. Wind-borne embers torched palm trees up to a quarter-mile from the river. ``Those fires are almost impossible to put out under the best of conditions,'' Fire Chief Douglas Greene said of the tree fires. Residents helped their neighbors ward off the flames. The American Red Cross closed a shelter for evacuees after serving just one person. Riverside is about 60 miles east of Los Angeles. In Diamond Bar, a brush fire spread quickly to a residential area and severely damaged three homes Monday, said Los Angeles County fire Capt. Cliff Norton. The roofs of four other homes suffered minor damage. Firefighters aided by water-dropping helicopters controlled the blaze by 5 p.m., sheriff's Sgt. Sylvia Fort said. Some residents were evacuated to Diamond Bar High School shortly after the fire was reported at 3:15 p.m., Fort said. A small brush fire in Fontana destroyed one structure, leaving just a stone chimney, witnesses said. It was controlled before incurring any more damage. Fontana is 50 miles east of Los Angeles. About 10 miles north of Fontana, a fire at the base of the Cajon Pass near Glen Helen Regional Park scorched 148 acres, said Greg Cooper, a spokesman with the California Department of Forestry. The blaze briefly threatened the Treehouse Fun Ranch nudist camp, but no evacuation was ordered, Cooper said. The fire was controlled at 6 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: Court Will Hear Case on Random Searches of Public Transportation
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court said Tuesday it would decide whether police may conduct random drug searches aboard buses and trains without a warrant. The court, which has never ruled on random searches aboard public transportation, said it would review a Florida court ruling that such searches violate passengers' rights. A decision is expected by July. The Florida Supreme Court ruled 4-3 last year that travelers, in effect, are coerced into consenting to have their luggage searched when police come aboard and randomly choose passengers. The passenger has been placed in temporary police detention since there is ``no place to which a reasonable traveler might leave and no place to which he or she might walk away,'' the state court said. The Florida court ruled in a case in which Broward County sheriff's officers boarded a bus bound from Miami to Atlanta during a stopover in Fort Lauderdale. The officers said they were looking for illegal drugs and asked a passenger, Terrance Bostick, to let them search his luggage. They said he consented before a search found cocaine in one of his bags. Bostick said he was asleep, lying across the back bench of the bus when the police boarded. He also said the officers blocked the aisle, making it difficult for him to leave. Florida courts noted that one officer carried a zipper pouch containing a pistol. The officers had no court-issued search warrant and no grounds to suspect Bostick had illegal drugs. The state Supreme Court said Bostick was detained unlawfully by the officers. Even if the passenger felt free to leave, the state court said, he was not about to get off the bus moments before its trip to Atlanta was to resume. ``Bostick in fact was `seized' by the officers and any consent he gave to search his luggage was not free from the taint of the illegal detention,'' the state court said. Florida prosecutors told the justices the state court's ruling ``severely restricts the ability of police to interdict illegal drug shipments i public transportation facilities.'' State officials said the problem is particularly acute in Florida because it is a pipeline for drug smugglers. They said police in Broward and Palm Beach counties regularly board buses and trains during scheduled stops to conduct such searches. The justices in 1968 gave police the authority to stop people on the street and question them if they had reason to suspect them of a crime, or frisk them if they had a reasonable suspicion they were carrying a weapon. The court also has given authorities considerable latitude to question people in airport terminals who fit so-called drug-courier profiles. Recently, the court bolstered police search powers even when they have no reason to suspect criminal conduct. For example, the justices said in June that police may try to curb drunken driving by setting up roadblocks and requiring motorists to submit to sobriety tests.

DOC.HEAD: Suspect in Florida Students' Slayings Goes on Trial in Assault Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with judge excluding grandmother's statements. Picks up 7th graf, ```That has ...'
DOC.TEXT: Statements made by the grandmother of a teen-ager prominently mentioned as a suspect in the slayings of five college students will not be allowed as evidence in his trial on charges of beating her. Edward Humphrey, 19, faces an aggravated battery charge in the beating of his grandmother, Elna Hlavaty, 79. She has said she no longer remembers what happened that night and does not believe her grandson attacked her. Today's ruling by Brevard Circuit Judge Theron A. Yawn not to allow Mrs. Hlavaty's statements was expected to lead to a mistrial motion, since prosecutor Philip Williams summarized the now-excluded testimony in his opening arguments. But testimony by a doctor who examined Mrs. Hlavaty began with no mistrial request by the defense. In his earlier arguments before the judge, Williams said the state was concerned about Mrs. Hlavaty's motivations in changing her version of the incident and needed the statements of others who initially arrived on the scene. Humphrey is accused of beating Mrs. Hlavaty shortly after he arrived at her Indialantic home on Aug. 30 from Gainsville. He had gone to Gainesville five days before to attend classes at the University of Florida. During the time he was there, five students - four females and a male - were stabbed to death in their off-campus apartments. No one has been charged in connection with those crimes, but police say Humphrey is one of several possible suspects. Yawn reminded jurors Monday that Humphrey was only on trial in his courtroom for the Brevard County assault charge. ``That has nothing to do with the trial we are undertaking,'' he said of the Gainesville slayings. Ms. Hlavaty, who is listed as a prosecution witness, recanted her initial allegations, saying instead that she accidentally fell and was not attacked by her grandson. If convicted of aggravated battery on a person over the age of 65, Humphrey faces at least three years in prison without parole. He also faces charges in connection with a 1988 attempted rape and burglary in Indian River County and an Aug. 25 assault on two male students at the University of Florida. Most of the jurors questioned Monday were aware that Humphrey was a suspect in the five slayings, but said they could render an impartial verdict in his assault case. Humphrey appeared to be dazed at the start of the proceedings, but later he smiled and laughed. At one point, he began reading aloud from a small booklet and was quieted by a court official. His mother, grandmother and two brothers sat in the courtroom throughout much of the jury selection. ``The state's attorney has harassed me and my family so terribly they should be in a cell,'' his grandmother said during a break in the selection process. ``He sure did not hit me and he knows he did not hit me.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Decision Giving Religious Groups Access To Public Schools
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court sent an unsettling message Tuesday to public schools that refuse to rent space to outside religious organizations while allowing such access for non-religious groups. The justices, without comment, turned down the appeal of a Centennial, Pa., high school that had been forced to rent weekend use of its auditorium to the Campus Crusade for Christ. A federal appeals court ruled that denying such access would violate the group's free-speech rights. Tuesday's court action set no national precedent but allowed the appeals court ruling to become binding law in Pennsylvania, Delaware and New Jersey. The appeals court ruling also could serve as a model for other courts. Lawyers for the Centennial school district said the appeals court ruling, if applied nationwide, would convert ``most American public school facilities into open public forums, to which even the most fractious religious and political speakers must be routinely allowed access.'' Acting in numerous cases the day David H. Souter became history's 105th Supreme Court justice, the court also: -Agreed to decide in a Florida case whether police without a court warrant may conduct random searches aboard buses and trains. -Left intact an affirmative action program plan for hiring and promoting more minorities and women in San Francisco's fire department. The plan had been challenged as discriminatory against white men. -Revived a $4 billion lawsuit by a millionaire Florida inventor who says an American Broadcasting Companies television program falsely portrayed him as a liar and hypocrite. The justices told a federal appeals court to restudy Arthur Jones' libel suit against ABC over a 1987 report by the ``20-20'' TV program on the fate of 63 baby elephants Jones rescued from death in Africa. The high court last June upheld the federal Equal Access Act, in which Congress required that virtually all public high schools must allow student prayer groups to meet and worship if other student clubs are permitted at school. The court said in its June decision that the law does not violate the constitutionally required separation of church and state. But the federal law applies only to student groups - not to outside organizations seeking use of school facilities. In the Pennsylvania case, the 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals relied, instead, on the Constitution's First Amendment when it ruled last summer that school officials violated the free-speech rights of Student Venture, a subsidiary of the Campus Crusade for Christ. The officials refused to rent space at William Tennent High School for a program aimed at religious conversion. By a 2-1 vote, the appeals court ruled that the school district had created an ``open public forum'' by renting space to, among others, the local Rotary and Kiwanis clubs, an adult education program offering night classes and two labor unions. The appeals court said religious groups could not be excluded, because of the message they sought to communicate, from such an open forum. The 3rd Circuit court relied in part on a 1981 decision in which the Supreme Court said state-run universities cannot ban student groups from using campus facilities for religious worship and study. The 1981 ruling said such bans generally violate students' free-speech rights because it prevents them from using an open public forum. In the appeal rejected Tuesday, lawyers for the Centennial school district argued that public high schools and elementary schools, for free-speech purposes, differ from college campuses. The appeal said the 3rd Circuit court ruling ``turns the First Amendment into a sweeping equal access act, putting school districts to an `all or nothing' choice regarding access to nonstudent-initiated groups.''

DOC.HEAD: Names of Missing Crash Victims Released
DOC.TEXT: The Marine Corps released the names today of the eight crew members missing in the crash Monday of two Huey helicopters over the Arabian Sea. Maj. Nancy LaLuntas, a Marines spokeswoman in Washington, said the families of the eight have been notified that they are missing, but she declined to specify whether the men are presumed dead. She said she did not know if the search was continuing. The eight missing men were identified as: Capt. Gary S. Dillon, Capt. William D. Cronin Jr., Capt. Kevin R. Dolvin, Capt. William J. Hurley, Sgt. Kenneth T. Keller, Sgt. John R. Kilkus, Cpl. Timothy W. Romei, and Lance Cpl. Thomas R. Adams. The Marine Corps had not yet released the men's ages, hometowns or other information. All eight were part of a search-and-rescue squadron based at the Marine Corps Air Station at Camp Pendleton, Calif. The helicopter crews were conducting routine night training operations about eight miles from their shipboard base when radar and radio contact was lost at 5:13 a.m. local time, said Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams. He said ``some floating debris'' from the downed helicopters was discovered on Monday, but he would not comment on any preliminary results of the crash investigation.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: The muse has overtaken Marilyn Quayle, wife of Vice President Dan Quayle, and flown her imagination to Havana. Mrs. Quayle has just completed her first novel, a story about the quest for control of Cuba after the death of Fidel Castro, according to the latest issue of New York magazine. Written with her sister, Nancy Northcott, the manuscript tentatively titled ``The Rage of the Lamb,'' is making the rounds of some publishers, the magazine said. Details of the Mrs. Quayle's literary effort were as hard to come by as a good Cuban cigar in the United States. Robert Barnett, Quayle's lawyer, told the magazine: ``I have been working on a project with Mrs. Quayle and Nancy Northcott, but I'm not prepared to discuss it at this time.'' --- IRVINE, Calif. (AP) - Folk singer Judy Collins says she's enjoying renewed interest in her career and having as much fun recording, writing and singing as she did at the height of her popularity in the 1960s and '70s. Miss Collins was scheduled to perform Tuesday at the University of California, Irvine. Best known for her renditions of ``Both Sides Now'' and ``Amazing Grace,'' the performer's recordings on the Elektra label are being reissued on CDs. She also has a new album, ``Fires of Eden.'' Even the association Miss Collins had with the peace movement two decades ago is continuing with her current involvement in social issues. She recently performed at a New York rally for African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela. ``I went to sing for Mandela this year and Tracy Chapman was there,'' she said in an interview published Monday in the Orange County Register. ``It felt good to be linking arms with the present.'' --- EUGENE, Ore. (AP) - To honor the memory of his son Jed, author Ken Kesey went where he'd expect to find him. The Kesey family gathered early Monday on Mount Pisgah for installation of a bronze sculpture by Peter Helzer. The artwork commissioned by the family commemorates the lives of Jed Kesey and Lorenzo West, teammates on the University of Oregon wrestling team. They died six years ago when a team van plunged off an icy Washington highway. The surface of the 40-inch-high sculpture is a relief map of mountains, rivers and towns in the Eugene area. Supporting it are three bronze columns depicting Oregon's geologic history with images of fossils. The family selected the mountaintop after Kesey's daughter, Sunshine, asked him where they might go to meet Jed if ``somehow we were to die and go into some kind of limbo.'' ``I had this flash,'' said Kesey, who wrote ``One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'' and ``Sometimes a Great Notion.'' ``And then I knew that if we were going to meet somewhere, Jed would know to meet me up here on Mount Pisgah.'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Cartoonist Matt Groening, creator of television's offbeat cartoon family ``The Simpsons,'' says his mission is to offer a joke for everyone. ``Our ambition is to do a show that is watched by the whole family,'' Groening said in an interview for Wednesday's syndicated TV show ``Personalities.'' ``We know that not everybody is going to get every joke, but we think that there's enough stuff in there for the little kids as well as more sophisticated stuff for grownups and ourselves to keep everybody amused.'' The fall premiere of Fox Network's ``The Simpsons'' airs Thursday night. Groening said he's always dreamed of having a prime-time cartoon show. ``It's a strange fantasy to have,'' he said. ``I was actually surprised that no one else did it. I mean, when I was a kid watching `The Jetsons' and `The Flintstones' and `Johnny Quest' and a few other forgotten ones, I thought that somebody else would catch on. ``It seems to me that there was an audience there, and I certainly felt part of it was for good animation on at night.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Tries to Block Telescope Venture
DOC.TEXT: The Federal Trade Commission moved Tuesday to block a joint venture it said would create a virtual monopoly in the making and sale of a telescope commonly used by serious amateur astronomers. The commission said it has authorized its staff to ask a federal judge in Los Angeles for a preliminary injunction blocking the proposed venture by Meade Instruments Corp. and Celestron International, the two largest producers of mid-size Schmidt-Cassegrain telescopes. These telescopes use mirrors and lenses and are suited for observation of both nearby planets and deep-sky objects, as well as for astrophotography, the commission said. They generally cost $1,000 or more. The commission said believed the joint production would virtually monopolize the production and sale of these telescopes. It said it would ask the court to block the acquisition until its legality has been determined by administrative proceedings. If the preliminary injunction is granted, the commission will have 20 days to issue a complaint beginning the administrative procedure. Meade is headquartered in Costa Mesa, Calif. and owned by Harbour Group Investments, L.P. Celestron is located in Torrance, Calif., and owned by Diethelm Holding (USA) Ltd., a subsidiary of Diethelm & Co. Ltd. of Switzerland. Harbour Group and Diethelm have announced plans to form Celestron Meade International, which would be half-owned by each of the two companies.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Armed Forces Radio Rocking Saudi Arabia
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Armed Forces Radio started live broadcasts in Saudi Arabia Tuesday with an almost inevitable opening line: ``Goooood Maaawrning, Saudi Arabia!'' Echoing comedian Robin Williams' intro in the movie ``Good Morning, Vietnam,'' disc jockey Rich Yanku broke in at 9:05 a.m. to bring the Heart of the Desert FM 107 direct from an airbase in the desert. An average mobile home would dwarf the two trailers that make up the broadcast unit. They were dubbed Camp Schmooz by the four disc jockeys after the favorite question of the unit's director, Bronx native Lt. Arnie Pon. ``What are you guys schmoozing around for?'' Pon asks constantly, using the Yiddish slang for idle talk. Picking the first song took a lot of schmoozing. Much of it was worthy of Adrian Kronauer, the character Williams portrayed in the film about Armed Forces Radio during the Vietnam War. ``Midnight at the Oasis'' was rejected as too sugary. Ray Steven's ``Ahab the Arab'' was also passed over and Hank Williams' ``Don't Give Us a Reason'' was dismissed for hinting at criticism of rather senior officials. ``We're probably always going to avoid playing that,'' acknowledged Air Force Staff Sgt. Harry Lockley, 25, of New Castle, Pa. ``Rock the Casbah'' by The Clash finally was first on the air. It seemed to fit with both the Middle East landscape - the tune abounds with references to sheiks, Bedouins and Cadillacs - and the role of nearly 200,000 U.S. troops underwritten by Saudi Arabia to confront Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein after he invaded neighboring Kuwait Aug. 2. One verse goes: ``The king called out his jetfighters. ``He said you better earn you pay. ``Drop your bombs between the minarets, ``Down the Casbah way.'' The radio station's format will be rock 'n' roll, with some country, folk, rap and reggae music from their collection of 8,800 compact discs. There will also be a jazz hour on most nights. The station starts the hour with the AP Network News. Classical music? None scheduled, and polka is also doubtful. ``There are a lot of young guys out here used to hearing hard-core rock 'n' roll, hard driving music,'' said Air Force Staff Sgt. John Haynes, 27, of Phoenix, Ariz., one of four disc jockeys. ``I try to target the young guys.'' The Saudi government has put some limits on what the radio can broadcast. But no one in the unit would specify what was forbidden. ``It's basically just common sense,'' about what might offend Saudi sensibilities, said Lt. Col. David MacNamee, head of the Armed Forces Radio and Television Services in Saudi Arabia. A TV station is still under discussion. The Moslem and tribal codes that determine public behavior in Saudi Arabia include bans on alcohol, and the mixing of men and women outside their homes. Most U.S. soldiers out in the field have been prohibited from entering villages, and there has been cultural friction in places where the troops share facilities. Saudi troops are shocked by American men walking naked to the showers. Part of the radio broadcasts include pep talks on the kingdom. ``Saudi Arabia's a land of mystery. Or is it?'' said Yanku between songs during his first 30 minutes on the air. ``If you take a little time to learn about i you'll make your stay more enjoyable.'' Public service messages will include warnings about scorpions in the desert. There's some question about how many soldiers will hear the 24-hour broadcasts because the number of transmitters is limited and few troops brought radios. Several thousand radios have been distributed and another 30,000 donated in the United States are expected to arrive soon. Requests started rolling in within minutes of the live show. The first soldier to call was a woman named Kim, dedicating Bruce Springsteen's ``Born in the U.S.A.'' to her fellow troops. Got a request? Dial 9663-899-1119, extension 7231.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Bloodied by Budget Turmoil
DOC.TEXT: ``The jury's still out,'' President Bush says, but in reality he's been badly bloodied by the budget turmoil. The president's poll ratings have slipped, his leadership abilities are being questioned, his own Republicans are in revolt, and he has thrown away his no-new-tax trump card. All this, and still no budget agreement. After five months of wrangling, Congress has given Bush only a vague budget agreement along with promises to fill in the blanks later with tax increases and spending cuts. To get even this much, Bush had to shut down the government in an embarrassing spectacle. At a news conference Tuesday, Bush acknowledged that Americans might justifiably wonder about the ability of the president and Congress to govern. ``I can understand the frustration,'' he said. ``I feel it myself at times.'' Bush badly misread congressional Republicans and the American public about whether they would support a painful prescription that would boost taxes on gasoline, alcohol and cigarettes and raise health-care costs under Medicare. The voters spurned the appeal for sacrifice. Instead, they called lawmakers to demand that they vote against the president. And that's exactly what Congress did. On the critical budget vote, Bush could not muster half of the GOP members of the House. Even most of the Republican leadership abandoned him. For Bush, it was a crushing disappointment on an issue that he had described as the biggest test of his presidency in the domestic field. Bush may be enjoying still-high popularity ratings, but what's it worth if it doesn't get him the results he wants? What Americans seemed to want was the old Bush - the feel-good leader who promised not to raise their taxes. Many GOP politicians, facing the voters in November, also liked the old Bush better. The president made it easy for Republicans to defect. He promised there wouldn' be any penalty for a no vote. He's even going out campaigning for turncoats, beginning with Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., on Wednesday. Despite Bush's collegial attitude, there are bad feelings between the White House and congressional Republicans over the budget negotiations. Bush's strong-willed chief of staff, John Sununu, and his budget director, Richard Darman, were accused by some lawmakers of acting arrogantly and treating them with disrespect. In one instance, Sununu dismissed Sen. Trent Lott, R-Miss. as ``insignificant'' when he said he would vote against Bush's budget. Bush says he has full confidence in his staff. ``And when the passions get high,'' Bush said, ``I understand that there's bound to be a little broken china up there.'' He said the complainers are just ``squeaky wheels.'' ``The news of course is man bites dog, Republican goes after Republican.'' In less than a month, Bush's popularity rating has dropped 10 percentage points to 65 percent, according to a Washington Post-ABC News Poll. A CBS News poll measured the erosion at 14 percentage points and pegged his approval rating at 62 percent. ``I guess I learned that you can't do it exactly my way when we get down on something like the deficit,'' Bush said. ``So, when you get into somebody's pocketbook, or you're worrying about a tax or a spending cut that affects someone, I've learned that it's just not going to be done the way I want it, especially if you don't control the Senate or you don't control the House.'' On the other hand, a 65 percent approval rating after 20 months in official is unprecedented. Stephen Hess, a presidential scholar at the Brookings Institution, said Bush probably has not suffered long-term damage even though Washington insiders will put it down in their books that Congress can whip him. The significant thing, said Hess, is that Bush's name won't be on a ballot until 1992. ``He has a lot of time to make it up.'' Besides, Hess said, ``The defining feature at this moment is that we've got 200,000 American troops sitting on the sand in Saudi Arabia. This (the budget) has to recede in the background.'' Bush seems to agree. Is he vulnerable? Has he slipped? Are the Democrats smelling blood? ``Well, without referring to the polls that I don't like to refer to, have them take a look,'' Bush said. ---
DOC.HEAD: EDITOR'S NOTE - Terence Hunt has covered the presidency since
DOC.TEXT: 1981 and is the AP's chief White House correspondent.

DOC.HEAD: Four-Star General Retiring After 37 Years of Service
DOC.TEXT: Gen. Maxwell Thurman, commander of the U.S. Southern Command and the field commander in charge of the 1989 invasion of Panama, is retiring, the Pentagon announced Tuesday. Thurman, 59, who was diagnosed with leukemia last July, currently is undergoing chemotherapy treatment at Johns Hopkins Oncology Center in Baltimore. The Pentagon said Lt. Gen. George A. Joulwan, 50, currently commanding general of the 5th Corps, U.S. Army Europe and the Seventh Army, has been nominated by President Bush to replace Thurman and to be promoted to the rank of general. Thurman has been commander of the U.S. Southern Command, based at Quarry Heights, Panama, since September 1989. He played a central role in drafting the invasion plan for the December 1989 invasion. The four-star general had been scheduled to take mandatory retirement in August 1989 but Defense Secretary Dick Cheney insisted he take over the Southern Command to help with the administration's struggle with Gen. Manuel Noriega's regime in Panama. A native of High Point, N.C., and a graduate of North Carolina State University at Raleigh, Thurman held numerous key Army posts, including Vice Chief of Staff and commanding general of the U.S. Army Training and Doctrine Command at Fort Monroe, Va., before taking the top spot at Southern Command. Cheney also announced Tuesday that Adm. Huntington Hardisty, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Command, is retiring after 38 years of active service. He is to be succeeded by Adm. Charles Larson, currently commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet.

DOC.HEAD: National Parks Reopen after Budget Agreement
With AM-Budget Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The silver inkstand used by signers of the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution returned to public display Tuesday after being locked up three days by a federal budget impasse. Nearby, the Liberty Bell could be touched again by visitors to Independence National Historical Park, where for three days the cracked symbol of freedom could be viewed only from a distance through windows. Visitors also returned to Valley Forge National Historical Park, Gettysburg National Military Park, the Statue of Liberty, Grand Canyon National Park, Mount Rainier National Park and other historic and recreational sites across the nation. But the emergency spending plan that allowed the sites to reopen is only effective until Oct. 19. ``We're back in business for 10 days and then we'll see what happens,'' Valley Forge superintendent Warren Beach said. ``It's not the best way to run a park.'' ``I think we're all pleased to be still employed this morning, but we've only got a 10-day reprieve,'' said Richard G. Ring, superintendent of Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area near Stroudsburg. ``We're hoping that things sort themselves out on a permanent basis for the coming fiscal year.'' The government lost its authority to spend money at 12:01 a.m. Saturday after Congress and the White House failed to agree on a spending plan for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. Non-essential services were halted during the three-day Columbus Day weekend, hitting tourist sites the hardest but keeping open the threat of broad government layoffs until early Tuesday. President Bush signed an emergency spending bill early Tuesday to keep the government operating normally through Oct. 19. By then, congressional leaders hope to work out a deficit-reducing budget that will last through next September. The inkstand is among the highlights of Independence Hall, once known as the State House of the Province of Pennsylvania, where the Declaration and the Constitution were signed. Marilyn Ritter of Gainesville, Fla., said she was moved ``almost to tears'' to see the 18th century brick building. ``We didn't think it would be open, but we were real happy it was,'' said Larry Head, of Dayton, Ohio. Head's brother, David, of Florence, Ky., said he blamed Congress for not passing budget legislation soon enough to avoid a shutdown. Asked if anyone had won his vote during the budget wrangling, he said: ``Yes, anyone new.'' At Valley Forge, the Continental Army campsite during the winter of 1777-78, Gen. George Washington's headquarters and the visitor center were open again and the interpretive and custodial staff were back, Beach said. ``The main residual problem is the tremendous amount of trash that was generated the past few days,'' the superintendent said. The park's roads and fields remained open to visitors during the warm, sunny weekend. On New York Harbor, ferries resumed hauling tourists to the Statue of Liberty and the Ellis Island immigration museum. ``It's shaping up as a typical weekday and we'll have had about 3,000 to 4,000 visitor by the end of the day,'' said Park Service spokesman Manny Strumpf. The average on a weekend is 25,000 a day, he said. The first on line for the Ellis Island ferry were two women from Portland, Ore., who flew in Monday night for a one-day visit specifically to visit the museum, Strumpf said. One said her mother was processed through Ellis Island when she emigrated from Norway, he said. National parks lost thousands of dollars in uncollected entry fees during the weekend. Grand Canyon National Park can can take in $20,000 in fees on a normal weekend day, said spokeswoman Maureen Oltrogge. ``So, I guess we could have lost $100,000 through the holiday weekend,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Official: Diplomatic Ties Possible With Albania
DOC.TEXT: The United States is moving toward renewing diplomatic ties with communist-led Albania, possibly before the end of the year, a State Department official said Tuesday. Assistant Secretary of State Raymond Seitz said discussions have been taking place since the government of Ramiz Alia announced in June that it wished to join the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe and re-establish ties with Washington. Asked at a congressional hearing if a decision on Albania could be made before the end of the year, Seitz said, ``I don't see why not.'' He said the discussions were ``moving in a positive direction.'' The ruling Communist Party maintains tight control over Albania, but Alia has said voters are to be given some freedom of choice. The party leader also has hinted at wide-ranging economic changes. The country of 3 million people has emerged from years of isolation and last month renewed diplomatic ties with the Soviet Union after a break of three decades over ideological differences. In August, three members of Congress visited Albania. In May, Alia told the first official U.S. delegation to visit the Balkan nation since 1946 that he wanted to renew ties with Washington as soon as possible.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Sworn In at Low Key Ceremony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with later cases, subbing 2nd and next-to-last grafs
DOC.TEXT: Justice David H. Souter took his seat on the Supreme Court Tuesday in a solemn, hushed ceremony that contrasted sharply with the loud debate over issues he'll help decide on the divided court. After taking an oath to ``do equal right to the poor and the rich,'' the 105th justice in U.S. history spoke briefly with reporters and then began work by sitting silently through oral arguments in four cases. ``I got to work on time this morning. I'm starting off on the right foot,'' he said outside the court building after being sworn in by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist. As cameras clicked and whirred, he said, ``Hurry and load up. I've got to go to work.'' Rehnquist told Souter, 51, ``I wish you a long and happy career in our common cause.'' Souter, whose views on most controversial topics remain largely unknown despite three days of Senate questioning, joins the court at a time when the future of legalized abortion, affirmative-action hiring laws, church-state relations and other major issues hang in the balance. Three appointments by President Reagan pushed court to the right during the 1980s, and early votes by President Bush's first appointee will be closely watched for signs of whether that trend will continue. In the audience for Souter's swearing-in were neighbors and lawyer friends from New Hampshire, where he had served as a state Supreme Court justice, White House Counsel C. Boyden Gray and members of the Senate Judiciary Committee, which recommended his confirmation. Also present was retired Justice William J. Brennan, whom Souter succeeds. Attorney General Richard Thornburgh, wearing the morning coat that is traditional for such ceremonies, presented Souter to the court. Souter wore a three-piece business suit. Rehnquist then asked the new justice if he was ready to take the oath. ``Yes, I am,'' Souter replied softly. After administering the oath, the chief justice gave his new colleague a congratulatory handshake. Then, as Souter made his way to his seat at the far left of the bench, he paused for a handshake with Justice Thurgood Marshall. It was Marshall who said, after Souter's nomination July 23, that he didn't have ``the slightest idea'' why Bush had nominated the ittle known jurist, and added, ``Never heard of him.'' At the time, Souter declined comment on Marshall's remarks. Souter said outside the court that he had preparedfor his cases on a ``catch as catch can'' basis while also lining up a place to live in Washington. He said he had signed a lease, and court sources said he would be renting an apartment in Washington. When he signed the lease, the sources quoted him as saying, he didn't know what his new salary was but was able to get by wen he put down the chief justice as a credit reference. Souter will make $118,600 a year. He was confirmed by the Senate, 90-9, after confirmation hearings that focused on how he would rule if the court had occasion to review its decision striking down state laws against abortion. He declined to say, and many abortion rights activists opposed his confirmation. His first case as a justice, however, focused on the less emotional issue of whether shareholders may sue a company over allegedly misleading proxy statements. The three other cases argued Tuesday dealt with pension disputes, payment of expert witness fees and the authority of prosecutors to exclude blacks as jurors at trials for white defendants. Six of the nine justice interrupted the lawyers to ask questions from time to time, but Souter listened in silence, often resting his head in his hands. Once, he exchanged a few words that could not be heard with Justice Antonin Scalia, who sits next to him.

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Council Moves to Curb Mayor Barry's Spending Powers
DOC.TEXT: The District of Columbia Council passed emergency legislation Tuesday to restrict Mayor Marion Barry's spending authority in his last weeks in office. Approved by voice vote were proposals to restrict Barry's ability to lease property or award construction projects for the district, and require the council to review any city contracts proposed by Barry that exceed $1 million. The temporary, 90-day statutes can take effect without the mayor's signature and will expire six days after Barry leaves office on Jan. 2. ``The fact of the matter is we just don't want the mayor to spend any money,'' said council member John Ray. ``That's the emergency.'' ``What we are seeing looks like an attempt to get a lot of things signed, sealed and delivered before Jan. 2,'' said council member Betty Ann Kane, who sponsored the bill intended to restrict the mayor's leasing authority. Barry was convicted in federal court Aug. 10 of a misdemeanor charge of cocaine possession. Before his conviction, he said he would not seek a fourth, four-year term as mayor. Barry is running as an independent for a district-wide city council seat. In recent weeks, council members have become concerned that the mayor might be using city funds to reward his friends with pay raises and contracts before he leaves office. Other members said they supported the bills to help fight the city's projected $100 million budget deficit. Documents obtained Tuesday by The Associated Press show that more than two dozen of Barry's political supporters holding city jobs have received pay raises since August. The records do not indicate that Barry himself requested the raises, but did show that they were approved by two of his top assistants. Most of those getting the raises will receive a minimum of $55,000 annually. Others employed under lucrative annual contracts were given full-time positions. That would make it difficult to remove them from office once Barry leaves as mayor. Democratic mayoral nominee Sharon Pratt Dixon has promised that if she is elected on Nov. 6, she will fire 2,000 mid-level city managers to save an estimated $95 million. The bills approved Tuesday will require council approval of all city leasing or construction contracts proposed by the mayor's office. The city spends about $40 million annually on such agreements, under authority assigned to the mayor's office. Kane's aides said the restrictions were prompted partly by Barry's announcement in June that the city will build a $20 million office building to house city officials during renovation of the city hall. Kane and others argued that the city could save money by renting exising office space. They also questioned awarding the contract to a developer who had contributed to Barry's past mayoral campaigns. Council chairman David Clarke sponsored the bill that would empower the council to review all contracts for goods and services that exceed $1 million. Previously, the council could only review proposed renewal of such contracts. ``We are in a peculiar position in this city right now that the chief executive is not answerable to the people,'' Clarke said. ``The council ... should take up that burden.''

DOC.HEAD: Shoppers Vote to Keep Junk Structure
DOC.TEXT: Residents want to junk the 60 tons of concrete and metal that decorate a suburban mall, but shoppers say it'll stay. By only three votes, a Gallup Organization survey indicated Cermak Plaza Shopping Center's clientele wanted to save ``Big Bil-Bored'' - a $25,000 pork chop-shaped sculpture that mall owner David Bermant promised to tear down if a majority of shoppers wanted it gone. ``The piece stays. I am delighted and completely astonished,'' Bermant said in a telephone interview Monday from Santa Barbara, Calif. Bermant hired Gallup to poll his shoppers after residents of the western suburb of Berwyn voted 4-1 in a March referendum to tear down the sculpture. Bermant then hired Gallup to poll his shoppers and said if a majority wanted the sculpture gone, he would destroy it. The poll of 312 shoppers in early September indicated 145 people wanted ``Big Bil-Bored'' torn down, 148 wanted it to stay and 19 were undecided. Bermant has commissioned large, unusual sculptures for five of the 20 malls he's owned nationwide. ``Spindle,'' a stack of cars impaled on a huge spike, also stands in the Cermak Plaza parking lot. ``Big Bil-Bored,'' embedded with small appliances that symbolize America's throwaway society, was erected a decade ago by artist Nancy Rubins. ``The residents want it gone,'' Berwyn Mayor Joseph J. Lanzillotti said Monday. ``I think the voters casting their ballots are a lot more reliable than his survey.'' Bermant earlier launched a public-relations campaign to save ``Big Bil-Bored,'' taking out full-page newspaper advertisements explaining the sculpture's message and mailing copies to 30,000 mall-area homes. ``I think that might have convinced people,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Nobel Descendant Announces Prizes for Environmental Achievements
DOC.TEXT: Top achievers in pressing environmental causes soon will have their own version of the Nobel Prizes, a descendant of the Swedish inventor of dynamite said. Claes Nobel, a Swedish-born resident of Milwaukee and a great-grand nephew of the founder of the Nobel Prizes, unveiled plans Monday to create Earth Prizes for environmental accomplishments. Nobel said the Earth Prizes will be in the ``same tradition and in the same spirit'' as the Nobel Prizes established by Alfred Nobel. The environmental awards will not be affiliated with the Nobel Prizes, he said. ``Let us all be inspired by the fact that each of us may bring about a small change, and that all of us together can make an enormous difference,'' Nobel said. He said seven Earth Prizes will be awarded annually in each of two levels, one for grass roots activists, the other for heads of state, world leaders, corporations and organizations. The seven categories are conservation, food, energy, pollution abatement, population, disarmament and Earth ethics. Nobel, whose foundation, United Earth, will name the winners, said the prizes will include cash awards of undetermined amounts. Seed money will come from organizers of New World's Eve, an international television telethon planned for Dec. 31. Bill Marshall, organizer of New World's Eve in Los Angeles, said plans for an annual telethon for the next 10 years involving his group and United Earth will be completed this week. The initial grassroots awards will be presented during the telethon and financed by John LaBatt's Ltd. of Canada, Marshall said. Nobel was invited to Douglasville by resident Leslie Schulten, founder and president of Project Peace Tree, an organization that works to improve East-West relations. Alfred Nobel invented dynamite in 1866 and endowed prizes for science, literature and peace. The prizes are announced every October in Stockholm. The Swedish Academy of Sciences has established prizes for sciences not endowed by Nobel, including one for ecology. A 1987 genealogy of the Nobel family lists Claes Nobel as an executive at Eweson Digester Corp., Alternatives Combustion Engineering Inc. and the Earth Aid Society.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Opposition Supporters Shave Heads in Support of Hunger Strike
DOC.TEXT: Opposition supporters shaved their heads and staged sit-ins Tuesday in support of their leader, Kim Dae-jung, who was on a hunger strike to press for democratic reforms. At least 23 members of the Party for Peace and Democracy shaved their heads in a ritual show of support at a district political office in Seoul. Hundreds of party members wearing headbands and shouting slogans also staged sit-ins at the party headquarters in Seoul and at a dozen local offices. Kim began fasting Monday with four demands - dissolution of the Defense Security Command, early implementation of local autonomy, economic reform and scrapping of plans to change the form of government from presidential to Parliamentary-Cabinet. President Roh Tae-woo and ruling party leaders appealed for a truce in the political fight, but the opposition party threatened to mount a national movement to topple Roh if the president rejected Kim's demands. In a meeting Tuesday, dissidents and opposition party leaders vowed to join forces for their anti-Roh campaign, including a major rally Saturday in Seoul. Kim spent the second day of his hunger strike at his office reading books and chatting with visitors. A 24-hour nurse assistant periodically checked his blood pressure and temperature. The latest political turmoil began last week after an Army private released classified documents he said showed the government illegally spied on more than 1,300 civilians. Roh fired his defense minister and the powerful chief of military intelligence Monday to minimize the impact of the most serious scandal since he took office in early 1988. Roh asked the opposition to settle issues through dialogue, warning that its boycott since August of the National Assembly would ``amplify political and social unrest.'' Kim demanded that Roh end ``dirty political operations aimed at harassing opposition parties.'' He said the spy allegations showed Roh's administration is ``a disguised military government.'' The hardened position of Kim, who has survived political persecution for more than 20 years, was apparently propelled by mounting public criticism of Roh and the ruling party. The scandal jolted domestic politics, which have been in limbo since August, when opposition legislators resigned from Parliament en masse charging the government with railroading bills and curtailing democratic reforms. Roh has pledged broad reforms, including an end to military intervention in politics. He captured two-thirds of the 299-member National Assembly in January by merging his party with two minor opposition groups. But his popularity has dwindled because of inflation, social disturbances and disputes within the enlarged governing party.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Sharply Reduce Growth Of Installment Credit In August
DOC.TEXT: Americans cut the growth of their installment credit in half in August, the government said Tuesday. The Federal Reserve said consumers took out a seasonally adjusted $2.1 billion more than they repaid, an increase of 3.4 percent at an annual rate over July and slightly more than the average $1.78 billion a month during the first seven months of 1990. But the growth of consumer credit slowed dramatically from a net increase of $4.73 billion, or 7.8 percent at an annual rate, during July, the Fed said. Consumer credit averaged $4.42 billion a month during 1988 and 1989, the Fed said. Consumer confidence plummeted after Iraqi tanks stormed Kuwait on Aug. 2, according to various surveys. The Conference Board, a New York-based business research group, said confidence in the U.S. economy in August dropped to its lowest level since 1983 when the nation was emerging for its last recession. ``The slower growth in August reflected a larger decline in auto loans outstanding and a smaller expansion of revolving credit than in July,'' the report said. Automobile loans continued their slide, down 7.3 percent or $1.74 billion. The sluggish automobile sector declined 1.6 percent, or $377 million, in July and 7.3 percent, or $1.76 billion, in June. Revolving, or credit card, debt rose $1.78 billion, up 10.1 percent from the previous month. But that was less than half of the 21.7 percent, or $3.78 billion, gain in July. Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate rose 10.6 percent, or $1.84 billion, after a 7.4 percent, or $1.27 billion, increase the previous month. Borrowing for mobile homes advanced 10.9 percent, or $208 million, after a 3.3 percent, or $63 million, gain in July.

DOC.HEAD: Arab World Condemns Jerusalem Killings, Extremists Seek Revenge
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Much of the Arab world bitterly condemned the killing of 19 Palestinians in Jerusalem by Israeli forces, and some extremists vowed Tuesday to exact vengeance against Israel and the United States. The killings at Jerusalem's Temple Mount - sacred to both Islam and Judaism - could drag Israel into the Persian Gulf dispute at a time when it has been trying to avoid just that. Middle East experts in Jordan expressed concern that Monday's deaths might trigger terrorist acts which could be interpreted as Iraqi-sponsored and bring the U.S.-led muliinational force and Iraq closer to war. Palestinian terrorist Abul Abbas threatened to retaliate unless the United States cuts its strategic ties with Israel. And President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said the deaths brought Israel closer to ``the abyss.'' Iraq called for U.N. action, while the radical Moslem Brotherhood in Jordan called for a Jihad, or Holy War, to liberate Palestinian land. Saddam also announced that a new Iraqi missile with a range of hundreds of miles could be launched against ``the targets of evil when the day of reckoning comes.'' President Bush said Tuesday in Washington that Israeli security forces should have acted ``with more restraint'' when they opened fire on the rioting Palestinians. ``Let me just express my strong feelings about this, my sorrow at this tragedy. It is particularly saddening because of the sanctity of the holy places. Violence shattered all this,'' Bush said. Iraq, which has been trying to rouse the Arab masses against the U.S.-led multinational force in the gulf, said the battle against the foreign presence in Saudi Arabia and Israeli occupation of Arab lands was the same struggle. Thousands of Palestinians and Jordanians took to the streets of Jordan's capital, Amman, Tuesday under a sign reading ``Mohammed and Christ came for peace, Bush and Israel came for Blood.'' In Beirut, hundreds of Palestinians burned tires around their refugee camps, while shops closed and protesters marched through the shantytowns shouting ``Stop the massacres!'' Israeli officials said the shooting started Monday after Arabs began stoning Jewish worshipers at Judaism's holiest site, the Western Wall, which is below the Temple Mount. It was the bloodiest incident in Jerusalem since the Middle East war in 1967. ``Palestinian blood will not be cheap. We will wait and see what the United States reaction will be. But our retaliation will be severe against Israel and the United States,'' said Abbas, leader of the Palestine Liberation Front and suspected mastermind of the Achille Lauro cruise ship hijacking in 1985. Abbas, at a news conference in Baghdad, set several conditions he said Washington must meet to avoid retaliation against U.S. targets. Among them were resuming its suspended dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization, suspending its alliance with Israel and not vetoing U.N. Security Council resolutions expected against Israel because of the killings. The 18-month U.S.-PLO dialogue was broken off by Bush last May after PLO leader Yasser Arafat refused U.S. demands that Abbas be punished for an abortive raid on Israel by the Palestine Liberation Front. Saddam said Tuesday that ``We, the Arabs, will not be satisfied and it will not heal the hearts which have grieved over their dearest in Palestine with anything except action.'' His speech was monitored in Nicosia. Baghdad's state-run al-Qadissiyah daily called on all Arabs to ``consider the battle against foreign intervention and that against the Zionist occupation as one.'' More than 200,000 troops were deployed in the Persian Gulf area after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. The multinational force, which is led by the United States, includes Western and Arab troops. George Habash, leader of the Popular Front For the Liberation of Palestine, said the international community that condemned the Iraqi invasion must also force implementation of U.N. Resolution 242, calling for an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied Gaza Strip and West Bank. Also condemning the Temple Mount killings were Egypt, Jordan and the PLO's executive committee. Saudi Arabia, meanwhile, accused Israel of trying to ``erase the Palestinian identity.'' Jordanian newspapers said the Temple Mount killings demonstrated the link between the gulf crisis and Israel's hold on the occupied territories. Several newspapers urged an international blockade of Israel. Jordanian police dispersed thousands of protesters who tried to march on the U.S. Embassy in Amman. The demonstrators denounced President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, President Hafez Assad of Syria and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, the three Arab leaders who have backed the U.S.-led military intervention in the gulf. Several Arab governments, including Syria, have made no official comment on the killings.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Satisfied With German Efforts Against Exports To Iraq
With AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.TEXT: U.S. officials are satisfied with German efforts to prevent illegal shipments of war materials to Iraq, a State Department official told Congress on Tuesday. Assistant Secretary of State Raymond Seitz said Germany has ``overhauled and tightened up'' its laws covering exports that might be used for the production of chemical, biological or nuclear weapons. Seitz told the House Foreign Affairs Committee that there are ``German footprints'' all over equipment that has gone to Iraq in recent years. Seitz said companies in other countries also have assisted Iraq in its production of chemical weapons and other armaments. He declined to identify those ocuntries. ``This is not exclusively a German problem,'' he said. More than 20 people working for nine German companies are suspected of helping Iraq obtain chemical weapons and other arms in the years before Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, a German government prosecutor said Tuesday. Four are in custody for investigation and three have been released on bail or for health reasons, the official said. The magazine Der Spiegel has named nearly 40 German companies it says supplied Iraq with equipment needed to produce chemical, biological, nuclear and conventional weapons in recent years. ``There is no question in my mind that the intent of the German government to get hold of this problem is very serious,'' Seitz said. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., who conducted the hearing, said the Germans appear to have ``an extraordinarily distressing record.''

DOC.HEAD: Fires Damages Homes, Threatens Endangered Bird Habitat
DOC.TEXT: Two brush fires burned out of control Tuesday in Southern California. One threatened more homes a day after fires fanned by Santa Ana wind damaged 28 houses. In Oregon, the Forest Service called in 280 firefighters to attack a forest fire threatening to roar out of a wilderness into sensitive spotted owl habitat on the Siskiyou National Forest. A 700-acre blaze in dense brush threatened homes near South Mountain, south of Santa Paula, said Ventura County fire dispatcher CeCe Grives. Three air tankers and more than 220 firefighters attacked the blaze, which began late Monday and raged uncontained 50 miles north of Los Angeles. Firefighters formed a defense line overnight to protect 20 homes from the flames near South Mountain, Grives said. No residents were evacuated. Another fire broke out Tuesday morning and raced up a brushy hill 10 miles north in the rural Mupu area of Santa Paula Canyon, blackening about 100 acres but not threatening homes, said Fire Department spokeswoman Bobbie Barker. A highway between Santa Paula and Ojai was closed in the Mupu area, Barker said. Northeasterly wind began blowing up to 15 mph early in the day. ``That's going to hamper the firefighters,'' Barker said. In Riverside and Los Angeles counties, nearly 300 acres of brush were burned and 28 homes damaged Monday by stubborn fires pushed by Santa Ana wind. A 125-acre wildfire that began in the dry Santa Ana River bottom in Riverside damaged 20 homes. In the Los Angeles suburb of Diamond Bar, a 20-acre fire badly damaged three homes and slightly damaged four. The causes of the fires were under investigation. Riverside Fire Chief Phil Clinton said arson investigators were checking reports that teen-agers were playing in the Santa Ana River area shortly before the fire. In the southwestern corner of Oregon, the Chrome fire grew to 640 acres Tuesday as it was driven by dry easterly wind. It was headed south out of the Kalmiopsis Wilderness toward areas set aside from logging to preserve sensitive plants and old growth forest habitat for spotted owls, said Forest Service spokeswoman Patty Burel. No rain was expected in the next 10 days to douse the fire, which was blamed on a runaway campfire, Burel said. Firefighters had to hike two hours through steep rugged country to reach the southern front of the fire. The fire was about three miles from the Wheeler Creek Research Natural Area, the Lemmingsworth Gulch Botanical Area, and spotted owl management areas, Burel said. The spotted owl was named a threatened species this summer because of the loss of so much of its habitat to logging.

DOC.HEAD: Crowds Tear-Gassed Outside Courtroom During Bhutto Hearing
DOC.TEXT: Stone-throwing crowds were tear-gassed by police Tuesday as they waited to see ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto when she appeared before a judge on corruption charges. Witnesses said 30 people were injured in the melee. A week earlier, supporters stormed the courtroom and injured dozens of people so security was tight Tuesday around Punjab High Court, where Ms. Bhutto went to answer charges of misconduct and abuse of power. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan on Aug. 6 dismissed Ms. Bhutto's 20-month-old government, the fifth popularly elected administration to be sacked in Pakistan's 43-year history. Ishaq Khan, whose disagreements with Ms. Bhutto were often highly publicized, cited a litany of charges, including corruption, nepotism, ineptitude and abuse of power. Ms. Bhutto says the charges are a smear campaign. ``All this is done to eliminate Benazir Bhutto, who cannot be eliminated politically,'' she said Tuesday during a break in the hearing. Ms. Bhutto is standing trial before the Lahore tribunal on charges of illegally selling federal land to a London-based company owned by her cousin and giving lucrative contracts for distribution of liquified gas to friends and relatives she said suffered during a decade of martial law. She faces two similar charges before a special tribunal in her hometown of Karachi. The three-hour hearing was adjourned Tuesday by the judgh until Oct. 16 to give Ms. Bhutto's lawyers more time to prepare their defense. Ms. Bhutto, 37, sat quietly throughout the proceedings, at times scribbling notes or toying with her orange prayer beads. Occasionally she read the Koran, Moslem's holy book. About 2,000 supporters pressed against street barricades to see Ms. Bhutto, and witnesses said police tried to force them to leave. Some angry supporters started throwing stones and bricks, and police tried to drive them away with tear gas, the witnesses said. At least 30 were hurt, the witnesses said. Some police officers blamed 30 to 40 of Ms. Bhutto's supporters for the trouble, but said they were chased away and that no one was hurt. Witnesses said police beat some supporters with cane batons and arrested others. Police refused to answer questions. Most Pakistanis, including some of Ms. Bhutto's opponents, have criticized the so-called accountability process used by the caretaker government as a blatant attempt to force the former prime minister out of politics. Most observers say the tribunals have strengthened her campaign and galvanized her party, which two months ago was showing signs of major divisions between the leadership and the rank and file.

DOC.HEAD: After the Killings, Divide Between Jews and Arabs Wide As Ever
With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: In the city's Jewish Quarter, where a forced gaiety seemed to prevail Tuesday, a bearded Israeli in a religious skullcap asked his young daughter, ``Are you having a good time? Do you want a Popsicle?'' In the neighboring Moslem Quarter, black flags flew in sympathy for the 19 Palestinians killed in a clash with police atop the Temple Mount. The violence Monday was the worst in Jerusalem since Israel captured the Arab part of the city 23 years ago, and it only appeared to deepen the chasm between Jews and Arabs. Even longtime Mayor Teddy Kollek, who has struggled for decades to unite the city, acknowledged that his goal of Jewish-Arab coexistence is a long way off. ``I still believe it will be all right someday, but it will take generations,'' he said. In the Jewish Quarter of the walled Old City, Jews continued marking the eight-day holiday of Sukkot. The Arab quarters were virtually empty, shut by a general strike marking the killings and the start of the 35th month in the Palestinian uprising. Palestinians on the streets were bitter. ``This is worse than in '67, worse than any other time,'' said one who gave his name as Adan. ``There will never be peace now with Jews.'' Monday's rioting began when Palestinians atop the Temple Mount hurled rocks at Jews praying at the Western Wall just below. About 25 people were injured by the stones, and police stormed the mosque compound, firing tear gas, rubber bullets and live ammunition. The Temple Mount is sacred to both Jews and Moslems. Because of that, both sides see themselves as under attack. Israelis are fuming at the violation of the Western Wall, the last remnant of King Herod's Second Temple and Judaism's most revered site. It is also known as the Wailing Wall. Palestinians feel they were protecting Islam following rumors that Jewish zealots, who want to rebuild the ancient temple where the Dome of the Rock and Al Aqsa mosques now stand, would march on the mount. The mount, known to Moslems as Haram es-Sharif, is Islam's third-holiest site after Mecca and Medina in Saudi Arabia. ``The seam that divides the city runs on top of the Western Wall,'' the Israeli daily Yedioth Ahronoth concluded. Michael Ben Ari, a museum curator, said coexistence has been a one-way affair. ``An Arab can walk about freely in Jewish neighborhoods, but a Jew cannot walk about any east Jerusalem neighborhood without endangering his life,'' he said. Thousands of Israelis flocked to the Western Wall on Tuesday. Ultra-Orthodox Jews, many in festive silk garb and fur hats for the holiday, shopped in the Jewish quarter. Some Israelis had pistols dangling from their hips. Many seemed oblivious to the increased patrols by riot squad police wearing flak vests and carrying submachine guns. In the Arab quarters, isolated groups of tourists shuffled down the quiet stone streets. James and Carol Collier of New York City said they had originally planned to come in September, but had postponed the trip because of the Persian Gulf crisis. ``We just decided you don't know which crisis you're going to step into, so you just go with one,'' Collier said. Across the street, Palestinian Mazen Aslan carried a stereo to the hostel where he works. ``Israeli soldiers, you know, are like children,'' he said. ``They want to be like Rambo. But we are human beings and we are not broken yet.'' Immanuel Mizrachi, an antiquities dealer in the Jewish Quarter, said Monday's violence ``just added another layer ot the hatred between Jews and Arabs, and it will take something very special to make them come together.''

DOC.HEAD: Hungarian Parliamentarians Walk Out of Romanian Senate Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic Hungarian parliamentarians walked out of Romania's Senate on Tuesday following the passage of legislation they considered discriminatory. The state news agency Rompres reported the disagreement resulted from a clause in a new law about the formation of private companies that said ``the executive or executive secretary and at least half of the leadership of commercial societies will be Romanian.'' The 12-man faction of the Democratic Union of Hungarians in Romania charged this could be interpreted as not including Romanian citizens who are not ethnic Romanians. But their proposal to explicitly extend the law to include ``Romanians of other nationalities'' was rejected. When the article was passed in its original form the 12 walked out in protest. Rompres later carried a government statement saying the article should say ``all Romanian citizens irrespective of nationality'' could head companies. But it was not clear whether the government was suggesting reworking the legislation and then voting on it anew. Sen. Zoltan Hoszu of the Democratic Union said ``it is outrageous ... to have a Romanian in charge of a company that is mostly Hungarians.'' The incident followed several days of tension between ethnic Hungarians and Romanians. On Sunday, state television reported that several Hungarians attempted to destroy a Romanian flag on a statue and were arrested in Tirgu Mures, site of bloody ethnic rioting in March that claimed six lives. In the capital, Hungarians and Romanians have been demonstrating this week before a school that was once exclusively Hungarian, with both sides charging discrimination. There are 2.5 million Hungarians in Romania, a nation of 23 million residents. Most of them are in Transylvania, the northwestern part of Romania that was controlled by Hungary for centuries.

DOC.HEAD: CNN Plans Live Coverage of Shuttle Landing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to CORRECT that NBC will air live coverage of shuttle landing only where its `Today' is still on air; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The Cable News Network will provide live coverage of Wednesday's scheduled landing of the space shuttle Discovery, network executives said Tuesday. CNN will open its live coverage with a live report at 9 a.m. EDT from the landing strip at Edwards Air Force Base in California. Then CNN will go live to cover the landing itself, scheduled for 9:57 a.m. EDT. ABC and CBS will air their regularly scheduled programs, ready to go live in the event of an emergency, officials of those networks said. NBC said it would have live coverage of the landing only on the West Coast, where its ``Today'' show would be on the air.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Former FBI Agent Guilty on All Counts in Third Espionage Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 5 grafs with more details
DOC.TEXT: Former FBI Agent Richard Miller was convicted of espionage Tuesday for a second time by a judge who rejected Miller's claim that he romanced a Soviet agent in the interest of the United States. U.S. District Judge Robert Takasugi said he concluded that Miller once intended to use his relationship with the Soviet woman, Svetlana Ogorodnikov, to enhance his position with the FBI by becoming a double agent. But the judge said that after Mrs. Ogorodnikov enticed Miller with money and sex, the agent yielded to her demands for classified information. ``In the battle of wills, Mr. Miller finally succumbed, begrudgingly perhaps,'' Takasugi said. ``He became entangled with Svetlana and compromised his position in the FBI.'' Takasugi, who presided over Miller's retrial without a jury, said the most convincing evidence was a tape recording of Miller and Mrs. Ogorodnikov in a private conversation that was recorded by the FBI. He said the tape clearly demonstrated her domination over the agent. ``The court does find Mr. Miller guilty of counts one through six,'' the judge said of the six charges that alleged espionage, conspiracy and communication of classified material for the benefit of a foreign power. Miller leaned forward on the defense table, stared straight ahead and looked surprised. Sentencing was scheduled for Jan. 1. The trial was Miller's third. The jury in his first trial deadlocked and the guilty verdict in his second trial was overturned by an appeals court on grounds that lie detector evidence was improperly admitted. As in both other trials, the defense argued that the obese, inept Miller was not the classic picture of an FBI agent and that his failings led him to try to save his career by infiltrating the Soviet KGB. The prosecutor, Assistant U.S. Attorney Adam Schiff, argued that Miller was merely a victim of his own weaknesses and that he was ultimately led to espionage by his love affair with Mrs. Ogorodnikov. ``He was fascinated with Svetlana Ogorodnikov,'' Schiff argued. ``She was exotic to him.... He went out and slept with her.''

DOC.HEAD: Famed U.S. Army Unit Bolsters Force in Saudi Arabia
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Army's 1st Cavalry Divison, whose combat history stretches from last century's frontier Indian wars to Vietnam, has begun arriving in Saudi Arabia. It is the latest addition to the mass U.S. military buildup that began after Iraq seized Kuwait on Aug. 2. Advance units of the division, based in Fort Hood, Texas, have been in the country for three weeks, and the main body of 17,000 troops is now arriving on the airlift from the United States. The division's M1 tanks, Bradley fighting vehicles, helicopters and other heavy equipment will arrive by ship over the next week, U.S. military sources said. The 1st Cav, as it is known, is the last major army unit known to be marked for assignment to Operation Desert Shield and will boost the U.S. commitment close to, if not beyond, the 200,000-man mark, the sources said. The Army's Chief of Staff, Gen. Carl E. Vuono, told reporters during a visit to army units Monday that the 1st Cav was ``flowing in,'' but he refused to discuss its deployment. The division is the fourth elite U.S. Army unit deployed in Operation Desert Shield, and it brings with it part of a fifth. The 82nd Airborne, 101st Airborne and 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, sent earlier, all have storied pasts.
