So does the 2nd Armored Division, whose ``tiger'' brigade of 3,000 troops will round out the 1st Cav as a full-sized division. The 1st Cav has served outside the United States for nearly 30 years since the end of World War II, possibly an army record. It was first organized as a division in 1921 at Fort Bliss, Texas, drawing together some units that had already earned a niche in history and remain part of the 1st Cav today. Among these are battalions of the 5th Cavalry Regiment, which fought the American Indians in the 1850s, and the 7th Cavalry, a noted Civil War regiment. It later gained notoriety under Gen. George A. Custer at the Battle of the Lttle Big Horn in 1876 when the Sioux and other Indian tribes wiped out much of his command. The 1st Cav patrolled the Mexican border in the 1920s and '30s. During World War II it retired its cavalry mounts to become infantry, and joined the 1944 campaign to recapture the Philippines from the Japanese. The division was the first unit to enter Manila, a claim it would repeat in Tokyo, and again during the Korean War when its troops were first to reach the North Korean capital of Pyongyang. After years of postwar occupation duty in Japan, the 1st Cav returned to the United States, to be called on again when hostilities escalated in Vietnam in 1965. By then it had become the army's first airmobile division, applying a then-untested concept of using helicopters instead of armored vehicles on a massive scale. The 1st Cav participated in many events that symbolized both the battlefield courage and the political controversy that marked the American role in Indochina. It relieved the siege of marines at Khe Sanh, battled Communist infiltrators along the Cambodian border and was the main force in the 1970 incursion into Cambodia to destroy North Vietnamese sanctuaries. In 1971, the 1st Cav became the last full American combat unit to withdraw from Vietnam.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Suffers Setback As Humphrey Testimony Begins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Names Hlavaty and Yawn cq.
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors suffered a setback as testimony opened Tuesday in the trial of Edward Lewis Humphrey, who is accused of beating his grandmother and is a suspect in the slayings of five college students. The judge refused to allow the prosecution to introduce as evidence police accounts of statements the grandmother, Elna Hlavaty, allegedly made the night she was battered at her home. Mrs. Hlavaty, 79, has said she can't remember what happened, and doesn't believe her grandson attacked her. Humphrey, jailed on a $1 million bond, is charged with aggravated battery in the Aug. 30 assault. The 19-year-old University of Florida freshman has been listed as a suspect in the mutilation-slayings of five students in Gainesville in late August. No one has been charged in the killings. The alleged assault on his grandmother occurred the weekend after four women students and one man student were stabbed to death in their off-campus apartments. Three of the women were mutilated and one was decapitated, authorities said. In the assault case, prosecutor Philip Williams, saying Mrs. Hlavaty was trying to protect her grandson, sought to introduce her statements to Brevard County Sheriff's Deputy Douglas C. Hammack. The deputy had answered an emergency 911 call from her home. But Brevard Circuit Judge Theron A. Yawn rejected the testimony, saying the hearsay account of her statements shouldn't be used since Mrs. Hlavaty was available as a witness. Before the ruling, Hammack told the judge out of the jury's hearing that when he found Mrs. Hlavaty, her hair was matted with blood, she was holding a bowl of ice on her face and her right eye was swollen shut. ```He hit me. I can't believe he did this to me,''' the officer quoted her as saying. When asked who did it, she replied, ``Edward.'' The prosecutor said Mrs. Hlavaty also told Hammack and an ambulance driver the attack began when Humphrey entered the house yelling, ``You're going to hell and you're going to die!'' She stated that ``the defendant picked her up, choked her and beat her about the face,'' Williams said. Humphrey was also present and covered with blood, the prosecutor said, and allegedly told the officer, ``I hit her - I'm sorry.'' Dr. Jeri Fitts, the first witness in the trial, said he examined Mrs. Hlavaty in the hospital. He said she suffered a broken facial bone under her eye and a possible broken jaw, along with numerous contusions. He denied the injuries could have been caused by a fall, as she later said, testifying it would have taken three or four blows to cause that much damage. If convicted of aggravated battery on a person over the age of 65, Humphrey would be sentenced to at least three years in prison without parole. He also faces unrelated charges of attempted rape in Indian River County and assault in Alachua County.

DOC.HEAD: Kasparov-Karpov: Bigger Than the `Nasty Boys' vs. `Killer Bs'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 5 `Who will' to fix spelling of paper, grammar. Picks up 6th pvs, `Karpov? Kasparov?'
DOC.TEXT: For Soviet sports fans, the fall classic has begun. In a nation where chess is a national pastime, the confrontation between Soviet rivals Garry Kasparov and Anatoly Karpov is far bigger than anything on the American sports scene - more colossal than Dave Stewart vs. Roger Clemens, or Cincinnati's ``Nasty Boys'' against Pittsburgh's ``Killer Bs.'' In World Series-style hype in the Soviet press, nearly every newspaper's sports section Tuesday was splashed with pre-game photos and expectations of the matchup in New York. ``Duel of the Giants Begins,'' the newspaper Lenin's Banner said in a bold headline. ``Who will be smiling at the end of the match?'' Moskovsky Komsomolets, another paper, asked the chess-mad nation. It showed the grinning visages of the bitter antagonists already likened by Kasparov himself to an American sports feud on the order of baseball's Yankees and Red Sox. ``Karpov? Kasparov? Who then?'' wondered the Vechernaya Moskva newspaper, with the large question mark inverted and wearing a crown. The outcome of Monday's first game - a draw - came too late for Tuesday morning newspapers, but Soviet television carried full details. A floating chessboard appeared on the nation's TV screens following Tuesday's midday newscast, the pieces moving by themselves. Footage of Kasparov and Karpov appeared above it, then dissolved into the words ``The World Chess Championship.'' International Grandmaster Yevgeny Vasyukov stood on a sparse set in a sweater vest and tie and spoke in soft tones. ``The attention of world chess lovers is centered on New York, where two outstanding Soviet chess players, world champion Garry Kasparovand former champion Anatoly Karpov, are playing each other in their fifth meeting,'' Vasyukov said, beginning his blow-by-blow account of Game 1. ``It was a highly dramatic match and abounded in many interesting moments,'' Vasyukov said. Then he walked in front of a large board and ``played'' the game by moving the magnetic pieces as Kasparov and Karpov had done, noting that Karpov failed to develop a slight advantage due to several wasted chances. The government newspaper Izvestia was caught up in the glitz of the festivities before the first of 24 scheduled games between Kasparov, 27, and Karpov, 39. ``Smiling broadly like great actors, they both energetically made their way up the stage of the famous hotel `Waldorf Astoria' - black tail coats, black bow ties on snow-white shirts,'' wrote correspondent Alexander Roshal. ``According to the strict request of the organizers, most famous American and foreign guest celebrities present were dressed likewise,'' he wrote. ``And ladies glittered in rich evening dresses ... in the light of a thousand candles.'' Small details of the tournament did not escape Izvestia's notice, such as 13 being Kasparov's lucky number, and how since the age of 13, he has had that many members in his entourage. Karpov decided to counter by having the same number in his party, it added. The military newspaper Krasnaya Zvezda even carried the latest on a scandal in which one of Kasparov's coaches supposedly was offered a $100,000 bribe to disclose the champion's strategies. When Kasparov coach Zurab Azmaiparashvili refused, his apartment in Tbilisi, the capital of Soviet Georgia, was burned. But Tbilisi police Maj. P. Lachkepyani said an investigation of the apartment showed only an empty liquor bottle, scraps of the newspaper Literaturnaya Rossiya, and a slightly burned front door. ``The evidence does not give cause for legal procedures,'' Lachkepyani said, calling the arson job ``amateurish.'' His conclusion? ``It was most probably a hooligan indifferent to chess but obviously eager to get some press,'' the newspaper quoted him as saying. ---= EDITOR'S NOTE: Brian Friedman is an AP correspondent in Moscow. He plans to be in his hometown of Cincinnati later this week for the conclusion of the National League playoffs.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Confer With Pacific Leaders in Hawaii
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS pvs grafs 3-4 bgng, Deputy White, with new graf giving list of invited nations; SUBS last graf pvs to identify Popadiuk.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will confer with leaders of Pacific island nations on economic and security issues during a meeting in Hawaii on Oct. 27, White House officials said Tuesday. Invitations to the Pacific leaders were cabled Monday, said Jerry Norris, executive director of the Pacific Basin Development Council. The meeting will take place during a Bush political swing through Hawaii and California. White House officials said invitations were sent to the Cook Islands, Fiji, Kiribati, Marshall Islands, Micronesia, Nauru, Nieue, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu, Vanuatu and Western Samoa. White House spokesman Roman Popadiuk said he could not confirm Norris' statement that the main topic of discussion is expected to be the proposed destruction of chemical weapons at Johnston Atoll, 800 miles from Hawaii.

DOC.HEAD: Blacks Stab Eight Whites in Rampage
DOC.TEXT: Blacks armed with knives went on a rampage Tuesday and stabbed eight whites, raising the specter of new racial violence, authorities said. About 20 young blacks stole knives from a store and began stabbing people along a street near the beach, police said. ``They were in a berserk state and were lashing out with knives at anyone who was near them,'' witness Robert Trulock told the independent South African Press Association. Two suspects were shot and wounded by police, and seven were arrested, police said. The attack may have been racially motivated, said police Lt. Nina Barkhuizen. Police were investigating the possibility that some participants wore badges of the Pan Africanist Congress, a militant black opposition group, she said. Despite deep racial divisions and widespread violence in South Africa, there have been few cases of blacks randomly attacking whites. Law and Order Minister Adriaan Vlok condemned the violence and called for private citizens to refrain from seeking revenge. ``It might be somebody trying to provoke a reaction from the white population,'' said Thabo Mbeki, a spokesman for the African National Congress. The black youths took the knives from a store specializing in weapons from the Far East, Barkhuizen said. They then ran down a street next to the beachfront and stabbed whites, witnesses said. Bleeding victims staggered into the lobby of the Lonsdale Hotel and collapsed in front of horrified guests. Eight people, ranging in age from 15 to 85, were hospitalized with stab wounds, Barkhuizen said. A hospital official said three of the white victims were in serious condition. Patrick Lekota, an ANC official in Durban, called the attack ``a desperate attempt to discredit the liberation movement as a whole.'' About 5,000 blacks have been killed in factional fighting since 1986 in Natal Province, which includes Durban. But the violence has been almost exclusively in black areas, pitting Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha movement against Xhosas and other blacks linked to the ANC. The warfare spread to black townships around Johannesburg in August, and about 800 people were killed in the ensuing weeks. Fighting in the townships has eased recently, but strained relations remain between the white-led government and ANC. ANC leader Nelson Mandela has accused security forces of fanning the violence, possibly at the behest of right-wing elements who oppose government-ANC peace talks on ending the apartheid system of racial segregation. The government has denied the charges and challenged accusers to provide proof. Vlok said Tuesday that affidavits supplied to the government purportedly backing the accusations had proved to be fabrications. Both the ANC and Inkatha oppose apartheid but differ on the shape of a future South Africa. Inkatha supports a free market economy and promotes tribalism, while the ANC promotes more leftist and pan-tribal positions.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery Homeward Bound
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 16th graf starting `The National ...' to UPDATE with latest on shuttle shuffling.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HTN1
DOC.TEXT: Discovery's astronauts, flush with success from a near perfect mission, packed up their gear Tuesday for their return to Earth while the satellite they released streaked deeper into space. The Ulysses satellite, which will study the sun, was 1.7 million miles from Earth three days into its five-year journey and hurtling through the solar system at more than 24,000 mph. Discovery was scheduled to land at 9:57 a.m. EDT Wednesday at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., to conclude NASA's first shuttle flight in almost half a year. Good weather was expected. ``This flight is probably as close to perfect as we can get,'' said flight director Ron Dittemore. The biggest problemoccurred Tuesday when a heater on one of Discovery's three auxiliary power units failed. Mission Control in Houston said a backup heater was activated and working fine. The heaters could be operated manually, if necessary. Discovery's commander, Richard N. Richards, and pilot, Robert Cabana, completed a series of tests Tuesday to make sure the shuttle's systems were ready for the fiery descent into the Earth's atmosphere. The astronauts later retracted Discovery's 50-foot-long robot arm, which was extended Sunday as part of an experiment to measure the deteriorating effects of space on an Intelsat satellite stuck in a useless low orbit. Attached to the boom is material identical to that used on the satellite's solar panels. Intelsat, an organization of countries that owns the communications satellite, will study the amount of decay and decide whether it is worth sending astronauts on a rescue mission in 1992. Scientific data to date indicates the spacecraft would be salvageable. The $157 million satellite is orbiting about 345 miles above Earth, 22,000 miles lower than intended. An unmanned rocket failed in March to boost the spacecraft to its proper altitude. Before stowing cabin gear, astronauts Bill Shepherd and Bruce Melnick ran a third and final test of an experimental voice command system. The system would allow astronauts to move shuttle TV cameras by spoken commands, freeing their hands for other tasks. Shepherd had trouble getting the system to recognize his voice on his previous attempts. He reported complete success Tuesday after recording his voice again, and speaking louder and more directly into a microphone. The crew also wrapped up an experiment involving ozone measurements in low Earth orbit. The data will be used to calibrate ozone-measuring instruments aboard weather satellites. The highlight of the four-day mission came shortly after liftoff Saturday, when the astronauts started Ulysses on its 1.86 billion-mile journey. The satellite was accelerated out of Earth orbit at 34,130 mph, the fastest speed ever for a manmade object. The $250 million European spacecraft is expected to reach Jupiter in February 1992. Ulysses will use the planet's strong gravity to sling it back through the solar system and into an unprecedented orbit over the sun's poles. It is expected to pass over the sun's south pole in 1994 and the north pole in 1995. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration, already preparing for its next shuttle flight, had to move the Columbia off the launch pad and back to the assembly building Tuesday because of bad weather expected from Tropical Storm Klaus. Columbia will remain inside until Monday, while Atlantis will be rolled out to one of the two pads on Thursday. Atlantis is due to fly next, carrying a secret military cargo into orbit in early November. The mission originally was scheduled for July, but was delayed by the shuttle's hydrogen leaks. Still to be performed are repairs to Atlantis' engine compartment, damaged slightly by a metal beam that was left there by workers. The 9-foot-long beam left about 25 dents and dings when it rattled around while the shuttle was being hoisted upright.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Tries to Contain Arab Rage After Temple Mount Shootings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with further Shamir quotes, Vatican paper denunciation, Amnesty wants inquiry. ADDS Moslem name for Mount Temple, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos JRL1,2,3
DOC.TEXT: Israel sealed the Temple Mount for a day and imposed curfews in the occupied territories Tuesday to contain Arab fury over the killing of 19 Palestinians at the hallowed site. Monday's bloodbath threatened to rekindle the Palestinian uprising and thrust Israel back into the spotlight at a time when the Persian Gulf crisis had given it a respite from international criticism of its policies. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir rebuffed suggestions for a U.N. Security Council investigation. ``We won't accept it,'' he told reporters. While large parts of the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip were under curfews and village closures, rioting erupted in three Arab districts of Jerusalem and in Nazareth, a mainly Arab city inside Israel. In Umm Tuba on Jerusalem's southern outskirts, two border policemen were stabbed with a screwdriver by Arabs they stopped at a checkpoint. As the car drove away the police fired, hitting two occupants, police said. No one was seriously hurt, police spokesman Uzi Sanduri said. Police fired tear gas to disperse dozens of activists who blocked roads in Nazareth with rocks and garbage cans, an Arab reporter said. Masked youths shouting pro-Iraqi slogans smashed a department store's windows and beat shoppers. Police seized the keys to the gates of the Temple Mount, Islam's third holiest site and known to Moslems as Haram es-Sharif, and fired tear gas at Moslems who tried to break through their cordon, an Arab reporter at the scene said. Jerusalem's chief Moslem cleric, 80-year-old Saad al-Din al-Alami, was overcome by tear gas and carried away on a stretcher and hospitalized. Moslem leaders said the keys were returned after dark to allow evening prayers. They said it was the first time Israel has sealed the Temple Mount, a compound containing the city's two main mosques. It abuts the Western Wall, also known as the Wailing Wall, and is revered by Jews as the site of their biblical temple. Moslems believe the Prophet Mohammed ascended to heaven from the site. Monday's incident was the worst in Jerusalem since Israel captured the city's Arab sector from Jordan in 1967, and was swiftly condemned by Arab leaders throughout the world. Japan, the European Community's executive body and the president of the European parliament also condemned the violence. President Bush said Israel should have acted ``with more restraint.'' Amnesty International, the international human rights organization based in London, proposed a public judicial inquiry. The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano condemned ``indiscriminate killing'' in Jerusalem and said the world is counting on new efforts to resolve the Palestinian question. The flareup came after a relative lull in the 34-month-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli rule. It began when Moslems on the Temple Mount tossed a barrage of stones onto Jews celebrating the Sukkot festival at the Western Wall below. The attack was provoked by rumors that Jewish zealots planned to march on the Mount and reclaim it for Judaism. Police assurances to the contrary were ignored. Riot squads charged into the Temple Mount compound and, according to Israeli officials, opened fire when they found themselves up against a mob of thousands. Police said about 140 Arabs were wounded, along with a half-dozen policemen and 28 Jewish civilians hit by rocks. Thirty-seven Arabs and five Jews remained hospitalized Tuesday, according to hospital officials and police. Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek accused the Arabs of ``a planned and organized provocation,'' but he also chastized Jewish zealots who lay claim to the Mount, saying they ``exacerbated the Arabs' deepest fears and angers.'' Arab activists called a weeklong protest strike in the occupied territories and a two-day shutdown in Israel's Arab towns. Israeli public reaction consisted of: -Outrage at what was seen as a planned attack by Moslem zealots on Jews praying peacefully at their holiest shrine. -Allegations that police failed to foresee the attack and take precautions that would have avoided fatalities. -Fears that the incident would distract world attention from the gulf crisis and play into the hands of Iraq's Saddam Hussein and his Palestine Liberation Organization supporters. Shamir, visiting a Jewish settlement in the West Bank, said Saddam was trying ``to turn this confrontation between Iraq and the whole world into a confrontation between Iraq and Israel.'' ``We have no interest in this and we will not help him to do this.'' But left-wing legislator Yair Tzaban argued that those making that claim should also explain why they allowed ``such an escalation on both sides.'' Shamir said ``the rioters paid a heavy price in human life . . . But this is exactly what their leaders and activists want. They place no value on human life, whether Arab or Jew.'' He said Israel would strengthen its hold in the occupied lands - ``We will remain here, establish and fortify our presence in all parts of the country, no matter how angry it makes them. This is our country, our land.'' Police began an investigation into their conduct at the Temple Mount. Police Commissioner Yaacov Terner rejected the allegations already leveled against his officers as ``simply not true.'' He said he would not let the force become ``a punching bag for all sorts of things. . . . Where we are guilty, where we are responsible, we'll take the blame.'' Jerusalem city councilor Shmuel Meir said, ``Whoever throws stones and rocks at policemen should know that he'll get what's coming to him, and he won't get home in one piece.''

DOC.HEAD: Trinidad and Tobago Prime Minister Seeks U.S. Intelligence Support
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 10th graf, bgng: ``If we xxx to include White House comment; adds byline.
DOC.TEXT: The prime minister of Trinidad and Tobago on Tuesday sought better U.S. intelligence communication following an attempted coup he contends could have been prevented by U.S.-supplied information. ``If we had the information that was in possession of certain American authorities then we would have been able to prevent this taking place,'' Prime Minister Arthur N.R. Robinson said in reference to the July 27 uprising on his Caribbean island in which he was taken hostage. However, he insisted that he was not saying the United States purposely withheld information. ``It was not an accusation,'' he said. He said ``certain authorities'' in Florida had information about one of the coup leaders procuring arms in Florida for the coup attempt. Robinson previously made similar statements. He told reporters at the White House that in his meeting with Bush they ``talked generally about collaboration and exchange of information ... in the field of containing attempts to disrupt regimes in the region.'' ``Certainly in the future we'll be seeking to be sure that there's closer collaboration so there is an easier and freer exchange of information,'' he said. Administration officials deny they had any knowledge of arms being procured in Florida for the purpose of an overthrow in Trinidad and Tobago. ``If we had we would have tried to alert them and stop it,'' one White House official said. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush congratulated Robinson and his government ``for the bravery shown in confronting the terrorists and in defending their democratic institutions.'' Bush also ``commended the prime minister for his market-oriented economic policies, his commitment to the war on drugs and for his strong statement of support for U.N. measures against Iraqi aggression,'' Fitzwater said. He said the recent extension of the Caribbean Basin Initiative was ``a sign of our firm commitment to the economic well-being of the Caribbean, and we are confident that the Enterprise for the Americas initiative will support Caribbean integration.'' In the coup, Moslem militants stormed Parliament and the government-run TV station and took Robinson hostage with about 50 other officials. The coup was suppressed after six days, during which 24 people were killed. The government has declared a state of emergency and cancelled elections scheduled for Oct. 15. No new date has been set, Robinson said. The Bureau of Alcohol Tobacco and Firearms in Miami arrested Louis Haneef of Pompano Beach, Fla., on charges of supplying weapons to the coup leaders. A spokesman has said the bureau did not know of his connection to the oup until after it occurred. Robinson was in Washington on his way home from the United Nations General Assembly session in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Radio Host Pulls Plug on Unruly Candidates
DOC.TEXT: A radio talk show host pulled the plug on two congressional candidates whose on-air discussion deteriorated into a shouting match. ``I don't know how to tell you this,'' WELI-AM's Steve Kalb told the candidates, who continued jawing into dead microphones Monday night. ``Your microphones are off, so no one can hear you.'' During the discussion, Democrat Rosa DeLauro and Republican Thomas Scott clashed repeatedly over abortion, taxes and what each described as the other's hypocrisy and mudslinging. The two candidates are vying for the House seat of Democratic Rep. Bruce Morrison, who is running for governor of Connecticut. At one point, when the discussion turned to abortion, the pro-choice DeLauro told Scott, ``I speak for women all over this country.'' ``No you don't,'' Scott said. ``Yes, I do,'' DeLauro said. ``Yes I do.'' ``You wish,'' Scott said. ``You're an extremist and a radical.'' Kalb told the candidates to pipe down so he could regain control of the ``Telephone Talk'' show, and when they didn't, he shut off their microphones. After Scott and DeLauro left, Kalb told his listeners order had been restored. ``All right folks,'' he said, ``we've cooled down the room ... turned up the air conditioner ... poured water on the microphones.''
DOC.HEAD: Rinfret Going On Television To Promote ``900'' Number
DOC.TEXT: Republican Pierre Rinfret plans to run TV ads urging viewers to call a ``900'' telephone number to raise money for his struggling campaign for governor. The TV ads, Rinfret's first, will encourage people to call in to hear a recorded message from the candidate. People will be billed $5 for the call, of which about $3 will go to the Rinfret campaign, according to Rinfret aide John Denny. Rinfret's campaign plans to promote the ``900'' number service with radio and newspaper ads as well. Rinfret is challenging Democratic Gov. Mario Cuomo. Last week, Rinfret reported that his campaign had less than $94,000 in the bank and $189,000 in unpaid bills. Cuomo, meanwhile, reported his campaign had nearly $6.1 million. Cuomo's campaign has been airing TV ads since early August.
DOC.HEAD: Poll Suggests Helms and Gantt Still Neck-and-Neck
DOC.TEXT: GOP Sen. Jesse Helms and his Democratic rival, Harvey Gantt, remain locked in a dead heat one month before Election Day, a survey of likely voters shows. The survey of 617 North Carolinians, conducted last week, asked people who they would vote for if the election were held that day. Some 43.5 percent favored Gantt, 42.7 percent said Helms, 9 percent were not sure and 4.2 percent said neither. The survey, released Monday, had a 4 percentage point margin of error. It was conducted by Independent Opinion Research and Communications for WRAL-TV and The News and Observer of Raleigh.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Official Cites Widespread Problems at B-2 Builder
DOC.TEXT: The Northrop Corp., maker of the B-2 stealth bomber, is plagued by widespread problems in its operation that federal investigators have not addressed in their inquiry, an Air Force official said Tuesday. Dismayed by what it considers Northrop's poor performance in production of several weapons, the services assistant secretary for acquisition, John Welch Jr., ordered an in-depth review of the company. Brig. Gen. Robert W. Drewes, who led the eight-man team that conducted the review, told a House panel the California-based company was beset by problems in nearly every aspect of its business. Drewes identified weaknesses in systems engineering; the transition from research and development to production; software management; subcontract management; organization and personnel; and business systems, which includes cost and schedule estimates. ``Name one Northrop program that is in good shape based on what the Air Force or taxpayers tolerate?'' Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore., asked Drewes. ``All the programs I looked at, there were some problems,'' the Air Force official said. A Northrop spokesman, who requested anonymity, said the company is taking steps to correct problems. ``We still have things to do, but the recognition by the Air Force that changes have been made and are being made is a favorable indication of the direction the company is moving,'' the spokesman said. At the Pentagon, spokesman Pete Williams told reporters that Northrop ``remains an important supplier to the United States and we will obviously look very closely at any problem we have with any contractor.'' The Air Force review examined major Northrop programs, including the B-2, the ALQ-135 radar system for the F-15 jet fighter and several classified programs. Drewes said, however, that his eight-man team did not delve into problems associated with federal investigations of Northrop. Justice Department officials told the House Energy and Commerce subcommittee on oversight and investigations in July that the California company should be barred from government business. The officials described how Northrop falsified reports on the air-launched cruise missile and conducted improper tests on the Harrier AV-8B jet. The company's action led to its guilty plea in February on 34 charges of fraud and a fine of $17 million, the largest criminal fine ever imposed on a defense contractor. Drewes told the panel he was not aware of the 34 charges against Northrop, prompting an angry response from several lawmakers. ``Do you all operate over there in a vacuum?'' asked Rep. James Slattery, D-Kan. Drewes said he avoided areas that were the subject of ongoing or completed federal investigations to avoid complicating the inquiries.

DOC.HEAD: Temperature Drops Like a Rock in Texas; Coastal Flooding in Florida
DOC.TEXT: A `blue norther' dropped the temperature 26 degrees in a half-hour Tuesday in Texas as strong wind whipped arctic air into Texas behind a cold front crossing the south-central and eastern part of the nation. Harlingen, Texas, reported wind gusts of 40 to 50 mph with the passage of the cold front. The temperature plunged from 94 degrees to 68 in about 30 minutes at Brownsville during the afternoon. Afternoon temperatures were only in the 40s and 50s across much of the south-central section of the country as well as the middle Mississippi Valley and Great Lakes region as strong northwesterly wind behind the front ushered in cold air. Temperatures dropped below freezing overnight across much of the Plateau and Rocky Mountain region. Tuesday's record low temperatures included 2 degrees at Laramie, Wyo., Tuesday's low for the Lower 48 states; 42 at Redding, Calif.; and 20 at Valentine, Neb. A freeze warning was posted into Wednesday morning for the west-central mountains and northern third of New Mexico, the Texas Panhandle, the Oklahoma Panhandle, and western and central Kansas. A frost advisory was issued for the eastern third of Kansas, eastern Nebraska, southern Minnesota and northwestern Wisconsin. Readings in the teens and single digits were reported at a few locations in Colorado and Wyoming. Showers and thunderstorms extended over coastal Texas and parts of the lower Mississippi Valley. Showers prevailed from the middle Mississippi Valley through the Ohio Valley to the lower Great Lakes region. There were showers and a few thunderstorms over southeastern Georgia and the Florida peninsula. Light rain and drizzle were over parts of New York state and northern New England. Heavier rainfall totals included an 1.38 inches at Key West, Fla., 1.17 inches at Homestead, Fla., 1.10 inches at Victoria, Texas, and 1.08 inches at Shreveport, La. Temperatures remained in the 40s and 50s overnight in much of the Northeast but dipped into the 20s and 30s from the High Plains to the upper Mississippi Valley and upper Michigan.

DOC.HEAD: With Budget Passed, Congress Turns to Tax Increases, Medicare Cuts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with Bentsen stand, inserting 2 grafs after 11th graf pvs, Democrats have
DOC.TEXT: A two-penny tax on home heating oil and a delay in unemployment benefits, two deficit-cutting proposals that drew widespread objections, are likely to be dropped from the plan about to be crafted in Congress. The impact on Medicare recipients will almost certainly be cushioned. But taxes on gasoline, tobacco and alcohol almost certainly will rise by the time Congress fills in the blanks on its $500 billion deficit reduction package. And a debate about which taxes to raise - and whether to cut the capital gains tax - will move to the front. Each proposed spending cut and tax increase will be debated intensely over the next 10 days as Congress struggles to complete the deficit accord by an Oct. 19 deadline, lawmakers involved in the effort predicted on Tuesday, ``It's going to be the equal of the struggle we've had so far,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., who has been in the middle of this year's budget negotiations. The plan will be crafted in more than a dozen congressional committees, and in a Congress where nerves have been frayed by months of grappling with the deficit. The conservative and moderate wings of the House GOP have clashed bitterly in recent weeks, and many Republicans feel wounded by what they considered rough lobbying by White House aides during last week's fight over the first budget pact. ``I'm nervous that it's made Republicans in the House less effective,'' Frenzel said. Whatever the difficulties, there is no choice but to go ahead. Agreement between President Bush and Congress on the bare bones deficit agreement ended a budget impasse early Tuesday, and led to legislation restoring the federal government's ability to operate normally. Another shutdown is threatened for Oct. 19 if there is no agreement on the fine points of the $500 billion plan to cut domestic spending, trim the military and raise taxes over five years. Some of the toughest bargaining is expected to be over taxes. Bush said for the first time Tuesday that he could accept higher tax rates on the wealthy in exchange for a cut in the capital gains tax he has long campaigned for. Democrats have long resisted the cut in the capital gains tax rate unless it was blended with higher taxes on the wealthy. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Bush had ``apparently come around to our point of view,'' and aides to Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee, said he was endorsing the changes as part of a deficit-reduction plan on which the committee was to begin working Wednesday. In past years, Bentsen had endorsed taxing capital gains - which are profits from the sale of investments - at lower rates than apply to wages. But he has opposed such a change recently because most of the benefit would go to those with incomes over $100,000 a year. Republicans also will push for renewal of expiring tax provisions that help companies that perform research and experimentation and for housing credits for low-income people. Democrats are serving notice they will seek deeper cuts in defense spending than the earlier plan envisioned. ``Is the military going to help with the burden sharing or not?'' asked liberal Rep. George Miller, D-Calif. For their part, Republicans are expected to fight elsewhere for the deepest spending cuts possible, and the most modest tax increases. Congressional negotiators will be building on the remains of a deficit-reduction plan that was rejected last week in the House. ``Obviously, we're trying to get to where we don't hit the average-income people so much,'' said Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee. Two items that prompted objections from House members last week are expected t be excluded from the final package, according to lawmakers and aides who spoke on condition of anonymity. One would have placed a 2-cent-per-gallon tax on home-heating oil, and was vociferously opposed by lawmakers from Northern states. The other would have required states to delay unemployment benefits for two weeks, an idea that drew cries from legislators from states where the economy is soft. There is a general agreement that Medicare, which provides health care for the elderly and handicapped, will end up taking a major hit. The pact that Bush and congressional leaders had agreed to would have slated Medicare for $60 billion in savings, half of it coming from reduced benefits and higher costs for participants. Lawmakers say the new package will probably reduce those cuts to the $40 billion to $45 billion range, with most of the savings coming from reduced payments to doctors and hospitals. Likely to remain in the plan are higher taxes on gasoline, alcohol and tobacco, although the amounts are up for grabs. The reason for them remaining - they were merely minor irritants when the House rejected the measure. ``On the floor, they weren't much of a problem,'' said Rep. Rod Chandler, R-Wash., a member of the House Ways and Means Committee. ``Why do something for an area that wasn't much of a problem.''' The rejected pact would have boosted the 9-cent-per-gallon gasoline tax by 12 cents and raised the 3-cent-per-bottle tax on wine to about 25 cents. It would have added 8 cents to the 16 cent tax on a pack of cigarettes, and brought the 16-cent tax on beer six-packs to 36 cents. The new plan contains other broad categories of cuts that lawmakers will have to assign to specific programs. Agriculture stands to lose $13 billion over the next five years, federal retirees are due an $8 billion reduction, and the Guarantee Student Loan programs is bracing for a $2 billion cut. Defense is another question. The budget pact seemed to call for about $10 billion in military reductions next year, bringing defense spending to about $296 billion. But liberals say they would like to chop more out of Pentagon spending.

DOC.HEAD: Depleted Swedish Academy Prepares to Award Literary Prize
DOC.TEXT: The Swedish Academy, depleted by the resignation of three members and under fire for some of its past selections, will announce the Nobel Prize in literature Thursday. The academy has refused to accept last year's resignations of Lars Gyllensten, Kerstin Ekman and Werner Aspenstrom, saying members are named for life, and academy prestige would be shattered if anyone were allowed to resign. None of the three took part in this year's deliberations, and it is unclear whether their presence would have changed the decision. Gyllensten, 69, who had been with the 18-member academy for 23 years, and Ms. Ekman, at 57 its youngest member, quit to protest the organization's reaction to Iranian death threats against British author Salman Rushdie. They said the academy's general statement, condemning censorship without referring specifically to Rushdie, was weak and politically motivated. With them, the 204-year-old institution lost one of its most knowledgeable members and one of only two women. Author Aspenstrom, 71, said his reasons for resigning were different, but indicated support for a stronger statement on the Rushdie case. ``The Rushdie-case was the last drop, but the crevice in trust had been deepening for some years,'' Gyllensten said as the academy made its final decision on who will win the 4 million kronor ($704,000) prize. Ms. Ekman said that if the more conservative majority continued to regard expression of new opinions as a challenge to its power, ``the old institution'' would become sterile. Gyllensten has said the academy should become more active in the issues being debated in modern literary circles. The academy has been pressured for years to award the prize to a woman. Six female laureates have been chosen since the prize was first awarded in 1901 under an endowment from Alfred Nobel, the Swedish inventor of dynamite. Swedish-German writer Nelly Sachs was the last woman winner, in 1966. Nobel specified in his 1896 will that the prizes should be awarded with no regard to nationality. The most frequent criticism of the academy, however, has been that it focused on the accomplishments of Western European and North American writers. The academy took steps in the last two decades to draw attention to authors who write for a limited language group, but drew fire for that, too. It selected an Arab-language writer, Naguib Mahfouz, for the first time in 1988. Critics then noted that no Chinese writer has ever been chosen, despite China's 3,000-year-old literary tradition. The academy says it never considers politics. Its citations for Mahfouz and for last year's winner, Spaniard Camilo Jose Cela, draw attention, however, to works their governments had banned. British author Anthony Burgess has complained that the prize is awarded on the strength of a single book, although the academy says it is for the author's body of work. ``It is inevitably one novel that sticks in the jury's collective brain,'' Burgess wrote in a magazine article this month. ``The wrong novel has consistently been chosen.'' King Gustav III founded the academy in 1786 to protect and promote Swedish language and literature. It has maintained a tradition of grandeur and secrecy behind the 18th-century walls of the Stock Exchange building in Stockholm's Old Town. Caj Lundgren, culture editor at the Svenska Dagbladet daily, said the academy ``has always been the target of criticism, simply because it's an ancient type of institution. ``It has been criticized for being old-fashioned and stiff-legged and some may take . . . (the rift) as a kind of proof for this. Others see it as a sign of life that members actually protest and ask to leave.''

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Call Sexual Harassment Common at Naval Academy
DOC.TEXT: Sexual harassment of female students at the Naval Academy is widespread, and some victims don't complain openly for fear of reprisal, according to an internal academy report released Tuesday. ``In such a climate it is not surprising that some midshipmen have lost the ability to distinguish a blatant incident of sexual harassment from routine pranks,'' it said. The report by a seven-member panel of academy faculty, military staff and midshipmen said immediate action is needed to correct the conditions allowing mistreatment of women. ``Most midshipmen readily acknowledge women midshipmen are not accepted as equals in the (academy),'' said the report by the academy's Women Midshipmen Study Group. ``This lack of acceptance has created an environment in which steady, low-level sexual harassment passes as normal operating procedure in company areas and classrooms alike.'' The report was one of several special inquiries prompted by a hazing incident at the academy last December in which a female student was handcuffed by male midshipmen to a urinal as other men jeered and took photographs. The woman, Gwen M. Dreyer, a second-year student, resigned from the academy last May, citing her humiliation and anger at the way the academy responded to it. The Navy on Tuesday released copies of the internal report as well as other studies that were reviewed by a special committee appointed by the academy's Board of Visitors. The committee was comprised of Board Chairman James M. Cannon, Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md.; Rep. Helen D. Bentley, R-Md., and other outsiders. Mrs. Mikulski issued a statement urging swift action to correct conditions at the Annapolis institution. ``There is a real and continuing problem at the U.S. Naval Academy,'' she said. ``Women are neither accepted as equals nor treated with respect. The Annapolis administration - from the top down - must act swiftly and decisively to end this harassment.'' Mrs. Mikulski said she was troubled by the investigators' finding that a vocal minority of midshipmen, officers, staff and graduates believe women should not be midshipmen. ``This attitude is antiquated, unrealistic and unacceptable,'' she said. At the Pentagon, Navy Secretary H. Lawrence Garrett III said ``prompt action will be forthcoming'' to address the concerns raised by the inquiry reports. ``I am confident that as the result of these exhaustive studies, necessary corrective actions will enable the Naval Academy to build on its impressive 145-year history with a renewed sense of purpose and mission,'' Garrett said in a written statement. In its own report, the Board of Visitors special committee offered a series of recommendations for improving the treatment of female students, including adoption of a ``zero tolerance policy to end all forms of discrimination.'' The panel also recommended imposing severe punishment for sexual harassment, sexual discrimination and hazing. It should be made more clear to academy students that they will be kicked out if they are found to have engaged in such violations of academy policy, the panel said.

DOC.HEAD: List of Week's TV Shows Ratings

DOC.HEAD: Magazine: Woman Spy Most Serious Case Ever
DOC.TEXT: A woman accused of counter-espionage for the former East German government had access to top-level intelligence reports and could represent the most serious infiltration by a foreign agent, a magazine reported Tuesday. The Hamburg-based Stern magazine identified the woman only as ``Gabriele G.,'' 47, and said she had worked since 1973 in the former West German intelligence service's headquarters in Pullach near Munich, where secret reports were regularly prepared. They included weekly intelligence summaries for Chancellor Helmut Kohl. The woman was arrested Sept. 30 following a tip from the former East German secret police, the magazine reported. The report quoted security experts as saying the woman's activities were far more serious than the 1974 case of spy Guenter Guillaume, who worked as a top aide for former Chancellor Willy Brandt. Revelations that Guillaume was an East German agent forced Brandt's resignation. Also Tuesday, German television reported there was another serious espionage case in the Federal Office for the Defense of the Constitution, but did not provide details. Stern said the woman apparently began working for the East German secret police in 1968 when she completed her political science doctorate and paid a visit to East Germany. The magazine said the suspect routinely made copies of the secret reports and gave them to the Stasi, the name of the East German intelligence service. ``For the investigators the only question that remains open is whether former (East German) state security chief Erich Mielke received the West German intelligence service report to read before or after Helmut Kohl,'' Stern said. Excerpts from the report, which will appear in Stern's Thursday editions, were provided early to some news media. A spokesman for the chief federal prosecutor's office in Karlsruhe confirmed a Stern report that the office had sought the arrest of ``Gabriele G.'' on suspicion of high treason, which carries a maximum sentence of life in prison. ``However, the investigating judge issuing the arrest warrant reduced that to `secret agent activities,' '' spokesman Hans-Juergen Foerster said. Foerster said the investigation against the suspect is continuing, and that it is still not clear what level of charges would be filed. ``But we do see it as a very grave case,'' the spokesman said. Retired U.S. Army Sgt. Clyde Lee Conrad has been the only spy sentenced to life in prison by a West German court since World War II. Conrad was convicted in June of passing military secrets to Hungary and Czechoslovakia from 1975 to 1985 in return for $1.2 million. Foerster declined to comment on the other case reported by the ARD television network on its evening news program, but said that his office was likely to make a statement on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Lennon, Not Lenin, On Minds of Soviet Youth for Birthday Bash
With AM-Lennon-50th
DOC.TEXT: On the spot where Lenin once spoke, the focus Tuesday was on Lennon. Official newspapers, which once denounced the Beatles as harmful pests from the decadent West, joined a worldwide celebration and ran stories of tribute about the late John Lennon, who would have turned 50 on Tuesday. State radio broadcast his music and interviews about him. Two concerts devoted to the songwriter, guitarist and singer, who was shot to death in 1980, were held in Moscow. Even the staid state television program ``Vremya'' got into act. An anchorman, more accustomed to reading official government news, reported on the worldwide Lennon birthday bash and called his song ``Imagine,'' an ``anthem of peace.'' The broadcast ended with an instrumental version of ``Yesterday'' playing as temperatures from around the nation rolled across the screen. The celebration was a dramatic turnabout from Soviet authorities' repression of Beatles fans and supression of their music in earlier times. Their music was banned and the Soviet press condemned them. A 1964 article, for instance, commented, ``These bugs can swiftly ignite the very darkest and primitive passions.'' About 1,000 Soviets, mostly second generation Beatles fans, flocked to the Moscow Electrical Lamp Factory's cultural hall in northeastern part of the city to rejoice in Lennon's music. A plaque outside the hall reminded Beatles fans that Lennon's near namesake, Vladimir Lenin, the founder of the Soviet state, had spoken at the spot in 1917 and 1919. Inside, fans listened to recordings of Lennon's music, attended a concert of about a dozen Soviet rock bands, bought his albums and posters and reflected on his life. ``He's like a hero, a symbol for every person: a symbol of honesty, talent, devotion to his ideals, notion of love, equality between people and goodness,'' said Irina Dykomkina, the 21-year-old secretary of the Sgt. Pepper's Club, a Soviet Beatles fan club formed two years ago. Lennon's music, she said, crosses borders easily. ``His music is so sincere, it's so understandable, even to people who don't know English. They feel the music.'' Andrei Trushkin, a correspondent for Komsomolskaya Pravda - the Communist Party youth newspaper that devoted a full page Tuesday to Lennon - said he appeals to Soviet youth in part because he was a rebel, like many of them, and was a ``difficult teen-ager.'' ``The cops would have locked him up many times,'' said Trushkin, who helped organize the concert. Tuesday's concert opened in the spirit of a birthday party. Balloons floated down from the balconies as a tape of Lennon's song, ``Starting Over,'' played. The stage was adorned with a painting of Lennon and life-size cardboard cutouts of the Fab Four in front of the British flag. ``Oorah! Oorah!'' shouted the audience, which included a few soldiers in uniform. Onstage, the groups Sprint, Quiet Hour and Optimal Variant played in Beatles style but were joined by a group that didn't quite fit in the genre, an American-style country ensemble that wore plaid vests and performed ``Night Train to Memphis.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Pushing for Consulates in Soviet States
DOC.TEXT: The State Department is looking into setting up consulates in Soviet republics where strong independence movements have emerged and expects to have an office in Kiev within a few weeks, an official said Tuesday. Each office would likely mean a new Soviet consulate in an American city outside Washington because the Soviet Foreign Affairs Ministry would insist on reciprocity, said Assistant Secretary of State Raymond Seitz. A Soviet consulate is to be opened in New York when the Kiev office is approved, he said. Consuls are officials who represent their government on all kinds of affairs not connected with the diplomatic, government-to-government dialogue - for example, issuing travel visas, replacing lost passports or finding lawyers for those arrested. They are generally supervised by the embassy in the capital. ``This is an idea whose time has come,'' Seitz told the House Foreign Affairs Committee. ``We're considering recognizing that there are now centers that are taking on their own characteristics in the Soviet Union and that a presence there would be helpful and interesting from our point of view,'' Seitz said. Seitz said that no formal talks are under way to establish other consulates, but the idea has been raised in ``a very informal manner.'' The Soviets currently have an embassy in Washington, a mission to the United Nations in New York and a consulate in San Francisco. The United States has a Moscow embassy and a consulate in Leningrad. The Kiev office would be in the heart of the Ukraine, which recently has declared its residents immune from conscription into the Soviet military. Seitz said six months ago the Ukraine was one of the last regions analysts expected to show a break-away spirit. He said U.S. officials have been trying to set up a consular office there for more than 10 years. ``My guess is that if all of these trends continue for the next three or four years, we will see a Soviet Union almost unrecognizable from the one that we have become familiar with,'' Seitz said. He said conditions vary for each of the union's constituent republics but now ``each of them has declared a degree of a kind of sovereignty.'' U.S. officials have regular contact with leaders of the 15 Soviet republics whenever they can have access to them, he said. Seitz said if consulates are set up in leading regional cities, they would likely be only small offices of two or three people without any classified operations. He said consulates could be established in the Baltic states, among others. The United States has never formally recognized the 1940 Soviet annexations of independent Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia, and still accredits diplomats representing the last independent governments at legations and consulates in the United States. Seitz said conditions in Lithuania after the republic's leaders declared independence from the central government earlier this year seems to have ``passed the crisis point.'' A trade embargo by Moscow has been lifted and dialogue has begun, Seitz noted. Asked about reports that Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev is losing control, Seitz noted that the Soviet leader has acquired new decree-making powers and added, ``It becomes a regular event to speculate about Mr. Gorbachev's future before each grand challenges that he faces, and after each grand challenge he emerges with his political authority intact.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Says She's Been Threatened, Won't Campaign in Boyd County
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES word `there' from lead because governor hasn't said where the threat originated; SUBS 5th graf pvs, `Mrs. Orr...,' with two grafs to CLARIFY that threat is believed linked to dispute over nuclear waste disposal site. Pick up 6th graf pvs, `There are...
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Kay Orr said Tuesday she won't campaign for re-election in a county bitterly divided over a proposed radioactive waste warehouse because her life has been threatened. Boyd County, a sparsely populated ranching area on the state's northern edge, has been in turmoil since officials began considering it as a possible home for low-level radioactive waste from five states. A rancher who opposes the plan is on a hunger strike. The Nebraska State Patrol said a letter was received in early August ``that contained some implied threats.'' Patrol spokesman Jeff Hanson declined to release any further details, saying the matter was under investigation. Hanson said the letter lacked some elements needed before authorities could charge anyone with making terroristic threats. Orr spokesman Doug Parrott said he understands that the threat is related to the nuclear waste dispute. Mrs. Orr said she knows who made the threat but wouldn't disclose the name. She said she had hoped the situation in Boyd County wouldn't deteriorate to the point of threats. ``There are a lot of things that you consider when you step into a public office,'' Mrs. Orr said. ``I think most of it was pretty well understood by Bill (her husband) and me. ``It's dismaying to think that we have gotten to this point that people lose faith and confidence in their government.'' The proposed waste site lies about two miles outside Butte, a village of about 500 people. Supporters have welcomed the money the dump may bring. Opponents have said they fear accidents and long-term effects of the radioactive waste. US Ecology, a waste site developer chosen by the Central Interstate Low-Level Radioactive Waste Compact Commission, has applied to the state for permits to build the waste warehouse. The reinforced concrete warehouse near the South Dakota border would hold waste from the five states that make up the commission: Nebraska, Arkansas, Louisiana, Oklahoma and Kansas. Democratic gubernatorial candidate Ben Nelson's campaign manager, Sonny Foster, said it was the first he had heard of any threat against Mrs. Orr. He said it had ``absolutely nothing'' to do with the Nelson campaign. ``I think that I can say on the behalf of Ben Nelson that we don't feel that threatening people is part of the political process and there's no way that Ben Nelson would ever condone that kind of activity,'' Foster said. Nelson has visited Boyd County and has said that he is concerned about the diisions in the community, Foster said. One rancher who opposes the waste site has been on a hunger strike for more than three weeks. Lowell Fisher of Spencer, who said Tuesday he had lost 29 pounds since his fast began on Sept. 17, said he didn't believe the threat against Mrs. Orr was a serious one. ``I think it's stupid but if you have enough people who are emotionally upset, they say something,'' Fisher said. Fisher said he intends to continue his water-only diet until the governor tells the waste compact commission that the community objects to the waste site or holds a special election to see if there is. An aide to the governor has said Mrs. Orr lacks the power to call such an election and noted that the village board has supported the waste site plans.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Claims Creation of Adam Contains Hidden Picture
LaserPhoto planned.
DOC.TEXT: Michelangelo's ``Creation of Adam'' painted on the ceiling of the Vatican's Sistine Chapel contains an image misunderstood for 478 years - a huge brain that symbolizes God bestowing intellect on man, a doctor says. The fresco, completed in 1512 for Pope Julius II, shows Adam and God reaching toward one another, arms outstretched, fingers almost touching. Many scholars have interpreted the painting to mean God bestowed life on man. But Frank Lynn Meshberger, a doctor at St. John's Medical Center in Anderson, Ind., says Adam's eyes are already open, suggesting he's alive. He contends Michelangelo intended the painting to portray God giving man the gift of intellect. ``Look at the image that surrounds God and the angels,'' Meshberger wrote in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``This image is the shape of a brain.'' One art historian was skeptical. ``Holy mackerel! I never heard tell of such a thing,'' said Olan Rand, a professor of art at Northwestern University in Evanston. ``I always thought it was a cloak,'' Rand said Tuesday. ``I'd better go look at it again.'' Meshberger said his conclusion is obvious - particularly if you studied a picture of the fresco following classes on dissecting a human brain. He had just finished dissecting and drawing a brain in a medical school class in 1969 when he happened across a three-page fold-out photo of the painting in a magazine. Meshberger said he waited 20 years to publish an article on it because he was busy establishing himself as a doctor and had little time to do research on Michelangelo's background. ``As a medical student, I was quite busy and, at the time, thought it was an interesting observation but didn't have time to look into it,'' he said. Meshberger said that when he began researching the question years later, he learned that Michelangelo had deep religious beliefs and used to dissect cadavers to study the human form for his art. Other art lovers might have reached the same conclusion before this century except they didn't have the benefit of the clear images seen in modern photography, Meshberger said. He also said artists who would have had access to the painting generally weren't skilled in anatomy. He plans to give a lecture on his theory at a two-day science reporters conference in Boston this week and expects doctors attending to debate his interpretation.

DOC.HEAD: Klaus Ends With Whimper
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Klaus ended with a whimper off Florida's Atlantic coast Tuesday, causing no damage but bringing welcome rain to the drought-parched state. Klaus ran into a low pressure area over Cuba and tore apart, pulling its top wind speed down to no more than 35 mph, said Bob Sheets, director of the National Hurricane Center. At the same time, Tropical Storm Lili in the mid Atlantic weakened and lost its center and rotation, although it still had high wind. It was reclassified a nontropical storm front, the hurricane center said. Klaus left six dead and more than 500 homeless on the island of Martinique during its trek through the Caribbean, and briefly was classified as a minimal hurricane. But other than coastal erosion and blustery weather that left beaches treacherous, the system's effect on the United States was expected to be positive. ``The good news is it's going to bring a lot of rain over Florida,'' said Sheets. The state has suffered two years of drought, and while rain has returned to normal in some parts of Florida, the water supply is still so low that even Klaus' remnants are not expected to end the shortage, said Ann Overton, spokeswoman for the South Florida Water Management District. By the last hurricane center advisory at noon EDT Tuesday, the depression left by Klaus was centered near 24.0 north latitude and 76.0 west longitude, or about 115 miles southeast of Nassau in the Bahamas. It was heading west-northwest at about 15 mph and was expected to continue on that course.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
Court Refuses To Consider Pricing Dispute Involving Natural Gas Pipelines
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court refused Tuesday to hear an appeal of a lower court ruling that a federal plan for natural gas pipeline companies to recover lost revenues is illegal. Federal regulators must now devise a new plan for pipeline companies to recover millions of dollars in losses dating back nearly a decade. Retail natural gas prices in some areas may increase, while elsewhere they could be unaffected or decline slightly depending on the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission's new cost recovery plan, industry experts said. The issue involves attempts by natural gas pipeline companies to charge customers - often utilities - for costs incurred in the late 1970s and early '80s when gas supplies fluctuated dramatically and pipelines were tied into binding contracts that required them to buy gas they no longer needed. The pipeline companies are trying to regain more than $3.5 billion by imposing surcharges under a complex recovery plan approved by the FERC. That plan, however, was found to be illegal by a federal appeals court. A spokeswoman for FERC said the agency would have no comment on the court decision except to say that staff members were trying to work out a new cost recovery plan as directed by the appeals court. ``We are disappointed by the Supreme Court's denial (of the petition),'' said Jerald Halvorsen, president of the Interstate Natural Gas Association, which represents natural gas pipeline companies. Many of the pipeline companies had welcomed the FERC recovery plan as a way to assure at least partial recovery of the costs they incurred during the early 1980s. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia had said in a case involving the Tennessee Gas Pipeline Co. that the company's surcharge under the FERC plan amounted to a retroactive rate increase and was illegal. The case involved only Tennessee Gas, but is expected to serve as a precedent in other cases involving pipelines, industry experts said. Tennessee gas has sought the recovery of about $300 million, attorneys familiar with the case said. The surcharges imposed by Tennessee Gas had been challenged by a number of utilities and another pipeline, the Columbia Gas Transmission Corp., which buys gas from Tennessee Gas and sells it to utilities. They argued that they were required under the FERC formula to assume too much of the cost-recovery burden, while other utilities were paying no surcharge. Columbia Gas serves utilities across much of the Mid-Atlantic states into New England and as far west as Ohio and Kentucky.

DOC.HEAD: Four More Officers Blast KGB Influence
DOC.TEXT: Four more senior KGB officers have leveled public charges of corruption and favoritism in the intelligence service, according to the independent Interfax news service. The allegations, following similar charges by former KGB Gen. Oleg Kalugin, come as the national parliament is considering legislation to ban all police, military and KGB employees from membership and involvement with the Communist Party. Interfax said the four issued an open letter to the public and lawmakers saying that ``without a cardinal reorganization of the KGB there can be no positive changes in Soviet life because state security bodies remain an armed unit of the party.'' The letter demanded ``depolitization in the army, the KGB, the Interior Ministry and their law enforcement bodies, speedy adoption after a broad national debate of laws on state security ... and the subordination of judicial authorities only to law.'' The letter was signed by Maj. Valery Bulychyov, Maj. Sergei Voronin, Lt. Col. Alexander Kichikhin and Lt. Col. Vladimir Morozov, said Interfax. It did not say when the letter was dated. Lawmakers debated wording of a bill Tuesday that says law enforcement officers should ``be guided in their official activities by the requirements of law and shall not be held bound by the decisions of parties or mass public movements of which they are members.'' Kalugin, who has retired, has won a seat in parliament since his statements earlier this year blasting the KGB. He also has filed a lawsuit against the agency's directors.

DOC.HEAD: Air Canada to Lay Off 12 Percent of Workforce
DOC.TEXT: Air Canada will lay off 2,800 of its 23,000 employees and cut routes to Europe and the Far East because of rising fuel costs and the recession, unions representing the workers said Tuesday. Customer service workers - which include baggage handlers - will be hardest hit, losing 990 people across Canada, or 25 percent of their workforce, said the sources, who requested anonymity. The unions said company officials told them the layoffs would include 225 pilots, 440 flight attendants, 350 maintenance workers, 425 ticket agents and 265 members of the management and clerical staff. Dates for the layoffs and severance packages were not immediately known. Flights to Athens, Greece; Lisbon, Portugal; and Madrid, Spain, as well as Bombay, India, and Singapore will be cut and the airline will sell some aircraft and close its Halifax, Nova Scotia, maintenance base. Canada, with 25 million residents, has been hit in recent months by rising interest rates as well as increased costs for fuel in the aftermath of the Iraqi invasion Aug. 2 of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Governor Makes Opponent's Divorce Dispute A Campaign Issue
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Rudy Perpich, who bristles at news stories about his own family, says his opponent's dispute over child-support payments is fair political game because his rival lacks a record in public office. The Democratic governor said Tuesday he has no intention of backing off from his strategy. Republican challenger Jon Grunseth says it amounts to character assassination. ``I have a public record and he doesn't,'' said Perpich, who has held office for 30 of the last 34 years, including a record 10-year stint as governor. ``What he does as a private citizen reflects on what he'll do, I think, as governor,'' Perpich said of his campaign references to Grunseth's court battles with his former wife over child support. ``So I'm saying ... he wasn't meeting his family obligations, his first family. It took four court orders.'' Grunseth said much of his dispute with his first wife stems from his decision to withhold $50 a month from his $1,700 monthly maintenance payments to protest her refusal to remove their daughter from the Minneapolis Children's Theatre School, where a sex abuse scandal had surfaced. The governor said Grunseth invited the close scrutiny by saying during a debate in August with his primary opponents that ``my life is an open book.'' Perpich said he is not trying to make a campaign issue out of Grunseth being divorced. ``There's a lot of people who are divorced, even my own brother,'' he said. In 1974, the last time he ran for office, Grunseth made a bid for a U.S. House seat, but came up short with 45 percent of the vote. Grunseth, a 44-year-old businessman, said he deeply resents Perpich's attempts to publicize his court dispute with his first wife. Grunseth was divorced in 1983 and remarried in 1984. ``I think that he's engaging in willful and deliberate character assassination,'' Grunseth said. Perpich supporters also have claimed Grunseth was late on several property tax payments over a 16-year period. But Grunseth aides say he wasn't responsible fr most of the delinquencies. Charles Backstrom, a political science professor at the University of Minnesota for 30 years, said he can't recall a gubernatorial campaign where so much attention has been devoted to a candidate's personal life. The governor has objected strongly in the past to news stories focusing on his family. Late last year, angered by a newspaper article that suggested they family lived in too grand a style, Perpich and his wife, Lola, proposed selling the governor's mansion and giving the proceeds to the homeless. Next, Perpich turned in his leased Lincoln Town Car after a television reporter called it a limousine. Then, after a newspaper reported that the State Patrol had given his daughter rides to concerts, stores and her office, he canceled his bodyguard. In the current campaign, Perpich also has called for Grunseth to release copies of his income tax returns for the past several years as Perpich has done. Grunseth has refused, but offered to release a summary of his returns if Perpich agreed to five regional debates. Perpich said he would not participate in two of three scheduled debates until Grunseth releases his tax returns.

DOC.HEAD: Former Cabinet Member Says European Community Shirked Gulf Role
DOC.TEXT: A former Cabinet minister who resigned after likening the European Community to Hitler said Tuesday that member nations neglected their responsibilities in Persian Gulf crisis because they are ``obsessed'' with closer political union. ``Some member states did not want to get involved in the international force; many were tardy in their response to it,'' said former Trade and Industry Secretary Nicholas Ridley at the annual conference of the governing Conservative Party. ``It shows that many on the Continent remain obsessed by political union, neglecting their responsibilities toward the rest of the world,'' he said. Earlier, party chairman Kenneth Baker opened the four-day conference by saying Britain had proved itself America's most loyal ally in the gulf. ``We are not a nation that shirks its duty ... that forsakes its friends,'' Baker told the 5,000 delegates who gathered in a seafront convention center under tight security prompted by fears of an Irish Republican Army attack. ``In our long history, we've had to take up burdens which others have found too heavy,'' added Baker. ``And when an old ally and friend, the United States of America, calls for our help they do not call in vain.'' Britain, the first Western U.S. ally to send units to the gulf after Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, projects its force in the gulf could reach 15,000 troops. Ridley, a member of Parliament and close associate of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, reiterated the anti-German overtones of his remarks in July, when he accused Germany of pushing EC monetary union as a means of dominating Europe and said giving up Britain's sovereignty would be like surrendering to the Nazis. He said Tuesday that a single currency for the European Community ``would be a disaster.'' ``The history of Western Europe cannot be belied,'' said Ridley. ``Germany has always striven, first to unite German-speaking people and then to build up its strength, which tends to dominate the western half of the Continent.'' Baker and other Cabinet ministers defended the government's decision last week to link the pound to the community's other major currencies. The move fulfilled Britain's obligation to the first stage of a plan for economic and monetary union. European Commission President Jacques Delors has expressed fears that Britain will still attempt to block the proposed final stages, including a single currency and one central banking system. In addition to Britain, EC members include Belgium, Denmark, France, Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Spain and Portugal. As the Conservative Party meetings began, sharpshooters were posted on the roof of the convention center and truckloads of police reinforcements rolled through Bournemouth, about 100 miles southwest of London. Fears of an IRA assassination attempt on Mrs. Thatcher have grown since the group killed a close Thatcher political associate in a July car bombing and attempted to kill a government minister by planting a bomb at London conference last month. The IRA, which is fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland, exploded a bomb in the hotel where Mrs. Thatcher was staying during the 1984 Conservative conference, killing five people. The Conservative government, which has trailed Labor in opinion poll ratings for more than a year, seeks to lower interest rates and inflation - now 10.6 percent - before the next election. On Monday, the government lowered interest rates one point to 14 percent. Mrs. Thatcher must call an election by mid-1992. But she may do so next year if inflation and interest rates fall.

DOC.HEAD: Houston Firm Reaches Agreement To Develop Hotel In Moscow
DOC.TEXT: Muscovites might one day visit a Soviet version of the hotel President Bush officially calls home. A Soviet-born entrepreneur who lives in Houston says he has reached agreement with Moscow city officials to develop a 300-room Houstonian Hotel, with health center, about two miles from the Kremlin. The project would be named the Houstonian because Soviets tend to associate quality with anything from the United States, Alex Genin said Monday. Many Soviet citizens are familiar with Houston because of NASA's Johnson Space Center, he said. President Bush lists the Texas Houstonian, not the White House, as his official address. And Genin, managing director of Eastern Credit Limited, said Soviet tourism officials recently visited Houston's Houstonian Hotel and liked it. The land and buildings would be owned by the government and leased to the hotel operators for 50 years, Genin said. The business would be a joint venture between the Soviet government and Eastern Credit.

DOC.HEAD: Greenpeace Complains Soviets Holding Ship, Crew
DOC.TEXT: Greenpeace complained Tuesday that Soviet officials were ignoring their requests about the fate of 34 activists and a ship seized by the KGB near a Soviet nuclear weapons test site. Those seized Monday included four activists who were last seen heading toward the test site at Novaya Zemlya in the Barents Sea, said Rebecca Johnson, spokeswoman for the world environmentalist organization in London. Greenpeace identified the four as Ted Wood of Hollywood, Calif.; Jorn Haye of Germany; Jeane Ni Ghormain of Ireland; and Bjoern Okern of Norway. ``We are being stonewalled by the Soviet authorities,'' Ms. Johnson said. ``Their refusal to answer to the status of our ship parallels their refusal to talk about nuclear testing.' The ship, with 28 Western activists and six Soviets aboard, had permission to tour the Soviet arctic, Greenpeace said. Soviet officials have not commented since Monday, when the official Tass news agency said a Coast Guard icebreaker, under command of the KGB intelligence service, fired across the bow of the motor vessel Greenpeace off Novaya Zemlya and seized the craft. Tass said the ship would be taken to the Kola Gulf for an inquiry, but gave no details about the crew. They were seized just after the four were dispatched to the island to trek several miles to the test site, which Greenpeace asserts is being used despite Soviet assures of a unilateral moratorium on weapons tests. The four carried radios and radiation detection equipment to try to document the tests and protest against them, Ms. Johnson said. She said Greenpeace representatives met Tuesday in Moscow with Soviet officials, including a KGB press officer, but got no answers. On Monday, Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov said the vessel was detained for ``deliberate violation of the state border of the U.S.S.R., failure to obey border authorities, landing people at unpermitted places and an attempt to enter an area closed to navigation.'' Before communications with the ship were lost, Greenpeace activist Steve Shallhorn said from Oslo, Norway, that about 15 border guards had boarded the 190-foot, Dutch-registered vessel. He said the icebreaker threatened to fire on the Greenpeace ship, which was about four miles from the two-island group. Ms. Johnson, who is international test ban coordinator for Greenpeace in London, said, ``We informed the Soviets early on that we were sending people ashore.'' ``Our expectation is that everyone is in fact safe but we want communication back with the ship so we can verify that,'' she said. She said Greenpeace planned to ask the U.S., British, Dutch and German governments for help.
