The Soviets had told Greenpeace to steer clear of Novaya Zemlya, which is about 370 miles from Norway and was a primary Soviet nuclear test site from 1958 to 1963. Environmental groups claim it was last used in 1988. On Tuesday, a member of the parliament of the Russian Federation, the largest Soviet republic, demanded that authorities investigate plans to test nuclear devices at Novaya Zemlya, the independent news agency Interfax reported.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Suspends Embassy Operations in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: Poland announced Tuesday that it has been forced to temporarily ``suspend activity'' of its embassy in Kuwait after a cutoff of water, electricity and telephones made normal operations impossible. Although the embassy has shut down, a Foreign Ministry statement stressed that Poland continues to condemn the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and does not recognize Iraq's claims to have annexed the oil-rich kingdom. The lone Polish diplomat in Kuwait, charge d'affaires Janusz Dworak, left the country on Saturday, the state PAP news agency reported.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Backs Away From Possible Tax-Rate Trade
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs; editing at bottom to shorten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush appeared to open the door Tuesday to higher income taxes on the wealthy as part of a budget compromise but later abandoned that strategy under pressure from Republican senators, senators and officials said. The quick turnabout came after Bush met with GOP senators and was told not to try to trade lower capital gains taxes, which he wants, for higher income taxes on the wealthiest Americans, which Democrats want. Bush initially voiced a new readiness to bargain with congressional Democrats on the long-divisive tax issue after signing a temporary spending bill that ended a three-day government shutdown. The agreement gives Congress until Oct. 19 to come up with a new $500 billion, five-year deficit-reduction package. At a morning news conference, Bush had said - for the first time - he could accept higher income taxes on affluent taxpayers ``at some level'' ifit were coupled with a reduction in capital-gains taxes. However, Republican leaders warned Bush away from that idea. After a late-afternoon meeting between Bush and GOP lawmakers, Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., said, ``We all put up our hands and said, `no deal on (tax) rates at all.' He (Bush) just acquiesced in it.'' Capital gains, which are profits from the sale of assets such as houses or corporate stock, currently are taxed at the same rate as ordinary income. The administration has argued that a lower tax rate would stimulate the economy; Democrats have countered that most of the benefits would go to the wealthy. Although he declined to discuss details at the news conference, Bush had clearly indicated he could support a compromise coupling higher taxes on the wealthiest Americans in exchange for the cut in capital-gains tax rates that he has long sought. ``That's on the table. That's been talked about. And if it's proper, if it can be worked in proper balance between the capital gains rate and income tax changes, fine,'' Bush said. But later, Republican leaders said they cautioned Bush against pursuing such a trade, suggesting Democrats would never agree to drop capital-gains taxe rates low enough to make the bargain worthwhile. ``The president agreed. Our uniform position was that we will not go up on the (income tax) rates, no matter what,'' said Packwood, the senior Republican on the Senate Finance Committee. He said Bush asked the Senate GOP leaders at the meeting if they would hold fast to such a position. ``And to the man, in the room, every single person said we will support that,'' Packwood said. ``Stop trying to buy us off with capital gains. We're not going to change that summit agreement,'' said Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska, at a remark directed at Democrats. A senior administration official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said that Bush told the GOP leaders that he did not want to raise the marginal tax rate - that is, the tax rate on the last extra dollar of income, sometimes called the ``tax bracket'' - if he couldn't get a capital gains rate cut at ``an acceptable level.'' The marginal rate for the wealthiest Americans is 28 percent. ``These guys said, 'you're not going to get it' and he (Bush) said, 'fine, we don't need either one of them. ... there's nothing in it for us,''' the official said. ``Basically what they told him was you're not going to get the kind of capital gains (cut) you want. The president said he didn't want to raise the rates and the conclusion was to forget all of it - capital gains and the change in the top rate.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, earlier hailed Bush's seeming turnabout. ``I have personally advocated (an increased tax rate) on those making more than $200,000 a year for some time. And I'm pleased that the president has now come around, or apparently come around, to our point of view and to recognize fairness of such a change,'' Mitchell said. And aides to Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee, said he would ask the panel to accept the idea. Bush promised to do ``everything in my power'' to make sure Congress comes up with a five-year deficit reduction package that matches the $500 billion goal of an earlier package supported by the president and congressional leaders but rejected in the House. Bush also apologized to ``the valiant federal work force'' and others inconvenienced by a three-day government shutdown and continuing budget uncertainty. After vetoing an earlier stopgap spending bill on Saturday, Bush gave his early morning signature to a new temporary spending bill that keeps the government operating until Oct. 19 while Congress tries to come up with the budget accord. The president's signature, just hours before the bulk of the government's 2.4 million work force was to return from a three-day holiday weekend, averted a widespread disruption in government services. The government's authority to spend money expired at 12:01 a.m. Saturday. However, the impact of the shutdown was largely confined to museums, monuments and other federal institutions open on weekends. Bush said he signed the new measure while vetoing the first one because both chambers subsequently had passed a framework budget agreement. However, Congress now must fill in gaping blanks in the agreement. ``On Saturday morning, I said we cannot have business as usual. But the Congress has finally acted and we are back on course,'' Bush told a news conference at the White House. He told the news conference he was ``open minded'' about coupling a lower capital-gains tax with ending the current tax-code anomaly under which some Americans pay a 33 percent marginal income tax rate while even wealthier ones pay only a 28 percent rate. In the past, the administration has never publicly supported proposals to end this so-called tax ``bubble'' by raising the top rate to 33 percent. A proposal to trade off capital gains and the top tax rate is currently being advanced by some Democratic leaders, including House Ways and Means Chairman Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., and Senate Finance Chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas. The now-repudiated budget agreement backed by Bush would have raised excise taxes on gasoline, cigarettes and liquor and certain luxury items but would not have affected income tax rates.

DOC.HEAD: Youths Set Fires in Lyon for Fourth Night of Disturbances
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf on where most of immigrants are from.
DOC.TEXT: Youths late Tuesday torched a tobacco shop and a store in the shopping center of a low-income suburb in the fourth straight night of unrest, but police said the situation was under control. A group of youths made a protective chain around firemen putting out the blazes in the shopping complex at Vaulx-en-Velin, a heavily immigrant community east of Lyon, the police said. The situation was far from that of the previous three nights when hundreds of stone-throwing rioting youths set fire to 20 buildings and burned two dozen cars. Police used tear gas to keep them at bay. The youths protecting firemen told reporters they were seeking an end to the violence and wanted ``outside troublemakers out.'' About 700 police were deployed in the community outside Lyon after rioting started Saturday night, centered in the low-income complex known as Mas du Taureau. The rioting was triggered by the death earlier Saturday of Thomas Claudio, 21, a passenger on a motorcycle that collided with a police patrol car. Police claim the motorcycle's driver panicked and lost control of the vehicle when he saw the patrol car. But the driver, Laurent Assebille, said police caused the accident by stopping their car suddenly in his path. Local officials, along with the youths, blamed police for the unrest, claiming they routinely harrassed youthful residents with ``humiliating'' identity checks. Social Affairs Minister Claude Evin, visiting Vaulx-en-Velin on Tuesday, met with local officials and called for a dialogue between youth and police. Premier Michel Rocard said the problem stemmed partly from a lack of communication between different social sectors in France. Hubert Prevot, the government official in charge of immigration, said the ``susceptibility'' of the youth was ``understandable'' even if it was ``not reasonable.'' In 1981, Lyon's heavily immigrant blue-collar suburbs were the scene of the worst riots in France in recent times. Most of Lyon's immigrants are from southern Europe and North Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Two Schools Ban Slap Bracelets
DOC.TEXT: The hippest fashion accessory for kids, the ``Slap Wrap'' bracelet, has been banned at two public elementary schools on the grounds that their sharp edges could cause injury. When slapped against the wrist, the low-budget bracelet grabs on and wraps around to become an instant wristband. It's a flat, 9-inch long steel spring resembling a ruler wrapped in eye-grabbing neon fabric. Principal Joseph Longobardi said Tuesday he was prohibiting his pupils at Colonial and Siwanoy schools from wearing them during school hours because if the fabric wears away, a sharp edge can be exposed and lacerate hands and arms. But Gene Murtha, president of Main Street Toy of Simsbury, Conn., which makes ``The Original Slap Wrap'' and sells it for $2.49, said his product hasn't caused any injuries. He blamed cheap imitations made in Taiwan and illegally sold in the United States for reported injuries. ``The metal is inferior, low-grade caliber steel with poor quality fabric,'' he said. ``The sealing is also inferior. The steel can either break through or snap through and cause injury.'' Murtha said his bracelets are made of high-grade steel with rounded rather than sharp edges and a double-knit fabric that is tightly sealed. He claimed the cheap products were pirated and legal action is difficult, but cease-and-desist letters against the illegal products have been issued nationwide and seizures of them by U.S. Customs have also begun. Longobardi, who is principal of two of the four elementary schools in the Pelham school district, sent a letter to parents last week advising them of the possible dangers and asked them to keep the pop toy at home. ``I have four kids of my own,'' Longobardi said. ``I know how popular these things are. ... But the possibility of injury does exist because of that sharp cutting edge.'' Longobardi said he decided to ban the toy after hearing of injuries in the West Orchard Elementary School in nearby Chappaqua. Officials there said a pupil who had removed the material covering required three stitches in her hand after she was cut with an exposed bracelet edge. West Orchard's principal, Dr. Frederick Wilhelm, ordered his teachers to confiscate any slap bracelets missing the fabric cover, but did not impose a broad ban. Main Street Toy has shipped out nearly 1 million of its bracelets since the fad started this summer.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Fails To Remove Judge in 2 Live Crew Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-10, bgn `A six-member ...' to UPDATE with day's proceedings ending.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH4
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors in the obscenity trial of bawdy rap group 2 Live Crew failed Tuesday to have the judge dismissed because a defense lawyer was her law professor 15 years ago. Luther Campbell, Chris Wongwon and Mark Ross face misdemeanor charges stemming from a June 11 adults-only performance at a nightclub in nearby Hollywood. If convicted, the Miami-based rappers could be sentenced to up to a year in jail and fined $1,000. The first two days of the trial have been devoted largely to motions and and challenges over jury selection. Defense attorney Bruce Rogow challenged Broward County's voter-based jury pool as unconstitutional in cases that depend on community standards, like obscenity. But Broward County Judge June Johnson said she wanted to see the whole 70-person pool before ruling on the defense motion. Prosecutors on Monday asked the judge to step down, noting that Rogow taught her law at nearby Nova University in the mid-1970s. Johnson refused, saying she lost touch with Rogow after the class. Prosecutors appealed the decision before Circuit Judge George Brescher, but he denied the challenge Tuesday, saying the motion lacked a required document and was filed too late. ``I think what the state has done is try to interfere with this case getting to trial,'' Rogow said. ``This was utterly frivolous and I think in bad taste.'' Rogow also represented Charles Freeman, a black record store owner convicted of obscenity last week by an all-white jury for selling the group's album, ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' A six-member panel is to be chosen from 70 prospects requested by the judge. No jurors had been selected by the end of Tuesday's session, although about 25 had been questioned. Jury selection is expected to take several days. Only three of 25 potential jurors questioned Monday were black, and potential jurors interviewed by early Tuesday afternoon included three blacks. Music by the black group is aimed principally at a young black audience. Jury composition is particularly sensitive because obscenity cases are decided on the basis of how the panel defines community standards. The album, which U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez earlier ruled obscene, has sold about 2 million copies. Most obscenity cases are argued on the U.S. Supreme Court's Miller v. California test. Essentially, it holds that material is obscene if the average person, applying contemporary local community standards, would find that it is designed to cause sexual arousal, if it depicts sex in a patently offensive way, and if, taken as a whole, it lacks serious literary, artistic, political or scientific value. Campbell, the leader of 2 Live Crew, told reporters he was unhappy with the way jury selection was going. ``I need young people and black people,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Donated Corpses Spoil While State Waits For New Embalmer
DOC.TEXT: A staff freeze that has prevented the hiring of a new state embalmer has forced the state to cremate about a dozen human bodies donated for research. Ronald Wade, administrator of the Maryland Anatomy Board, said the bodies were too deteriorated to be used in studies. A hiring freeze Gov. William Donald Schaefer imposed to deal with a budget crisis has kept Wade from hiring a replacement for the board's previous embalmer, who suffered a heart attack last month. Wade has run the operation alone while the state considers an exemption to the hiring freeze. The Anatomy Board receives unclaimed and donated bodies and prepares them for use by medical and dental schools, as well as hospital training programs. The board receives about 65 corpses a month and expects almost 800 this year.

DOC.HEAD: Arrests Reopen Emotionally Charged Case Poles Never Thought Closed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to ADD comment on arrests at campaign rally, television appearance by former interior minister, CLARIFY role of fourth department. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Charges that two former police generals ordered the murder of a Solidarity priest are the first major prosecution of Poland's old guard and officially reopen a case most Poles never considered closed. The arrests in the case of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko come six years after the crime that shocked the nation, and at the outset of a presidential race in which Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's careful treatment of former Communists is being challenged by Lech Walesa. On Monday, authorities also disclosed that a former interior minister and six other officials have been accused of taking bribes of gold and jewelry dating to 1971. ``In cases of clear crimes, party people will be punished. If proven, these people will be condemned,'' Aleksander Smolar, a senior adviser to Mazowiecki, told an American Society of Newspaper Editors delegation Tuesday. At a Walesa campaign rally in Warsaw on Tuesday, a spectator challenged the timing of the arrests ``right now before the elections,'' scheduled for Nov. 25. But Smolar said there was absolutely ``no political calculation'' in the arrests, which he said were ordered by independent courts. He said there would be no departure from the government's basic policy ``that our evolution to democracy should be as peaceful as possible, trying to reconcile the two parts of Poland,'' rather than waging a ``cold civil war'' against former Communists. Smolar said he recognized that the prosecutions of former police officials would prove popular because of ``the feeling of bitterness and injustice'' after 45 years of communism. ``There is a need of a clear moral condemnation, everybody needs it for a sort of catharsis,'' Smolar said. However, he added, most Poles understand the wisdom of avoiding purges. Those Interior Ministry records that survived destruction - the Mazowiecki government did not take steps to prevent the burning of documents - will not be opened to show who cooperated with the secret police, Smolar said. ``It is extremely dangerous and destroys the nation to judge people for their weaknesses ... in very harsh times, when only heroes were able to survive with dignity,'' he said. The 1984 kidnapping and murder of the 37-year-old Popieluszko, whose body was pulled from a river, gave a martyr to the then-underground Solidarity movement the Communists were trying to crush. Many Polish households still display photographs of the priest that were put up during the 1980s as a sign of protest. Four secret policemen from the Interior Ministry's Fourth Department, the unit responsible for spying on the Roman Catholic Church and clergy, were tried and convicted in Popieluszko's death. Two have been paroled. But no involvement was found on the part of higher authorities - a conclusion that satisfied few and came to symbolize ruthless communism. ``Something unprecedented has happened,'' Jerzy Jachowicz, an expert on the security services, wrote of the arrests Tuesday in a front-page Gazeta Wyborcza commentary. The two generals, former Deputy Interior Minister Wladyslaw Ciaston and Zenon Platek, former head of the Fourth Department, were charged with plotting the priest's slaying during September and October 1984 and directing the Oct. 19, 1984 killing, officials said. Prosecutors said the corruption charges were unrelated to the killing. But among those arrested was onetime Interior Minister Miroslaw Milewski, a former Communist Party Politburo member who was Central Committee secretary in charge of internal affairs when Popieluszko was murdered. After the slaying, Milewski was quietly dismissed. Milewski was given the party posts after being replaced as interior minister by Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak in 1981, during Solidarity's first legal period. Kiszczak, a Communist holdover in the Solidarity government until he resigned last summer, told Polish television in September that he believed the priest's killers could not have acted ``without the inspiration of someone standing higher then them.'' He suggested the crime was committed by those aiming to destabilize the ``reform-oriented'' Communist government of then-party leader Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, now the outgoing president. On Polish television Tuesday, Kiszczak said he believes Ciaston and Platek, who worked for him, are innocent. He said the corruption charges against Milewski were investigated in May 1984 and a ``thorough report'' was given to superiors, but he did not elaborate. The Popieluszko case was reopened July 24, three weeks after Kiszczak's resignation, by the Office for the Protection of the State, the smaller and tightly controlled agency that replaced the disbanded secret police. The arrests made since Thursday open a ``new chapter in the case,'' the government daily Rzeczpospolita said. ``The direct perpetrators of a crime were already judged. ... However, unanswered questions still remain,'' the newspaper said. The corruption inquiry, which also targets two unidentified other generals and two colonels, involves acceptance of bribes of ``great value, including many kilograms of gold and jewelry,'' Prosecutor General Aleksander Herzog said. The alleged crimes span the period from 1971, when Milewski was a deputy interior minister, to 1981, Herzog said.

DOC.HEAD: Justices Order Court to Reconsider Libel Suit Against ABC
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 8th graf: ``The 1987,'' to clarify that there were two broadcasts, in 1984 and 1987
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Tuesday revived a $4 billion libel suit in which a millionaire inventor says an ABC television program falsely portrayed him as a liar and hypocrite. The justices told a federal appeals court to restudy Arthur Jones' suit against American Broadcasting Companies over a 1987 report by the ``20-20'' TV program about the fate of 63 baby elephants Jones rescued from death in Africa. The justices said the case should be reconsidered in light of their ruling last June that the Constitution's guarantee of free speech did not ``create a wholesale defamation exemption for anything that might be labeled opinion.'' The June decision, however, did not strip away constitutional immunity for pure expressions of opinion that cannot be proved true or false. Jones, the inventor of Nautilus exercise machines, was the subject of the ``20-20'' broadcast in 1984 - the year he airlifted the 63 elephants from Zimbabwe to the Ocala, Fla., farm he calls Jumbolair. The elephants had been marked for death as part of a culling, or herd thinning, operation. The elephants lived on Jones' Ocala estate until the summer of 1986, when the herd began to be dispersed. The 1987 report aired by ``20-20'' looked back at the 1984 broadcast and was preceded by a comment by host Barbara Walters that it would discuss ``the fate o some baby elephants to whom a promise was not kept.'' According to Jones' suit, that comment and others contained in the report ``falsely cast him as a liar and a hypocrite, and accused him of animal cruelty.'' Lower courts dismissed the suit, ruling that the sued-over comment were not defamatory or were expressions of opinion, not fact.

DOC.HEAD: At Least 1 Dead as New Clashes Break Out Over Nicaragua Land
DOC.TEXT: The latest in a series of violent land disputes has left at least one peasant dead and several others injured, officials said Tuesday. Frank Cesar, spokesman for the Interior Ministry, said Caroos Eurarios died Monday in a shootout when police tried to dislodge peasants from a private farm they had seized near Yasica Sur, 75 miles north of the capital. Police Capt. Mario Medina, deputy chief of national police in the region, said a policeman named Edwin Cisne also died in the shootout, although Cesar said the death had not yet been confirmed. The officials said about 12 police tried to evict 30 peasant families led by former Contra guerrillas from a private farm. Cesar said at least four other people were wounded, but ``information up to this moment is confused and we are investigating further.'' About 20,000 Contra rebels were demobilized in June after the Sandinista government they had opposed was defeated at the polls. But the end of the civil war has led to a series of local conflicts involving former rebels of the U.S.-backed group demanding land. At least four peasants died and eight were wounded last week when pro-Sandinista peasants battled with ex-rebels over land in the northern province of Matagalpa. In a similar incident Monday, a group of peasants destroyed a car owned by farmer Eduardo Callejas when he tried to recover land confiscated in 1980 by the Sandinistas, who turned it into a cooperative for 50 families. Former rebel chief Israel Galeano said Tuesday over state Radio Nicaragua that the government should form regional commissions to solve the problem. He said members of the ruling United National Opposition and the Sandinistas ``are acting irresponsibly to incite peasants from both sides to take lands.''

DOC.HEAD: Tax Bubble Explained
With AM-Budget
DOC.TEXT: Discussions of higher taxes on the wealthy in exchange for lower taxes on capital gains have focused on an oddity in the federal tax code, the so-called ``bubble'' that finds rates in the top tax bracket lower than in the bracket immediately before it. The marginal tax rate - the tax rate paid on each extra dollar of income - is different in each tax bracket. Currently, single taxpayers face a marginal rate of 15 percent on adjusted gross income - income after deductions and exemptions - from zero up to $18,500. For incomes between $18,500 and $44,900, the marginal tax rate is 28 percent, and it is 33 percent between $44,900 and $93,130. But it drops back to 28 percent again above $93,130. For married taxpayers filing joint returns, the marginal rate is 15 percent up to $30,950, 28 percent from $30,950 to $74,850, 33 percent from $74,850 to $155,320, and 28 percent again above $155,320. The ``bubble'' is not an accident. Congressional tax writers installed in the 1986 overhaul of federal income taxes to keep the average tax rate from ever rising above 28 percent, no matter how large the income.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Awarded $150 on Court Claim that Prom Date Stood Her Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf pvs, `Neither Ms....,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with comment from defendant's father.
DOC.TEXT: A girl has won her court battle to show up the guy who was a no-show for the high school prom. Now all Wendy Collins has to do is collect $150 from David Schlosser, who she said stood her up for the dance at University High School. Pima County Justice Court Judge Robert Gibson on Friday ordered Schlosser to reimburse Ms. Collins the $150 she spent for a dress, shoes and accessories for her would-be date. Ms. Collins sued Schlosser in Small Claims Court. He did not respond to the claim, so the award was automatic. The defendant's father, Dr. Harry Schlosser, said his son was on active duty with the Air Force National Guard when the court summons arrived by certified mail in June. He said his son, now a student at the University of Arizona in Tucson, never received notice of a date for trial or notice for a default date. He said his son told him he had heard through school friends before the prom that Ms. Collins, then a sophomore, did not want to go to the prom with him after all. Ms. Collins phone number is unlisted.

DOC.HEAD: Mexican Attorney General Claims Largest Cocaine Seizure Ever
DOC.TEXT: The attorney general announced Tuesday that police had seized more than six tons of Colombian cocaine base, the largest such confiscation in Mexican history. Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo said Colombia's notorious Medellin cocaine cartel was trying to smuggle the drug through southern Mexico into the United States. Alvarez said police learned of a shipment of Colombian drugs in Guatemala and traced it to the El Retiro ranch, 50 miles northwest of the Guatemalan border. Federal anti-narcotics police fanned out around the ranch at midnight Friday and advanced on foot through the swampy surroundings, Alvarez said. The drug traffickers spotted the police and in a 90-minute gunbattle one policeman was injured. The officers returned again at daybreak to find the area abandoned, but discovered several guns and 172 half-buried bags and three metal drums of cocaine base. Alvarez said the haul totaled 12,760 pounds of 96 percent pure cocaine base. He described the bust as ``the largest in the history of our country.'' ``It has been possible to determine that this drug is the property of the Medellin Cartel,'' the attorney general said. ``At this time, one person has been detained for investigation and it is hoped that soon the participants will be detected and detained.'' Alvarez said police found blood stains at the ranch, indicating somebody had been injured in the shootout.

DOC.HEAD: Air Canada to Lay Off 12 Percent of Work Force
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new layoff figures, dates from airline, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Air Canada will lay off 2,900 of its 3,000 employees and cut routes to Europe and the Far East because of rising fuel costs and the recession, the airline announced Tuesday. Customer service workers - which include baggage handlers, mechanics and ramp workers - will be hardest hit, losing about 1,390 people across Canada. The Montreal-based carrier also said cuts will include 220 pilots, 440 flight attendants, 425 ticket agents, 265 members of the management and clerical staff, and various personnel from other departments. Earlier Tuesday, union officials estimated 2,800 workers would be laid off. Most of the cuts would be made by Jan. 31, said Claude Taylor, Air Canada chairman. The layoffs in management would likely be completed by mid-1991. ``The passenger market is well down this year and fuel costs are driving us to raise our prices,'' he said. Canada, with 25 million residents, has been hit in recent months by rising interest rates as well as increased costs for fuel in the aftermath of the Iraqi invasion Aug. 2 of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Illegal Ivory Workshops Raided in Zambia
DOC.TEXT: Zambia's state anti-corruption commission said Tuesday it raided three illegal ivory workshops, breaking a link in a smuggling chain. Two owners of the Zairean-run workshops in Lusaka were arrested, said Paul Russell, the commission operation's director. The third owner escaped. Russell said police seized meat carvers and electric sanders used to cut elephant tusks into small pieces for smuggling out of the country. The workshops, believed to employ people mainly from neighboring Zaire, were the first such hideouts found in Zambia, Russell said. Also Tuesday, the commission arrested two police officers and a hotel employee for transporting poached elephant tusks in police and civilian vehicles. Zimbabwe has frequently accused senior figures in Zambian political and business life of funding cross-border poaching forays for valuable rhino horn and ivory. Zambia's own rhino and elephant herds have been decimated by poaching and lax conservation policies in the past decade. Early this year, Zambia formed a group of paramilitary rangers to combat illegal hunters and investigate poaching networks. In August, the armed game rangers seized the tusks of 63 elephants found in a poachers' hideout in a nature reserve 361 miles south of Lusaka. Western diplomats in Lusaka have said the ivory is smuggled to South Africa and Swaziland before going on to Hong Kong.

DOC.HEAD: Trophy Arrives for Fastest Atlantic Crossing by Passenger Ship
DOC.TEXT: A much-coveted trophy for the fastest crossing of the Atlantic by a passenger vessel arrived Tuesday from the United States after an American company decided to drop its challenge to the record. Three months ago, a ``SeaCat'' catamaran built and owned by the British company, Hoverspeed Ltd., set a record of 3 days, 7 hours and 54 minutes for the 2,740-mile crossing from Cape Cod, Mass., to Bishop's Rock. The crossing by the Hoverspeed Great Britain beat the previous record by 2{ hours. The previous record holders, U.S. Lines Inc., questioned the new record and objected to the revolutionary design of the British craft. For a while, it seemed the dispute would be taken to court. ``We got the best legal advice and the conditions of the trust are quite clear,'' said Commander Michael Ranker, secretary of the trustees for the Blue Riband award. ``In the end I think the Americans decided they did not have a leg to stand on and could not afford protracted litigation,'' he said. The U.S. company released the trophy on Thursday and it arrived at Heathrow Airport early Tuesday. The award, represented by the Hales Trophy since 1935, has not been held by the British for 38 years. It will be presented by the Blue Riband trustees to the SeaCat owners in a few weeks. The Hales Trophy was last won by the SS United States of the U.S. Lines Inc. in 1952. It had recently been on exhibit in a Long Island, N.Y., museum. The onyx and silver trophy, presented in 1935 by Harold Hales, a member of Parliament, stands near 4 feet high and is worth about $475,000.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Robert Kennedy to Marry
LaserPhoto WX30
DOC.TEXT: Victoria Anne Strauss, a student at the University of Virginia Law School, will marry fellow student Matthew Maxwell Taylor Kennedy, son of the late Robert Kennedy. A wedding announcement was distributed Tuesday by the office of the groom's uncle, Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. Miss Strauss is the daughter of Benjamin Strauss of Haverford, Pa., chairman of The Pep Boys auto supply stores, and Bonnie Strauss Gould of Los Angeles, a television journalist. The bride is a 1987 graduate of Wesleyan University. The groom is a 1988 graduate of Harvard College. He is the ninth of 11 children of Robert and Ethel Kennedy. His father served as attorney general and senator from New York.

DOC.HEAD: Police to Take Target Practice at Roosting Pigeons
DOC.TEXT: Police on the graveyard shift will soon practice their marksmanship on roosting pigeons. Acting on orders of the City Council, officers with air guns will make occasional pigon-control forays, said Police Chief Dave Gilbert said Monday. ``There was no easy solution,'' said Councilman Bill Massengale, who headed a committee named to resolve downtown merchants' complaints about the messy birds. ``We have a serious problem. The pigeons have to be killed.'' Last year, the council chose to organize a team of sharpshooters and hold a pigeon shoot-out on the city streets, using standard firearms and ammunition. But the tactic met with criticism from several citizens who have since organized into a local humane society chapter. ``I hope the members of the humane society realize that we're trying to do what's best for the people who work downtown,'' Massengale said.

DOC.HEAD: Psychiatrist Testifies Surrogate-Baby Bond is Paramount
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `A judge ...,' with one graf to CORRECT that testimony to continue Wednesday. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `Mark and ...'
DOC.TEXT: A psychiatrist testified Tuesday that the motherly bond should be paramount in a custody battle over an infant that a surrogate mother agreed to carry for a childless couple for $10,000. A judge was to continue hearing testimony Wednesday about who should get custody of the three-week-old boy. Mark and Crispina Calvert, who hired Anna Johnson to bear their baby and supplied the sperm and egg, have temporary custody. Ms. Johnson claims they neglected her, and the couple contends she wanted more money. Attorneys in the case say it is unique because the surrogate has no genetic link to the baby she wants to keep. In the much-publicized Baby M case in New Jersey, the surrogate mother was also the baby's genetic mother. One witness called by Ms. Johnson's lawyers was David Chamberlain, a California psychologist and vice president of the Prenatal and Perinatal Psychology Association of America. He wrote ``Babies Remember Birth.'' Chamberlain testified about his hypnosis experiments that show children can remember their birth and have memories of experiences in the womb. The relationship between a birth mother and a child is extremely close, Chamberlain said. ``Nothing could be closer than a baby in utero and a birth mother,'' Chamberlain said. Psychiatrist Michelle Harrison, a teacher at the University of Pittsburgh and a consultant to the National Coalition Against Surrogacy, said she counseled Johnson by telephone five or six times during her pregnancy. ``The natural mother is the woman who gives birth to the child and that includes whether or not the child is of her genetic origins,'' she testified in Orange County Superior Court. She said Ms. Johnson feared losing the baby but seemed to cling to the idea that society would recognize the child as hers. Ms. Johnson has been granted twice-weekly visits with the baby. The psychiatrist said Ms. Johnson believes the child recognizes her by smell, feels safe with her and attempts to nurse. However, she also said she has never seen the baby with either the surrogate mother or the Calverts and couldn't judge either side's attachment to the child. Christian Van Deusen, the Calverts' attorney, asked Ms. Harrison about a letter Ms. Johnson wrote to the couple during her pregnancy. The letter read in part: ``I am asking you for help in paying off the final $5,000. Once this baby is born my hands are free of this deal, but see, this situation can go two ways. One, you can pay me the whole sum early so I don't have to live in the streets. Or two, you can forget about helping me out, calling it a breach of contract, and not get the baby.'' Ms. Harrison said the letter didn't affect her opinion of Ms. Johnson's concern for the baby. She said pregnant women under stress ``say and do a lot of things to keep the baby.'' Harold LaFlamme, the baby's court-appointed attorney, questioned the psychiatrist about the propriety of counseling by phone. She said she believed it was appropriate because of the unusual circumstances. Ms. Johnson, who worked with Mrs. Calvert at a hospital in this Southern California city, was hired by the couple to bear their child because a hysterectomy prevents Mrs. Calvert from carrying a baby.

DOC.HEAD: Missing Pilot ``A Marine Through and Through,'' Says N.H. Dad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS second-last graf to correct to Baton Rouge Parish sted County.
DOC.TEXT: Flags flew at half-staff across Alabama on Tuesday in honor of two Alabama Air National Guardsmen who died in the crash of their jet during Persian Gulf operations. In New Hampshire, the father of a Marine pilot missing after a helicopter crash in the Arabian Sea said his son had written a letter saying he didn't mind being in the world's hot spot because that's why he was in the military. Alabama Guard officials said the bodies of Maj. Barry K. Henderson, 40, a senior pilot from Tuscumbia, and Maj. Stephen G. Schramm, 43, a master navigator from Birmingham, were being flown home from the Persian Gulf region this week. They were among 111 members of the 117th wing who volunteered for duty in the Persian Gulf, leaving for assignments in Operation Desert Shield on Aug. 24. Henderson's father, Joe, said ``I had to accept it when he left. I told him, `Son, you're going to where it's beyond my control. All I can do is put you in the hands of the Lord.' '' Henderson often teamed up with David Elliott, another Alabama Guard pilot, but Elliott apparently was sick at the time of the flight, said his sister, Sharon Melson. ``I know they don't know the cause of the crash,'' said the father. ``But David and Barry could almost tell what the other one was thinking, they had flown so much together ... If they could have been together it (crash) might not have happened.'' Schramm is survived by his wife, Cynthia, and two children. Henderson, who turned 40 on Saturday, is survived by his wife, Myra, and two sons. In New Hampshire, Glen Dillon said of his son, Gary: ``He's a Marine through and through. He felt if that's where we needed to go, that's where he needed to be. That's what he was in the service for.'' Capt. Gary Dillon, 29, has been missing since Monday when two helicopters disappeared over the Arabian Sea during training flights. The elder Dillon said Tuesday the Marines told him they didn't expect to find survivors. ``He had written and said it was kind of quiet,'' Dillon said. ``He was just waiting for what ever orders came through and flying a lot of training missions.'' He said his son was engaged to be married. The other seven men missing on the two helicopters were identified by the Marine Corps on Tuesday as: Capt. William D. Cronin Jr., 29, of Du Page County, Ill.; Capt. Kevin R. Dolvin, 29, Stark County, Ohio; Capt. William J. Hurley, 27, Cook County, Ill.; Sgt. Kenneth T. Keller, 26, Cook County, Ill.; Sgt. John R. Kilkus, 26, Norfolk County, Mass.; Cpl. Timothy W. Romei, 22, San Francisco County, Calif.; and Lance Cpl. Thomas R. Adams, 20, Baton Rouge Parish, La. The Corps did not release the men's hometowns or other information. All eight were part of a search-and-rescue squadron based at Camp Pendleton, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Says He Has A New Missile, U.S. Army Radio Debuts In The Desert
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 7 grafs after 7th graf pvs `The Pentagon' to ADD names of missing Marines, update on flight, crude oil futures hitting record high. Picks up 10th graf pvs, `Japan's governing...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LON3
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein announced Tuesday that Iraq had added another missile to its arsenal, and he said it could be launched ``against the targets of evil when the day of reckoning comes.'' The Iraqi leader made it clear he was referring to Israel and the U.S.-led forces massed in Saudi Arabia to deter further Iraqi aggression following the invasion of Kuwait. Iraq has other missiles that can travel hundreds of miles and it was not clear what the significance of a new one would be. Saddam appeared to use the occasion to try to exploit the deaths Monday of 19 Palestinians in Jerusalem to whip up support for his seizure of Kuwait. U.S. armed forces radio took to the airwaves Tuesday with live broadcasts, and rock 'n' roll blared across the Saudi desert. The first song on Desert Shield Network FM 107 brought the troops a little closer to home - The Clash's ``Rock The Casbah'' about a fight over ``boogie sound'' in a traditional Middle Eastern city. The Pentagon said the Navy continued to search for eight Marines whose two helicopters disappeared Monday over the North Arabian Sea during a training exercise. Rescue teams located debris from one of the aircraft on Monday, but no bodies. The Marines released the names of the missing servicemen Tuesday, but Marines spokeswoman Maj. Nancy LaLunta in Washington declined to say whether the men are presumed dead. The missing men were identified as: Capt. Gary S. Dillon; Capt. William D. Cronin Jr.; Capt. Kevin R. Dolvin; Capt. William J. Hurley; Sgt. Kenneth T. Keller; Sgt. John R. Kilkus; Cpl. Timothy W. Romei; and Lance Cpl. Thomas R. Adams. The Marine Corps did not release the men's ages, hometowns or other information. All were part of a search-and-rescue squadron based at Camp Pendleton, Calif. In other developments: -A U.S. Embassy official in Baghdad said that a U.S.-chartered Iraqi jetliner will evacuate about 350 more Americans Wednesday. Most passengers will be transported from Kuwait to the airport in the Iraqi city of Basra, said the State Department, which estimated 400 Americans and foreign-born family members will be on the flight. The plane is due to arrive in Raleigh-Durham airport in North Carolina on Thursday after an overnight stop in London. -Crude oil prices reached an all-time high of $40.40 a barrel Tuesday. The futures price last topped $40 after the 1979 Iranian Revolution. In reaction, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 78.22 points, or 3.1 percent, to close at 2,445.54. It was the Dow average's 11th worst point drop, after the fall of 86.61 points on Sept. 11, 1986. -Japan's governing party was to present a proposal to a special session of Parliament Friday that would allow military forces to help with U.N. peacekeeping efforts in the Persian Gulf and to be armed in case they were attacked, a party source said. The proposal would allow Japanese forces to be sent overseas for the first time since World War II. Force overseas is barred by the country's constitution, and Japan has been criticized for not doing enough in the current crisis. -A spokesman for Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev expressed optimism over a settlement to the gulf crisis following a meeting Friday between Saddam and a Soviet envoy. Vitaly Ignatenko would not give details but said Gorbachev would nform President Bush by letter of the latest Soviet diplomacy. The gulf crisis began when Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. Since then, Saddam has linked withdrawal from Kuwait with an Israeli pullout from Arab territories captured in 1967. Saddam made his announcement about the new Iraqi missile in a statement read by an announcer on Baghdad Radio. The new missile is called the al-Hijara, or Stone, apparently in honor of Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories who throw stones at soldiers. Palestinians are among Sadddam's staunchest supporters. Monday's bloodshed in Jerusalem occurred when police opened fire on Palestinians who hurled stones at Jews worshiping at the Western Wall. The wall is just below the Temple Mount, which is sacred to both Jews and Moslems, and there had been rumors that Jewush zealots were planning to march on the mount. Addressing Israel, Saddam said: ``The faithful Palestinians faced up to you ... with stones which no power on earth can withhold from those who wish to use them. ``They are the Stones of the new missile, which the Iraqis have invented with the help of almighty God and which can be launched from somewhere in the land of Iraq to reach the targets of evil when the day of reckoning comes,'' Saddam said. He again demanded that Israel withdraw from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, and that the United States remove its troops from the region. ``There is no way out for you except to leave the land of Palestine and the sanctities of the Arabs, just as there is no way out for the armies of America and its allies except to leave the holy land of the Arabs and Moslems,'' Saddam said. ``There is room only for this, otherwise you will get what you will get.'' The statement gave no details on how many of the reported missiles Iraq has, whether they have been deployed or what kind of warhead they can carry. It was not possible to obtain independent verification of Saddam's claim. But Don Kerr, a weapons analyst at London's International Institute for Strategic Studies, said the claim would not be outlandish. ``Iraq has had considerable success with surface-to-surface missiles, mostly derivatives of the Soviet-made Scud,'' Kerr said in a telephone interview. Iraq's al-Hussein missile has a range of 310 to 370 miles and the al-Abbas missile a range of 500 to 560 miles, he said. Last December, Iraq test-fired its Tammuz missile, a three-stage rocket ostensibly designed to lift satellites into lower orbit, Kerr noted. ``The thing to remember about a firework that will put a satellite into orbit is that will send a warhead much farther than a few hundred (miles) on the flat,'' he said. But Iraq's missile guidance systems are questionable, Kerr said, and ``those used have not been too impressive.''

DOC.HEAD: Report Says Hostage-Linked Prisoners Now on the Run in Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: A Kuwaiti lawyer who fled to Bahrain said Tuesday that a few of the 15 pro-Iranian terrorists whose release was a key demand of Lebanese hostage-takers now are hunted men inside Kuwait. The lawyer, who spoke on condition of anonymity because of family in Kuwait, said some of the 11 Iaqis, three Lebanese and one Kuwaiti escaped to Iran and Lebanon but others remained in Kuwait. All 15 were Shiite Moslems and most belonged to Iraq's al-Dawa group, seeking to topple Saddam Hussein. They were convicted in the 1983 bombings of the U.S. and French embassies in Kuwait. The Islamic Jihad organization in Lebanon repeatedly demanded release of their fellow Shiites from prison in Kuwait as a condition for freeing Western hostages. ``They are no different from the Americans now,'' the lawyer said of the former prisoners still in Kuwait. ``They are hiding from the Iraqis. If they catch them, they will consider them prize hostages to trade with the Americans. ``I saw two or three in Kuwait, met them in mosques, or at various houses.'' He said those with Iranian or Lebanese connections ``fled as soon as they could'' after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait by Iraq. Shortly after the invasion, Kuwaiti prison guards fled and ``the Iraqis opened the doors to the jails, wanting chaos,'' the lawyer said. He said the escapees were ``not gloating'' about what happened to Kuwait. ``They entered jail because of Saddam Hussein,'' he went on. ``They repeatedly say they have nothing against Kuwait, that their bombing raids were meant to alert Kuwait that it was wrong to support him, wrong to make enemies with Iran against Iraq, and history has proved us right.'' Seventeen men were jailed in the bombings. Two were released last year after completing five-year sentences. The lawyer was among the latest group of Kuwaitis to make it through the Saudi border at Khafji that reopened over the weekend. He estimated about 100,000 Kuwaitis remained in what Iraq now calls its 19th province. That was far lower than other estimates of 300,000. ``Some want to die there. . . . There is no food, no medicine, no antibiotics any more.'' He said there were ``Iraqi soldiers at all intersections . . . checking cars and identity.'' He said there was ``haphazard searching of houses. They search for arms used by the resistance, pictures of the emir, and the Americans and Westerners that Kuwaitis hide.'' ``It's getting worse and worse . . . please help,'' he said. Kuwait contained about 1.9 million people before the invasion, about 60 percent of them non-Kuwaitis. Many foreigners fled. The lawyer said Kuwaiti resistance fighters were trying to expand operations to outlying areas and to Iraq itself, but ``a bullet from a house means the whole area is burned down by the Iraqis.'' He said one Kuwaiti officer used as a bodyguard for visiting dignitaries was suspected of resistance and was killed after being tortured, his mutilated body thrown in front of his house.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecution Suffers Setback As Humphrey Testimony Begins
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with testimony. No Pickup. Names Hlavaty and Yawn cq.
DOC.TEXT: A University of Florida freshman listed as a suspect in the slayings of five students confessed to battering his grandmother and asked repeatedly ``Why did I do it?,'' an ambulance driver testified Tuesday. Edward Lewis Humphrey, jailed on a $1 million bond, is charged with aggravated battery in the Aug. 30 assault on Elna Hlavaty at her Indialantic home. The alleged assault occurred the weekend after four women students and one male student were stabbed to death in their off-campus apartments in Gainesville. Three of the women were mutilated and one was decapitated, authorities said. No one has been charged in the killings, and Humphrey has been listed as one of several suspects. In the assault case, prosecutors suffered a setback when the judge refused to allow them to introduce as evidence police accounts of statements the grandmother allegedly made the night she was battered at her home. Mrs. Hlavaty has said she can't remember what happened, and doesn't believe her grandson attacked her. Prosecutor Philip Williams, saying Mrs. Hlavaty was trying to protect her grandson, sought to introduce her statements. But Brevard Circuit Judge Theron A. Yawn rejected the testimony, saying the hearsay account of her statements shouldn't be used since Mrs. Hlavaty was available as a witness. Ambulance driver Cliff Cooper, who took Mrs. Hlavaty to the hospital, testified that he heard Humphrey repeatedly say, ``Why did I do it?'' Brevard County Deputy Sheriff Doug Hammack, who also answered an emergency 911 call to her home, testified that he heard Humphrey say, ``I hit her and I'm sorry. I'm going to kill myself.'' The prosecution rested its case Tuesday; the defense planned to call more witnesses Wednesday. Public Defender J.R. Russo said the state had failed to link Humphrey to the actual injuries inflicted on his grandmother and failed to prove she suffered a permanent injury or that there was great bodily harm. ``Without a doubt, none of those factors have been proved by the state,'' Russo said, adding that they are required for conviction on aggravated battery charges. Before the ruling, Hammack told the judge with the jury outside the courtroom that when he found Mrs. Hlavaty, her hair was matted with blood, she was holding a bowl of ice on her face and her right eye was swollen shut. ```He hit me. I can't believe he did this to me,''' the officer quoted her as saying. When asked who did it, she replied, ``Edward.'' Dr. Jeri Fitts, the first witness in the trial, said he examined Mrs. Hlavaty in the hospital. He said she suffered a broken facial bone under her eye and a possible broken jaw, along with numerous contusions. He denied the injuries could have been caused by a fall, as she later said, testifying it would have taken three or four blows to cause that much damage. Later, in defense testimony, two ophthalmologists who examined Mrs. Hlavaty and a radiologist who looked at two sets of X-rays said they found no evidence of the fracture below her eyeball. If convicted of aggravated battery on a person over the age of 65, Humphrey would be sentenced to at least three years in prison without parole. He also faces unrelated charges of attempted rape in Indian River County and assault in Alachua County.

DOC.HEAD: Students Commit Suicide to Protest Job Quota Program
DOC.TEXT: At least six students died across India on Tuesday to protest a job quota plan that reserves half of the government's vacancies for low-caste Hindus, news reports said. Press Trust of India said the students either took poison, hanged or immolated themselves in the states of Punjab, Himachal Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh. In New Delhi, a student set himself ablaze and died. But another student, a 14-year-old girl, said she was set on fire by two other students. Parveen Kaur said before dying that she was forcibly set ablaze by two boys of an adjoining school. The state-run television quoted a senior police official as saying it was case of murder and not suicide. The deaths brought the total number of people killed in the job quota protest violence to at least 97 since Prime Minister V.P. Singh announced the plan on Aug. 7. Students from higher castes, angered by a government refusal to review the plan, forced strikes in the states of Rajasthan and Himachal Pradesh, the state-owned television reported. Public opposition to the plan has been widespread in the politically influential cities of northern India. The army has been called out and curfews clamped on several towns to control rioting students, joined sometimes by housewives and government employees. Two members of Singh's governing party have resigned from Parliament and some colleagues demanded his ouster because of the quotas. Singh has refused to abandon the policy, saying it is an affirmative action program that would give social justice to the lower castes. Critics say he fears alienating the lower castes, which form a majority of the eligible votes among India's 880 million people. Upper-caste students say reverse discrimination will deprive them of government jobs for which they believe themselves to be better qualified. The plan reserves 27 percent of federal jobs for low-caste Hindus. An additional 22 percent already are set aside for the lowest strata in the rigid hierarchy of Indian society, tribespeople and the so-called untouchables.

DOC.HEAD: Shootout Leaves IRA Suspect, Another Dead
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers killed a suspected veteran IRA terrorist and a former official of the IRA's political wing Tuesday at a shootout southwest of Belfast, police reported. Desmond Grew, 37, and Martin McCaughey, 23, died in a pre-dawn ambush at a farm outside Loughgall. The shooting occurred just after the pair arrived with two men and a woman, said the Royal Ulster Constabulary. The unidentified men and the woman were not hurt and were arrested at the scene. Three rifles were seized in the incident, 30 miles southwest of Belfast, police said. Grew was believed ``to have been involved in acts of kidnapping, murder, attempted murder, bombing attacks, shootings and armed robberies'' since the 1970s, said police. Police in other countries also were investigating Grew's activities in connection with terrorist incidents, police said. The domestic news agency Press Association said German police wanted him for questioning about terrorist incidents, including the killing in October 1989 of a Royal Air Force corporal and his 6-month-old daughter in Wildenrath. In 1976 he was sentenced to six years in a Belfast jail for kidnapping, possession of explosives and other charges, and spent eight years in jail in Ireland for armed robbery from 1980-88, police said. Grew's brother, Seamus Grew, was shot by the Royal Ulster Constabulary in 1982. He had been a member of the outlawed Irish National Liberation Army. Another brother, Adrian Grew, is serving a 14-year sentence for attempting to blow up an army patrol. McCaughey, former councilor for the IRA's political wing, Sinn Fein, was also believed to belong to the IRA and to have been involved in terrorist activity, said police. Security in County Armagh had been increased the last few weeks following a rise in the number of attacks on off-duty police and soldiers. The attacks were blamed on the outlawed Irish Republican Army, which is fighting to oust the British from the Protestant-dominated province of Northern Ireland. In May 1987, eight IRA members were shot to death by elite British troops as they launched a bomb attack on the Loughgall police station. A ninth man unconnected with the attack died when he was caught in crossfire. Last month, the same police station was demolished in an IRA bombing. The building was empty at the time.

DOC.HEAD: Africa Watch Calls for Pressure on Malawi Government
DOC.TEXT: The government of Malawi is suppressing dissent by detaining, torturing and murdering political opponents, a human rights organization said Wednesday. Africa Watch urged the West to cut aid to president-for-life Kamuzu Banda's government, which it likened to ``regimes such as the late Nicolae Ceausescu's in Romania and Kim il-Sung's in North Korea.'' The U.S. government has criticized the detention of Malawian poet Jack Mapanje, but also has substantially increased military assistance to the southern African country the past two years, Africa Watch said. Britain has a stated policy of linking aid to Africa with human rights, ``but it has apparently not made such a connection in the case of Malawi,'' the group said. Malawi, a former British protectorate, gained independence in 1964. Banda took office in July 1966 and became life president five years later. In a 116-page report to be published Wednesday, Africa Watch said there is ``a totalitarian suppression of all independent expression with a high degree of personal despotism by the life-president and his `official hostess,' Cecilia Tamanda Kadzamira.'' The report says Malawian police in March fatally shot more than 20 protesters in Kawale, a suburb of the capital city of Lilongwe. Other ``political murders'' included the death of journalist and human rights monitor Mkwapatira Mhango, who died in a firebomb attack in Lusaka, Zambia, in October 1989, along with his family, Africa Watch reported. ``Only weeks earlier he had been publicly denounced by Banda,'' the report said. Africa Watch said it gathered testimony showing that three cabinet ministers and a legislator who died mysteriously in 1983 were murdered while in official custody. The four favored electoral and decision-making reform, Africa Watch said. The government said they died in a car accident. The report said detention without trial is also ``an important weapon against dissent.'' ``Presidential detention powers are arbitrary, with no possibility of administrative or judicial review,'' the report said. Africa Watch also accused the government of discriminating against people living in the northern region of the nation of about 7.1 million residents. Banda and his associates are from the central region. Africa Watch said political prisoners are reported to have been severely beaten. ``But the worst treatment is reserved for persistent criminal offenders,'' it said. ``According to testimony, these prisoners ... are stripped naked, chained to the floor of their cells and either denied food or given one-quarter rations. Many are reported to have died.'' Africa Watch has been denied access to the prisons. Africa Watch is part of Human Rights Watch, an nonprofit organization with regional divisions monitoring Asia, the Americas and Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Legislature Adopts Limits on Nuclear Testing
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet legislature on Tuesday followed the lead of the U.S. Senate by unanimously adopting limits on nuclear weapons testing embodied in two treaties from the 1970s. The Supreme Soviet went beyond the Senate, appealing to parliaments around the world to ban nuclear testing and repeating the Kremlin proposal for ``global nuclear disarmament.'' The significance of the treaties has waned since the 1970s. Today, the superpowers are preparing to seal one pact to cut their nuclear arsenals and another to scale back conventional forces in Europe. Additionally, environmental protests might force the Soviets to unilaterally suspend nuclear testing. On Monday, KGB border guards boarded a Greenpeace vessel in the arctic after it dispatched environmentalists to go ashore to a nuclear test site. Earlier this year, public pressure forced the Soviet government to suspend testing at its main site, Semipalatinsk, in Kazakhstan. Maj. Gen. Anatoly Koltunov, a member of the parliament of the Russian Federation, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics, demanded Tuesday that authorities investigate plans to test nuclear devices at Novaya Zemlya, the independent news agency Interfax reported. In the Kremlin on Tuesday, Soviet lawmakers voted 347-0, with nine abstentions, to approve the 1974 Threshold Test Ban Treaty, which limits weapons tests to 150 kilotons, and the 1976 Peaceful Nuclear Explosions Treaty, which places the same limits on explosions for engineering purposes. Adoption of the treaties was slowed because former President Carter wanted a more sweeping ban on testing, and his successor, former President Reagan, did not believe the technology existed to verify compliance. President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev cleared the way for ratification at their last summit by agreeing to a new set of verification rules. Supporters say the new verification measures are likely to set important precedents for further reducing or banning nuclear tests. In approving the treaties, the Soviet parliament asked its international and national security committees to review questions stemming from four reservations that the Senate attached to the pacts. A U.S. Senate aide, contacted in Washington, said ``none of the reservations was serious enough for the Soviets to really care about.'' One of the reservations authorized the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff to make plans to test above the 150-kiloton limit if the Soviets break the treaty, said the Senate aide, who spoke on condition he not be further identified. The second urges the United States to begin negotiations immediately to lower the ceiling. The third commits the administration not to change its interpretation of the treaties, and the fourth requires the government to notify the Senate if the means of verification change. The treaties focus mainly on verification methods, and allow each country to maintain on-site monitoring equipment at three sites on each other's soil.

DOC.HEAD: Imagine All the People Listening to John
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, `Other observances ...' to DELETE duplicated sentence.
DOC.TEXT: John Lennon's worldwide message of peace was delivered Tuesday as his song ``Imagine'' was played simultaneously for 1 billion people in 130 countries to celebrate what would have been his 50th birthday. ``A dream we dream alone is only a dream, but the dream we dream together is reality. Happy birthday, John. The world is better today for sharing a time with you,'' Yoko Ono said at a United Nations ceremony before the playing of ``Imagine.'' The slain former Beatle himself issued a call for harmony in a taped message that served as an introduction to the music. ``We all want peace, whatever sort of job we have. ... Think of your children. Do you want them to be killed or don't you? And that's the choice we have in front of us. War or peace,'' said Lennon, whose son Sean turned 15 Tuesday. None of the other Beatles were at the United Nations, but a tribute came from Lennon's old songwriting partner, Paul McCartney, who released a live version of the Beatles' tune ``Birthday.'' The song, originally on the ``White Album,'' was the first Lennon-McCartney single released since the Beatles broke up in 1969. ``The release date and John's birthday is just a happy coincidence, but it's also a nod and a wink to my old mate,'' said McCartney, 47. Other observances were held from Liverpool to Moscow to Los Angeles. In Lennon's hometown in England, fans gathered at the former site of the Cavern Club, where the Beatles were discovered. Among those attending was Lennon's 71-year-old uncle, Charlie Lennon. When asked how his nephew would have reacted to the ceremonies, he said: ``If he had been alive I doubt he would have come and even if he had, he would sat with me in the pub and had a good laugh.'' On the West Coast, about 50 people - part of an estimated 1 billion people worldwide who had access to the event - stood near Lennon's star on the Walk of Fame and listened to the ``Imagine'' broadcast: ``Imagine all the people, living life in peace ``You may say I'm a dreamer, but I'm not the only one ``I hope some day you'll join us ``And the world will live as one.'' ``His spirit still lives in all of us whose lives have been touched with him,'' Ono said of her late husband. ``I would like us to remember and celebrate his birthday as a day of love, because he was a man of love, and because love is much needed at this time in our lives.'' Ono was greeted by Marcela Perez de Cuellar, wife of the U.N. secretary-general. During her brief remarks, Ono also quoted a line from another of Lennon's songs, ``Happy Xmas (War is Over)'': ``Remember, war is over if you want it.'' More than 1,000 radio stations and networks from 50 countries broadcast the 10-minute event. U.S. Armed Forces television and radio beamed it to 80-plus other countries. MTV televised the ``Imagine'' video in 25 countries, said Andrea Smith, a spokeswoman for the network. In Moscow, about 1,000 Soviets gathered at the Moscow Electrical Lamp Factory's cultural hall to listen to Lennon's music, snap up his albums and posters and reflect on his life. Even the staid state television program ``Vremya'' got into the act. An anchorman, reporting on the worldwide birthday bash, described ``Imagine'' as an ``anthem of peace.'' The broadcast ended with an instrumental version of ``Yesterday.'' Not so long ago, the Beatles' music was banned in the Soviet Union. In 1964, one commentator warned that ``these bugs can swiftly ignite the very darkest and primitive passions.'' Lennon was shot to death by a deranged fan outside his Manhattan apartment building on Dec. 8, 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Guerrilla Leader Asks for Help to Reopen Talks
DOC.TEXT: A Cambodian guerrilla leader has asked France and Indonesia to intervene to help reopen peace talks between the guerrillas and the Vietnamese-installed government in Phnom Penh. A guerrilla radio broadcast said Son Sann suggested France and Indonesia help break the stalemate over Cambodia's Supreme National Council, a national reconciliation body, by participating in its next meeting. He said the Cambodians could resolve their dispute by asking the two nations, which co-chaired the international conference on Cambodia in August 1989, to interpret the documents of the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council and of the Cambodians in talks in Indonesia. A transcript of the Sunday broadcast was seen Tuesday in Bangkok. Son Sann heads the Khmer People's National Liberation Front, which is allied in a resistance coalition with the Khmer Rouge and the forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk in fighting the government Vietnam installed after a late 1978 invasion. The Supreme National Council is supposed to send a joint delegation to the United Nations, arrange the first truce in the war, and eventually guide the nation to democracy through new elections. But its first meeting, in Bangkok on Sept. 17, collapsed in squabbling over opposition demands that Sihanouk, a former head of state and the coalition leader, join the council as its chairman. The guerrillas have rejected the government's demand that if Sihanouk became chairman, the government side should have the vice chairmanship. A Security Council plan adopted in August said that, ``should Prince Norodom Sihanouk be elected by the SNC as its president, the Five would welcome this decision.'' The five permanent members of the Security Council are Britain, China, France, the Soviet Union and the United States. The joint communique in Indonesia, where the Supreme National Council was formed on Sept. 10 with six government members and six guerrilla members, said that ``if the 12 members of the SNC so desire,'' they could elect a chairman who would be the 13th member. The problem was largely due to Sihanouk's failure to attend the Indonesia talks. He stayed at his Beijing home, saying he was ill.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Marcos Moved Funds Through Actor George Hamilton
DOC.TEXT: Actor George Hamilton was a conduit for $12 million taken out of the Philippines by former President Ferdinand Marcos and his wife Imelda, a newspaper reported. Court records obtained by the Los Angeles Times indicate the actor used some of the money to finance the mortgage on a Beverly Hills mansion and to launch a film development project. In a previously sealed deposition, Hamilton testified that he received money from associates of the Marcoses but didn't know it was linked to the couple, the Times reported Tuesday. Hamilton said he paid the money back. ``Maybe he was a tool for someone, an innocent,'' said Arthur N. Greenberg, Hamilton's attorney. ``He would not knowingly participate in any transaction that has any taint.'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Charles G. LaBella, a New York prosecutor, said the Marcoses used Hamilton as ``a front'' to move money out of the impoverished country. No investigation of Hamilton is planned, he said. The deposition - a sworn statement made under questioning by lawyers outside of court - is on file in one of many civil lawsuits filed in California against Imelda Marcos by the Philippine government. The lawsuits accuse Mrs. Marcos of converting billions of dollars in government funds into private wealth during her husband's 20-year rule. She was acquitted in July of fraud and federal racketeering charges in a New York criminal case in which Hamilton was an unindicted co-conspirator. Marcos died last year in exile in Hawaii. Hamilton, 51, has acknowledged publicly that he received many gifts from Mrs. Marcos, whom he has known for about 10 years. He also acted as a financial adviser to her, the Times said. He and Mrs. Marcos have denied rumors linking them romantically. Hamilton is known for his portrayal of a vampire in the movie, ``Love at First Bite.'' Court documents show that $12 million flowed from secret Marcos bank accounts in the Philippines through Hamilton investments in the United States to other banks and offshore shell companies associated with the Marcoses. The Times said Hamilton received $5.5 million from a Marcos associate to invest in a film project but returned the money to a Hong Kong bank in 1983 after deciding against making the movie. Hamilton also received a $6 million loan - $4 million of which was secured by his Los Angeles-area estate - from Antonio O. Floirendo, a Marcos confidante, the documents show. In 1986, the house was sold to an offshore corporation controlled by Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, who was indicted along with Mrs. Marcos and also acquitted. The newspaper said the property will soon be turned over to the Philippine government, which contends it was financed with looted money.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty Details Killings, Torture In India
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International urged India on Wednesday to curb abuses of special anti-insurrection powers that give security forces broad authority to shoot and make arrests. The statement by the human rights group accompanied a 73-page report detailing arbitrary arrests and torture of hundreds of people in and around Oinam village in northeast Manipur state in 1987. ``Soldiers appear to believe they can beat, kill and torture young or old without fear of punishment. The government must send a clear message that this will not be tolerated,'' said the group, which has headquarters in London. Indian security forces were granted similar powers earlier this year in Kashmir, where Moslem militants are demanding an independent state, it said. More than 250 people have been killed in Jammu-Kashmir state since a government crackdown began in January. The report quotes witnesses as saying villagers in Manipur were beaten, given electric shocks, burned with cigarettes or hung upside down by troops of the Assam Rifles unit. Amnesty said the abuses came during a counterinsurgency campaign launched after secessionists based in Nagaland state attacked an Assam Rifles' outpost and killed nine soldiers. Nagaland borders Manipur. The report alleged that Assam Rifles soldiers tortured and illegally executed at least 11 men. Assam Rifles personnel said the men died in clashes or trying to escape, but Indian courts ruled two of the slayings illegal, Amnesty said. It said women reported being raped by Assam Rifles soldiers and that at least four children died in detention due to lack of medical care. Amnesty said security forces in Manipur still retain the special powers and that abuses contnue. It said the government failed to investigate the incidents, despite calls from Amnesty and others. Amnesty said the Assam Rifles tried to cover up the abuses by harassing and intimidating villagers. . ``Witnesses were arrested after testifying in court and a lawyer presenting their claims for damages was threatened in court,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Bargain Hunters Throng Oil-Spill Auction, Drive Up Prices
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf pvs, `Ritchie Bros...,' to UPDATE with $3.8 million in sales the first day of auction.
DOC.TEXT: Bargain hunters by the thousands descended on an Anchorage industrial lot Tuesday to pick through acres of gear unloaded by Exxon after two summers of oil-spill cleanup. ``You really realize the size of the spill by all the garbage that came out of it,'' said Anchorage aviation mechanic Rod Meeks, who bought two outboard boat motors at the auction. Many failed to find the deals they had hoped for, however, and blamed it on the crowd. ``We were looking for anything, but there's too many people bidding high,'' said Doug Parr, a construction consultant who flew to Anchorage from Seattle for the three-day sale. He hoped prices would come down after the first day. It looked like the day before Christmas at the world's biggest bargain basement. Parked cars lined the roads for miles in all directions. Ritchie Bros. Auctioneers International, which bought the merchandise last month from Exxon Corp. for a price Ritchie officials would only describe as ``millions,'' ran shuttle buses into the site. There, an auctioneer was driven through the throngs in a booth atop a truck, stopping here to sell dozens of all-terrain vehicles, there for pallet after pallet of brand-new fishing nets, somewhere else for containers filled with flotsam, from life jackets to tables and chairs. Half the yard seemed filled with boats - aluminum skiffs, inflatable power boats. Inside a hangar, pallets reached to the ceiling containing more stuff: outdoor thermometers, clothing, even kitty litter. And the site was just one of three filled with surplus merchandise from the Exxon Valdez oil-spill cleanup effort. The tanker ran aground in Alaska's Prince William Sound in March 1989 and spewed nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil in the nation's biggest oil spill. Exxon crews worked that summer and this one to clean shorelines, and plan to return next spring for a shoreline survey. Exxon officials said they didn't sell any equipment that could be used for additional clean-up. Ritchie Bros. wouldn't say how much it expects the merchandise to bring. Nearly 8,000 potential bidders had signed up by midday Tuesday, and by the end of the day, company officials said everything on the first lot had been sold for a total of $3.8 million. A 1966 turboprop float plane with an old Esso tiger painted on its tail sold for $435,000 to an undisclosed bidder. New, the plane would cost about $700,000, several air-taxi company officials in the crowd said. Four used television sets sold for $2,000 - a price some frustrated buyers said was too high. ``A welding machine went for five or six thousand dollars - I can buy a new one for seven and it has a warranty,'' said Steve Pittillo of Anchorage, a drilling contractor who looked unsuccessfully for equipment. Butch Johnson, from the Prince William Sound fishing community of Cordova, hoped to buy some nets but feared they would be too expensive. ``It's a feeding frenzy,'' he said. ``It's the biggest thing happening in Alaska,'' said a Kodiak fisherman who wouldn't give his name. ``Prices are way out of line. The people we know - the fishermen - aren't buying anything. They're just shaking their heads.'' Dan League, pastor of the Hillcrest Church of the Nazarene in Anchorage planned to bid on tables and stack chairs for their Sunday school classes. Melissa Stevison, co-owner of Alpine Aviation in Valdez, flew in to buy one of 38 Valdez mobile homes on sale so the company can have more office space. Others were there to see what effect the auction would have on their livelihoods. Phil Lian, owner of a net supply store in Cordova, angrily pulled out a notebook listing dozens of his customers whom he spotted at the auction. He said he hasn't received orders in a few months - ever since the auction was advertised. ``It impacts the fishing community when you put this much material on the market,'' said Lian, who attended the auction to see who buys the net and whether it will glut his market. ``This is depressing. We were impacted big time during the spill and now again. It's probably cost us half a million dollars this year.'' Anchorage businessman Brian Watson, looking for equipment for his water purification business, was in awe of the sky-high piles of merchandise. ``People from all over the world are here looking for deals.
