It's a great windfall,'' he said. ``The magnitude of this - and all because one ship blew it big. That's amazing to me.''

DOC.HEAD: Lois Scripps Wife of Scripps Co. Chairman Dies
DOC.TEXT: Lois Anne MacKay Scripps, wife of Charles E. Scripps Sr., the chairman of the E.W. Scripps Co., has died at age 62. Mrs. Scripps died Monday at her Cincinnati home after a two-year illness, the Cincinnati-based company announced Tuesday. Mrs. Scripps served as trustee of Thomas More College and Cincinnati Technical Center, and was a horticulturist who developed the grounds of her home, built on former vineyard slopes overlooking the Ohio River. She was active with her husband in causes promoting literacy and, through the Inter American Press Association, worked to promote a free press throughout the Western hemisphere. Mrs. Scripps was born in New York City and grew up in La Jolla, Calif. She graduated from Stanford University with a degree in English literature. She married Charles Scripps in 1949 and moved to Cincinnati, where the newspaper and broadcast company has its headquartered. E.W. Scripps is the parent of Scripps Howard Newspapers, which has has 19 daily papers, including The Cincinnati Post and the Pittsburgh Press. She is survived by her husband, four children and four grandchildren. Memorial services are scheduled Oct. 15 at First Unitarian Church in Cincinnati.

DOC.HEAD: National Airline Shakes Up Staff Following Hijacking
DOC.TEXT: China's national airline said Tuesday it was shaking up airline and airport management following a hijacking and crash a week ago that killed 128 people. In the first disclosure of the details of the hijacking, officials said a lone hijacker who claimed to have explosives attacked the pilot as he was making an emergency landing in Canton. They said the pilot did not have enough fuel to fly to Taiwan, where the hijacker wanted to go, or Hong Kong. For the first time since the Oct. 2 crash, the Civil Aviation Administration of China expressed regret for the worst reported air disaster in Chinese history. ``We are deeply grieved over this. We profoundly mourn the passengers killed ... and offer our sympathy,'' said an unidentified CAAC spokesman. His remarks were carried by the official Xinhua News Agency. ``This serious incident has revealed the existing problems of the airport and airline company in their management,'' the spokesman said, without giving details. ``It has been decided that a shakeup of the airport and the company will be made,'' he said. No details were given in the Xinhua dispatch, and CAAC officials contacted by phone in Beijing had no information. The Boeing 737 from the coastal city of Xiamen was hijacked early Oct. 2 en route to the southern city of Canton. The hijacker forced his way into the cockpit and ordered all crew members but the pilot to leave, said a report on the crash investigation. The hijacker demanded to be flown to Taiwan, but the pilot said he did not have enough fuel and offered to fly first to Hong Kong, which actually is farther away. Taiwan is 150 miles from Xiamen, and Hong Kong 300 miles. The report said the hijacker threatened to blow up the plane if it landed in Hong Kong, and the pilot finally made an emergency landing at Canton's Baiyun International Airport as fuel was running out. The official account conflicted with that of survivors, who said the plane circled over the Canton airport for 40 minutes before landing. The hijacker attacked the pilot as the plane taxied down the runway, sending it out of control. It plowed into two parked jets, one full of passengers and ready to take off for Shanghai, the report said. The hijacked plane and the Shanghai plane both were engulfed in flames. At least 128 people, including residents of Hong Kong and Taiwan and an American, were killed. Forty-six were seriously injured. No trace of explosives has been found, said the report by the Canton Aviation Administration and the Canton Public Security Bureau investigation report. It identified the hijacker as Jiang Xiaofeng, of the Hunan capital of Changsha, a purchasing agent for the Linli County Goods and Materials Bureau Development Corp. The report said Jiang was being sought by local police for absconding with $3,591 in company money. He previously had been charged with robbery. In earlier hijacking attempts, China has said the hijackers had criminal records and were motivated by criminal rather than political reasons. China has faced intense criticism for its handling of the latest such incident. Aviation experts have questioned Chinese authorities' decision not to evacuate the Canton airport while the hijacked jet circled overhead. The flight crew apparently decided to fight the hijacking attempt without considering the possible consequences. Chinese flight crews during previous hijacking attempts also have been more interested in thwarting hijackers than ensuring safety, the experts said.

She married Charles Scripps in 1949 and moved to Cincinnati, where the newspaper and broadcasting company has its headquarters. Mrs. Scripps was active with her husband in causes promoting literacy and, through the Inter American Press Association, worked to promote a free press throughout the Western hemisphere. Mrs. Scripps served as trustee of Thomas More College and Cincinnati Technical Center, and was a horticulturist who developed the grounds of her home, built on former vineyard slopes overlooking the Ohio River.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to fix slug to Poland-Priest sted Poland
Arrests Reopen Emotionally Charged Case Poles Never Thought Closed
DOC.TEXT: Charges that two former police generals ordered the murder of a Solidarity priest are the first major prosecution of Poland's old guard and officially reopen a case most Poles never considered closed. The arrests in the case of the Rev. Jerzy Popieluszko come six years after the crime that shocked the nation, and at the outset of a presidential race in which Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's careful treatment of former Communists is being challenged by Lech Walesa. On Monday, authorities also disclosed that a former interior minister and six other officials have been accused of taking bribes of gold and jewelry dating to 1971. ``In cases of clear crimes, party people will be punished. If proven, these people will be condemned,'' Aleksander Smolar, a senior adviser to Mazowiecki, told an American Society of Newspaper Editors delegation Tuesday. At a Walesa campaign rally in Warsaw on Tuesday, a spectator challenged the timing of the arrests ``right now before the elections,'' scheduled for Nov. 25. But Smolar said there was absolutely ``no political calculation'' in the arrests, which he said were ordered by independent courts. He said there would be no departure from the government's basic policy ``that our evolution to democracy should be as peaceful as possible, trying to reconcile the two parts of Poland,'' rather than waging a ``cold civil war'' against former Communists. Smolar said he recognized that the prosecutions of former police officials would prove popular because of ``the feeling of bitterness and injustice'' after 45 years of communism. ``There is a need of a clear moral condemnation, everybody needs it for a sort of catharsis,'' Smolar said. However, he added, most Poles understand the wisdom of avoiding purges. Those Interior Ministry records that survived destruction - the Mazowiecki government did not take steps to prevent the burning of documents - will not be opened to show who cooperated with the secret police, Smolar said. ``It is extremely dangerous and destroys the nation to judge people for their weaknesses ... in very harsh times, when only heroes were able to survive with dignity,'' he said. The 1984 kidnapping and murder of the 37-year-old Popieluszko, whose body was pulled from a river, gave a martyr to the then-underground Solidarity movement the Communists were trying to crush. Many Polish households still display photographs of the priest that were put up during the 1980s as a sign of protest. Four secret policemen from the Interior Ministry's Fourth Department, the unit responsible for spying on the Roman Catholic Church and clergy, were tried and convicted in Popieluszko's death. Two have been paroled. But no involvement was found on the part of higher authorities - a conclusion that satisfied few and came to symbolize ruthless communism. ``Something unprecedented has happened,'' Jerzy Jachowicz, an expert on the security services, wrote of the arrests Tuesday in a front-page Gazeta Wyborcza commentary. The two generals, former Deputy Interior Minister Wladyslaw Ciaston and Zenon Platek, former head of the Fourth Department, were charged with plotting the priest's slaying during September and October 1984 and directing the Oct. 19, 1984 killing, officials said. Prosecutors said the corruption charges were unrelated to the killing. But among those arrested was onetime Interior Minister Miroslaw Milewski, a former Communist Party Politburo member who was Central Committee secretary in charge of internal affairs when Popieluszko was murdered. After the slaying, Milewski was quietly dismissed. Milewski was given the party posts after being replaced as interior minister by Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak in 1981, during Solidarity's first legal period. Kiszczak, a Communist holdover in the Solidarity government until he resigned last summer, told Polish television in September that he believed the priest's killers could not have acted ``without the inspiration of someone standing higher then them.'' He suggested the crime was committed by those aiming to destabilize the ``reform-oriented'' Communist government of then-party leader Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, now the outgoing president. On Polish television Tuesday, Kiszczak said he believes Ciaston and Platek, who worked for him, are innocent. He said the corruption charges against Milewski were investigated in May 1984 and a ``thorough report'' was given to superiors, but he did not elaborate. The Popieluszko case was reopened July 24, three weeks after Kiszczak's resignation, by the Office for the Protection of the State, the smaller and tightly controlled agency that replaced the disbanded secret police. The arrests made since Thursday open a ``new chapter in the case,'' the government daily Rzeczpospolita said. ``The direct perpetrators of a crime were already judged. ... However, unanswered questions still remain,'' the newspaper said. The corruption inquiry, which also targets two unidentified other generals and two colonels, involves acceptance of bribes of ``great value, including many kilograms of gold and jewelry,'' Prosecutor General Aleksander Herzog said. The alleged crimes span the period from 1971, when Milewski was a deputy interior minister, to 1981, Herzog said.

DOC.HEAD: Dissident Arrested After Clandestine Return
DOC.TEXT: A former legislator and leader of an underground opposition group was arrested after secretly returning from self-imposed exile, state radio reported Tuesday. The Kenya Broadcasting Corp. said Koigi wa Wamwere was taken into custody in the capital city of Nairobi in a pre-dawn raid Monday in which ``substantial assorted arms were seized.'' The broadcast, quoting a government statement, said Wamwere and an unspecified number of accomplices recently entered Kenya from a neighboring country that was not identified. The broadcast did not indicate whether others were arrested. Wamwere fled to Oslo, Norway, in late 1986 claiming his life was in danger. He continued to issue statements critical of President Daniel arap Moi's government and in 1988 announced the formation of the opposition Kenya Patriotic Front. The statement claimed Wamwere and associates entered Kenya to organize anti-government activities among illegal hawkers and operators of matatus, privately owned vans widely used as public transportation in Kenya. There have been violent confrontations recently between street hawkers and police trying to clear them from sidewalks. Hawkers also took part in July riots following an aborted pro-democracy rally in this single-party East African nation. The government said 20 people died, but the London-based human rights group Africa Watch put the death toll at more than 100. Wamwere's brother, Charles Kuria Wamwere, pleaded guilty to a charge of belonging to the Patriotic Front and was sentenced to a four-year jail term Sept. 22. Koigi wa Wamwere had been an outspoken member of Parliament before he was detained without charge in 1975 by the government of President Jomo Kenyatta, Kenya's first president. Kenyan law permits detention without charge or trial of individuals the government considers a threat to security. Koigi wa Wamwere was among political detainees Moi freed on succeeding Kenyatta in 1978. He was detained again in August 1982, two weeks after loyalist troops suppressed a rebellion by junior air force officers. He was freed in 1984. Two lawyers, Rumba Kinuthia and Mirugi Kariuki, were also detained Monday. In July, the government began a crackdown of proponents of political pluralism. Two former Cabinet ministers and the son of Kenya's first vice-president are still in jail.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Say U.S. Supports Resolution Against Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with continuing attempts to reach compromise on anti-Israel resolution, most council members sent home. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Israel, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States decided Tuesday to vote against Israel and back a U.N. resolution that condemns the killing of 19 Palestinians in Jerusalem and asks a U.N. investigation, U.S. officials said. But the Palestine Liberation Organization and non-aligned nations opposed the U.S. draft resolution as too weak. They said they would press their own stronger resolution, possibly forcing the United States to use its veto power and infuriate Arab states that backed the U.S.-led coalition against Iraq. The Security Council had been expected to convene Tuesday night to consider the two drafts, but by late Tuesday the council president had sent most council members home except for those holding consultations. Diplomats reported scant progress in their search for a compromise. The Bush administration's decision followed daylong negotiations at the United Nations to avert a threatened U.S. veto of a resolution that already had the support of the four other permanent members of the Security Council. Officials in Washington said the U.S. draft condemns Monday's violence ``and particularly the excessive Israeli response.'' It welcomes the decision by U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar to send a delegation to Jerusalem to investigate. Israel already has rejected any Security Council mission, saying it would infringe on Israeli sovereignty. But it has accepted personal emissaries of the secretary-general in the past. The PLO and other states say the council itself must take a strong stand and that findings of a council delegation would have to be acted on by the council. The findings of a mission by the secretary-general's personal representative would not carry the same weight or convey the same urgency. The United States was considered likely to veto a resolution that contained a call for a tough Security Council probe. America was ready to veto an earlier draft, finally deciding to draft its own resolution because a veto would only benefit the PLO and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, diplomats said. A U.S. vote against Israel would be the first since Jan. 5, 1988, when the United States supported a Security Council resolution opposing deportations of Palestinians in the uprising against Israel occupation. America usually sides with Israel, shielding it from harsh criticism with a veto. Occasionally the United States abstains. The council has been debating the killings on Temple Mount, a site holy to both Jews and Moslems. Police fired on Monday on Palestinians who stoned Jewish worshipers at the Western Wall, or Wailing Wall, just below the mount. The mob had heard rumors that Jewish zealots planned to march on the mount. Israel claims the attack was planned by the PLO to deflect attention from Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The United States has claimed when it vetoed anti-Israel resolutions in the past that they were not balanced or did not accurately reflect the violence and provocation of the Palestinians. But the current debate has been heavily linked to the Persian Gulf crisis. Many Arab nations and others claim Israel should not be spared from U.N. action after sanctions were imposed on Iraq. The PLO and some Arab states also said a U.S. veto would erode support for the U.S.-led international force opposing Iraq. Bush told a news conference Israeli security forces should have acted ``with more restraint.'' The five permanent council members - the United States, Britain, China, France and the Soviet Union - met privately Tuesday to discuss a possible common strategy. In the U.N. debate, more than 30 speakers condemned Israel's treatment of Palestinians, demanded Israeli withdrawal from territories captured in the 1967 Middle East war and called for U.N. protection for Palestinians. On Tuesday, Iraq accused the United States and its allies of ``hypocrisy'' for shielding Israel over the years and failing to condemn and punish Israel for violence against Palestinians. Kuwait's deputy prime minister and foreign minister, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmad al-Jaber al-Sabah, spoke in sympathy with Palestinians. Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Tunisia and other nations joined him in urging firm council action against Israeli occupation, just as it acted against Iraqi occupation of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Paramilitary Game Rangers Kill Six Rhino Poachers
DOC.TEXT: Paramilitary game rangers have killed six poachers believed to be stalking endangered black rhinos, officials said Tuesday. The action brought to 10 the total number of poachers killed in one operation to pursue two gangs that entered Zimbabwe in the middle of the year. A National Parks' spokesman said four poachers of the six-member gang were killed Oct. 1 in a gun battle in a nature reserve 485 miles southwest of Harare. Two poachers escaped but were shot to death last Saturday in a shootout with anti-poaching patrols. The poachers were believed to have crossed into Zimbabwe from neighboring Zambia, the spokesman said. He said Zimbabwe rangers found two rhino horns and automatic assault rifles used by the illegal hunters. The black rhinocerous has one large horn on its snout, with a smaller one behind it. The horns, made of matted hair and cartilage, are carved into ornamental dagger handles or crushed into powder as an ingredient in traditional medicines in the Middle East and Asia. On Sept. 10, paramilitary rangers captured another gang of six poachers who had killed 15 rhino, the largest number of these endangered animals slaughtered by one group in this southern African nation, the spokesman said. So far this year, anti-poaching patrols have killed 34 mainly Zambian poachers and captured 14 others. The world's largest surviving black rhino population of about 2,000 lives in Zimbabwe.

DOC.HEAD: Standard & Poor's Places City's Bond Rating on Credit Watch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT rating to A-minus sted A; SUBS 9th graf, `An A...,' to ADD explanation of plus or minus ratings.
DOC.TEXT: A major bond rating agency said Tuesday it is reviewing the status of New York City's ability to repay debt following a tentative agreement to give teachers a 5.5 percent pay raise. After reviewing its A-minus rating of New York City's $13 billion in outstanding general obligation bonds, Standard & Poors Corp. could decide to lower the rating. ``I'm confident we are going to satisfy them that we are in control,'' Mayor David Dinkins said at a City Hall press conference. ``We have a plan. We are going to meet that gap.'' The mayor has projected a $1.4 billion deficit next year in the city's approximately $28 billion budget. The city has been hurt by the slump in the Northeast economy, particularly by the declining fortunes of Wall Street firms. S&P said it was re-evaluating the city's payroll burden in light of a weakening economy that leads to lower tax revenues. State Comptroller Edward Regan said S&P's move appeared to be based on a perception of economic crisis, rather than reality. ``The city is not on the verge of an economic disaster,'' Regan said. ``It's a cyclical downturn with an erosion of revenue, but that can be handled. The problem is that this year's budget was too large to begin with.'' An A rating from S&P means the agency believes the city has a strong ability to pay interest and principal on the bonds, although that ability is more susceptible to economic downswings. A plus or minus sign on a rating shows its relative standing within the catagory. The next step down is a BBB rating, which signifies that adverse conditions make it more likely the city would have trouble paying interest and principal. Lower ratings make it more expensive to borrow money in the bond market since investors usually demand higher yields for the riskier debt. City Council President Andrew Stein said it was inconceivable that the administration could give teachers a 5.5 percent pay raise on Monday ``and then announce on Thursday that it was planning for 15,000 layoffs. This is not fiscal leadership. It is fiscal folly.'' The mayor has said he is considering laying off 15,000 city workers to save money. Dinkins said the city has made it through past financial difficulties and that, ``I can assure Standard and Poor's, taxpayers, noteholders and the citizens of this city that my administration will continue this tradition of responding fully and quickly to the difficulties a deteriorating economy and rising costs pose for our budget.''

DOC.HEAD: Martin Media Adviser Calls Simon `Slimy,' `Weenie'
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Lynn Martin's media adviser Tuesday called Illinois Sen. Paul Simon a ``weenie'' and ``slimy'' and promised a ``bang-up finish'' in the final weeks of the campaign. Roger Ailes, the ad man who worked for President Bush's campaign in 1988, called a news conference in Chicago to defend Martin, who is running far behind Simon in the polls and has had trouble raising money. ``People like Paul `Slimon' Simon are the ones who are hurting America,'' said Ailes, according to a tape recording provided by the Martin camp. ``The truth isn't getting out there, so now we're going to have to let people know about him,'' he said. ``There won't be anything in our ads that's not true. It will all be there - but it will hurt.'' Simon campaign manager Anne Roosevelt responded: ``Lynn Martin is getting awfully desperate if she's sending in her media adviser as a hatchet man to call Paul Simon names.'' Meanwhile, the Illinois League of Women Voters postponed a debate between the candidates that was set for Thursday, after Democrat Simon said his Senate schedule would prevent him from returning to Chicago. Ailes said Simon has ``slandered'' Martin by running TV ads that say the former teacher is an enemy of senior citizens and schools. He acknowledged that Martin voted against increasing Medicare spending and against lowering the rate of out-of-pocket costs, ``but these were not votes to cut Medicare.'' ``Simon is just being Simon which is unfortunately being slimy,'' Ailes said. During the news conference, Ailes also called Simon a ``weenie,'' a comment that later led to an apology from Martin.

Israel's leaders imposed curfews in the occupied lands and mobilized troops today after police opened fire on Palestinians who rioted at holy sites in the Old City, killing at least 19 Arabs and wounding 140. Palestinian leaders in the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip demanded U.N. protection and announced a weeklong protest strike beginning today, the start of the 36th month of the anti-Israeli uprising in the territories. Monday's incident at the Temple Mount, which is sacred to both Moslems and Jews, forced the Palestinian question back onto the international agenda. It was the bloodiest clash in Jerusalem since the 1967 Middle East war, when Israel seized the city's eastern Arab sector and the West Bank from Jordan and the Gaza Strip from Egypt. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - David H. Souter, a mild-mannered, well-read and previously little-known judge from New Hampshire, becomes history's 105th Supreme Court justice today after pledging to ``do equal right to the poor and to the rich.'' Souter, 51, planned to take the judicial oath, administered by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, and almost immediately get to work hearing high court arguments with his eight new colleagues. The oath requires Souter to ``solemnly swear to administer justice without respect to persons, and do equal right to the poor and to the rich.'' Afterward, Souter and Rehnquist planned to pose for photographers outside the building on Capitol Hill before heading back inside to take their seats on the bench for the start of the court's regularly scheduled proceedings. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - The super-rich are getting a dose of what many Americans already know: rougher economic times. Fifty-three of the nation's 400 richest people suffered declines in net worth this year ranging from $100 million to $880 million, Forbes magazine said in its Oct. 22 edition. For the first time since Forbes began publishing the list in 1982, the minimum net worth required to join the elite ranking dropped, from $275 million last year to $260 million. Among marquee names evicted from the list was Donald Trump, who symbolized the 1980s era of living on borrowed money. Forbes said Trump's fortune, estimated at $1.7 billion in 1989, was possibly within ``hailing distance of zero'' because of looming loan deadlines and a slow economy. ---= SALT LAKE CITY (AP) - The son of former Gov. Scott M. Matheson believes the open-air atomic testing whose dangers his father fought to expose caused the cancer that killed him. Matheson died Sunday at age 61 of multiple myeloma. He lived in Cedar City in the early 1950s when the government conducted dozens of above-ground tests 300 miles away in Nevada that caused radioactive fallout to drift into Utah. As governor from 1977 to 1985, Matheson fought to expose the dangers of those tests and gain compensation for radiation victims - an effort that succeeded with the passage by Congress last week of a compensation bill. Scott M. Matheson Jr. said Monday his father found it an ``interesting wrinkle'' that he was diagnosed with a disease that Congress recognized as having possible links to atomic fallout. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Secretary of State James A. Baker III is switching back to Cold War-era language in an effort to defeat a House move to cut off U.S. aid to anti-communist rebels in Angola. In a private memo he sent recently to House Minority Leader Robert Michel, R-Ill., Baker said ending aid to the Angolan rebels would derail peace negotiations ``and would be a vote for more killing, more stalemate and more suffering.'' This is ``the absolutely worst time'' to halt the aid, Baker said. The United States has been providing covert aid to the UNITA rebels in the southwest African country since 1986, but congressional sentiment against continued assistance seems to be increasing.

DOC.HEAD: BAD BLOOD: Money, Drugs, Sex and the Law - The Von Bulow Odyssey
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Reversal of Fortune'' opens in New York on Oct. 17 and elsewhere in November.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: In the movie ``Reversal of Fortune,'' based on Claus von Bulow's legal morass after his fabulously wealthy wife slipped into a coma, his lawyer declares the Danish socialite to be a ``very strange man.'' Von Bulow, played with jaw-clenched control by Jeremy Irons, peers out from behind a heavy shadow and responds, ``You have no idea.'' Off-camera, Irons painstakingly maintains the von Bulow mystique. Indeed, he massages it with ice cold hands. And that jaw rarely relaxes. Don't ask him whether he thinks von Bulow is guilty or innocent of attempting to kill his wife, Sunny, by injecting her with insulin and causing her to slip into an irreversible coma. Irons, despite his extensive research into the role, won't say. ``Work it out, work it out,'' he implores. ``The court found him innocent,'' he flatly offers. Then suddenly things turn philosphical. Irons gets pensive. ``Is there a heaven or a hell? The sad thing is we don't know,'' he says. ``It's a great weakness of our society. We like to have everything black and white. We'd like to know that if we think Saddam Hussein is a mad dog, we're happy. We're wrong because he ain't. He's a leader of a huge nation. That's what he is. So I always question this desire to say `he's guilty' or `he's innocent.' Life ain't like that.'' Life for von Bulow turned ugly in 1980, when Sunny went unconscious one morning, sequestered in her only sanctuary - her bathroom. Their marriage was foundering and her children believed their stepfather engineered her tragedy by pumping her full of insulin. They hired private detectives and damaging evidence was found. After von Bulow was convicted of attempted murder, he hired high-profile Harvard University law professor Alan Dershowitz to appeal, which is where ``Reversal of Fortune'' picks up. Director Barbet Schroeder has crafted a twisted tale rendered somewhat implausible because of its narrator - Sunny (Glenn Close), who, of course, is in a persistent vegetative state. How, you ask yourself over and over, are we to beieve this story, told in the voice of a person we already know has been left forever mute? But ``Reversal of Fortune,'' based on Dershowitz's book of the same title, aptly depicts the couple's guilded, sordid excess: They keep a pharmacy of drugs next to their bed, they guzzle booze, sleep with others and then coldly detail their philanderings at cocktail parties. And Ron Silver weighs in with his usual steely verve in his portrayal of Dershowitz, giving the fast talking lawyer a wonderful emphatic brilliance. Von Bulow's 1982 conviction in Rhode Island on two counts of assaut with intent to kill his wife was overturned by the appeal and second trial in 1985. In 1987, he agreed to a divorce from his wife and renounced all claims to her fortune, including the $120,000-a-year trust fund created for him before she lapsed into the coma. His share of her estate was estimated at $25 million. Von Bulow, now 63, lives in London and will receive no remuneration from the movie. Martha ``Sunny'' von Bulow remains in a coma at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in New York City. Irons recently spent an entire day pussy-footing around over von Bulow's culpability during a tightly scheduled 24-hour media stop in New York, wedging reporters in back to back, between photo shoots and television filming. ``I'm very to the point,'' he declares at the start of the interview at his hotel suite. While chatting, the sepia-tanned Irons reclines his lanky frame sideways into a deep chair, swinging his legs and stocking feet over one side so that his body forms a lazy ``u.'' He nibbles grapes when he isn't puffing down Silk Cut-brand cigarettes. Meanwhile, soup from a nearby deli grows cold. He's prone to one- or two-word answers followed by long piercing stares. When describing von Bulow's predicament, he purses his lips together and crisply pronounces it ``tricky stuff, tricky stuff.'' To prepare for the role, Irons studied taped interviews von Bulow had with Barbara Walters and Phil Donahue. He also said he read all of the trial transcripts. And he spent hours interviewing those who knew the socialite, although he never approached von Bulow directly. Still, Irons is mum. ``I wouldn't describe Claus von Bulow because I've never met him,'' he says. ``My reading of him is what I show on the screen.'' Irons doesn't believe his portrayal of von Bulow gives him license to discuss him. ``I don't want to comment on him because it's not my job, not my position to talk about Claus von Bulow and I wouldn't think if I was in his situation I'd enjoy reading what some actor thought about him.'' In fact, Irons prefers that the issue of guilt or innocence remain an idelible question mark. ``I wanted to keep him an enigma,'' Irons says. Tricky stuff, tricky stuff - and very strange, indeed.

DOC.HEAD: `Maniac Mansion' - Situation Comedy's Answer to `Twin Peaks'
DOC.TEXT: ``Maniac Mansion'' is what ``Twin Peaks'' would be if it were a situation comedy that was inspired by a Nintendo computer game. Where ABC's ``Twin Peaks'' brings horror, violence and intrigue to prime-time soap opera, ``Maniac Mansion'' brings horror, family values and a crazy sweetness to domestic comedy. ``Maniac Mansion'' has Joe Flaherty playing the mildly eccentric scientist Fred Edison, a man who looks like he's just realized his pants are on fire. Deborah Theaker plays his sweet, nurturing wife, Casey. The kids are Tina, Ike, and Turner. Ike and Tina (Avi Phillips and Kathleen Robinson) are fine, but Turner (George Buza) . . . well, Turner's been a 6-foot-4, 250-pound 4-year-old ever since he walked into an experiment that went awry. Then there's Uncle Harry (John Hemphill), who's half human, half housefly (with tiny human head and a cute, squeaky voice), who was transformed by the same experiment that turned Turner into a credible hulk. Harry doesn't seem to mind being a fly, although his diet never comes up in conversation. He might even enjoy the life, since it gets him away from his sometimes aggravating wife, Idella, played by Mary Charlotte Wilcox. The series, airing early Friday nights on cable TV's Family Channel, is suffused with a wonderful note of suppressed hysteria. It's as easy to watch with grandchildren as with grandparents and it raises important questions: How would YOU handle the hurt feelings of a typical 4-year-old who's built like an All-Pro linebacker? This is the first foray into TV programming for Lucasfilm Ltd., which brought us the ``Star Wars'' and Indiana Jones trilogies as well as the Maniac Mansion computer game for Nintendo machines. The game and the show have little in common, other than a scientist named Fred and a mansion with a strange meteorite beneath it that pulses eerie radiation. The TV show gets its edge from alumni of the Toronto-based Second City troupe and others who brought us the Emmy Award-winning ``Second City TV'' in the late '70s and early '80s. Flaherty and Eugene Levy, a writer and executive producer of ``Maniac Mansion,'' were mainstays of an ``SCTV'' cast that included John Candy, Andrea Martin, Bob Thomas, Catherine O'Hara, and Martin Short. Wilcox and Hemphill are former ``SCTV'' writers. Hemphill, who also played the fragile, booze-tremored barfly who anchored his ``SCTV'' kiddie show from a tavern, is a staff writer as well as housefly for ``Maniac Mansion.'' Is this just another formulaic, three-camera sitcom? Uh-uh. It's shot on film, and Ray Brounstein's agile photography gives the show a rich, distinctive look. There is no laugh track. Shows like ``Moonlighting'' and ``Twin Peaks'' won critical acclaim for violating the conventions of series TV, ``breaking the fourth wall'' with asides to the audience or defying viewers' expectations of a linear plot. ``Maniac Mansion'' flings those conventions down and tramples on them. In the pilot episode, the camera tracked past Fred and thumped him a glancing blow on the head. (``Ow!'') The show, titled ``The 10th Anniversary Special,'' began as the Edisons went to celebrate their decade on TV with dinner at a Chinese restaurant. Uncle Harry the Fly chirps his anticipation: ``I've been regurgitating all day!'' Suddenly the authorities announce they're spraying for Medflies. The family - especially Harry - can't leave home. Fred realizes that this leaves an incredible hole in the first act. How will they recap the past decade's shows? Idella's home movies don't help. Film of her 1963 vacation trip to Dallas includes a downtown picnic on a grassy knoll where bystanders see something horrible happen off-camera and duck to the ground in fear. There, behind oblivious Idella and her picnic companions, men in raincoats and sunglasses carry away a rifle. ``You say no one has ever seen this?'' Casey asks, frowning. No, Idella says. Why? ``Oh, nothing. Never mind.'' In a later episode, Uncle Harry falls for a cute girl fly who's had a hard life. Born in a garbage can, she grew up in Chinatown and got hooked on MSG. Ah, but when she flashes those baby-black compound eyes! Eventually, Idella's suspicions are aroused and she begins to believe she's being made a fool of by some cheap, little . . . fly. Despite Harry's denials, Idella determines to eliminate her rival by . . . murder! KILLING A FLY!!! Is there a happy ending? That's probably the nicest thing about ``Maniac Mansion.'' Underneath all that weirdness, the Edisons are a fine, likable family, coping with absurd situations with dignity and grace. And you'll never feel the same way about 4-year-olds or flies. --- Elsewhere in television ... GROENING NOT COMPLAINING: ``The Simpsons'' cartoon maestro Matt Groening (whose name rhymes with ``complaining'') is featured in an interview segment today on the syndicated show ``Personalities,'' with host Charlie Rose. A native of Portland, Ore., Groening moved to Los Angeles in 1977 and began drawing the cartoon strip ``Life in Hell,'' which appears in more than 100 newspapers. ``The Simpsons,'' Fox's runaway prime time hit last season, began life as ``bumpers'' leading into and out of commercials on ``The Tracey Ullman Show.'' ``The Simpsons'' return to first-run episodes Thursday night against NBC's perennial ratings winner, ``The Cosby Show.''

DOC.HEAD: Small Business Gets Depressed
DOC.TEXT: The small-business community is becoming distressdd. A survey conducted in September by the National Federation of Independent Business showed confidence collapsing to the lowest level in a decade, lower even than in the deep recession of 1982. The decline in confidence was across the board, encompassing nine of the 10 components that make up the federation's optimism index. Capital spending plans dropped, hiring plans weakened, and inventory investment plans were cut. The survey was conducted before budget negotiators reached agreement to raise taxes, but it hardly could have helped: taxes were named by respondents as the biggest problem facing small businesses. It was a runaway. Respondents named taxes nearly five times as often as they mentioned inflation, and four times as often as financing difficulties, which have been widely reported as being of credit-crunch magnitude. The federation has conducted surveys since 1974 under the direction of economist William Dunkelberg, now dean of Temple University's school of business and management, and has published the results quarterly. Rarely are monthly findings published, but the federation departed from its usual practice because of the ``unusual findings'' of the September survey. After studying 766 responses, Dunkelberg said the economy ``appears poised to enter an `NBER' recession, a reference to the National Bureau of Economic Research's definition of a recession as two straight negative quarters. While the latest decline was unusually sharp, Dunkelberg observed that the nation's economy has been weakening for many months, provoking the question of whether ``the process of undoing the recession will be gradual as well.'' The small-business optimism index is devised from answers to 10 questions, including expected business conditions, expected credit conditions, current job openings, plans to hire and capital outlay plans. The September drop of 3.2 points brought the index to 92.1 from an August reading of 95.3 points, based on the 1978 economy equaling 100. The lowest in the 1981-1982 recession was 92.5 points. Since 1983, the reading has rarely fallen below 100. It reached an all-time high of 108.8 points in the second quarter of 1983, and stood at 104.5 as recently as early 1988. While the federation's figures are gathered from companies too small to make their way onto lists of the 1,000 largest companies - some, in fact, are tiny proprietorships - it claims the results are an accurate barometer. Dunkelberg observes that while the largest companies obtain the greatest publicity, the smaller businesses represented in the survey employ one-half the private, non-farm work force and produce half the nation's private product. Historically, the survey has an accurate record of forecasting the economy's direction, a record sometimes ascribed to the ability of smaller companies to sense grass-roots consumer responses and changes of attitude. Based on September's results, Dunkelberg believes the current quarter may be the first one of negative growth in the current downturn. Negative growth occurs when gross national product actually shrinks rather than expands. Among other things, that report will reflect attitudinal changes resulting from the budget negotiating now under way in Washington, including reactions to any tax actions.

DOC.HEAD: City Faces-City Fears: One in a Series
Critical Care: Emergency Room Like `War Zone Medicine'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Series Logo
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Emergency rooms are overburdened with the worst wounds of urban America: the gunshot holes from drug wars, medicine for the homeless and uninsured, care for AIDS patients. In this final part of an occasional series, ``City Faces, City Fears,'' a doctor talks about ``war zone medicine.'' ---

Dr. Robert Hessler surveys the gridlock of gurneys cramming the emergency room hallways and makes a troubling diagnosis: Something is wrong beyond the chest pains, broken limbs and stomachaches confronting him. Each patient has a crisis, and has hurried here only to wait. The emergency room is an overstretched strand in the health care safety net, backlogged to the bursting point by overcrowding and social wounds. ``The emergency room is overwhelmed with patients who need to be administered to,'' says Hessler, assistant director of emergency services at city-owned Bellevue Hospital. ``We do what we can minute to minute. We're using every little nook and cranny we can find to take care of these people.'' Five patients are going to intensive care; four more to the heart attack unit. Twenty-one have been patched up and are awaiting admission to the hospital, including one man with an oxygen tube in his throat. But the traffic doesn't stop with this batch of casualties. A cluster of arriving emergencies queues up for riage. The worst get seen first. Time passes with neither comfort nor silence in this makeshift ward. Patients on stretchers stare at the ceiling without so much as a curtain for privacy. Hessler, 38, patrols the area with a stethoscope dangling from his neck and the pocket of his unbuttoned lab coat bulging with diagnoses on a notepad. Delays are more than just an inconvenience; they imperil the delivery of care. ``It's not a pleasant way to be sick,'' Hessler said. ``I'm always afraid that somebody who's seriously ill has to wait longer than they have to for a physician.'' An average of 300 people a day pass through the emergency room at Bellevue. President Bush, Mikhail Gorbachev and other dignitaries would be rushed here if something happened while they were in New York. Because of its quality care, city cops hurt in the line of duty prefer 264-year-old Bellevue, the nation's oldest continuously operating public hospital. It also sees the worst wounds of the city: crack addicts, bullet holes from drug-related assault guns, AIDS patients, the homeless who have no place else to go for care, teen-agers run over by subway cars who need their severed limbs reattached, inmates from city prisons whose manacled ankles protrude from stretchers. At Bellevue, battlefield images fit like bandages on a wound. ``We're kind of a field hospital. This is war zone medicine. We see all the casualties,'' Hessler said. ``We see everything here. We are the window to the world. You will never go anywhere else in the world and see something we haven't already seen at Bellevue.'' Drugs are found in two out of three patients who are shot, stabbed or hit by a car, doctors say. One-fourth of the trauma cases involve people who have mixed two or more intoxicants, usually alcohol and cocaine. The homeless seek treatment for such ills as frostbite and rotted feet similar to soldiers who suffered trench foot, a disease caused by prolonged exposure to wet, cold and inactivity. ``It's like a Third World situation,'' Hessler said. ``And when it's cold, we see body temperatures of 66 degrees. That's almost the equivalent of hibernation. Their whole body is cold, not just their feet and hands.'' The river of patients creates stress and frustration. ``A patient doesn't have things people come to expect in a hospital - a bed, a room, certainly not a TV. If you have to go to the bathroom, you get a bedpan,'' Hessler said. The clamor is a long way from the quiet calm of Hessler's hometown of Billings, Mont. He spent seven years at the University of Miami Medical School before doing his residency at New York University, one of the country's top medical schools. Hessler specialized in internal medicine, but opted for emergency doctoring. It allows him to do a little bit of everything that interests him: internal medicine, pediatrics, obstetrics-gynecology, and surgery. ``I like to work with critically ill patients. They make you think and work the hardest you possibly can. You're keeping people alive,'' Hessler said. ``You have to do the right thing in the first few hours for whatever they have. It puts such a stress on some people that one of the major problems is physician burnout. Some doctors aren't able to function with that pressure.'' Or the daily dose of death. For every rush of adrenalin that comes with saving a life, there are terrible pendulum swings of seeing people die. ``We're not God. Not everybody can be saved,'' Hessler said. ``But if you die in spite of everything I could possibly have done, at least I feel we delivered the best possible care and did everything we could have.'' He stays, even though there are better-paying jobs with less heartache. ``People asked me why anybody from the NYU training program would want to do emergency medicine,'' Hessler said. ``We're a setting of last resort, delivering care to people who don't have any insurance, don't have any money and don't have any place else to go. We're here because we want to help people.'' On call 24 hours a day, Hessler escapes the bedlam of Bellevue at his suburban home in River Vale, N.J. He eases the tension by clipping his rhododendrons, junipers and yews. ``After a day of wild and chaotic work, I can go home,'' Hessler said. ``I can trim the bushes, look at my lawn, water the plants, watch the birds flying around. I'm used to a more calm lifestyle.'' In addition to sewing up accident victims or treating kids who swallow rat poison, doctors care for societal ills. A Polaroid camera is kept to document suspected child abuse. A standard evidence kit can store specimens from rape victims. In one sweep through the room, Hessler bandages a smashed nose, takes vital signs on a heart patient, scalpels the bureaucratic red tape so a patient can get X-rays and tries to find out why a patient is waiting for attention. ``You're doing three, four or five things at the same time,'' Hessler said. ``You're working so hard you don't have time to think about what you'd rather be doing. You're too busy patching people's lives back together.'' Splotches of dried blood, bandage wrappings, discarded surgical gloves, bedpans, surgical tape, syringe cases and other medical flotsam litter the floor. Patients stack their shoes, coats and other possessions on the bottom of their gurneys as they wait to be released or admitted. Their medicine is not sugarcoated. ``If you come to the emergency room, I can't give you peace and quiet and comfort,'' Hessler said. ``And for people who aren't critically ill, I can guarantee you a very long wait.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues AMs, Oct. 16

DOC.HEAD: Problem Diagnosis: Emergency Rooms in Critical Condition
With AM-City Faces-Doctor
DOC.TEXT: A crush of patients has put city emergency rooms in critical condition. The average wait is six to eight hours, and one New York patient languished eight days before being admitted, surveys show. The backlog imperils the quality of care in 41 states and the District of Columbia, according to a survey last year by the American College of Emergency Physicians. The Northeast and West Coast have particularly acute congestion. ``It's a cruel illusion to dismiss this as a New York problem. This is emphatically a nationwide problem,'' said Dr. Arthur Kellermann, a member of the ACEP study group on overcrowding. The only states not reporting backlogs were Idaho, Minnesota, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New Mexico, North Dakota, Oregon, Utah and Wyoming. The nation's 5,700 emergency rooms had 90 million visitors last year, an increase of 30 percent in 10 years, according to the American Hospital Association. There were 80 million visits five years ago. The overcrowding crisis stems from a number of reasons: the surge in drug overdoses and drug-related violence; the AIDS epidemic; the fact that emergency rooms are a place of last resort for the homeless and an estimated 37 million Americans who have no health insurance; a nursing shortage; cutbacks in the number of hospital rooms; and formulas for federal money that discourage emergency admissions. ``We are on the verge of a major crisis,'' said Dr. Stephan Lynn, chairman of the ACEP study group and director of emergency medicine at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in New York City. ``The lights never go out. The noise never turns off,'' Lynn said. ``Some of my patients have no means to pay their bill and some could buy the hospital, but all of my patients wait. When there is no bed available, it doesn't really matter how rich you are.'' A 1989 survey by the New York state health department showed that of 2,000 emergency room patients being treated one day, 210 waited eight to 24 hours for care, and 108 waited longer than 24 hours. The average wait in an emergency room is six to eight hours, according to a survey of 300 hospitals in 43 states by the National Association of Public Hospitals. At Harbor-UCLA Medical Center in Los Angeles, patients wait eight to 10 hours - four times longer than they did 10 years ago. The emergency room is so busy that it turns away arriving ambulances 20 percent of the time. ``That results in ambulances wandering around the city trying to find emergency departments that are open,'' said Dr. Robert Hockberger, chairman of emergency medicine at Harbor-UCLA.

DOC.HEAD: Bradys on Stage Draw Bunches of Fans - But Why?
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: OK, video kids, fill in the blank: ``Here's the story ``Of a man named - - - - -'' If you answered ``Brady,'' get in line for the unlikeliest hit on Chicago's theater scene: ``The Real Live Brady Bunch.'' The show is a live, word-for-word re-enactment of different episodes from the early 1970s television series, ``The Brady Bunch.'' The all-adult cast plays it straight, from the dopey sing-along theme song to little Cindy's irritating lisp. The show has become so popular since beginning its Tuesday night run in early June that the 110-seat Annoyance Theater added a second weekly performance in mid-August. The cramped theater in a funky, North Side neighborhood charges $7 a ticket. If ``The Real Live Bradys'' is art - and not even the actors agree on that point - it may be the first case of art imitating TV sitcom life, a kind of life so far removed from the real thing that it's, well, laughable. A concept this loopy could only have been hatched by people with genuine affection for the Bradys: sisters Faith and Jill Soloway, who jointly produce and direct the shows for the Metraform theater company. ``We pay tribute to the Bradys, we don't disrespect them,'' Jill said. Like the young professionals who fill the theater, the Soloways are in their mid-20s and grew up watching the Brady Bunch, which stayed on television from 1969-'74 and ran as an hour-long series in 1977 before hitting the rerun trail. ``We were all really jealous of the Bradys,'' Jill said, a sentiment also expressed by several spectators at a recent performance. Brady envy? It's not hard to understand. In their suburban digs, the Bradys resided in a universe far removed from the social and political turmoil of their times. Teen-ager Greg Brady never worried he might be drafted and sent to Vietnam. No Brady ever wondered if Nixon was a crook. Nor were the Brady children ever stressed by the dynamics of their mix-and-match family: a widower and his new wife, her three daughters, his three sons and Alice, their old-maid housekeeper. Brady family crises involved such mundane aggravations as Dad's misplaced architectural plans and middle daughter Jan sneaking a peek at eldest daughter Marcia's diary. And as self-styled Brady historian Max Merlin, a Northwestern University film student, observed, ``their problems always worked out in 23{ minutes.'' Actress Eve Plumb, who played Jan in the series, experienced the Brady revival first-hand when the Soloway sisters flew her in from Los Angeles to guest star in one of their shows during the summer. She played a bit part, choosing not to reprise her role as pubescent Jan at age 32. It was ``a totally bizarre experience,'' Plumb said in a telephone interview from Los Angeles, where she is a rotating cast member of the Groundlings, an improvisational troupe. She said she doesn't understand the Bradys' enduring appeal, but thinks the Chicago show is ``sort of a hoot.'' ``Brady Bunch'' creator Sherwood Schwartz, who also gave us ``Gilligan's Island,'' suggested the lure of the Bradys is mostly nostalgia. ``It's something people have as a reference point in their youth, and they hold fond memories of those shows,'' he said in a telephone interview from Los Angeles. But Chicago actress Jane Lynch, who plays mother Carol in ``The Real Live Bradys,'' holds that nostalgia is only part of the show's draw. She said the other half - the element that transforms ``The Real Live Bradys'' from camp into art - is the realization by audience members that the Bradys' uncomplicated lives were nothing like what life turned out to be. ``A teacher once told me the purpose of art is to enlighten and inform,'' Lynch said. ``This informs us as to what we bought into as children and enlightens us that it was crap.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv

DOC.HEAD: Doctors for Sale
Part II: Money for Patients: One Hospital's Story
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Series Logo
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Many doctors receive financial help from hospitals. But ethical and legal lines are crossed when the deals require doctors to admit patients. In Part II of ``Doctors For Sale,'' National Writer Fred Bayles and Science Writer Daniel Q. Haney tell how one California hospital used money and favors to influence doctors' practice of medicine. ---
DOC.HEAD: and
DANIEL Q. HANEY
DOC.TEXT: When Simi Valley Adventist Hospital gave a $25,000 loan to a young obstetrician, it wanted something more valuable than money: his pregnant patients. ``You will attempt to bring 100 percent of your deliveries to this hospital,'' the loan agreement read. ``You will attempt to bring the vast majority of your elective GYN cases to this hospital.'' In return for ``supporting the hospital with your patients,'' no money need be paid back. After five years, the doctor would owe nothing. The agreement concluded with a plea he keep the deal secret ``for various reasons.'' At least one reason was obvious: It was illegal, according to a later grand jury finding. State and federal laws bar doctors from accepting financial rewards for sending patients to hospitals. The doctor, Vihe Azizian, an Iranian immigrant, said he didn't know the arrangement broke the law. But he had no doubt why the hospital gave him money. ``They weren't in love with my pretty eyes,'' Azizian said. ``It wasn't a loan. It was a gift to put my patients in their hospital.'' Azizian's gift was everyday business, it appears, during the 1980s at Simi Valley Adventist, a 215-bed hospital affiliated with the Seventh Day Adventist Church. Interviews, along with logs, internal memos and insurance records obtained by The Associated Press, show the hospital showered doctors with hundreds of thousands of dollars in loans, subsidized rent, equipment and discounted hospital services. One complicated deal even made it possible for doctors to get a cut when they referred patients for X-rays. The hospital kept these patients' records in a school composition book rather than its computer. ``There were things done that seemed obviously illegal and unethical,'' said Dr. Paul Ironside, a surgeon. ``The administrator told me some doctors would actually pound on the desk and say they would take their patients away unless they got a check.'' Offers of interest-free loans, income guarantees and other subsidies have become commonplace across the country as hospitals compete to win physicians' allegiances. But some of the Simi Valley deals bluntly stated what most others only imply: The money was payment for patients. Many worry that kickbacks, whether spelled out or implied, are more than technical violations of law. They can harm patients. The doctor has a financial enticement to send sick people to the hospital that gives him the best deal, not the one that gives patients the best care. ``Physicians are complaining that they made requests for new equipment at the hospital and were told that money was tight,'' said Dr. Martin Wareham, Simi Valley's chief of staff. ``At the same time, the hospital was loaning out all this money.'' The deal-making at Simi Valley Adventist grew out of economic changes that have made patients a coveted commodity. Government programs and private insurers push hospitals to send patients home sooner or treat them as outpatients. The result has been empty beds and hefty competition for patients. In Simi Valley, the competitors were two modest community hospitals. Adventist is a low, spartan facility built 25 years ago against the dry brown hills on the edge of town. Its competitor, Mountain View Medical Center, was an even smaller, privately owned hospital on the other side of the narrow valley. As the one-time farming town was overtaken by the housing projects and condominiums creeping northwest from Los Angeles, both hospitals tried to persuade doctors and patients not to take their business ``over the hill'' to facilities in adjoining valleys. ``They were struggling, and we were struggling,'' recalled Dr. Elvin Gaines, a longtime Adventist family practitioner. ``It became a competition for physicians and their loyalties.'' Once the deals began, Gaines said, many doctors wanted in. Gaines himself was a recipient. He got a $1 million construction loan from the Adventist system to build an office building across the street from the hospital. ``It mushroomed,'' he said of the deals. ``They said, `You treated him good. Why don't you treat me good?' '' The hospital's current administrator, Alan Rice, declined to talk about specific deals that took place before he came to Simi Valley. ``As far as this administration is concerned, we are taking an extremely conservative position on how we would behave as it relates to marketing practices,'' he said. Most of the deals were struck by Darwin Remboldt, administrator from 1984 until 1989. He declined to be interviewed, but records and interviews show Remboldt established a wide range of arrangements with doctors: -Hundreds of thousands of dollars were loaned to several doctors. Among the largest series of loans went to Drs. George Dichter and Geoffrey Graham to set up the Sterling Group, a multi-specialty group. Gaines, a former member of the hospital board of directors, said the two received as much as $600,000. A recently concluded county grand jury investigation found Dichter and Graham would not be required to pay back the loans if, among other things, they admitted patients to Simi Valley Adventist for five years. Christopher Caldwell, the attorney representing the doctors, declined comment on the grand jury's findings other that to say, ``There was nothing illegal or improper about the doctors' arrangements with the hospital.'' -The hospital gave special discounts on X-rays to some doctors, who in turn were free to charge patients the full fee. Physicians said a dual price list and a crude, handwritten record of patients' X-rays were kept at a hospital reception desk. Ethical and legal rules prohibit doctors from marking up patients' bills. -The hospital established an Ask-A-Nurse hot line, through which callers were referred to doctors, who were expected to return the favor by putting patients in Adventist. A hospital memo stated the program would exclude doctors who placed their Ask-A-Nurse referrals ``at a facility other than Simi Valley Adventist Hospital.'' -The hospital helped a doctor build a chain of walk-in clinics. ``The hospital thought it would be a good referral source,'' said Dr. Walter Thomas, adding that he repaid hospital loans with interest. Those who questioned the deals risked retaliation, Gaines said. He said he was kicked off the hospital's board of directors following a disagreement with Remboldt. The deals began unraveling in 1987 after the Adventists bought the competing hospital. A doctor who lost a contract for staffing Mountain View's emergency room filed a lawsuit bringing some of them to light. Federal investigators looked into the case, and a county grand jury called Remboldt and a number of doctors to testify. Many declined, citing Fifth Amendment rights against self-incrimination. Remboldt later spoke to the panel after he was granted immunity from prosecution. The grand jury issued a report in June, stating the deals with Azizian, Dichter and Graham violated California law. The question was moot, however, because the three-year statute of limitations had run out. Administrator Rice said the grand jury findings showed his administration has met the letter of the law. But he complained the panel's findings that earlier deals were illegal ``applied present interpretations of the law to three years ago when circumstances were very different.''

DOC.TEXT: Azizian, who cooperated with the grand jury, denied the loans affected his practice of medicine. ``My admission situation did not change at all,'' he said. ``I sent people where they wanted to go.'' The grand jury made no mention of the other specific deals, such as the X-ray arrangements, and its records are now sealed. The panel was highly critical, however, of hospital deals. ``Such incentives to physicians increase costs to public and private insurance programs and ultimately to patients by causing physicians to overuse hospital facilities,'' the panel's report said. ``Perhaps more importantly, these incentives can hurt patients by inducing physicians to favor one hospital, even though other hospitals may offer better care for a particular patient need.''' In Simi Valley, doctors remain suspicious of the hospital and each other. ``I think a lot of it was the physicians' fault,'' said Gaines. ``A lot of physicians who went to the trough didn't have to. They were making good money and didn't need it. It was wrong.''

DOC.HEAD: X-Ray Arrangement Part of Unusual Deal With Doctors
With Doctors for Sale II
DOC.TEXT: When some patients went to Simi Valley Adventist Hospital for X-rays, a clerk entered their records in a black-covered school composition book instead of the hospital's computer. A special cut-rate price list also was reserved for these people's X-rays, part of an unusual deal offered to a handful of doctors who referred patients to the hospital. Confidential interviews, internal memos and secret records show it appeared to work this way: A chest X-ray usually cost $56, and the hospital billed the patient directly. Under the special arrangement, the hospital sent the bill to the doctor and charged him $16. The doctor, in turn, charged the patient whatever he pleased. Ethical and legal rules prohibit doctors from marking up patients' bills. One variation on the arrangement was available to a few doctors who sent patients to the hospital for breast X-rays known as mammograms. A crude handwritten record of their X-rays was kept in the composition book stored in the radiology department reception desk. Those doctors, not the patients, were charged a discounted $90 for the X-ray and $25 for a radiologist's interpretation. According to billing and insurance records obtained by The Associated Press, the doctors then charged their patients $150, the full fee. ``I questioned why I would pay the doctor separately for the mammogram,'' recalled one patient, Patricia Gillesby. Her physician said the difference between the hospital charge and what his office collected went to compensate him for extra work. ``There are many, many times when I review a mammogram myself,'' he said. Another doctor who participated in the arrangement defended the markup, saying he brought patients back for a second, free visit to tell them their results. ``The difference was justified in our examination and discussion with the patient,'' he said. When staff radiologists complained, they were threatened. Minutes from a 1986 meeting of the Mid Valley Radiology Medical Group noted that administrator Darwin Remboldt told one of the radiologists ``that he would terminate our contract if we do not allow it.'' The radiologists viewed the agreements as bad medicine. ``There will be considerable confusion to patients, radiology staff and referring physicians when sometimes X-rays taken in the hospital are not the property of the hospital and no records or reports of the examinations are made,'' the radiologists wrote in a letter to Remboldt. Another complaint: Some of the X-rays were being interpreted by general practitioners, not radiologists. ``They would read their own films and bring them down to us and say `What's that?' and point to something insignificant when there was something that was significant that they missed,'' said a radiologist who asked not to be identified for fear of retribution. Alan Rice, the hospital's current administrator, said he knew nothing about the X-ray arrangement. Remboldt declined to discuss it.

DOC.HEAD: Details of One Hospital Deal with Doctor
With Doctors for Sale II
DOC.TEXT: When Darwin Remboldt, head of Simi Valley Adventist Hospital, gave a loan to Dr. Vahe Azizian, he spelled out the terms in a letter. Here is the text of the letter, written July 17, 1985, on hospital stationery. Amortized means written off: ``This letter will confirm that Simi Valley Adventist Hospital will loan you $25,000 under the following conditions. Acceptance of these conditions will be shown by your signature at the bottom of this letter. ``A. The loan will be amortized over 5 years at $5,000.00 a year. Should you leave the Simi Valley area or change your admitting practices, the balance will immediately become due and payable. ``B. You will continue to work towards becoming an active staff member at Simi Valley Adventist Hospital, attend the OB/GYN Department Meetings, and be active in Medical Staff Activities. ``C. You will attempt to bring 100% of your deliveries to this hospital. ``D. You will attempt to bring the vast majority of your elective GYN cases to this hospital. ``We both realize that much of what you have agreed to is being supportive of the hospital and giving your time on medical staff activities and supporting the hospital with your patients. There is no other way for me to know exactly where your patients are going other than your word and your desire to establish a good relationship with this hospital. ``I hope that we have a long and beneficial relationship between yourself and Simi Valley Adventist Hospital. I trust that this arrangement will be kept confidential for various reasons.'' The hospital may have had second thoughts about the deal after investigators began looking into the way it did business. Azizian, in a sworn affidavit connected to another physician's lawsuit, said Remboldt later asked him to sign a document stating the $25,000 Azizian received was for his emergency room services. ``I refused to sign the document at the time ... because the statements in the document were not true,'' he said. Remboldt declined to be interviewed about the letter.

DOC.HEAD: Doctors for Sale
Part III: What Happens to Some Doctors Who Put Patients First?
An AP Extra
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Series Logo
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Increasingly, doctors are under pressure to practice a style of medicine that is financially healthy for their hospitals. Those who insist on putting the patient's well-being first can find themselves in trouble. In the final part of ``Doctors For Sale,'' National Writer Fred Bayles and Science Writer Daniel Q. Haney explore the ways some hospitals punish doctors who become economic liabilities. ---
DOC.HEAD: and
DANIEL Q. HANEY
DOC.TEXT: When six people were hurt in a car wreck a few years ago, the surgeon on duty at nearby Parkland Medical Center knew his small emergency room would be overwhelmed by all the cuts and broken bones. So Dr. Paul Harper made a quick decision: Ambulances should carry the victims to three other hospitals besides Parkland. Spreading the carnage around meant the injured would get help more quickly. The doctor felt it was best for patients. But in this case, what was best for patients was not necessarily best for the hospital. Parkland lost business. ``I caught it for that,'' Harper recalled. ``The patients were supposed to come to Parkland, even though they couldn't handle them. The head nurse told me the administration was mad, and I shouldn't do that again.'' Such vignettes are common. Hospitals need patients. Doctors who send them away for any reason, even for better care, risk rebuke: A gentle scolding, perhaps. A quiet lecture about hospital economics. Or worse. In Harper's case, what came next was much worse. His career is in ruins. Once he performed 350 operations a year, the hospital's busiest surgeon. Now he performs a dozen. Harper has filed a lawsuit claiming the hospital engineered a slander campaign that destroyed his reputation and made doctors afraid to send him patients. Richard V. Wiebusch, the hospital's attorney, counters that Harper is in trouble because he is an incompetent doctor, not because he is a financial liability. Such open warfare between doctors and hospitals still is unusual, but the rules of conduct are changing. Many fear that blunt coercion is becoming more customary as more hospitals press doctors to practice a style of medicine that puts the health of the institution first. Usually, hospitals try to keep doctors in line through more subtle means: Nurses, who lose their jobs when hospital beds stand empty, cajole doctors to admit more patients. Many hospitals post names of those who fail to discharge elderly, low-paying Medicare patients quickly enough. Physicians who don't get the message may suddenly stop receiving referrals from the emergency room, an important source of new patients. But gentle persuasion can turn harsh. Some doctors complain they have been dogged by crudely planted rumors of incompetence, that hospital administrators have ordered other doctors to stop sending them patients or that their tiniest medical misjudgments are scrutinized by hospital review committees. The worst of these abuses do happen, said Dr. Howard L. Lang of Kentfield, Calif., chairman of the American Medical Association's Hospital Medical Staff Section. ``It's not a daily occurrence,'' he said, ``but it is occurring enough that it is not rare. We are not talking about a few whining malcontents. There are real problems out there.'' In general, hospitals want their doctors to bring in lots of patients. They want them to order plenty of X-rays and tests when the sick are covered by generous private insurance plans. And they want them to do just the opposite when Medicare picks up the tab. Hospitals lose money when the elderly ill linger too long. Medicare categorizes virtually all old people into DRGs, or diagnosis-related groups. The DRG classification for a particular illness pays a single flat fee for the patient, no matter how sick he is or how long he stays in the hospital. ``DRGs encourage the hospitals to keep their costs down, and yet the physician controls what the hospital bill will be,'' said Dr. E. Haavi Morreim of the University of Tennessee. ``The hospitals have had to do something to bring the physicians under the same incentive. Many hospital administrators have felt the necessity for some sort of system of carrots and sticks, either formal or informal.'' Perhaps the most feared and effective of these sticks is peer review. This process is the main way doctors watch over the competence of their hospital colleagues. Critics complain the system is sometimes perverted into a way of punishing those who are economic threats to the hospital or to other doctors. At its most extreme, doctors lose the right to admit patients or to perform specific tests, procedures and operations. ``There is overwhelming economic motive to eliminate doctors who cost the hospital money,'' said Dr. Verner S. Waite of Downey, Calif. ``Doctors who complain about unethical billing practices, unnecessary tests, using items the hospital can charge for that are not necessary, are all at great risk of a peer review.'' Waite has formed an organization to fight abuses of peer review. He and many others believe that instead of weeding out bad doctors, the system sometimes may protect dangerous hacks who are financially and politically powerful because they admit lots of patients. ``When they want to get you, they get you good. They blackball you,'' said Dr. David M. Freedman. ``They will take away privileges for nothing, when another doctor can murder someone, and because he's in good standing they don't bother him.'' Freedman works with Harper at Parkland Medical Center, an 86-bed community hospital owned by Hospital Corporation of America, the nation's largest for-profit hospital chain. Freedman believes his own practice has suffered because he refused an order from a hospital administrator to stop referring patients to Harper for surgery. Harper claims many other doctors in this distant suburb of Boston also were warned not to send him patients, in large part because he went against the hospital's financial interests. Sometimes, a hospital can get rid of someone its considers a financial nuisance simply by giving another physician the sole right to perform that doctor's medical specialty. Ohio cardiologist Dr. Efraim Montesinos contended he was forced to move his busy heart surgery practice from Toledo Hospital because his patients often ran up bigger bills than were covered by Medicare's flat-fee DRG system, which began in 1984. Said Dr. Peter Overstreet, one of Montesinos' supporters: ``Before DRGs, he was a hero. Since DRGs, he is a villain. It's the same guy.'' Montesinos said he cared for a large number of very sick patients. They often took longer than usual to get better, so the hospital lost money. ``I am in the service of my patients,'' he said. ``I am not in the service of the hospital or the insurance company. As long as I am a physician, I will do what I think is proper for the patient.'' Last year, the hospital decided to give an exclusive contract to a single heart surgery group. Montesinos, who could have bid for the job, believes the exclusive contract was a ploy ``to get me out of the hospital.'' He moved his practice to the nearby Medical College of Ohio.

DOC.HEAD: DERRY, N.H.: of Ohio.
DOC.TEXT: Dr. John Gibbs, the hospital's director of medical affairs, acknowledged finances played a role in the decision to change surgeons. ``Most of his (Montesinos') patients weren't covered under the DRGs,'' he said. ``The resource utilization was high - the amount of (blood) pump time, a lot of X-rays, and the resources of the hospital.'' Hospitals now must go to considerable lengths to get rid of financially rebellious doctors, but some fear it soon will become much easier. Some medical consultants and attorneys suggest rewriting hospital bylaws to permit ``financial credentialing.'' This would allow review committees to consider doctors' economic profiles, including the profitability of their patients, when deciding whether to allow them to admit patients. Others worry doctors will shortchange their patients if they are forced to put the hospitals' interests first. Said the AMA's Lang: ``When you base medical staff privileges on economic criteria unrelated to quality, you are setting up a situation where the patient can be harmed.''
