DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Stocks Dip
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar fell slightly against the Japanese yen today while prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange erased early gains and fell. The dollar closed at 129.95 yen, down 0.10 yen from Monday, for its lowest finish since March 15, 1989. The dollar has fallen 7.20 yen since Oct. 1. The dollar fell sharply in early trading but bounced back up before midday following calls from the Bank of Japan to major banks, said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. The central bank uses such calls to dissuade banks from too much buying or selling of dollars. The dollar also was supported later by reports of final U.S. Senate approval for a $500 billion deficit-reduction plan, said Yoshikazu Kuroda, a dealer with Fuji Bank. Kuroda said, however, the positive effect of the deficit plan's passage could last only temporarily. ``With prospects of the U.S. economy getting so bad, even the positive news is not influential enough to reverse the dollar's downtrend,'' he said. Expectations that the Federal Reserve Board would lower interest rates to stimulate the U.S. economy also are depressing the dollar, dealers said. On the stock market, the 225-issue Nikkei index lost 134.89 points, or 0.57 percent, closing at 23,495.11. The index was off about 550 points from the day's high before recovering. Traders said investors were discouraged by the slowdown in the yen's surge against the dollar and a subsequent slip in bond prices. Some traders contend the market is slowly recovering from a series of big losses accelerated by the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. The index fell almost to 20,000 points last week, bringing its decline since the beginning of this year to about 50 percent. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 83.48 points, down from Monday's 83.54. Their yield rose to 8.035 percent from 8.020. Japanese financial markets will be closed Wednesday for a national holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Continues Decline; Gold Up
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar declined in moderate trading early today amid conflicting interpretations of the budgetary debate in the United States. Gold prices climbed slightly. Steve Barrow, a currency analyst at Chemical Bank in London, said the U.S. budget package cobbled together overnight would not be considered credible because it failed to specify cuts in some areas. In Frankfurt, dealers said the budget package was interpreted as a sign that the U.S. administration was not committed to deficit reduction. Barrow said the expectations of lower U.S. interest rates will remain and probably push the dollar lower in the short term. Despite suggestions during Tokyo trading that the Bank of Japan might be prepared to intervene to slow the dollar's slide, dealers said they doubted major central banks would be prepared to coordinate dollar purchases. Some speculate that the U.S. government would like a lower dollar to help ease monetary pressure on the economy and reduce the country's trade gap. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.10 yen to a closing 129.95 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at the same rate. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9765, compared with $1.9745 late Monday. Other dollar rates at midmorning in Europe, compared with late Monday's rates included: 1.5250 German marks, down from 1.5355; 1.2765 Swiss francs, down from 1.2840; 5.1062 French francs, down from 5.1400; 1.7200 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7315; 1,143.00 Italian lire, down from 1,150.75, and 1.1500 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1515 London's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended gold price of $395.45 per ounce at midmorning, up from $392.45 bid per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the bid price was $395.25, up from $391.80. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $5.68 to close at a bid $394.37. Silver traded in London at a bid price of $4.69 a troy ounce, up from Monday's $4.67.

DOC.HEAD: In the Midst of Budget Battle, Debt Limit Rising, Too
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Congress has voted to raise the government's debt ceiling yet again, this time to $3,195,000,000,000. But it won't be the last time. The $72 billion increase is only enough to carry the government through Oct. 20. By that date, Congress and President Bush are expected to have agreed on a way to reduce the budget deficit. Then, the administration will ask that the debt ceiling be raised once again - to $3.444 trillion, or enough to last through next Sept. 30. That will mark the 23rd increase of the Reagan-Bush era. The House approved the $3195-trillion figure Monday as part of a bill renewing federal spending authority while deficit-reduction efforts continue. The Senate did the same later in the day, as part of an emergency spending bill. Without the additional borrowing authority, the Treasury Department could not sell the securities necessary to obtain cash to pay for goods and services already purchased on credit and the government could not pay its bills. The debt limit was $935 billion when President Reagan took office in January 1981. One of the first pieces of legislation he signed raised the ceiling by $50 billion. Seven months later the ceiling rose by an additional $80 billion. By the time President Bush took office in 1989, the figure had soared to $2.8 trillion.

DOC.HEAD: Oil-Spill Auction Lures 7,000 Potential Bidders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Auction begins noon EDT; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of prospective buyers have signed up to bid for Exxon Corp.'s massive store of surplus oil spill clean-up gear at a three-day auction beginning today. On the block the first day are a seaplane, 38 mobile homes near Valdez, brand-new fishing nets, and assorted tools, boats and motors, among other items, said Rob Mackay, spokesman for Ritchie Bros. Auctioneers International. The company put together more than 4,800 lots of excess gear it bought from Exxon last month for an undisclosed amount. ``The amount of interest has been enormous. It's the largest number of people we've ever had at an auction sale,'' said Mackay. The Vancouver, British Columbia, auction company conducts more than 70 large auctions annually. Ritchie Bros. earlier had predicted that about 5,000 people would register as potential bidders and that the auction would bring in more than $10 million. Seven thousand people had signed up by today and Mackay said he couldn't estimate how much more money the auction might with the higher number of bidders. The merchandise is part of 33,000 tons of material moved to Anchorge last fall for storage after the summer oil-spill cleanup effort, said Exxon spokesman Karsten Rodvik. The Exxon Valdez tanker spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil into Alaska's Prince William Sound in March 1989 in the nation's biggest oil spill. Exxon crews worked to mop up shorelines that summer and this one, and plan to return for a shoreline survey next spring. Rodvik said the company is keeping enough equipment to conduct whatever additional cleanup is necessary. Specialized oil-spill equipment like skimmers and booms aren't being sold. The auction has drawn potential bidders from as far away as Florida and Hawaii, said Mackay. More bidders can sign up over the next three days. ``It's everybody from the guy that lives next door to you to dealers to contractors to fishermen,'' he said. Among the items for sale are 20,000 rubber gloves; 50 portable toilets; hundreds of washers, dryers, refrigerators, mattresses and desks; 10 cars; dozens of television sets; thousands of sheets and blankets; hundreds of hard hats; dozens of bottles of animal shampoo; scuba gear; two shipping vans full of thongs and deck shoes; eight fork lifts and a bathtub. Thousands of interested buyers have cruised past the three auction sites in recent days to inspect the merchandise. The auction will move to a different site each day. One Anchorage auctioneer said Alaska bidders probably will lose many lots to professional bidders who flew in from other states able to spend millions of dollars. ``There will be too many big-buck bidders,'' said Ron Alleva of Grubstake Realty and Auction Co. ``Anyone from around here will just be wasting his time.'' And Dudley Bennish, president of Alaska Mining and Diving Supply Inc., said he is concerned the auction may depress the market for awhile. He accused Exxon of breaking a promise not to dump the goods on the market in Alaska. But Bennish said he and other dealers profited when Exxon bought the equipment in the first place.

DOC.HEAD: Prudhoe Bay Owners Investing $1 Billion in Natural Gas Facilities
DOC.TEXT: The principal owners of the Prudhoe Bay oil field in Alaska announced today they would invest more than $1 billion to create additional natural gas handling facilities on the state's North Slope. The new facilities are expected to increase the liquids production in the field by some 100,000 barrels a day starting 1995, the companies said in a statement released in Anchorage, Alaska. The project will increase the field's gas handling ability to an average of 7.5 billion cubic feet a day, they said. The facilities handle natural gas that is extracted from the oil field along with crude oil. The statement said the principal owners of Prudhoe Bay had resolved a number of issues between oil and gas producers that had arisen since the original Prudhoe Bay operating agreement. The resolution of these issues will allow the development of projects in the future that would further increase production from the oil field, the companies said. The principal owners of the Prudhoe Bay field are British Petroleum, Atlantic Richfield, Exxon, Mobil, Phillips Petroleum and Chevron.

DOC.HEAD: May Department Stores Buys Thalhimers Chain
DOC.TEXT: May Department Stores Co., which owns 13 regional department store chains, said today that it will acquire the Richmond, Va.,-based Thalhimers chain for $325 million. Thalhimers operates 26 stores in Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina and Tennessee and had sales of $445 million in 1989. ``The acquisition of Thalhimers represents another important strategic step for the May Company, strengthening our business with prestigious, quality department stores,'' said David Farrell, chairman and chief executive officer of May. Like other May acquisitions, Thalhimers will retain its name and continue to be headquartered in Richmond. The deal is subject to federal regulatory approval. Thirteen of the 26 Thalhimers stores are in Virginia, 10 are in North Carolina, two are in Charleston, S.C., and one store is located in Memphis, Tenn. Thalhimers is owned by Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. May Department Stores, based in St. Louis, is one of the nation's leading retailers. It operates 289 department stores in 29 states and the District of Columbia. The company also operates 2,818 Payless ShoeSource discount shoe stores in 44 states. Its best-known department store chain is Lord & Taylor. Last year the company began what it said was the most aggressive expansion plan in the retailing industry, allocating $3.7 billion over five years for the purchase of new stores.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall As Oil Shoots Up
DOC.TEXT: The stock market opened lower this morning amid concern over higher oil prices and continual federal budget problems. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials fell 23.26 points to 2,500.50 in the first half hour of trading. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 2 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 547 down, 178 up and 315 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 19.22 million shares as of 10 a.m. Stocks fell early as oil futures prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange set new highs above $40 per barrel this morning. ``It's the price of oil,'' said Larry Wachtel, a first vice president with Prudential-Bache Securities Co. ``That is the minute-to-minute focus of the market.'' Wall Street also had its doubts about the temporary budget agreement today in Washington. Wachtel said it was being viewed as a ``non-event.'' President Bush signed emergency legislation to keep the government open for another 11 days. Bush said, however, there is ``no assurance'' Congress will reach agreement on a $500 billion deficit reduction package. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 1.19 to 170.46. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .74 at 305.77. On Monday the Dow Jones industrial average rose 13.12 to 2,523.76. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 4 to 3 on the NYSE, with 819 up, 621 down and 487 unchanged. Big Board volume came to 99.47 million shares, down from 153.38 million Friday and the lightest total since a 92.94 million-share day on Sept. 4.

DOC.HEAD: Thailand Allows Import of Foreign Cigarettes
DOC.TEXT: The goverment agreed Tuesday to lift a ban on importing foreign cigarettes. Cigarettes from outside Thailand will be subject to the same restrictions as local brands, deputy government spokesman Porntep Techapaiboon said at a news conference after a regular Cabinet meeting. The imported brands will be equally taxed and must carry health warnings on the packages. All advertisements are banned. Black market foreign cigarettes have been widely available in Bangkok and other cities. Thailand had been under strong pressure from its largest trading partner, the United States, to lift the 10-year-old ban. Late last year, the United States took the dispute to the General Agreement On Tariffs and Trade, an international body that sets rules for trade. GATT ruled last month that the Thai ban was illegal, Thai officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Philips Announces 4,900 Layoffs In Computer Division
DOC.TEXT: The Dutch electronics giant Philips NV said Tuesday it will lay off 4,900 people in its computer division as part of a major restructuring aimed at fending off its Japanese competitors. Separately, Philips said it is developing a new cassette player capable of recording digital sound on ordinary tape, which should give a boost its consumer electronics division. The 4,900 jobs being lost in Philips' information systems division are part of a restructuring program unveiled this summer by Philips' new chairman, Jan Timmer, in which up to 10,000 layoffs ultimately are expected. Timmer told shareholders in July that Philips might face a $1 billion loss, which media here blamed largely on disappointing computer sales. The company said in a statement that ``compulsory redundancies will unavoidable,'' mainly in Europe, as the computer division is cut to about two thirds its current size of 15,000 people. Philips is concentrating on the highly competitive personal computer market and pulling out of manufacturing and selling more complex mainframe and microcomputer systems, the announcement said. Under the reorganization, many computer division tasks will be taken over by Philips' consumer electronics unit, which was successfully pulled out of the red by Timmer before he took over as company chairman last May. That division also is responsible for developing Philips' latest product, the Digital Compact Cassette (DCC) recorder, which will be available for $500 worldwide in 1992, according to company spokesman Jan Geel. Unlike the digital audio tape recorders introduced in the mid-1980s by Philips' Japanese competitors, the DCC system won't need special tape to make high-quality recordings from digital audio sources like the compact disk, Geel said. Sales of the current digital audio tape system have been slow because the recorders include a device that stops owners from copying compact disk recordings without paying royalties to the artists. Geel said the DCC recorders would also include ``some kind of protection to preserve the rights of the artist, but it is not yet known what form it will take.'' He said DCC recorders might be fitted with an electronic device to stop large-scale bootlegging by allowing users to copy compact disks but not other tape recordings. The PolyGram recording firm in London said it was trying to secure ``an appropriate levy'' on DCC sales to compensate for the loss of royalties. Geel refused to disclose development costs for the DCC project.

DOC.HEAD: Company Founded by Bush Struggles To Stay Afloat
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Zapata Corp. helped make a future president wealthy. But the company founded by George Bush now is struggling to stay afloat. Saddled by about $560 million in debt compounded by overexpansion, Zapata announced in June a realignment that includes restructuring some debt and shedding the oil drilling business that was its foundation. The company will maintain its more profitable oil field service boats and continue in natural gas production and commercial fishing - divisions that began after Bush left the company 24 years ago. The restructuring must be approved by debtholders, and Chairman R. C. Lassiter has warned that rejection could spell bankruptcy. ``The root of our problem is the fact that we built drilling rigs in the '70s and '80s with the assumption of bringing in $50,000 a day,'' said company spokesman Barney White. In reality, the rigs brought in only about $10,000 to $15,000 a day, and debts mounted, he said. The modern Zapata Off-Shore Co. subsidiary had drilling operations in Texas as well as California, Singapore, Indonesia, Abu Dhabi, the Netherlands, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland and England. Bush started Zapata in Odessa, Texas, in 1953, five years after he moved to Texas to take a job in the oil patch. The company became public in 1955. When the Bushes and their five children later moved to Houston, they took Zapata with them. Bush sold his 6 percent stake in Zapata for $1.1 million after he was elected to Congress in 1966. But his ties to the company continued through the summer of 1989, when Bush turned 65 and his pension annuity from the company was paid out. White declined to reveal the full amount of the annuity. ``George made a comfortable amount of money out of it,'' said former founding partner and retired Pennzoil Corp. Chairman J. Hugh Liedtke. ``It was a substantial sum, but he's not what in Texas is called `Big Rich.' '' A White House spokesman said Bush would have no comment on the latest troubles at Zapata. Stockholders are expected to vote on Zapata's restructuring plan this month. The planned rig fleet sale should be completed by Oct. 31, but ``if there is not sufficient bondholder acceptance of Zapata's tender offer, the company will have little alternative but to seek protection under the bankruptcy laws,'' Lassiter said last month in the company's latest quarterly report. Zapata announced Sept. 5 that it would sell an offshore drilling rig fleet for $298 million to Arethusa (Offshore) Ltd., a Bermuda-based consortium of European investors formed for the deal. Under the terms of the sale, Zapata will reinvest $17.5 million in Arethusa, and continue to manage the fleet. Of the remaining, $7.7 million would go for commissions on the sale, $53.6 million would pay off debts specific to the rig fleet, $160 million would be paid to the banks and about $14.2 million are in taxes and fees related to the restructuring. About $45 million would be used as the company's working capital. As part of the restructuring, Zapata also will offer to retire about $78 million in bond debt, White said. Zapata lost $20 million, or 63 cents per share, in the three months ended June 30 on revenue of $39.1 million. During the same period last year, the company lost $26.1 million, or 82 cents per share, and had $51.7 million in revenue. Asked if the latest rise in oil prices caused by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait might help turn things around, White said, ``It would be a mistake to jump to the conclusion that the market is going to turn around. ``During the boom (of the early 1980s), everyone bought a drilling rig to get rich and saturated the markets. Now they, like us, can't make the payments,'' he said. ``We're getting out of drilling business permanently,'' White said. ``We can't count on Iraq to turn it around. In six months this will all go away and we'll still have too many rigs.''

DOC.HEAD: Motorola Earnings Up 14.6 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. said Tuesday increased orders for its communications and semiconductor products helped boost earnings nearly 15 percent in the third quarter, but the company's stock plunged. Motorola had plunged $6.75 a share to $53 in heavy trading by midday on the New York Stock Exchange, a day after the company announced the settlement of a patent infringement lawsuit with Hitachi Ltd. Motorola reported net income of $102 million, or 78 cents per common share, for the three months ended Sept. 30 compared with $89 million, or 69 cents a share, for the same period a year ago. Third-quarter sales rose 12 percent to $2.7 billion from $2.4 billion in the third quarter of 1989, Motorola said in a statement from its Chicago-area headquarters. Chairman George Fisher said new orders in the company's major businesses increased worldwide, with the strongest gains coming from Asian countries. ``Our customers are investing in Motorola products, systems and services that will improve productivity and efficiency and save time,'' Fisher said. For the first nine months of 1990, Motorola had net income of $390 million, or $2.98 a share, on sales of $8 billion, compared with net income of $366 million, or $2.82 a share, on sales of $7 billion for the 1989 period. Motorola has refused to give details of the settlement with Hitachi, which twice had threatened to cut off supplies of key parts to American computer manufacturers. Although terms of the settlement were not disclosed, Motorola executive James A. Norling said he was pleased. ``Our unwavering goals in this legal action were to protect Motorola's intellectual property and to assure our customers an uninterrupted supply of Motorola's leadership microprocessors,'' said Norling, president and general manager of the company's semiconductor products sector. Motorola sued Hitachi nearly two years ago in U.S. District Court in Austin, Texas, accusing the Japanese company of using certain microprocessor designs patented by Motorola. Hitachi countered by accusing Motorola of patent infringement when the Chicago-area company developed its widely used 68030 chip. A federal judge in Texas twice ordered the companies to stop selling their chips in the United States and to try to work out a settlement. The orders were stayed in both cases. The lawsuits involved Hitachi's H8 and H16 microcontrollers and Motorola's 68030 and 88000 microprocessors. Motorola said the companies will ask the courts to dismiss the lawsuits.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Narrowly Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid perceptions that Monday's gains were overdone, analysts said. Soybeans turned mixed after posting gains of as much 17 cents a bushel in the previous session. Corn and wheat futures also were narrowly mixed after advacing on Monday. Monday's rally was linked in part to worries about rain-related harvest delays in the Midwest, where farmers are trying to bring in the soybean and corn crops. Traders will get an update on the corn and soybean harvest after today's close, when the Agriculture Department releases its weekly crop progress report. The government will release revised production estimates for those crops on Thursday. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.79\ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to \ cent higher with December at $2.34\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to { cent lower with December at $1.23 a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents lower to 1{ cents higher with November at $6.33 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mostly higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .05 cent to .33 cent higher with October at 79.70 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .03 cent lower to .55 cent higher with October at 88.12 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .68 cent higher with October at 56.60 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent to .60 cent higher with February at 64.65 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled mixed on Monday; pork futures fell sharply.

DOC.HEAD: Court To Decide On Investor Deadlines
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide wat deadlines investors face when trying to sue over alleged securities fraud. The justices said they will use an Oregon dispute to decide whether state or federal law should determine the relevant statute of limitations for such lawsuits. The Oregon case began when various investors purchased from 1979 to 1981 units in limited partnerships for the buying and leasing of computer equipment and computer software. Each limited partnership was aimed at generated profits for the investors, who were limited partners, and to offer them attractive tax benefits. The deals were put together by a West Orange, N.J., law firm - Lampf, Pleva, Lipkind, Prupis & Petigrow. All the limited partnerships were economic failures, but investors did not investigate the reasons for the poor performance until 1986 - when the Internal Revenue Service began disallowing their tax benefits. The investors then sued the law firm, charging federal securities fraud violations. At issue is whether an absolute three-year deadline imposed by the federal Securities Exchange Act of 1934 should apply. The New Jersey law firm said it should, but the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled that the deadline should be determined by Oregon because the suit was filed there. Under the federal deadline, the clock would start ticking at the time of investment. The appeals court said Oregon's two-year deadline should apply from the time the investors were aware, or should have been aware, that fraud was a possibility. The 9th Circuit court, in its ruling earlier this year, told U.S. District Judge James A. Redden in Portland to reconsider what date should be used for measuring the start of the state-law time limit. Lawyers for the New Jersey law firm then sought Supreme Court review, arguing that the federal deadlne - not a state law one - should apply. The case is Lampf Pleva vs. Gilbertson, 90-333.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Declines, Gold Up
DOC.NOTE: EDS: UPDATES thruout with closing Europe, midday NY figures; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. dollar weakened in European trading today after a U.S. deficit-reduction accord refocused attention on prospects of lower U.S. interest rates. Gold prices rose. Dealers said doubts over the deficit-reduction accord had eased in recent days but news of the program still raised the probability of an easing of monetary policy by the Federal Reserve. Despite suggestions during Tokyo trading that the Bank of Japan might be prepared to intervene to slow the dollar's slide, dealers said they doubted that major central banks would be prepared to coordinate dollar purchases. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.10 yen to a closing 129.95 yen. Later in London, it was quoted at 130.30 yen. At midday in New York, the dollar was trading at 130.44 yen. He said even the big corporations, which do not have a primary agenda of social change, are seeing that such practices sell. ``It's a neat example of capitalism,'' he said. ``Some of it is going to be shallow, of course, but we ought to welcome even the most greedy enterprise that puts stakes in a service to society.''

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Up 2.4 Cents in Last Week
DOC.TEXT: The average price of self-serve unleaded gasoline nationwide rose 2.4 cents in the last week to $1.37 per gallon, the American Automobile Association said Tuesday. The average retail price of self-serve unleaded is up 29.5 cents, or 27.4 percent, from Aug. 1, the day before Iraq invaded Kuwait and triggered the Middle East crisis. The AAA's highest recorded price for self-serve unleaded is $1.388 per gallon before the Easter weekend in 1981. The survey is based on a nationwide spot check of stations conducted by Computer Petroleum Corp. of St. Paul, Minn. The AAA said stations continued to report adequate supplies of gasoline. Prices rose in all parts of the country, with largest increase in the West and the smallest in the Midwest, AAA said. The nationwide average for self-serve regular leaded gasoiline rose 1.5 cents to $1.387 per gallon. The average price of self-serve mid-grade unleaded rose 2.2 cents to $1.45 per gallon and self-serve premium unleaded gained 2.1 cents to $1.534 per gallon, AAA said.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Fall Sharply
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices fell sharply on London's Stock Exchange Tuesday on concerns that had dogged the London market before sterling's entry into the European exchange rate mechanism. Traders said the market fell prey to worries over hostilities in the Middle East and the state of the U.S. and British economies. The market had been euphoric Monday over the news of the pound's entry. ``The market has had its good news,'' one trader said, ``and I don't know what can force it higher.'' The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed down 67.5 points, or 3.1 percent, at 2,134.1. The Financial Times 30-share index closed down 65.2 points at 1,640.5. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 32.51 points to close at 1,132.58. Volume was a heavy 823.8 million shares, but down from the record 1.086 billion shares traded Monday. Monday's figure included trades executed in an extended Friday session which followed the government's announcement that sterling would move into the mechanism and base rates would be cut a percentage point to 14 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Laura Ashley Profit Falls 14 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Troubled retailer Laura Ashley Holdings PLC said Tuesday its earnings fell 14 percent in the first half of the year because of poor retailing conditions and a sharp increase in interest charges. The retailer of English country-style women's clothing and furnishings said its earnings for the six months ended July 28 fell to 3.6 million pounds, or $6.1 million, from 4.2 million pounds, or $6.9 million, in the same period a year earlier. Earnings per share came to 0.02 pence, or 0.03 cent, compared with 2.09 pence, or 3.4 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 30 percent to 173.9 million pounds, or $296 million, from 134.2 million pounds, or $221 million. The company's results reflected a one-time gain of 3.6 million pounds, or $6.1 million, from the 4.8 million pound, or $8.2 million, sale of its perfumery Penhaligon's Ltd. to the U.S. retailer Limited Inc. The retailer said its performance in Britain was affected by a slowdown in both home furnishing and clothing sales, company said. The company's continental Europe stores had a more positive performance, and U.S. sales improved, it said. The company said its interest charges more than doubled to 7.03 million pounds, or $12 million, reflecting the surge in British rates over the past year. The firm said it would not pay a half-year dividend. Chairman Bernard Ashley said the company's recent cost-cutting measures ensure it is ``well-placed to withstand the current trading environment.'' Last month, the company announced it would sell or close seven factories in Britain and cut 1,500 jobs. The figures announced Tuesday were converted at the company-provided exchange rates of $1.70 to the pound for the latest period, and $1.65 for the period a year ago. The company did not break out quarterly results. It is not required to do so under British law.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
UAL Board Rejects Employee Buyout Bid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with board rejecting offer, planning to order planes, seeking contract settlements; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: UAL Corp.'s board of directors today rejected an employee buyout bid and said it will proceed with plans to place a large aircraft order it had postponed at the labor group's request. The parent of United Airlines also said it would seek to quickly reach new contracts with its pilots, machinists and flight attendants unions, which led the buyout effort. The decision represented the fourth failed takeover bid in three years at UAL. UAL made the announcement late this morning after a meeting at which the board said the employee group failed to arrange financing for a $201-per-share, $4.38 billion acquisition offer that the board had accepted in principle in April. The board sad in a statement that it rejected a new employee offer that was ``at an uncertain but substantially lower value than the April 9 agreement, was not accompanied by definitive financing arrangements and was subject to other significant contingencies.'' UAL stock was trading at $93.50 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, up $1.50, following the early afternoon announcement. Gerald Greenwald, chief executive officer of the United Employees Acquisition Corp., had said Sunday that the employees failed to get bank financing for the $201-a-share bid but had hoped to make up the shortfall with other features. There was no official word on the specifics, but some reports put the revised bid at $165 to $170 a share, with about $150 of that in cash and the rest in securities. The New York Times, quoting an unidentified source, put it at about $160 a share, or $3.5 billion. In this version, only about $70 a share would be in cash. The rest would mostly be in notes secured by aircraft. The buyout group said the cash portion of its revised bid would come from loans from suppliers; revenue from sale-leaseback arrangements, in which the company sells equipment such as airplanes and leases them back; employee investments; and cash on hand. Greenwald said Monday he did not know what the group would do if the board rejected its restructured offer. He was not immediately available today. All three of the labor groups are working with expired contracts. The pilots, who have been trying to gain control of the company for 3{ years, had vowed to confront UAL's management with everything including a strike if the acquisition attempt failed. The directors also could face a movement to oust them by angry stockholders led by Coniston Partners, a New York investment group which owns 11.8 percent of UAL shares. The employee group asked the board in July to postpone the aircraft purchase while the future ownership of the corporation was in the air. UAL had said previously that it expected the order to be the largest ever placed for wide-body jetliners.

DOC.HEAD: Revived Soviet Stock Exchange May Lack Soviet Investors
DOC.TEXT: Soviet citizens probably won't be interested in buying stocks while grocery stores are empty, Finance Ministry officials cautioned Tuesday during a Wall Street seminar on reviving a Soviet stock exchange. Worse yet, they may not even have the option. The Soviet central bank said there were no facilities in this shortage-plagued country to print share certificates. ``Many people can't understand how we can sell securities when we can't sell them other products'' such as bread and cigarettes, Deputy Finance Minister Vladimir Rayevsky said in an interview. ``Our Soviet people, our public opinion doesn't know the essence of a stock exchange,'' he said during the seminar organized by the New York Stock Exchange. Trading in shares has been illegal in the Soviet Union for many years. The practice was prohibited after the 1917 Bolshevik Revolution, and although it was revived briefly during the 1920s, trading was banned again in 1928 by Josef Stalin. Officials from the New York Stock Exchange are trying to give would-be marketeers a boost with the three-day seminar, a crash-course on organizing, running and regulating a stock market. But Rayevsky and government spokesman Stanislav Assekritov said a national public education campaign will be needed to convince Soviets a stock exchange is needed in a market economy. ``What we need to do is change the mindsets of the public,'' said Assekritov, deputy chairman of a government economic reform committee. ``First we shall have to explain to the public that a market of securities, a stock exchange, will make our shops more plentiful because the transfer of capital will enable us to change the structure of our economy.'' Assekritov said unless that happens, ``even if we set up a stock exchange in Moscow by a decree of the city (council), people would ask this question: Why start trading in securities if shelves are empty?'' The Soviet economy has been in shambles this year. Consumers endured shortages of cigarettes, matches and even ice cream this summer, and bread shelves were empty for the first time since the 1960s. A bleak winter looms ahead, as much of a bumper potato crop rotted in the fields. Dmitri Tulin, managing director of the Gosbank central bank's new securities department, said one of the biggest concerns in reviving a stock exchange is the lack of facilities for printing share certificates that could not be forged. He said there was only one such plant in the country, but it's working at full capacity printing rubles and passports. ``We either have to build a new plant facility for producing paper or just leap over this stage and develop a paperless market from the very beginning,'' he said. But few Soviets would accept that, either, he said. ``In Central Asia, I could hardly imagine anyone buying something that they can't put under their mattress,'' Tulin said. The myriad of economic rescue plans being considered by the Soviet government calls for the creation of a stock market, some as soon as the end of this year. Assekritov said the end of 1991 would be more realistic. ``We cannot just decree a stock exchange into existence,'' he told the seminar. ``This is not a museum as some people think, where exhibits are put on display.'' Nicholas Rey, managing director of the New York-based brokerage firm Bear, Stearns & Co. Inc., said the Soviets need to privatize state industries gradually before a stock exchange can flourish. The government now owns 80 percent to 90 percent of the property in this vast country and is only slowing moving away from the ban on private ownership, one of the most sacred precepts of communism. ``I would start very simply with (privatizing) the most profitable enterprises,'' such as the oil industry, said Rey, a director of the Polish-American committee advising Warsaw on its privatization program.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Chiefs Recommend Approval of Pact with Ford
DOC.TEXT: United Auto Workers union leaders today overwhelmingly recommended ratification of a new three-year contract with Ford Motor Co. ``No one had to get up to try to get people to support this agreement,'' UAW President Owen Bieber said after the vote by the union's bargaining council. Union Vice President Ernie Lofton, in charge of the union's Ford Department, said he expects ratification to be completed by Oct. 21. The tentative agreement reached early Sunday closely follows a contract the union reached last month with General Motors Corp., which allows the automakers more flexibility but gives workers a greater degree of job security. GM workers ratified the pact by a margin of 4-to-1. About 300,000 GM employees are covered by the UAW contract. After the pact is ratified by Ford workers, UAW negotiations with Chrysler Corp. will accelerate. That bargaining is expected to be much more difficult than it was at Ford or GM because of Chrysler's deteriorating financial shape.

DOC.HEAD: Grains and Soybeans Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Grains and soybeans were mixed at the close of a slow day Tuesday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean futures prices remained in the same range following a sharp rally Monday spurred by harvest delays in the rain-soaked Midwest. Corn and wheat futures prices advanced slightly on rumors of possible export business, analysts said. ``We had wet conditions slowing the harvest (of soybeans) that kept prices up,'' said Mickey Luth, a grains analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``Other than that, it was pretty much a nothing session - consolidating after yesterday's sharp rallies.'' Speculators also stood on the sidelines in advance of a report from the Agriculture Department on Thursday with updated crop estimates, Luth said At the close, wheat futures were } cents lower to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in December at $2.78{ a bushel; corn futures were unchanged to 1 cent higher with December at $2.34 a bushel; oats were 3 cent to 1 cent lower with December at $2.78{ a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 4{ cents higher with November at $6.34 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: China Sends Buying Delegation to Smooth Trade Relations
DOC.TEXT: China is sending more than 300 government and business emissaries to the United States on a large-scale shopping trip to smooth strained trade and political ties, officials said Tuesday. Leaders of the delegation, which sets out Friday for a three-week visit, said members will be looking to place orders for products ranging from high-tech equipment to timber and grain. ``This is not only a gesture - public relations. We are doing the actual thing,'' Sun Zhenyu of the Ministry of Foreign Economic Relations and Trade told a news conference. Sun is deputy director of the ministry's department for trade with the United States and Oceania, and will take part in the buying mission. The delegation includes representatives from most of China's major foreign trade companies and other leading state corporations. Sun said some purchase orders to be signed on the trip would have been made anyway, but that the group is genuinely seeking to find new American sources for products to redress a longstanding trade imbalance. The U.S. Commerce Department says the United States imported $11.99 billion worth of Chinese goods in 1989, and sold $5.81 billion worth to China. The figures include Chinese products shipped through Hong Kong. China, which does not count the products that go through Hong Kong, says it sold just $4.4 billion worth of goods to the United States and bought about $8 billion in return. ``We are trying to sort it out with the U.S. Government and find out why there are different statistics,'' Sun said. But he acknowledged, ``China's imports from the United States have dropped, that's a fact, and the Chinese government attaches great importance to that. We must do something to correct that state of affairs.'' American products could be ordered through regular trade channels, he said, but sending the large delegation will ``demonstrate how eager we are ... And show our wish to restore relations in all aspects.'' U.S.-Chinese relations have been strained since June 1989, when China's ruling Communists ordered the army to attack pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing. The United States condemned the attack and halted military sales to China, blocked development loans by international agencies and stopped most high-level exchanges. Some U.S. legislators have proposed canceling China's most-favored nation trade status as a further sanction. The status subjects Chinese products to the lowest U.S. tariffs. Wang Rensheng, a former deputy trade minister who will head the delegation, said members will seek to meet with congressmen to press for continued MFN treamment. Proposals to cancel it this year appear to have lost support, but a bill has been submitted in the House to link next year's renewal to China's human rights record. U.S. imports from China appear largely unaffected by the political tension. They rose nearly 15 percent in the first eight months of the year over the same period last year, Chinese statistics show. Chinese imports from the United States dropped about 15 percent in the same period, however, due partly to a Chinese currency devaluation and a domestic austerity program. The buying trip coincides with a separate, 34-member Chinese delegation that will be promoting Chinese products in the United States and Canada.

DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Turns Down Natural Gas Dispute
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court turned away a multibillion-dollar dispute over natural gas costs but plans to decide what deadlines investors face when trying to sue over alleged securities fraud. Without comment, the court on Tuesday refused to reinstate a federal regulation to ease a burden on pipeline companies that signed contracts to buy gas in the 1970s and '80s at a specified price. The pipelines were required to pay for the gas even if they couldn't sell it. The so-called take-or-pay agreements were signed when the price of gas was higher than it is today. But natural gas supplies began to exceed demand by 1982 because of warm winters, a recession and customers' switching to alternate fuels. As a result, the pipeline companies were left with billions of dollars in costs for unwanted gas. The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission adopted a plan in 1987 allowing the pipelines to charge customers part of the cost. But an appeals court threw out the plan in December, saying the charges to pipeline customers amounted to a retroactive change in rates without advance warning. The appeals court said current customers who didn't buy gas from a pipeline until after 1986 would not have to pay any part of the liability. The court, which reviewed the problem in a case involving Tennessee Gas Pipeline Co., sent the case back to the commission for another solution. Gas customers in Mississippi, Louisiana, Tennessee, Kentucky and Ohio who could face higher gas rates joined the Bush administration and Tennessee Pipeline in urging the Supreme Court to step in. In a separate case, the justices said they will use an Oregon dispute to decide whether state or federal law should determine the relevant statute of limitations for securities fraud suits. The Oregon case began when investors purchased from 1979 to 1981 limited partnerships, put together by the West Orange, N.J., law firm Lampf, Pleva, Lipkind, Prupis & Petigrow and designed to generate profits and tax benefits. Though each was an economic failure, investors did not investigate the reasons for the poor performance until 1986 - when the Internal Revenue Service began disallowing their tax benefits. The investors then sued the law firm, charging federal securities fraud violations. At issue is whether an absolute three-year deadline imposed by the federal Securities Exchange Act of 1934 should apply. Under the federal deadline, the clock would start ticking at the time of investment. But an appeals court said Oregon's two-year deadline should apply from the time the investors were aware, or should have been aware, that fraud was a possibility. The court also revived a $4 billion libel suit in which millionaire inventor Arthur Jones charged ABC's ``20-20'' program falsely portrayed him as a liar and hypocrite in a 1987 piece about the fate of 63 baby elephants he rescued from death in Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Harvests 3 Million Tons of Grain, Increases Cultivated Land
DOC.TEXT: Iraq produced more than 3 million metric tons of grain in this year's harvest, and plans to produce at least 38 percent more next season to beat United Nations sanctions on trade, the government newspaper al-Jumhouriya said Tuesday. The increase will help Iraq achieve food self-sufficiency in the face of the U.N. embargo imposed after its Aug. 2 invasion and subsequent annexation of neighboring Kuwait, al-Jumhouriya said. Iraq produced 1.196 million tons of wheat and 1.854 million tons of barley, the country's main grain staples, in the April harvest, the paper quoted Ministry of Planning statistics as saying. Iraq produces smaller amounts of rice and maize, but the amounts were not given, nor did the newspaper indicate what last year's harvests were. The land area cultivated for wheat and barley for this year's harvest was 3.451 million hectares, about 8.5 million acres, but is expected to increase to 4.783 million hectares, about 11.8 million acres, for next season, the ministry said. President Saddam Hussein and officials of the planning and agriculture ministries have exhorted farmers to increase cultivation of cereals in recent weeks. The government hopes to raise the land area devoted to such crops to 8 million hectares, or 20 million acres in the coming years, and thus achieve food self-sufficiency, according to sources in Baghdad who spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates on Bills Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities were mixed in Tuesday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $9.4 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.19 percent, up from 7.18 percent last week. Another $9.4 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.21 percent, unchanged from last week. The rates for the three-month bills were the highest since they sold for 7.32 percent on Sept. 24. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors - 7.42 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,818.30 and 7.59 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,635.50. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 7.58 percent last week, down from 7.79 percent the previous week.

Stocks fell sharply today today as record-high oil prices replaced federal budget problems as the market's focal point. The market fell from the opening and moved steadily lower as oil futures prices on the New York Mercantile Exchange set new highs above $40 per barrel today, stirring fears of higher inflation. The rising oil price was ``the minute-to-minute focus of the market,'' said Larry Wachtel, a first vice president with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Wall Streeters also had doubts about emergency legislation signed by President Bush to keep the government open for another 11 days. Bush said, however, there is ``no assurance'' Congress will reach agreement on a $500 billion deficit reduction package.

DOC.HEAD: Group Says Public Health Insurance Far More Efficient Than Private Sector
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, A spokesman, with three grafs to add response from insurance industry, picks up 6th graf pvs, Medicare helps. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Commercial health insurance companies spend 14 times as much as the federal Medicare program does on administration, overhead and marketing, a private group said Tuesday. And the private insurance sector spent 11 times as much per dollar of claims paid as the Canadian national health care system, according to a report by the group, Citizen Action. If the private health insurance industry were as efficient as Medicare, about $13 billion could be saved and used to provide insurance to 11 million uninsured people, the group's study found. ``Competition in the insurance market is wasteful and expensive,'' said Robert Brandon, vice president of Citizen Action. ``In health care, a free market cannot work. What we need is a single-payer system, where the government is the sole insurer.'' The Health Insurance Association of America said Citizen Action's study was misleading because it did not include Blue Cross and Blue Shield plans or plans sponsored by large, self-insured companies. When these are factored in, the 1988 administrative costs in the commercial sector drop to 13 cents for each dollar of benefits paid, the association said in a statement. The association also said that private insurers are spending an increasing amount of money to make sure doctors' and hospitals' bills are appropriate. This effort saves billions of dollars annually, the association said. The association also said Citizen Action was misguided in its call for a government-run health insurance program. Noting the budget disagreement that shut down the federal government over the weekend, the insurers said that ``most logical observers ... would not be inspired with confidence by the efficiency of government-run programs.'' Medicare helps pay doctors' and hospital bills for the nation's 33 million elderly and disabled citizens. Medicaid is a federal-state program that provides medical services to the poor. An estimated 37 million Americans have no health insurance, public or private. Citizen Action's report showed that in 1988 commercial health insurance companies spent 33.5 cents on administration, marketing, commissions and other overhead expenses for every dollar in claims paid out. By comparison, Medicare's administrative costs were 2.3 cents per dollar in claims paid out. In the Canadian health care system, administrative costs amounted to about 3 cents per dollar in claims paid, the group said. Private insurance companies, in their efforts to compete for more business, spend money on things that are not necessary when coverage is provided by a single public program, the group said. One of these functions is the internal review required to deny claims. ``Incredibly, the commercial insurance way of paying for health care leaves Americans spending more to deny people coverage than it would cost to provide everyone with coverage,'' the report said. Citizen Action is a nonprofit, consumers rights group with affiliates in 30 states.

DOC.HEAD: NEW YORK: reduction package
DOC.TEXT: The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 78.22 points, 3.1 percent, to close at 2,445.54. It was the Dow's 11th worst point drop, after the fall of 86.61 points on Sept. 11, 1986. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 4 to 1 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,310 down, 286 up and 382 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 145.61 million shares, up from 99.47 million shares on Monday. The NYSE's composite index fell 4.24 to 167.41. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 3.46 to 303.05.

DOC.HEAD: Membership Cards Replace Coupons
DOC.TEXT: A family-owned supermarket chain is offering its customers a way to save without the age-old bother of coupon clipping. In a word: plastic. Big Y Foods Inc., began its Express Savings Club on Monday. Customers will receive a plastic membership card which will be scanned at the checkout counter for discounts and specials being offered that day. ``We don't have to print as many coupons; people don't have to bring them in, and we don't have to count them,'' said Claire D'Amour, vice president of marketing for Big Y Foods Inc. ``There is a lot of savings in the whole system because paperwork is diminished.'' The cards, which anyone can apply for and receive immediately at any Big Y store, will have to be presented to the cashier before a shopper checks out. When passed over the store's scanning equipment, the bar code on the back of the card will identify the customer by number and automatically discount items the customer has selected on which Big Y and its vendors are offering savings. People who bring in paper coupons will get double the value of the discount. But by using the card, shoppers can get a discount on up to five of the featured items, instead of the regular one coupon, one item rule. Cost-cutting is essential to the supermarket industry, which operates on extremely tight margins. Net profit industry wide is less than a penny on every $1, according to the Food Marketing Institute. The cards give the store a better way to know their customers, D'Amour said. ``Once a customer is identified by number and you have data on them ... there is a lot of...marketing potential,'' she said. ``We ultimately hope to be better, smarter retailers. This kind of electronic marketing is for the '90s,'' she said. ``They all fall under the term of `frequent shopper program,' to track what an individual is purchasing and give them a reward for volume and loyalty. It is something the industry is looking at carefully and will become more common.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mostly lower on world markets Tuesday, but selloffs in other currencies prevented its decline from deepening. Gold prices tumbled after rising overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery fell $5.20 to settle at $389.70 a troy ounce. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $390.75, down $4.25 an ounce from late Monday. The dollar fell sharply in Asian dealings, hitting new lows against the German mark and 18-month lows against Japanese yen before consolidating and recovering slightly when trading shifted to Europe and the United States, said Marc Chandler, an analyst with the consulting firm IDEA. Traders cashed in on the weekend runup in the British pound and the yen, and their profit-taking prevented the dollar from relinquishing further ground. ``Given the extended moves . . . in sterling and the yen, there was more cross-related trading today,'' said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago. Dealers expressed disappointment about lawmakers' extended haggling over a deficit-reduction package and complained about a seeming lack of commitment to resolve the budget problem. President Bush signed a temporary spending bill that keeps the government operating until Oct. 19 while Congress tries to come up with a budget accord. ``It's still not a sure thing,'' Chandler said. Any accord raises the possibility that the Federal Reserve would ease interest rates. Higher interest rates make dollar-denominated securities more attractive to investors, thereby increasing their need to hold the U.S. currency. Traders said the outlook for the dollar remains bearish ``given the problems with the budget as well as the economics we've seen with a recession scenario building here,'' Holzer said. In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.10 yen to a closing 129.95 yen. Later in London, it was quoted higher at 130.30 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 130.25 yen, down from 130.48 yen on Monday. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.9705, compared with $1.9745 late Monday. In New York it cost $1.9730 to buy one pound, less expensive than Monday's $1.9760. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates included: 1.5238 German marks, down from 1.5323; 1.2735 Swiss francs, down from 1.2800; 5.1015 French francs, down from 5.1300; 1,142.25 Italian lire, down from 1,151.50, and 1.1506 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1514. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Monday's rates included: 1.5245 German marks, down from 1.5355; 1.2765 Swiss francs, down from 1.2840; 5.1005 French francs, down from 5.1400; 1.7185 Dutch guilders, down from 1.7315; 1,143.25 Italian lire, down from 1,150.75, and 1.1507 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1515. Gold closed in London at a bid price of $396.25 per ounce, up from $392.45 bid per ounce late Monday. In Zurich, the late bid price was $395.50, up from $391.80 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $5.68 to close at a bid $394.37. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $4.593 a troy ounce, down from Monday's $4.670. But in London the metal rose to a late bid price of $4.68 an ounce from $4.67.

DOC.HEAD: Slumping Winnebago Offers Gasoline Rebates to New Customers
DOC.TEXT: Winnebago Industries Inc. on Tuesday offered a year's rebate on gasoline to buyers of recreational vehicles, in an attempt to break out of a sale slump aggravated by soaring prices at the pump. The Forest City, Iowa, motor home manufacturer is in the midst of a factory shutdown that's idled 1,500 employees, and has had four straight quarterly losses. The promotional program is aimed at holding down fuel costs to under $1 a gallon for motor homes sold through the end of the year at participating dealers. ``We are in effect rolling back gasoline prices to 99.9 cents per gallon, the price of gasoline prior to the current Mideast crisis,'' said Winnebago's sales director, J. Ronald Hanna. ``Our potential customers are concerned about rising gasoline prices due to the Mideast turmoil and economic uncertainty,'' Hanna said. ``By guaranteeing the price of gasoline, we will help relieve those concerns.'' Securities analyst Frank Rolfes, who follows Winnebago for Dain Bosworth Inc. in Minneapolis, said the sales incentive is worth a try. ``They can't just sit there and not sell anything,'' Rolfes said. ``I know their sales have been very, very weak,'' he said. ``The last time I talked to them things were pretty grim.'' Winnebago reported a net loss of $14 million for the nine months ended May 26, compared with net income of $6.6 million in the same period a year earlier. Fourth-quarter and yearly results are expected sometime this month. Inventories of unsold Winnebago and Itasca models are so high that the Winnebago factory was shut down Oct. 1 and is not scheduled to reopen until Monday, said spokeswoman Shiela Davis. Winnebago said it will issue a gasoline rebate coupon book when a customer purchases a new Winnebago or Itasca motor home. The rebates will be based in part on mileage allowances set by Winnebago of either 8 miles per gallon for large models and 15 miles per gallon for smaller motor homes. The price used in determining the rebate will be the average national price for self-service regular unleaded gasoline published the first week of each month by the Oil and Gas Journal magazine, a petroleum industry trade publication. The rebates will be good for 12 months or 12,000 miles, whichever comes first. Under the offer, the motor home owner brings in his vehicle to a dealership every three months or 4,000 miles to have the mileage verified and the rebate coupon notarized. Ms. Davis said the company has no estimate on how much the rebates will cost because there is no way of knowing what will happen to gas prices or how successful the incentives will be.

DOC.HEAD: Union Talks Move to Chrysler
DOC.TEXT: With the focus of auto union talks shifting to Chrysler Corp., Chairman Lee Iacocca plans to argue that his company can't afford to be as generous with its workers as Ford and GM. But United Auto Workers union officials said Tuesday his pleadings will fall on deaf ears. ``Anytime he (Iacocca) makes as much as he has in the last five years, it's pretty hard for him to plead poverty,'' said UAW Vice President Stan Marshall said. Iacocca earned more than $6.4 million since 1985 in salary and bonuses. Stock options have added millions more. But Chrysler spokesman Lee Sechler said: ``He (Iacocca) is going to explain we have specific needs and we want to talk to the union about it.'' In another deelopment, Canadian Auto Workers union officials said there has been progress in talks with General Motors of Canada, Ltd., but said talks would likely go ``right down to the wire'' to meet a strike deadline set for midnight Wednesday. The UAW reached a tentative agreement with Ford on Sunday. Voting will be completed Oct. 21. GM workers ratified their agreement last month by a 4-1 margin. The three-year pacts with Ford and General Motors provide, among other things, income guarantees for workers laid off due to sales reductions, penalties of up to $5 an hour for scheduling excessive overtime and a 3 percent raise in base wages during the first year coupled with 3 percent lump-sum payments in the second and third years of the contract. Perhaps most onerous to Chrysler is what's absent from the pattern agreements with Ford and GM: changes in health-care provisions. From the first day of bargaining in mid-July, Chrysler officials have said they need relief from soaring medical care costs, which reached about $684 million in 1989. The company proposed a multi-employer health care program to cut costs, but the UAW's Marshall said that suggestion is all but dead. ``The company could be in much better shape if those (Chrysler) executives would stop running around with all that money,'' said Marshall, who heads the union's Chrysler bargaining team. UAW President Owen Bieber said he would not be at a scheduled meeting Thursday with Iacocca, but ``I'm sure all the union people there will reply appropriately.'' Bieber said he would enter the Chrysler talks expecting a settlement rather than a strike. ``I'm not packing a six-gun when I get there,'' he said. At the end of August, the latest figure available from the union, the UAW had $770 million in its strike fund. Chrysler executives have said the GM and Ford contracts, which are nearly identical, would be extremely expensive for Chrysler. That doesn't faze Marshall or other members of the UAW's Chrysler negotiating team. ``There's no doubt about it,'' said Tony De Francesco, a shop committeeman from UAW Local 624 in Syracuse, N.Y., and a member of the team. ``They will follow pattern.''

DOC.HEAD: Pratt & Whitney, GE Aircraft Engines Team Up in Development Project
DOC.TEXT: Pratt & Whitney and GE Aircraft Engines, sometimes fierce competitors in the jet engine industry, will join together to study the possibility of developing a new propulsion system for supersonic commercial aircraft, the companies announced Tuesday. Depending on the results of the initial study, the companies will then decide how to divide responsibilities in developing the system. The companies said the uncommon alliance is a matter of necessity if either is to participate in developing a futuristic system capable of propelling a civilian aircraft at speeds up to 3{ times the speed of sound. ``We recognize neither company could realistically embark on this project alone,'' Arthur E. Wegner, president of Pratt & Whitney, said in a statement. ``By working together, we will greatly increase the prospects of resolving the enormous technical issues, while also evaluating methods to address the significant business issues associated with developing a supersonic transport engine,'' Wegner said. The companies plan to form a ``joint strategy board,'' with Pratt and GE assigning senior officers to serve as program managers leading each company's activities, the statement said. GE Aircraft, based in Evendale, Ohio, is a division of the General Electric Co. East Hartford-based Pratt and Whitney is a unit of United Technologies Corp. Tuesday's announcement comes less than six months after GE sued Pratt & Whitney for $1.15 billion after a German aerospace company, Motoren und Turbinen Union, withdrew from participation in GE's development of a new turbofan engine to compete with Pratt's PW4000. The suit was dropped after MTU agreed to continue consulting with GE on smaller engines only.

DOC.HEAD: Argentine Government Sale of State Phone Company Hits Snag
DOC.TEXT: The government has set a new date to sell the state phone company ENTel, following a snag that delayed the $5.5 billion deal last week. The Empresa Nacional de Telecomunicaciones is now due to be privatized Nov. 8. The privatization was to take place on Monday, but a U.S.-led group of investors dropped out at the last minute, and a European group that stepped in needed time to review the contract. Obstacles that remain include setting phone rates, which will be linked to the cost of living after privatization. The U.S. group of Manufacturers Hanover, and Bell Atlantic Corp., dropped out last Thursday when it could not meet the deadline to sign the contracts because it lacked $2.3 billion worth of debt papers. The government is offering to sell 60 percent of ENTel for $214 million cash, $5 billion in debt papers, and $380 million in deferred payments. The government is selling ENTel because it loses money, and President Carlos Menem is shifting the Argentine economy away from state control.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Budget, Bjt. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, will ask the panel to accept President Bush's capital gains tax cut and increase income tax rates on wealthier Americans, aides said Tuesday. Bentsen, a Texas Democrat, endorsed those tax changes as part of a deficit-reduction plan the committee will begin working on Wednesday. Disclosure of Bentsen's position on capital gains - he had been opposing a cut - came a few hours after Bush said he would accept higher tax rates on the rich in exchange for the capital gains reduction. Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., who leads the House Ways and Means Committee, has not disclosed whether he will support the capital gains cut. Bentsen's package follows in considerable detail the plan worked out over five months by the White House and congressional leaders. But it eliminates some provisions that had been especially distasteful to many lawmakers. His proposal, which envisions tax increases of up to $150 billion over five years, would: - Avoid increasing Medicare premiums. - Drop a proposed 2 cent-a-gallon tax on refined petroleum products, including home-heating oil and gasoline. - Cut from 10 cents to 9 cents the increase in the 9 cent gasoline tax. - Drop $12 billion worth of tax incentives for small corporations, wich had been attacked as a new system of tax shelters for the rich. Bentsen's plan retains: a 10 percent tax on part of the price of expensive cars, furs, jewelry and boats; an 8 cent boost in the tax on cigarettes and similar increases on other tobaccco products; doubling of the beer tax to 32 cents a six-pack; raising of the wine tax - from 3 cents per fifth to 25 cents for table wine, for example; and raising the liquor tax by $1.50 a gallon to $14. Bentsen also proposed to raise from $51,300 to about $85,000 the maximum annual wage to which the 1.45 percent Medicare tax applies. That tax is withheld from paychecks as part of the Social Security tax. Senate aides said preliminary estimates indicate Bentsen's proposal would be considerably fairer to low- and middle-income taxpayers than the bipartisan plan written by congressional leaders and the White House. Complaints that the bipartisan plan was overly generous to upper-income people were a major factor in its defeat by the House last weekend. In past years, Bentsen had endorsed taxing capital gains - which are profits from the sale of investments - at lower rates than apply to wages. But he has opposed such a change recently because most of the benefit would go to those who make more than $100,000 a year. The fight between Democrats and Republicans over capital gains has been a major impediment to a deficit-reduction plan this year. Bentsen's plan would exclude from taxation 30 percent of the profit from the sale of an asset held three years or longer. A 20 percent exclusion would be given to two-year property, and a 10 percent exclusion to one-year property. The plan also would eliminate a quirk in tax law that allows the 600,000 wealthiest Americans to pay a maximum tax rate of 28 percent, even though people making slightly less pay a top rate of 33 percent. Under the proposal, those in the wealthiest category would pay the higher rate. The combination of the capital gains exclusion and the 33 percent rate would result in a top effective capital gains rate of 23.1 percent. In addition, the plan would raise the individual alternative minimum tax rate, now 21 percent, to 25 percent. This tax is paid by about 150,000 people with incomes who, by using legal deductions, are able to reduce their tax liability to near zero. They are required to give back some of their deductions and pay the minimum tax if it is higher than their regular income tax.

DOC.HEAD: Purchaser of Thalhimers Chain Promises No Major Changes
DOC.TEXT: May Department Stores Co. has agreed to buy the Virginia-based Thalhimers department store chain from struggling Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc. for $325 million, the companies announced Tuesday. The transaction brings to 14 the number of regional department store chains owned by May, and it will allow Carter Hawley, which announced another quarterly loss on Tuesday, to reduce its debt and concentrate on its four West Coast-based department store chains. Thalhimers, which had sales of $445 million in 1989, operates 13 stores in Virginia, including eight in the Richmond area; 10 in North Carolina, two in Charleston, S.C., and one in Memphis, Tenn. May President Thomas A. Hays told a news conference there were no plans to close Thalhimers' downtown Richmond store, and no other major changes were planned at any of the branches. The stores will continue to operate under the same name and same management, Hays said. St. Louis-based May also owns Washington, D.C.-based Hecht's stores, which compete with Thalhimers in several locations. Hays said that rivalry will continue. ``Each one will report to a separate vice chairman,'' Hays said. ``They'll have different promotions and different merchandise, although there will be a little crossover.'' Hays said May owns competing stores in other markets as well. May's other divisions include Lord & Taylor, Filene's, Foley's, May Co., L.S. Ayres, and Kaufmann's department stores. It also owns Venture discount stores and Payless ShoeSource stores. May's 1989 sales totaled $9.4 billion. Carter Hawley has been struggling with slumping sales in recent years. The company announced Tuesday it had lost $25.5 million, or 92 cents a share, in its fourth quarter, which ended Aug. 4, compared with a loss of $8.3 million, or 39 cents a share, in the same period a year earlier. The retailer said its results reflected $6 million in expenses resulting from last year's earthquake in Northern California. Sales in the quarter were $633.3 million, up from $624.6 million for last year's fourth quarter. For the full fiscal year, Carter Hawley reported a loss of nearly $26 million, or $1.03 a share, compared with a profit of $13.5 million, or 62 cents a share, a year earlier. The full-year results reflected a $16.5 million charge related to the earthquake, the company said. Full-year sales totaled $2.86 billion, compared with $2.79 billion in 1989. Carter Hawley's divisions include Broadway, Thalhimers and Weinstocks department stores.

DOC.HEAD: P&G Shareholders Kill Resolution to Stop Salvadoran Coffee Buying
LaserPhoto CS2
DOC.TEXT: Procter & Gamble Co. shareholders on Tuesday rejected a resolution that urged the company to stop buying coffee from El Salvador until that nation ends its civil war. More than 97 percent of stockholders at the company's annual meeting voted against the resolution, with 2.6 percent in favor. James Gamble of Amherst, Mass., great-great grandson of the company's co-founder, and shareholder Patricia Close of Seattle had co-sponsored the resolution. P&G's board of directors had recommended shareholders reject the proposal. The maker of Folgers coffee refuses to say how much Salvadoran coffee it buys annually, but says the amount is less than 2 percent. P&G buys coffee from 30 countries. Also Tuesday, P&G directors raised the annual dividend on common stock from $1.80 to $2. They approved a 50 cent dividend payable on Nov. 15. P&G stock fell $1.25 a share to $78.75 on the New York Stock Exchange Tuesday. P&G's board said the U.S. government has urged trade with the American-backed Salvadoran government. The board also said P&G should not be drawn into a dispute between Washington and critics of the Bush administration's foreign policy. Edwin L. Artzt, P&G's chairman and chief executive, read letters Tuesday from President Bush's chief of staff, John Sununu, and Roman Catholic Bishop Romeo Tovar Astorga, president of the Catholic Conference of Bishops of El Salvador, supporting continued purchases of Salvadoran coffee. Artzt said P&G agrees with Astorga's contention that a boycott of Salvadoran coffee would hurt peasant farmers and laborers on coffee plantations. Artzt called the resolution and its supporters misguided. ``These people are obviously sincere in their thinking,'' Artzt said. ``You can be sincere and misguided at the same time.'' Gamble and his supporters said purchases of Salvadoran coffee provide money for wealthy, plantation-owning families who back El Salvador's war and may condone murder and torture of political opponents. Gamble and the Rev. Benjamin Urmston, a Jesuit priest, told the shareholders Tuesday that P&G's purchases of Salvadoran coffee could have indirectly helped arm the assassins who murdered six Jesuit priests in El Salvador last year. ``By buying Salvadoran coffee, Procter & Gamble helped buy the rifles to murder those priests,'' Gamble said. Gamble, 27, owner of 24,806 shares of P&G common stock, said his resolution had the support of his brother, Robert Gamble, 30, and their father, Walter. James Gamble said he was disappointed the resolution failed to muster the minimum 3 percent of shares voted that would have allowed him to bring it up again for a vote at the next shareholder meeting. ``We respect the results of the vote,'' James Gamble said. Shareholders also rejected, on recommendation of the company, a proposal that urged P&G to end remaining economic relationships with South Africa in protest of that country's apartheid system of racial separation. P&G said it has had no operations or employees in South Africa since selling a Richardson-Vicks subsidiary there in 1986. But P&G said it collects royalty payments of $500,000 annually for use of its trademarks in South Africa. Artzt said that abandoning those trademarks would hurt shareholders without improving the plight of South Africa's black residents. Seven animal-rights activists were arrested Tuesday, six outside the shareholders' meeting and one for interrupting the meeting. The activists and several shareholders urged P&G to end its use of animals in product safety testing. Artzt said P&G is reducing its use of animals in testing, but will not end the practice until alternatives are available to ensure consumer safety for all P&G products. Procter & Gamble had $24.1 billion in worldwide sales during the fiscal year that ended June 30.
