DOC.HEAD: Gold Prices Waver on Fear of Soviet Selling
DOC.TEXT: Gold prices declined sharply Tuesday on New York's Commodity Exchange amid soaring energy prices and fears of a massive Soviet gold sell-off, analysts said. On other commodity markets, grains and soybeans were mixed; meat and livestock futures were slightly higher; and energy futures rose sharply. Gold settled $4.80 to $5.30 lower with the contract for delivery in October at $389.70 a troy ounce. Silver settled 7.7 cents to 8.5 cents lower with October at $4.593 an ounce. Precious metals futures prices, which usually follow the energy futures market, plummeted after traders began selling off on rumors that the cash-strapped Soviet Union is expected to sell off a good quantity of its gold supply to finance recent purchases of grains and other goods. A large sell-off would flood the market and cause a drop in prices. ``All those Russian purchases put a lot of pressure on the market,'' said Stephen Platt, an analyst with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. ``Buying started to dry up, then there was a lot of local selling and dealer selling.'' Prices also fell amid a perceived inability to keep up with energy futures prices, Platt said. Crude oil and gasoline futures rose sharply on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting fears on a report from Iraq's Saddam Hussein that the country had developed a new missile capable of striking deep within Saudi Arabia, where U.S. troops are positioned. Light sweet crude settled 14 cents to $1.45 higher with November at $40.40 a barrel; heating oil was 1.30 cents to 3.19 cents higher with November at $1.0615 a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 2.05 cents to 4.51 cents higher with November at 98.26 cents a gallon. Grains and soybeans all were mixed at the close of a slow day on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean futures prices remained in the same range following a sharp rally Monday that was spurred by harvest delays in the rain-soaked Midwest. Corn and wheat futures prices advanced slightly on rumors of possible export business, analysts said. ``We had wet conditions slowing the harvest (of soybeans) that kept prices up,'' said Mickey Luth, a grains analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. ``Other than that, it was pretty much a nothing session - consolidating after yesterday's sharp rallies.'' Speculators also stood on the sidelines in advance of a report from the Agriculture Department on Thursday with updated crop estimates, Luth said. Wheat futures settled } cent lower to 2 cents higher with December at $2.78{ a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 1\ cents higher with December at $2.34\ a bushel; oats were 1\ cents lower across the board with December at $1.22\ a bushel; soybeans were \cent to 4{ cents higher with November at $6.34\ a bushel. Cattle futures were higher at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on expectations of higher cattle cash prices amid a short-term shortage of animals for slaughter. Price also rose as fears eased that meat inspectors would be furloughed through stalled federal budget negotiations. Pork futures were lifted by professional buying following Monday's sharp drop-off. Live cattle futures settled .05 to .18 cent higher with October at 79.57 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .25 cent lower to .30 cent higher with October at 88.12 cents a pound; hogs were .10 cent to .80 cent higher with October at 56.72 cents a pound; pork bellies were .08 cent lower to .73 cent higher with February at 64.45 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-UAL, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the major developments in the UAL Corp. buyout story: - June 1989: NWA Inc. accepts a $3.65 billion bid for Northwest Airlines from an investor group led by Alfred Checchi, stirring takeover interest in airline companies. - August: Los Angeles investor Marvin Davis offers $5.4 billion, or $240 a share, for UAL Corp., the parent of United Airlines. He later sweetens the bid to $6.19 billion, or $275 a share. - Sept. 14: UAL directors accept a $6.75 billion offrr, or $300 a share, from United's pilots, management and British Airways PLC. The offer includes labor and wage concessions. - Sept. 15: Davis says he will match the offer and demand no labor concessions. - Oct. 13: The $6.75 billion takeover by pilots, management and British Airways collapses when financing fails. On Wall Street, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials falls nearly 200 points. - Oct. 17: Davis withdraws his matching bid for UAL. - Oct. 20: British Airways says it will no longer participate in takeover talks. - Oct. 30: United pilots, without a contract since April 1988, resume talks with the company. - Oct. 31: Machinists union says it won't join Davis in making a new offer for UAL. - Nov. 1: Investor Saul Steinberg tells the government he wants to buy 15 percent to 25 percent of UAL stock. - Nov. 3: The investment group Coniston Partners says it has a 9.7 percent stake in UAL and wants to reduce the size of the board of directors. - Jan. 8, 1990: UAL directors tell financial advisers to consider a recapitalization of the company. - Jan. 24: United's three labor unions say they are willing to buy 75 percent of the stock. Directors say it is not a formal acquisition bid, and they tell their advisers to try to come up with a firm proposal. - March 19: UAL unions and Coniston Partners announce a new $3.8 billion offer. - April 10: UAL Corp. formalizes agreement to sell the company to employees for $4.4 billion. - May 11: Leaders of pilots union ratify tentative five-year contract, to be adopted if buyout succeeds. The pilots group becomes the last of the three major unions to ratify the tentative agreement, which contains wage and benefits cuts and a no-srike provision. - May 30: Union group recruits Chrysler Corp. Chairman Gerald Greenwald to lead the buyout effort. - July 9: Unions release names of lead lenders for buyout deal: Citicorp, Chase Manhattan Corp., Bankers Trust New York Corp., Manufacturers Hanover Corp and Chemical Banking Corp. - July 17: Non-contract employees agree to accept $50.5 million in wage cuts in exchange for 14 percent of UAL Corp., furthering the buyout attempt. - Aug. 8: Unions granted a two-month extension to line up financing. - Sept. 17: Reports emerge that unions may request a lower bid of $165-175 a share instead of $201-a-share bid proposed earlier. - Sept. 26: Davis re-emerges in market for UAL, suggesting he negotiate a merger in which employees receive 20 percent ownership and accept concessions. Unions say they expect to accomplish the deal without Davis' help. - Oct. 3: UAL unions line up $1.75 billion in financing for the employee buyout, still short of the $2 billion in bank loans needed for a bid of $165-$175 a share. - Oct. 9: UAL board rejects bid, although union group says it hasn't given up.

DOC.HEAD: American Airlines To Eliminate 1,000 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines has sent layoff notices to about 40 employees as part of a plan to eliminate 1,000 jobs and reduce costs, the company said Tuesday. The Fort Worth-based airline, which employs more than 90,400 workers, took the action because of rising jet fuel prices and a weakening U.S. economy. Spokesman Al Becker said the first notices were sent to about 40 people systemwide. ``The move is an effort to reduce costs,'' Becker said. ``The (cost-cutting) plan isn't completed yet and won't be for several more weeks.'' Trans World Airlines and USAir have also announced layoffs recently. Becker said this was the first time in several years that American has been forced to eliminate jobs because of rising fuel prices. Officials had said this past summer that the company planned to reduce costs sharply, and an unexpected rise in the price of jet fuel last winter contributed to a first-quarter loss of $19.3 million. An unexpected decline in domestic air travel helped reduce second-quarter profits to $129.2 million, 27.4 percent less than the comparable period in 1989. Jet fuel prices have soared again recently because of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. American officials had planned to reduce costs by implementing a freeze in management and clerical ranks. The company said it planned to eliminate about 1,000 jobs primarily through attrition, but did not rule out layoffs if necessary.

DOC.HEAD: Bond Prices Slump on Rising Oil Prices, Budget and Interest Rate Worries
DOC.TEXT: Bond prices plunged Tuesday as oil prices climbed past $40 a barrel and investors grew increasingly pessimistic about interest rates and the ability of Congress to pass a meaningful budget agreement. There was also concern about an oversupply of government bonds, with two auctions planned this week and the Treasury's quarterly refunding sale coming up next month. ``It would be difficult to conjure up a worse confluence of factors'' than those hitting the credit markets Tuesday, said Ward McCarthy, a managing director of Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bond dropped 1 25-32 points, or about $17.81 per $1,000 in face amount. Its yield, which rises when the bond's price falls, soared to 8.96 percent from 8.81 percent late Monday. Growing fears of war in the Persian Gulf unsettled the bond market and also sent oil prices rising. The higher energy costs underscored worries about inflation, which erodes the value of bonds. The November contract for light, sweet crude oil swept past $40 on the New York Mercantile Exchange, closing at $40.40 a barrel, up $1.45. A surge in inflation carries another threat for bonds - it gives the Federal Reserve less room to ease its monetary policy and allow interest rates to drop. Bond traders have been waiting anxiously for the Fed to relax credit, but they think higher oil prices and, more importantly, the lack of a budget agreement in Washington, will prevent the Fed from acting. McCarthy said bond traders were filled with ``utter disgust with the budget process.'' President Bush signed emergency legislation Tuesday that allows the government to operate while Congress continues to haggle over an agreement that would cut the federal budget deficit by $500 billion over five years. The credit markets, having seen a budget agreement collapse last week, are losing faith in the lawmakers' ability to reach a meaningful agreement. ``What seems to motivate Congress in the budget is self-preservation and the desire to get re-elected,'' McCarthy said. ``National interest plays a secondary if not tertiary role.'' The credit markets were also concerned that with several bond sales planned, there will be so many issues on the market that prices will drop to spark demand. The government is selling $8.5 billion in seven-year bonds this week, along with $5 billion in 30-year bonds to help fund the savings and loan bailout. The Treasury is also preparing for its quarterly refunding sale next month. Bond traders are also concerned that with the dollar at depressed levels, foreign investors will have little interest in U.S. securities at these auctions. Prices of short-term Treasury issues ranged from 3-16 point to 15-32 lower, intermediate maturities fell between 19-32 point and 1 1-16 point, and long-term issues lost between 1 17-32 point and 1 25-32 point, according to Telerate Inc., a financial information service. The Shearson Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, which measures price movements on all outstanding Treasury issues with maturities of a year or longer, skidded 8.42 to 1,146.89. The movement of a point is equivalent to a change of $10 in the price of a bond with a $1,000 face value. Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 7.38 percent as the discount jumped 13 basis points to 7.16 percent. Yields on six-month bills advanced to 7.54 percent as the discount gained 11 basis points to 7.18 percent. Yields on one-year bills rose to 7.59 percent as the discount jumped 9 basis points to 7.10 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point. The yield is the annualized return on an investment in a Treasury bill. The discount is the percentage that bills are selling below the face value, which is paid at maturity. The federal funds rate, the interest banks charge one another on overnight loans, was quoted at 8 1-16 percent, up from 7 15-16 percent late Friday. The fed funds rate from Monday was not available because of the Columbus Day holiday. In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds fell { point to 88 7-32. The average yield to maturity rose to 7.82 percent from 7.77 percent late Monday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 17th graf to CORRECT S&P 500 number; PICKUP final graf, The NASDAQ . . .
DOC.TEXT: Stocks fell sharply Tuesday as record-high oil prices and new war jitters pushed aside federal budget troubles as the market's focal point. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials tumbled 78.22 points, or 3.1 percent, to close at 2,445.54. It was the Dow average's 11th worst point drop, after the fall of 86.61 points on Sept. 11, 1986. Losers outnumbered gainers by more than 4 to 1 in composite trading on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1,313 down, 288 up and 388 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 145.61 million shares, up from 99.47 million shares on Monday. The Dow average was down 23.26 points during the first half hour of trading as oil futures began moving toward an all-time high of $40.95 per barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, fueling fears of higher inflation. The stock market's losses built steadily as traders kept selling amid heightened fears of war in the Persian Gulf. ``They don't want to own them overnight when there was such missile-rattling by Saddam Hussein,'' said market analyst Jack Solomon of Bear Stearns & Co. The Iraqi leader claimed he has a long-range missile that could threaten Saudi Arabia or Israel. Wall Streeters also had doubts about emergency legislation signed by President Bush to keep the government open for another 11 days. Bush said there was ``no assurance'' Congress would reach agreement on a $500 billion deficit reduction package. Vice President Larry Wachtel at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. called the political move a ``non-event'' and said oil prices were ``the minute-to-minute focus of the market.'' The most active NYSE stock was Motorola Inc., down 7 to 52} after settling a patent infringement battle with Hitachi Ltd. ``The people who had been betting on Motorola were disappointed Motorola didn't walk away a legal winner,'' Solomon said. Travelers Corp. fell another 1] to 13 amid continued concern over its recent losses. UAL Corp. was down 3\ to 88 after its board rejected an employee buyout bid, which became the fourth failed attempt to take over the airline in three years. The news from UAL helped propel Boeing up { to 44], as traders believed it likely that the airline would be ordering new planes that had been put on hold while the takeover offer had been in effect. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks fell 4.24 to 167.41. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 176.00 million shares. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market fell $70.7 billion, or 2.41 percent, to a value of $2.867 trillion. Standard & Poor's industrial index fell 10.51 to 358.67, and S&P's 500-stock composite index fell 8.38 to 305.10. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market fell 9.03 to 339.11. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index fell 3.46 to 303.05.

Intel Corp. said it has been granted a temporary restraining order barring Advanced Micro Devices from using the ``386'' designator on any of its products. The order remains in effect until Oct. 15, when a judge may rule on Intel's request to keep the Sunnyvale chip maker from using the number, which Intel uses on its trademark 80386 microprocessor. Intel said the temporary order was issued Friday. Intel has been the sole supplier of the 80386, which is the brains of the latest IBM and IBM-compatible personal computers. It is suing AMD for alleged trademark infringement. Last week, AMD acknowledged it has an unannounced product ``functionally equivalent to Intel's 80386 and that is called internally the AM386,'' according to AMD spokesman John Greenagel. The product has been shipped to customers, and other Silicon Valley companies have said they plan to provide chips compatible with the 80386.

DOC.HEAD: Air Canada To Lay Off 2,900
DOC.TEXT: Air Canada will lay off about 2,900 of its 23,000 employees and cut routes to Europe and the Far East because of rising fuel costs and fewer passengers, the airline announced Tuesday. Hardest hit will be mechanics and ramp workers - which include baggage handlers - who will see their workforce cut by about 1,390 across Canada. Layoffs will also include 220 pilots, 440 flight attendants, 425 ticket agents and 265 managers and clerks. Flights to Athens, Lisbon and Madrid, and Bombay and Singapore will be cut and the airline will sell some aircraft and close its Halifax maintenance base. Most of the cuts would be implemented by Jan. 31, said Claude Taylor, Air Canada chairman. The layoffs in management would likely be completed by mid-1991. ``The passenger market is well down this year and fuel costs are driving us to raise our prices,'' Taylor said.

DOC.HEAD: IMF Downgrades Dollar, Pound, Franc; Upgrades Yen, Mark
DOC.TEXT: The International Monetary Fund announced on Tuesday that it is downgrading the dollar, pound and French franc, and upgrading the German mark and Japanese yen in setting the value of its own currency unit. The IMF currency - special drawing rights, or SDR - is set as a ``basket'' of the five currencies, with each of them weighted by its importance in world trade. Currently, 42 percent of the value is the value of the dollar, 19 percent he value of the mark, 15 percent for the yen and 12 percent each for the franc and the pound. This proportion was set in 1986. It is revised every five years. Beginning Jan. 1, the proportions will be 40 percent for the dollar, 21 percent for the mark, 17 percent for the yen and 11 percent each for the pound and the franc. The SDR is not printed in notes or stamped as coin and is not used in private trade. It exists only as a bookkeeping entry. The fund issued SDRs to give member countries a reserve currency that they could use in addition to gold and dollars. The object was to make the member countries less dependent on the United States, which controls the number of dollars in the world, and on the Soviet Union and South Africa, the major sources of gold. Some advocates of the SDR hoped that it would eventually replace gold and dollars in the world's resevres, thus making the fund into a world-wide central bank. The fund now has 154 member countries. SDRs are distributed in proportion to a country's contribution to the fund. That means that the United States and other major industrial countries get the biggest share. Governments of poorer countries have repeatedly asked for new issues to be made on the basis of need, but the United States has turned the idea down.

DOC.HEAD: IBM to Settle Overcharges, Justice Says
DOC.TEXT: IBM Corp. has agreed to pay the government almost $800,000 to settle allegations of overcharging on the sale of electric typewriters, the Justice Department said Tuesday. The department said the General Services Administration, which bought an unspecified number of typewriters in 1985 and 1986, complained that IBM provided incomplete pricing data which resulted in the overcharges. The $798,764 IBM will pay ``represents a full recovery of the United States' monetary loss plus interest,'' the department said. In exchange, IBM is released from any ``further potential civil proceedings.'' No actual lawsuit had begun.

DOC.HEAD: Standard & Poor's Places City's Bond Rating on Credit Watch
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT rating to A-minus; SUBS 8th graf to INCLUDE explanation of plus or minus ratings.
DOC.TEXT: A major bond rating agency said Tuesday it is reviewing the status of New York City's ability to repay debt following a tentative agreement to give teachers a 5.5 percent pay raise. After reviewing its A-minus rating of New York City's $13 billion in outstanding general obligation bonds, Standard & Poors Corp. could decide to lower the rating. ``I'm confident we are going to satisfy them that we are in control,'' Mayor David Dinkins said at a City Hall press conference. ``We have a plan. We are going to meet that gap.'' The mayor has projected a $1.4 billion budget deficit for next year. S&P said it was reevaluating the city's payroll burden in light of a weakening economy that leads to lower tax revenues. State Comptroller Edward Regan said S&P's move appeared to be based on a perception of economic crisis, rather than reality. ``The city is not on the verge of an economic disaster,'' Regan said. ``It's a cyclical downturn with an erosion of revenue, but that can be handled. The problem is that this year's budget was too large to begin with.'' An A-rating from S&P means the agency believes the city has a strong ability to pay interest and principal on the bonds, although that ability is more susceptible to economic downswings. A plus or minus sign on a rating shows its relative standing within the catagory. The next step lower is a BBB-rating, which signifies that adverse conditions make it more likely the city will have trouble paying interest and principal. Lower ratings make it more expensive to borrow money in the bond market since investors usually demand higher yields for the riskier debt. City Council President Andrew Stein said it was inconceivable that the administration could give teachers a 5.5 percent pay raise on Monday ``and then announce on Thursday that it was planning for 15,000 layoffs. This is not fiscal leadership. It is fiscal folly.'' Dinkins said the city has met past financial difficulties and that, ``I can assure Standard and Poor's, taxpayers, noteholders and the citizens of this city that my administration will continue this tradition of responding fully and quickly to the difficulties a deteriorating economy and rising costs pose for our budget.''
